HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Continue to Slide As Fears About Brazil Grow
Stocks continued to decline as fears intensifed that Brazil's financial turmoil, reflected in the devaluation of its currency, may spread to other Latin American economies and dampen business with the United States. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 228.63 points, or 2.45 percent, to 9,120.93. It was the fourth consecutive decline for the index. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 22.21 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,212.19. The technology-heavy Nasdaq index fell 39.99 points, or 1.73 percent, to 2,276.82. Page C6.
 
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose for the third consecutive session. The yield fell to 5.05 percent, from 5.13 percent. C6.
 
Kodak Shares Drop on Profit Report
In a rare public forecast, the chief executive of Eastman Kodak, George M. C. Fisher, told analysts that Kodak would earn $4.81 to $5.24 a share this year, bracketing Wall Street's prediction of $5.19 a share. But that was not enough to appease investors, who focused on Kodak's other announcement, that its fourth-quarter earnings came in 10 cents below estimates and that its sales declined. Shares of Kodak plummeted $8.1875, or 10.4 percent, to $70.50. Market Place. C6.
 
Ratings High for '60 Minutes II'
The debut of the second CBS news magazine "60 Minutes" scored the highest rating of any program Wednesday at that time period and more than doubled the audience CBS had been attracting then. "60 Minutes II" had a 12.4 rating, 110 percent more than CBS has averaged on Wednesday nights at 9 this season. It also exceeded the expectations of network executives, who said that the numbers proved the value of the promotion of the program in recent weeks. C5.
 
European Economies Are Worsening
The economies of the 11 countries that have adopted the euro are stalling faster than experts had expected. C3.
 
Witness Accused of Altering Stance
A Justice Department lawyer produced several academic papers that he said showed that Microsoft's first witness in the antitrust trial, Richard L. Schmalensee, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, had written opinions that contradict views he offered in testimony for the software giant. C2.
 
Profits Increase 49% at First Union
First Union, the nation's sixth-largest bank, said its fourth-quarter profit jumped 49 percent based on renewed strength in its capital markets business, strong loan growth and robust fee income. C2.
 
Time Warner Believed to Be in Talks
Reader's Digest Association and Time Warner are said to be in talks to combine Reader's Digest with a number of Time Inc. titles and direct-marketing businesses. C5.
 
Nation's Economy Hummed in 1998
Consumer prices rose 1.6 percent in 1998, their slowest pace in 12 years, and retail sales surged nine-tenths of a percent in December, capping a year in which rising wages allowed consumer spending to jump at its fastest pace since 1984 and energized the economy's longest peacetime expansion. C2.
 
Tax on Cigarettes to Be Proposed
Another increase in cigarette prices is being proposed. This time it is from the Clinton Administration, which is proposing a Federal tax increase of 55 cents a pack to help pay for new domestic and military spending programs. Cigarette companies raised prices by 45 cents a pack last year to pay for a $206 billion legal settlement with 46 states. A21.

HEADLINE: THE TRIAL OF THE PRESIDENT: THE CAPITAL;
Business as Usual, but With TV Turned On Low

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
As the Senate listened to the case for her husband's removal from office today, Hillary Rodham Clinton's mind was a world away -- on Mars, to be precise.
Under a panorama of the Martian landscape in the planetarium at the National Air and Space Museum, Mrs. Clinton unveiled a program called the Mars Millennium Project through which schoolchildren will develop plans for how a colony on the red planet would function. 
 "It Takes a Village" meets "The Martian Chronicles."
It was not just his wife who was taking a page from the playbook of the Compartmentalizer in Chief as the impeachment proceedings against President Clinton unfolded on Capitol Hill and on television screens throughout Washington.
George W. Black, one of the five members of the National Transportation Safety Board, and an expert in highway safety, said, "I'm watching the Weather Channel."
As the weather here switched from rain to freezing rain and back to rain, Mr. Black said, "I'm trying to figure out whether to sleep in the office or drive home."
Mr. Black, a Republican appointed by Mr. Clinton, said he had not found time to watch the impeachment proceedings.
"We at the safety board have a lot of things to do," he said, including work on major unsolved air crashes. "I am totally immersed in reading dockets and technical reports."
From the bowels of the bureaucracy to the highest reaches of the political class, work went on, but with an occasional halt to view what jaded Washingtonians seemed to be straining to view as history. Even as televised drama, it did not seem to measure up to Sam Ervin listening to John Dean -- or Marcia Clark questioning Kato Kaelin, for that matter.
"This is quite different from Watergate," said Richard A. Steinwurtzel, a partner at the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, who as a law student had summer jobs in the Government during the Senate Watergate hearings and the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment proceedings against Nixon. "During Watergate, all the TV's were on, and we were hanging on every word."
Bob Squier, a Democratic strategist who worked for Mr. Clinton, said the television in his office was not working properly, so he walked home to watch, tuned in "and promptly fell asleep."
"Can you believe it?" Mr. Squier said. "The President I helped get elected is on trial for impeachment, and I can't stay awake."
At the offices of Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, televisions were on. "People are popping in and out and taking a look at it," said a staff member who insisted on anonymity. "But no one is glued to it."
Interest in the proceedings varied, unsurprisingly, by political conviction. Bill Pascoe, the political director for the American Conservative Union, was watching the trial at his home office in Alexandria, Va.
"I'm watching it for the same reason you watch a car race -- you keep watching in the morbid hope that someone is going to wipe out in the fourth turn," Mr. Pascoe said. "It's compelling."
Within the Clinton Administration, predictably, there was a concerted effort not just to get on with the people's work but to be seen as getting on with the people's work.
Mr. Clinton had lunch with Vice President Al Gore -- no talk of impeachment there, Mr. Gore's aides said -- and worked on his State of the Union address. Late in the day he canceled a trip to New York because of the wintry weather.
At the Pentagon, Deputy Defense Secretary John Hamre reported that the military was going all out to insure that software problems associated with the year 2000 would not imperil national security. The State Department proposed loosening restrictions on oil sales by Iraq. The Department of Housing and Urban Development unveiled a plan to help businesses in poor communities create jobs.
"I don't have the time or the inclination to watch this stuff," said David C. Leavy, the spokesman for the National Security Council, who said his television was not on. "All my colleagues on N.S.C. are focused on the hard work of Iraq and Kosovo and international economic issues and others. Even if I wanted to watch, I don't have the time."
Not all of his colleagues were quite so pure, with some stealing glances at television sets that were tuned to the proceedings, albeit with the sound turned down.
And at the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, some employees admitted to having tuned in, curious about a proceeding far different from their criminal and civil trials in Federal court.
One F.B.I. official said today's proceeding seemed devoid of new information, but was interesting as a piece of history. "It's pretty awesome." he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Wants Big Increase in Federal Tax on Cigarettes

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration plans to propose a Federal tax increase of 55 cents a pack on cigarettes to help pay for new domestic and military spending programs, White House and Congressional officials said today.
The new tax, if enacted, would raise $8 billion a year over the next five years and would be used to help pay for a host of new social initiatives the President has announced over the past two weeks, including expanded after-school programs, support for disabled workers, hiring of new police officers and a tax credit for people requiring long-term medical care. The money would also help offset $100 billion in proposed new Pentagon spending over the next six years. 
 The President has not announced how he intends to pay for these programs, promising that the details will be provided in the budget he submits to Congress on Feb. 1. But the White House has long signaled its intention to seek more money from tobacco, and officials confirmed a report in The Wall Street Journal today that Mr. Clinton will propose the tobacco tax, which is now at 24 cents, as part of a package of tax increases and loophole-closings that it intends to push to pay for new programs.
Mr. Clinton plans to discuss in the State of the Union address next week his Administration's efforts to reduce smoking by teen-agers, including the proposed tax increase to make cigarettes too expensive for some potential smokers.
But the money to be raised by the new levy would not be designated solely for anti-smoking programs, but rather to pay for a variety of social initiatives, a senior White House official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
Mr. Clinton is trying to tap the deep pockets of the tobacco industry for the second time in a year. In last year's budget, the President assumed that the Federal Government would collect $65 billion over five years from a proposed national legal settlement with the tobacco industry. But after an expensive lobbying campaign by the cigarette makers, the national pact died in the Senate, and the Administration realized none of the anticipated revenue.
The Administration hopes to claim some of the $206 billion the industry agreed late last year to pay 46 states to settle dozens of lawsuits filed by the states seeking reimbursement for health-care costs caused by smoking. Officials are considering withholding part of state Medicaid reimbursements to recoup part of the Federal share of the expenses of smoking-related diseases.
Cigarette companies raised prices by 45 cents a pack to pay for the settlement with the states, driving the price of cigarettes over $3 a pack in most markets. The Administration's 55-cent increase would be in addition to the industry's price increase and would more than double the Federal tax on cigarettes, which is already scheduled to rise to 39 cents a pack in 2002.
Ari Fleischer, spokesman for the House Ways and Means Committee, reacted skeptically to the Administration proposal, saying it was a part of a pattern of taxing and spending that was likely to meet strong opposition on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Fleischer said the President should cut spending in other programs to pay for his new programs.
"Why does everything have to be a tax hike?" he said. "Members of Congress on both sides of the aisle will be troubled by how much of his budget relies on tax and spend."
An industry spokesman said the tobacco companies would vigorously contest the tobacco increase.
"Federal Government economic terrorism of the industry has to stop," said Scott Williams, a spokesman for the tobacco companies. "The industry will oppose a more than doubling of the Federal excise tax on a legal consumer product in one fell swoop."
"As we all know, that $8 billion will fall primarily on lower- and middle-income Americans," Mr. Williams said. "The proposal is also an affront to people on both sides who have tried to bring a resolution to these issues."
The states are also likely to object to an effort to claim any of the money they won from the tobacco companies, saying that the Federal Government had no role in the litigation that led to the settlement. They are also expected to argue that while $206 billion sounds like a lot, a substantial part of the proceeds will pay lawyers' fees and the remainder will not cover all the health-care costs of treating tobacco-related illnesses.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 489 words

HEADLINE: French Mischief on Iraq

 BODY:
If the United Nations were to end sanctions against Iraqi oil exports and let the proceeds flow through the hands of Saddam Hussein, there is little doubt what would happen. He would use the oil money to rebuild his arsenal of biological, chemical and nuclear weapons and extended-range missiles. That is why France's proposal to lift the oil embargo and move to a weakened system of weapons monitoring and anemic safeguards against Iraqi weapons purchases is unacceptable. Sanctions can safely be lifted only when Iraq has fully complied with the disarmament requirements the Security Council imposed after the Persian Gulf war.
Before sanctions were imposed in 1990, Iraq used its oil revenues to import the equipment and ingredients needed to make large quantities of unconventional weapons. The tenacity with which it has shielded its weapons programs from U.N. inspection leaves little doubt that Baghdad means to rebuild them, and will resume buying components abroad as soon as it can afford to. 
 For now, sanctions are the only effective means to restrain these weapons programs. No system of monitoring Iraqi purchases, as the French propose, is reliable enough to prevent secret deals with rogue arms merchants from Europe, Russia, China or America. Iraq already has the technology and equipment for making germ weapons, nerve gas and nuclear bombs. The ingredients needed for resuming production are readily available in world markets.
The most compelling argument made for ending sanctions is the suffering of Iraq's people, who are innocent victims of a cruel dictatorship. But it is a deceptive argument. Under the United Nations program of oil for food and medicine, Iraq is already allowed to sell $5.26 billion worth of oil every six months, about as much as Baghdad can pump given today's low oil prices and Iraq's aging oil facilities. Washington now proposes allowing unlimited sales under this program, which finances supervised purchases of food, medicine and other basic consumer goods. If sanctions ended, there might be less money for civilian needs rather than more, since Baghdad would probably spend some of its oil income on presidential palaces, security forces and covert weapons purchases.
The French proposal includes monitoring of known Iraqi weapons facilities by a less aggressive inspection agency than the one now headed by Richard Butler. That is scarcely adequate. Because of Iraqi obstruction over the years, many weapons research and production sites remain unknown and would not be subjected to monitoring. Only aggressive, surprise inspections can keep Iraq from rapidly rebuilding its arsenal of terror.
For now, the United States and Britain stand almost alone in their insistence on effective measures to curb Iraqi weapons programs. But that is enough. Both countries can veto any weakening of Security Council resolutions on Iraq. They must stand ready to do so.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The U.N. Suicide Road

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Behind the closed doors of the United Nations Security Council, three of America's major partners are closing fast on their goal: to give Saddam Hussein victory in the war he lost eight years ago.
The victory would not just establish Iraqi dominance in the Mideast, it would threaten the pragmatic reality of the Western alliance and America's role in it. And in words I choose with unhappy care: It would bring into vivid danger the purpose and existence of the U.N. 
 Each of the countries -- France, Russia and China -- has worked long at those closed meetings to kill the oil embargo against Iraq, the only barrier that prevents Saddam from again building arsenals of nuclear, chemical and bacteriological weapons.
All three want to resume oil and industrial trade with Iraq. They are also bound by desire to build Mideast influence, squeezing out America's.
On Wednesday, France went public, proposing to lift the oil embargo. It was imposed by the U.N. for as long as Saddam keeps refusing to reveal his hidden weapons of mass destruction and his capacity to build more.
By his own decision, the embargo imposes suffering on Iraqis. He will not even give them ease by spending all the relief money the U.N. allows.
France has surrendered to his choice and with great spirit spits in the U.S. face.
The French have this terrific idea. After the embargo is lifted, the U.N. would kind of watch to see if Saddam bought or built the weapons. But it would end all the inspection that now stops him beforehand.
The U.S. said it stood by the embargo, but sent shivers through Saddam's enemies by saying the French proposal had "some positive elements." President Clinton has had no policy toward Iraq for his six years in office, except a couple of bomb-and-run bombings, which made Americans look like fools and cowards.
Certainly at the U.N. we have proved the former. Council meetings were open for the first two decades of the U.N., and the public could see and hear what was going on.
You can see that was an annoyance for diplomats. So they closed the meetings. They threw the press a few briefing bones after the sessions.
Americans, who would not let a village council meet in private about a school budget, allow Washington to agree that the Council should meet in private about issues of death or life, including ours.
For much of my career, I have been involved in U.N. coverage -- a decade of writing about it before I escaped to foreign places, then more decades of involvement back in New York as an editor and columnist.
I believed, and still do, that even with its failures, weaknesses and bouts of lickspittle about dictatorships, the U.N. could be a force for social decency and democracy. I am embarrassed that my country will not pay its dues -- something that I would never have imagined.
For many months I have been writing about the pro-Saddam tripartite alliance, while Washington told us how strong the anti-Saddam "consensus" was at the U.N. That escaped perjury because nobody put a hand on the Bible.
Usually, I am alone in my criticism. American "opinion makers" rarely set foot in an organization that affects American national interests around the world.
The guilt in the plot to rebuild Saddam rests mostly with the nations that hatch and nest it. But it lies too with U.S. ineffectiveness and with Secretary General Kofi Annan.
Mr. Annan's praise of Saddam and defensive attitude toward him may come from some concept of peacemaking. But they damage him and the U.N. more than he seems to know.
So, very carefully, I want to tell him, and all who have any hopeful interest in the U.N., that it is traveling the suicide road.
The U.N. was created to expand freedom on the defeat of Germany, Japan and Italy, not to strengthen other tyrannies or create new ones.
Dictatorships hold seats at the U.N. But their values and interests are contrary and fatal to those on which the U.N. was founded -- the preservation and growth of liberty. If the U.N. removes restraints it imposed itself on the resurgence of Saddam Hussein, restoring him as a threat to the existence of millions of people, free or tyrannized, it will have prostituted its own purpose and meaning.
The U.N. will have no reason to exist and will leave few to weep at its burial.

HEADLINE: On Iraq, Time for an Accounting

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "France, in Break With U.S., Urges End to Iraq Embargo" (news article, Jan. 14): As sanctions against Iraq are subjected to increasing criticism while Saddam Hussein's support in the Arab world is also at a new low, perhaps the time has come to address Mr. Hussein's status as a war criminal. Certainly, the Iraqi leader and his top lieutenants meet the test for indictment for aggression, genocide and other crimes against humanity. 
 Acting to require an accounting for their wrongdoing would distinguish them from the Iraqi people, who are most hurt by sanctions; sanctions could then be eased without giving Mr. Hussein a psychological victory. If the United States offered an easing of sanctions coupled with creation of a war crimes tribunal, the Arabs, Russians and French would have to support such a tribunal or admit that their concern is not really for the Iraqi people.
 
D. M. LYNN
Dallas, Jan. 14, 1999

HEADLINE: High Court Was Right to Back Initiatives;
A Case for Bilingualism

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The United States Supreme Court upheld a lower court ruling that an Arizona law requiring public employees to speak only English on the job was unconstitutional (news article, Jan. 12). 
 And last year, California voters approved the dismantling of hundreds of bilingual school programs. But as you reported (news article, Oct. 3, 1998), not all school districts have fully complied.
Many Hispanic parents, and others, are concerned that their children will not be able to communicate their most cherished dreams and intimate thoughts in their native languages, which is often necessary for warm relationships with relatives and friends who speak little or no English. Bilingualism is also necessary in an increasingly global economy.
 
(Rev.) JOSEPH A. FAHY
Atlanta, Jan. 13, 1999
 
The writer is the Hispanic Apostolate, Archdiocese of Atlanta.

LENGTH: 2339 words

HEADLINE: Sending Authority for Athletics Back to the Schools

SERIES: DROPPING THE BALL: The Decline Of School Sports -- Third of three articles.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON and JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
The breakdown of public school athletics in New York City over the last quarter century was to a great extent a matter of impersonal forces and unintended consequences. But in equally large part, the fate of school sports was determined by individuals -- people who made a difference or who did not, who tried to defend athletics or who stood idly by on the sidelines.
Ed Reynolds fought back. 
 Reynolds, the principal of West Side High School in Manhattan, became so angry that the 350 students at his alternative school could get no money from the city for sports that he formed his own league and ran it himself. Organizing the city's expanding group of smaller, specialized high schools beginning in the 1970's, Reynolds pushed and prodded and insisted that sports for students mattered. And it worked.
Now, the more than four dozen alternative high schools like West Side get money from the Board of Education that, while paltry compared to schools around much of the nation or in the New York metropolitan area, is better than nothing. The schools now participate in interscholastic sports alongside the oldest and largest schools in the city.
"You don't have to yell," Reynolds said of the lessons he learned in his battles over sports. "But you do have to be aggressive -- you have to continually lobby for your position, you have to write letters and organize meetings, you have to be sort of a crusader," he said.
But, coaches, teachers and administrators across the city say, Reynolds was an exception -- a principal who would go to the mat for sports. Most others would not, or could not. The pattern of de-emphasis of sports and physical education came from the top down, as Board of Education administrators cut and cut financing and never restored it, and partly from the bottom up as parents stopped caring as much or pushed for other school improvements. Principals were caught in the middle.
Most took the meager amount of money doled out by the Public Schools Athletic League -- the Board of Education's administrative arm for high school sports -- and did what they could. They found ways to raise more money through stopgap measures or they eliminated a sport here or a gym class there as they balanced their budgets and their needs for books, materials and teachers.
Athletics programs, as they struggled, came more and more to mirror everything that works and does not work about the New York City school system: varying resources from neighborhood to neighborhood, varying levels of commitment and ability from school to school, and always and everywhere a seemingly constant conflict over politics and labor and management and who was or should be in charge. Schools chancellors came and went like waves on the beach. Frank J. Macchiarola tried to rebuild some of the sports program in the late 1970's and early 1980's, and the current schools chief, Rudy Crew, has added back money in the late 1990's. But the deeper structural problems remained.
Now, in the city's first concerted effort in years to rethink and retool how it runs its high school sports programs, it has decided that the answer is to decentralize authority further, giving more responsibility to individual schools. What many principals and teachers had seen as a symptom of the erosion in commitment and money from the center -- decentralized sports programs that seemed orphaned and at the mercy of local neighborhood economics -- has now been embraced as a cure.
Leaders on the scene, the city has said, really do know best. Under the plan, parts of which are being put in place now, principals will be charged with insuring that athletes are academically eligible and medically fit to compete and that coaches are certified. Principals will enforce rules and assume legal liability for mishaps or oversights.
"We're now trying to say to the principals, 'It's your show,' " said Thomas Hemans, the director of the P.S.A.L., which has until now scheduled games, set rules, hired officials and certified the training of coaches since its creation in 1903.
 
Consequences and Politics
Caught in a Battle Involving Principals
The overhaul plan has in turn opened a new debate about what school sports could be and should be. Some principals and teachers say the city is giving up on the idea of systemwide improvement, while accepting the diminished state that sports has assumed. Some say they believe that the overhaul represents real hope of improvement. Still others say the timing, coming in the middle of a pitched battle between the city and the principals' union over tenure, promises to make school sports more of a political issue than ever. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has pushed to eliminate tenure for principals -- a move the principals' union has rejected.
Even principals who think the sports overhaul is a positive step say that greater decentralization will make the inequities between poor and middle-class schools more profound -- or at the very least leave the problems unaddressed -- because each school will be left more on its own than ever.
"Everything is moving toward school-centered leadership teams, everything is moving out, this is just in keeping with that whole movement," said Thelma B. Baxter, the principal of Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Fordham section of the Bronx; the district has a 100 percent poverty rate among its students and no athletic fields at all. "But I think it's going to make it more difficult for the schools to be competitive -- truly competitive."
The principal of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, Howard J. Lucks, also believes the changes -- contained in a new rule book given to principals last year -- have some positive aspects, notably the new section on sports and ethics. But for all the good intentions, he said, decentralized authority will inevitably mean unevenness of application.
"I think it's very difficult for every school to have the same kind of program," he said.
Phil Watnick, the girls' track coach at South Shore High School in Brooklyn, questioned the wisdom of further burdening principals. The new plan simply will not work, he said, because principals are already overwhelmed by the responsibilities they have. "How much do you want to put on their heads?" he asked.
Other administrators and sports officials, however, say that the city may have stumbled onto an important truth: that for all that principals did not do as the city's commitment declined, people like Reynolds -- scattered here and there across the system -- kept sports programs alive.
"Sometimes, I think it's a miracle that high school sports even survived in New York," said Arthur Greenberg, the schools superintendent for District 25 in Queens and a principal in the 1980's.
 What is indisputable about the city's sports overhaul is that it comes at the expense of the P.S.A.L.
Indeed, a Board of Education task force last year concluded that the P.S.A.L. , which administers sports programs for 165 high schools and 2,361 boys' and girls' teams, had to a great extent failed. Its staff of eight full-time employees and its network of coaches and athletic directors who serve as part-time commissioners for individual sports had been overwhelmed, the report said, by the sharp growth in the number of high schools in the 1990's and the explosion of girls' teams that the city was forced by Federal law to create in recent years.
The P.S.A.L.'s new role is more consultant than administrator. It will schedule games between schools, arrange for officials and umpires and offer advice about rules and procedures when asked.
By comparison with the P.S.A.L.'s original mission and historic role in the school system, such a diminished role falls just short of extinction. In the century's early decades, when New York City's system of high school sports and physical education was being built, and being seen as a national model, the agency was a central -- sometimes autocratic -- voice and authority and advocate for the value and necessity of school sports. In the name of greater local control, that unifying voice, however much it had already been eclipsed, has been silenced.
But many principals also fear that downsizing the P.S.A.L., whatever the result for students, will make sports more political in New York by injecting the issue directly into one of the most divisive subjects in public education: tenure for principals. The Board of Education and Giuliani are leading vehement campaigns to chip away at or eliminate tenure for principals.
In such an environment of acrimony, some principals say they believe the overhaul will change the traditional politics of money for sports into the politics of blame. Greater local control has raised the specter, some principals say, of a kind of Trojan horse -- a huge extra task, cast as an improvement, that principals cannot possibly keep up with, given all their other duties. The new rule book could come back to haunt them, they say, as a prosecutorial exhibit with the first major scandal of poor enforcement or student injury.
"The burden is now placed on the principals; if anything goes wrong, they can always point the finger at us," said Bruce Schnur, the principal of Liberty High School, a small specialized school in Manhattan mainly for new immigrants.
The principals' union, for its part, sees little change in the status quo. Sports will be made better, union officials say, because principals are more capable and competent than P.S.A.L. staffers.
"I think it will amount to a more effective administration of the sports programs and less chance for violations to take place," said Norman Sherman, the high school director for the principals' union, the Council of Supervisors and Administrators.
Crew, the city's Schools Chancellor, said he believed that spending increases for sports in the last few years -- and his own statements of commitment -- had changed the debate: The question is no longer survival, he said, but rather how to create the proper role for sports going forward. Crew said in an interview that athletics must become part of a broader educational effort aimed at putting students onto what he calls a "road of personal competency." Arts education and internships, in which students can get experience outside school in real-life working situations, are others.
"I would argue that there are many ways of being able to scale that road," he said. "And I have not chosen one over the other -- I'm saying all three have to be present."
Crew said he thought it was probably reasonable for principals to feel cynical about the recent changes for sports, given the long, dismal record of retrenchment. But he said he hoped to embed athletics once again so firmly in the curriculum that it would not be the first to fall when tough budget times return.
All across New York -- and in schools all over the nation -- educators are wrestling with similar questions. At a time of taxpayer revolts and state mandates for better academic performance, the question of how and whether to fit sports in -- let alone finance them seriously -- has become a burning question. And as the public schools have struggled, the number of new private groups seeking a new path for sports, or seeking to help finance existing programs, has exploded. In many corners of the city, in and out of the school system, people are searching for new vehicles to provide sports and are articulating new ideas about their value and role in youth development.
One group, for example, that is held out by some educators as a model of what school sports could be is a five-year-old program in Harlem called the Urban Youth Bike Corps.
The group is ostensibly about biking, said its director, Erik A. Cliette. But Cliette said that biking was in many ways just a cover story. The corps blends physical and emotional and academic development, all revolving around bike-riding trips, bicycle maintenance, personal responsibility and academic achievement, with all expenses paid for by private and corporate sponsors.
It is like school sports in its focus on physical development and training, he said, but with the emphasis shifted to a broad and structured coming-of-age strategy.
And many school officials, in struggling to keep sports programs going, have reached back to these private-sector efforts as well, forming public-private partnerships -- some as ambitious as raising money for a new gymnasium, some as small as the bats and balls that are being provided to several local school teams by the Shooting Gallery, a Manhattan-based movie production company that recently created a foundation to raise money for New York City public school teams.
 
Optimism and Resignation
A Need for Change, And Faith as Well
Many principals say they are optimistic about the changes at the P.S.A.L. mainly because they say the administration of sports could not get much worse.
At Liberty High School, for example, which has only three sports teams -- boys' and girls' volleyball and coed bowling -- Schnur, the principal, said that his new responsibilities had resulted in changes already. Students who want to use the gym after school must now provide proof that they have had a physical examination. That rule, he said, has probably been on the books for years, if not decades, but in the hands of the P.S.A.L. it was never enforced.
"It was essential that it be changed," said Eileen Taylor, the principal at Aviation High School in Queens and an enthusiastic supporter of the overhaul. "More accountability is built in, and it's more realistic."
Most school officials, though, said that keeping sports going in New York -- no matter what changes are made in the name of reform -- had become a matter of faith. Either you believe that it can be done, they said, or you don't.
"We grit our teeth and find a way," said Wanda Nix, the athletic director at Townsend Harris High School in Queens. "I think there are answers. I think they're out there somewhere."

HEADLINE: Wisconsin Welfare Overhaul Justifies Hope and Some Fear

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

 BODY:
Though Wisconsin's radical welfare experiment has drawn more interest than that of any other state, there was little information until this week on what was happening to the droves of people leaving the rolls. In a statistical vacuum, the key question -- "is it working?" -- was answered with a mix of hopes, fears and dueling opinions.
Now state officials have released a trove of information, on things as varied as the number of former welfare recipients with access to a car (54 percent) and the number who say they have been forced to abandon their children (5 percent). But in an environment of sudden statistical abundance, the question of "is it working?" still remains a matter of, well, hopes, fears and dueling opinions. 
 And perhaps it always will.
With the nation's toughest work requirements, Wisconsin has seen the steepest caseload declines.
The good news from Wisconsin, which began its program in 1997, is that the percentage of former recipients who found jobs remained high, even as the welfare exodus reached deeper and deeper into the caseload. Sixty-two percent of the former recipients were working at the time of the survey, and 83 percent had worked sometime in recent months.
Citing such numbers, Larry Mead, a welfare expert at New York University, went as far as to argue that "these work levels represent the greatest achievement in anti-poverty policy since the Great Society."
The bad news is that economic difficulties remained common and for some recipients grew worse. Despite the state's booming economy, sizeable minorities of those pushed from the rolls by the program's universal work requirement reported problems paying for such basics as utilities (47 percent), housing (37 percent) and food (32 percent). Indeed, after leaving welfare, families were almost 50 percent more likely to say they had no way to buy groceries.
"This supports the view of advocates who say the program has serious problems," said Pamela Fendt, a researcher at the University of Wisconsin in Milwaukee.
Though subject to sharply different interpretations, the study is destined to attract much attention from around the country. More than a dozen states have done similar studies, but Wisconsin's began after about 75 percent of the caseload -- presumably those most employable -- had already left the rolls. Therefore, it gives the first glimpse of how the nation's least job-ready recipients may ultimately fare. On balance, many experts are likely to see the study as reason for guarded optimism.
Though Wisconsin is now dealing with a more troubled portion of the caseload, the percentage of its "leavers" who find work remained comparable to those in other states.
"We're dealing with those at the bottom of the employability ladder, yet our work levels are on par with states that have reformed much less radically," said J. Jean Rogers, who runs the Wisconsin welfare program. "That implies either we underestimated the employability of our most disadvantaged clients, or that Wisconsin's done a good job of promoting and sustaining work."
Under the program, Wisconsin Works or "W-2," virtually everyone is required to work. But the state has created thousands of community service jobs and pledged services, like child care, to all who need them.
On the positive side, the study found most former recipients were earning considerably more than the minimum wage. The average wage was $7.42 an hour, with the median wage $7 an hour. Of those employed, 57 percent said they worked 40 hours or more a week while just 9 percent said they worked less than 20 hours. On average, the study calculated weekly earnings of $262 for those who had jobs.
At that rate, a former recipient who worked all year would earn about $13,600 -- just a few dollars shy of the official poverty threshold for a family of three. But such a worker could also qualify for tax credits worth several thousand dollars, lifting them out of poverty.
On the negative side, fewer than half of the former recipients -- 47 percent -- said they had more money now than when they were on welfare. When asked whether "they were just barely making it," 68 percent answered yes. The study also asked about 17 types of material hardship, such as the ability to afford food, housing and child care. Few of the areas showed substantial improvements since recipients left welfare, and in five categories recipients said things had gotten worse.
In general, surveys like these tend to underestimate the actual amount of hardship since the most troubled people are the hardest to find. Wisconsin found 69 percent of the former recipients it tried to contact, a good rate by national standards. The response rate was lowest in Milwaukee, the urban center where troubled clients are most concentrated.
Though the report is full of numbers, almost all can be bent to varying interpretations. For example, the high percentage of former recipients who say they "are barely making it" were responding to a highly subjective question. A high percentage of the country as a whole might answer the same way. And it is impossible to predict whether things will get better or worse with time.
It is plausible that the earnings will grow, and hardships diminish, as former recipients settle into their new roles as workers. "This is a new experience for them," Ms. Rogers said. As people grow more adept at budgeting, she said, problems with food and housing will abate. But it is also plausible that hardships may increase, especially for the 38 percent still unemployed.
There is one useful comparison. The Wisconsin study borrowed a survey used earlier in South Carolina. While the Wisconsin economy is somewhat better -- its unemployment rate at the time the study began was 3.2 percent, compared with 4.4 percent in South Carolina -- Wisconsin's levels of hardship ran higher. Only 13 percent of former South Carolina recipients reported an inability to buy food, for example, compared with 32 percent in Wisconsin.
Why the difference? At the time of its last survey, South Carolina had cut the rolls only by about half, compared with 75 percent in Wisconsin.
"It's evidence that the further we go down the rolls, the more problems we see," said Jack Tweedie, who tracks welfare programs for the National Conference of State Legislators. "We're not going to conclude that welfare reform 'worked' or 'didn't work' -- it'll work for some and not for others."

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
COHEN, HENRY

 BODY:
COHEN-Henry. With his passing on January 14, 1999, New York City lost a dedicated public servant and policy expert and New School University a passionate and creative educational leader. Henry Cohen served New York City from 1950 to 1968, blazing a path that opened the City's government to increasing numbers of highly-trained professionals. As Professor of Urban Affairs and Dean of the Graduate School of Management and Urban Professions from 1968 to 1982, he conceived new curricula and the concept of urban professionals and recruited a distinguished faculty to train the new urban leadership. The Board of Advisors to the Robert J. Milano Graduate School of Mangement and Urban Policy of New School University express their grief and deep sympathy to his wife Evelyn, daughter Alison, son Daniel and grandchildren Anna and Rosalie. There will be a funeral Friday, January 15th at 12:15 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, NYC. Bill Green, Chair Board of Advisors to the Robert J. Milano Graduate School Jonathan F. Fanton President, New School University

SECTION: Section A;Page 8;Column 1;Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Plot to Oust Castro, Run on a Shoestring, Lands 5 Underpaid Amateurs in Jail

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

DATELINE: GUATEMALA

 BODY:
When terrorist bombs began exploding in Cuba two years ago, speculation about the bombers' identity was rampant. Coup-minded military officers, some Cuban exiles insisted. Or right-wing infiltrators from Miami. A nascent rebel underground, perhaps, supplied from abroad.
But none of those theories help much to explain the role of Jazid Ivan Fernandez, a 28-year-old data processor from Guatemala City who is one of five Central Americans now in a Cuban prison on charges stemming from the attacks. 
 Mr. Fernandez, people who knew him in Guatemala said, was a punctual if undistinguished bureaucrat, a pleasant young man who compiled bus statistics for a Government transport office. He devoted most of his free time not to politics, they said, but to whatever happened to be on television.
The story of the accused saboteurs, assembled from interviews with the five in the Havana prison and accounts of their relatives, associates and others, suggests that even as radical Cuban exiles mounted their most intense campaign of violence in years against the Communist Government, their operations were less cloak-and-dagger than cut-rate and lucky.
"These do not appear to be militants or activists or doctrinaire fanatics," said the Guatemalan Foreign Minister, Eduardo Stein. "They seem to be something like what, in the drug-trafficking world, one would call mules."
 
The Recruits
Gang Couldn't Shoot, Straight or Otherwise
The accused bombers were anything but professional.
Two had had brief experiences as soldiers; a couple, at least, thought vaguely ill of the Cuban Government. But most important to the cause was that all of them were short of cash, struggling with debts on everything from cellular telephones to children's schools.
The most successful of the group, a 28-year-old Salvadoran who needed money for car payments, got $2,500. Another, an executive at El Salvador's biggest car dealership who was struggling to support two children he had fathered out of wedlock, agreed to make the trip to Cuba for $1,000.
Exactly who paid the bills is unclear.
Luis Posada Carriles, an aging Cuban veteran of Central Intelligence Agency crusades against Fidel Castro, acknowledged organizing the attacks, suggesting that he did so with money provided by Cuban exiles in the United States. But he declined to identify them.
United States officials said Federal prosecutors in Puerto Rico were also looking at the bombings as part of a grand jury investigation into what they say was a plot to kill Mr. Castro during a regional summit meeting in the Caribbean last May.
The prosecutors have filed conspiracy charges against seven men, including three with ties to the most prominent exile political group in the United States, the Cuban American National Foundation. A Federal judge recently decided to transfer these proceedings to Miami from Puerto Rico.
Cuban officials have repeatedly accused the foundation and its late chairman, Jorge Mas Canosa, of orchestrating the attacks, a charge it vigorously denies.
But recently Cuba made the charges more specific: In late October, the Government said that Mr. Posada's chief financier was Arnaldo Monzon, a wealthy businessman from Fort Lee, N.J., who is a director of the foundation.
In an interview at his office above a clothing store in Union City, just across the Hudson River from Manhattan, Mr. Monzon dismissed the accusations as ridiculous.
"That was the first I had heard of it," he said of the plot described by the Cuban Interior Ministry. "I don't think that is a way to overthrow a government."
Cuban security officials, speaking in interviews in which they discussed many details of their investigations for the first time, said they had already found traces of Mr. Monzon and other well-known Cuban-Americans as the pattern of anti-Castro attacks began to shift in 1994 and 1995.
Until then, said Col. Adalberto Rabeiro, a senior official of the Interior Ministry's counterintelligence directorate, such actions had typically been pirate raids on beachfront hotels, with attackers firing automatic weapons from speedboats. Then the attackers grew bolder, aiming at the tourist industry, a key source of foreign exchange.
Cuban officials allowed a reporter to interview the five suspects awaiting trial in Havana after Mr. Posada described his role in the attacks in articles published last summer in The New York Times.
The interviews were conducted at the Villa Marista prison, in a room that appeared to be monitored by security agents.
All five prisoners admitted the crimes of which they have been accused, and denied having been mistreated or coerced to do so. But several were held incommunicado for months, and though much of their accounts was corroborated by friends, relatives, employers and associates, it is impossible to tell whether parts of their stories might have been rehearsed.
Cuban officials said the five were only the last in a recent series of attackers trained abroad. Two of the first, they said, were young Cuban emigres trained in Miami and dropped back on the island in 1995, with 51 pounds of plastic explosives. They and two other exiles, who entered Cuba with a small quantity of explosives in 1996, were arrested before they could blow up anything, the officials said.
On April 12, 1997, however, a bomb exploded at the discotheque in Havana's newest five-star hotel, the Melia Cohiba, and another was found unexploded weeks later. Cuban officials said this marked the start of Mr. Posada's more direct management of the sabotage, a wave of 13 bombings that rattled Cuba for months.
 
The Lures
Jobless Salvadorans And Visions of Cash
As his first mercenary, Cuban officials said, Mr. Posada hired Francisco Chavez Abarca, 29, a Salvadoran. Mr. Posada had met Mr. Chavez's father, a well-connected arms dealer, after arriving in El Salvador in 1985 to work for the United States National Security Council when it was supplying Nicaraguan contra rebels.
That year Mr. Posada escaped from a Venezuelan prison where he had been held on charges of plotting the bombing of a Cuban airliner in 1976 in which 73 people were killed.
How the younger Mr. Chavez made his living is unclear. But to the young men who hung out with him, the Fat Man, as they called him, had the trappings of small-time underworld success: a used BMW, spending money, a semiautomatic handgun.
"I told him at one point, 'Look Francisco, I'm sure you're mixed up in the drug business,' " said one of those young men, Raul Cruz Leon. " 'When you've got a job, remember me.' "
Such activities were out of character for Mr. Cruz Leon, but his finances were getting desperate. His main job, driving Latin pop singers as the "security chief" for a Salvadoran promoter, rarely paid more than $500 a month. Between car payments, credit-card bills and his cellular phone, he owed nearly $6,000, and relatives said his mother finally mortgaged her small jewelry store to help him pay off the debt.
"I was drowning in the interest payments," he recalled.
Mr. Cruz Leon was clearly something less than the hardened military veteran that Cuban officials suggested and that many news accounts have described.
The son and grandson of army veterans, he had dreamed of entering the Salvadoran military academy, a well-traveled social escalator for boys from the working class.
But he had also studied at the Jesuits' Central American University, and said he was troubled by the military's killing of six priests there in 1989. Within a year of entering the academy, he rose almost to the top rank of his class -- then dropped out.
When Mr. Chavez approached him about "a little job" in late 1996, he said, he agreed immediately. When Mr. Chavez told him later that he wanted to set off small bombs at Havana hotels, Mr. Cruz Leon said he suspected some dispute with a hotel owner.
"I thought of that movie 'The Specialist,' with Sylvester Stallone and Sharon Stone," Mr. Cruz Leon recalled, looking pale and tired in a blue-polyester prison uniform. "That guy planted a bomb, and he ended up a hero."
Mr. Cruz Leon became the most able of the accused mercenaries, learning to assemble his bombs -- a small wad of plastic explosive, a detonator, a thin Casio alarm clock and a nine-volt battery -- in little more than a minute.
Mr. Chavez, who is said by associates to still be living in San Salvador, appears from travel and telephone records obtained from the Cuban authorities to have been in Cuba when the Melia Cohiba hotel was bombed on April 12. Mr. Cruz Leon followed him in July, he said, getting past a strip search at the Havana airport to bomb two hotels for $2,500. He was arrested during a second trip in September, after another of his bombs killed a 32-year-old Italian businessman.
Mr. Posada said he was unperturbed. "He's not Cuban," he said in the interview, referring to Mr. Cruz Leon. "He did this for money."
But as attention focused on El Salvador after those attacks, Mr. Posada turned to Guatemala, where he recruited a pair of young men to plant two more bombs in August 1997. Guatemalan newspapers reported that one of those men, Marlon Gonzalez, 31, and another man were found in a dump truck last May, badly beaten and shot to death.
Mr. Chavez apparently found his most unlikely recruits in late 1997, at the Guatemala City guest house of Maria Elena Gonzalez, a 54-year-old former school teacher who read tarot cards on the side.
In a prison interview in Havana, Mrs. Gonzalez said Mr. Chavez had come to her because she knew a woman he wanted to kill, apparently on contract, to retaliate for the murder of a wealthy Salvadoran businessman. He spent days having his cards read and hanging about at her pink-plaster home where, coincidentally, the Cuban patriot Jose Marti had once lived.
Cuban security officials suggested that some of their main evidence against Mr. Monzon came from his chatter during card readings by Mrs. Gonzalez. In two interviews, she said Mr. Chavez told her he was owed money by three men, two of whom he named as Arnaldo Monzon and Ramon Medina, an alias used in El Salvador by Mr. Posada.
Mrs. Gonzalez said she also took a telephone message for Mr. Chavez from a caller who identified himself as "the man from New Jersey."
Eventually Mr. Chavez recruited another of Mrs. Gonzalez's sometime guests, Nader Musalam, a 28-year-old Guatemalan who had previously owned a small store where, he said, he had done a modest business in stolen clothing. He had gone to Cuba on vacation years earlier, looking for girls; although the bombs seemed like "not such a good idea," he was eager to get back.
"I liked it a lot," he said. "It wasn't like they made it sound in Guatemala."
According to a deal he said he made with Mr. Chavez early last year, Mr. Musalam was to receive $1,300 for each bomb he planted, enough for a down payment on a Hyundai sedan that he could drive as a taxi. For $800, Mrs. Gonzalez said, she agreed to carry two toothpaste tubes filled with plastic explosives and two small alarm clocks. But she also had to pay for her own plane ticket, which she bought on credit.
"It was the end of the month," she said. "I had to pay the water bill, the electricity bill. I thought this would be some quick money."
Mr. Musalam was arrested at the airport, and Mrs. Gonzalez was picked up as she waited for him at his hotel. Mrs. Gonzalez's husband, Jazid Ivan Fernandez, 28, the data processor, said he had opposed the trip but helped pack the explosives. He was detained three weeks later when he traveled to Cuba to try to locate her.
 
The Organizer
Moving In, in Vain, To Keep Plot Going
When his sabotage network started to fray with the arrests in 1997, Mr. Posada -- who acknowledged before the Cuban Government's announcement that three of his bombers had been captured -- became more directly involved.
A retired Salvadoran Air Force captain, Alberto Barraza, whom Mr. Posada had known from the contra operation, said in an interview that he introduced Mr. Posada to Otto Rene Rodriguez, supposedly to buy inexpensive ammunition.
Mr. Barraza denied any knowledge of the Cuba plot. He said Mr. Rodriguez bought lots of ammunition because of his job as the security supervisor for the Salvadoran company that owns the car dealership, a position in which he supervised more than 200 guards and other employees. Mr. Rodriguez had also spent time at the Gerardo Barrios military academy, leaving early to attend architecture school. And he too was in financial trouble.
The son of a prosperous businessman and the nephew of one of El Salvador's most respected centrist politicians, Otto Rodriguez earned just under $1,000 a month at the car dealership. But in addition to supporting his two children by his estranged wife, he said, he was trying to help two children by other women with whom he had become involved.
"With $1,000 I could solve my problem," he said. "And I thought I could keep some of the expense money they gave me."
He arrived at the Havana airport in August 1997, carrying the explosives in a back pocket, the transistor batteries in a front pocket. He said he planted a bomb at the Melia Cohiba, had a brief affair with a young Cuban woman and returned home to pay off his elder children's school tuition.
After agreeing to try again, he was arrested at the Havana airport last June. This time he was supposed to meet a Cuban conspirator, identified to him only as Juan. Instead he has spent the last months wondering why he ever agreed to join Mr. Posada's campaign.
"This really doesn't have anything to do with us," he said of the plot to bring down the Cuban Government. "Sometimes, it takes a long time to figure out how lost you are."

HEADLINE: Industry Posts Rise in Output For December

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Despite falling exports, American industries churned out more goods in December and managed their most vigorous quarterly gain of the year during the final three months of 1998, the Federal Reserve said today.
Analysts said the robust production data demonstrated the resilience of the nation's nearly eight-year-old expansion. But they noted that turmoil in Asia and Latin America was taking a toll in lost manufacturing jobs and weaker foreign sales. 
 Production by the nation's mines, factories and utilities increased two-tenths of a percent last month after the figure was revised to a decline of one-tenth of a percent in November. Production gained a half-percent in October.
But for all of 1998, industrial production grew only 3.7 percent, far short of the 6 percent jump in 1997. It was the smallest rise in annual output since a 3.5 percent rise in 1993.
Businesses ran at 80.9 percent of maximum capacity last month, down from 81.0 percent in November and the weakest since 80.6 percent in August 1993.
A global slump in emerging markets in Asia and Latin America has sapped demand for many United States-made goods abroad. But production has stayed strong amid robust domestic demand.
For example, production of new cars surged by 79.3 percent in last year's final quarter after weakness earlier in the year related to a strike at the General Motors Corporation. And computer output soared all year, shooting up at a 50.4 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter.
The Fed said utility companies increased output by 1.6 percent in December after demand for electricity and natural gas slumped amid mild weather in October and November.
Manufacturers increased production by two-tenths of a percent last month after a pickup of one-tenth of a percent in November.
"While it is clear that the manufacturing sector increased at a slower rate than the overall economy last year, the main reasons were lower exports and the process of reducing excess inventories," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
Separately, the Commerce Department said today that business inventories in November rose four-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted $1.088 trillion, following a two-tenths of a percent advance in October. Sales also rose four-tenths of a percent after a three-tenths of a percent October gain, implying a healthy balance in stocks of unsold goods.
The picture remained mixed for manufacturing in 1999 after a difficult year in 1998.
"There have been 252,000 manufacturing jobs lost since March and what this output for the whole year reflects is the damage from Southeast Asia," said David Orr, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.

HEADLINE: Pete Wilson Reflects on One More, Elusive Rung

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15

 BODY:
For eight years in Sacramento, Pete Wilson had to look no farther than the big portrait of Ronald Reagan in his office to dream of what the future might hold for a Republican Governor of California. Now, in his second week as a private citizen, Mr. Wilson has begun sharing an office suite here with the former President himself, but the dream remains uncertain.
As he unpacks boxes and pictures from his tumultuous tenure at the helm of the nation's most populous state, Mr. Wilson is looking both backward and forward. He is celebrating, explaining and defending his record -- including a Presidential bid that died aborning three years ago -- and considering one more run for the White House. 
 "The table stakes are very high," Mr. Wilson said of the newly compressed primary election calendar and the $15 million to $25 million that he says would be needed to run a credible campaign. He has formed a political committee to advocate his policy ideas but makes clear that he will run only if he can raise the money. He plans a foreseeable future of private breakfast soundings and fund-raising phone calls, and promises a decision by "late spring or early summer."
Mr. Wilson, 65, who was barred by law from seeking a third term, has already had quite a ride. He has won four statewide elections since 1982 and built a reputation as one of the shrewdest politicians California ever produced. He has endured the biggest budget deficit and enjoyed the biggest budget surplus in the state's history, and persevered through a punishing recession and a plague of natural disasters to preside over a booming economic recovery that in the last three years has seen California create more new jobs than New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Illinois combined.
But he has also left a trail of controversy and divisiveness with his support for ballot measures to curtail social services for illegal immigrants and end state affirmative action programs, and with his breaking a 1994 re-election promise not to run for President in 1996. In November, Republicans lost the governorship by a landslide, and their minority in the Legislature shrank to the point where this is now the nation's most Democratic state except Hawaii.
Finally, as a prospective Presidential candidate whose principal draw is his electoral appeal in California, where a giant pile of delegates will now be chosen early in the nominating process, Mr. Wilson faces a painful paradox: He left office with the highest job approval rating of his tenure, but more than 6 in 10 California voters say they would not be inclined to support him for President.
"Toward the end of his term, he was finally getting some credit -- and quite a bit of it -- for the outstanding performance of the economy in 1998," said Mark Baldassare, survey director of the Public Policy Institute of California, a nonpartisan research group. "But assuming that is going to carry over into national leadership is another matter altogether."
In fact, the latest survey by Mr. Baldassare's organization shows Mr. Wilson supported by just 5 percent of likely voters in a statewide Presidential straw poll, one-quarter the level of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
Mr. Wilson swats away those poll numbers, saying with typical asperity, "Well, a lot of them have been told for a long time that I'm not popular," and noting that his ratings on leaving office were comparable to those Mr. Reagan had after eight years as Governor.
Yet Mr. Wilson has been hurt by a willingness -- sometimes even a seeming eagerness -- to take combative stands. His support for abortion rights and gay rights, which has given him a moderate coloration useful to any national candidate, has made him a pariah among many of the conservative activists who dominate the Republican primary process. His willingness to raise taxes to help close a crushing budget deficit when he took office in 1991 infuriated anti-tax crusaders while earning him little credit from liberals, because he insisted on cutting spending by a like amount.
That battle, Mr. Wilson says, taught him "that there are people who, when faced with certain options, were not capable of exercising any, and legislators can get away with that, but chief executives cannot."
The worst recession since the Great Depression severely curtailed Mr. Wilson's ability to deliver on the notion of "preventive government" that he initially campaigned on. He battled relentlessly with the state's public employee unions, and only in the last three years was he able to begin to restore spending for education, reducing class sizes in the early grades and forcing an annual student test through the Legislature -- accomplishments on which his Democratic successor, Gray Davis, is unabashedly building.
"He gets no credit for the good things he did for the state; he's got a legitimate gripe there," said Tony Quinn, a moderate Republican analyst in Sacramento. "But he picked all these unnecessary fights."
The fight most damaging to Mr. Wilson was his support for Proposition 187, the 1994 ballot measure curtailing health, education and other social services for illegal immigrants. It passed overwhelmingly but has since been tied up in court, and a Wilson television advertisement with the slogan "They keep coming" roused the state's growing Hispanic population to register and vote Democratic in record numbers.
Mr. Wilson is defiantly unrepentant about his stand, which he says grew out of a huge drain that illegal immigrants were causing in the state budget. He accuses his political opponents of demagoguery and derides Republican critics as "weak sisters in our party who make the mistake of letting the other side define the game and the rules."
"There was no 'inflammatory rhetoric,' " Mr. Wilson said. " 'They keep coming'? That's a statement of fact."
But the Democrats have effectively used the issue not only against Mr. Wilson but also against Republicans throughout the state, and the crowd at Mr. Davis's inauguration last week responded with a thunderous standing ovation when he promised to "ring down the curtain on the politics of division." Mr. Wilson and his wife, Gayle, alone among the dignitaries on the dais, remained seated.
"I thought they were a little tasteless, to be honest," Mr. Wilson said of his successor's digs. "But was I surprised? No. I mean, that was an audience that was hungry. That was a very partisan audience. They've been waiting for 16 years." Then, in a dig of his own, at the last Democratic Governor, the quixotic Jerry Brown, he added, "They've been waiting for longer than that, actually."
Mr. Wilson's last Presidential campaign collapsed after throat surgery left him unable to speak for nearly four months and he had trouble raising money. He acknowledges his decision to run as the one real regret of his tenure.
"If he hadn't run last time," one longtime former aide said, "they'd be talking about Wilson and Bush as the two powerhouses."
Mr. Wilson said the fund-raising necessary for a Presidential campaign was "an enormous chore," and predicted that the Republican field would be limited because of the costs.
But Larry Thomas, who was Mr. Wilson's press secretary when he was Mayor of San Diego two decades ago, and in his first, failed campaign for governor in 1978, said, "It's very difficult for me to believe that he will just go quietly into the night."
Mr. Baldassare, the pollster, agreed. "I think it's too early to count him out," he said. "People have counted him out before, especially in 1994, and he's somebody who knows how to put together a campaign to win. That's something the Republicans desperately need. But he still has an awful lot to overcome to convince those voters who know him the best -- Californians -- that he's Presidential material."

HEADLINE: Henry Cohen, 76, Urban Planner And a New York City Official

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Henry Cohen, an urban planner, a retired dean at the New School for Social Research and a prominent New York City official in the Wagner and Lindsay administrations, died Thursday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 76.
The cause was liver cancer, his family said. 
 Dean Cohen served in the city government from 1950 to 1968. He was the First Deputy Administrator and Acting Administrator of the Human Resources Administration before he joined the New School staff in 1968.
He was appointed a professor of urban affairs and became the founding dean of what is now the Milano Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy. He built the school into one of the foremost teaching centers of its kind in the country.
Starting in 1968, he was the director and then dean of the Center for New York City Affairs. The center was merged into the Graduate School of Management and Urban Professions when it was established in 1975.
Dean Cohen drew up innovative curriculums offering seven graduate professional degree programs. He recruited a faculty that trained a fresh generation of urban leaders and brought to life his concept of what he called "new urban professions." Among them were urban policy analysis and management, human resources management, health management and policy, and nonprofit management.
Henry Cohen was born in Manhattan, graduated from City College in 1942 and received a Master of City Planning at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1944. Toward the end of World War II, he fought in the Army's Ninth Infantry Division through the Huertgen Forest, the Battle of the Bulge and across the Rhine to occupied Leipzig.
He worked with the postwar military government in Germany, then did postgraduate studies at the University of Iowa and Columbia University, taught urban sociology at City College and lectured at the University of Birmingham, England.
In 1950, he joined the New York City government. He organized the research division in the Department of City Planning and directed it until 1955. He lectured on urban studies at Columbia's School of General Studies and School of Social Work, and did research for the New York Regional Plan Association.
He was a Deputy City Administrator and senior management consultant, simultaneously, in the office of Mayor John V. Lindsay. He was appointed First Deputy Administrator and Acting Administrator at Human Resources in 1967, the year before he moved to the New School.
Dean Cohen is survived by his wife of 50 years, Evelyn Fuhrman Cohen; a daughter, Alison Rose Levy of Brooklyn; a son, Daniel, of Needham, Mass.; a brother, Dr. Sidney Cohen of Manhattan; a sister, Margaret Weisman of the Washington area, and two granddaughters.

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN BRAZIL: THE POLICY MAKERS;
Brazil Is Warned to Clean Up Its Economic Act

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Having given up on defending the value of its currency at least temporarily, Brazil got a muted but clear warning from the International Monetary Fund and the United States today that failure to act quickly on pledges to bolster its financial condition through spending cuts and tax increases would lead to a downward economic spiral.
Two top Brazilian officials, Pedro Malan, the Finance Minister, and Francisco Lopes, the central bank governor, were flying to Washington tonight for meetings on Saturday at the I.M.F. and on Sunday at the Treasury Department. 
 Although the collapse of Brazil's effort to prop up the currency revealed the depth of the country's economic and political problems, it also came as something of a relief to policy makers, who had come to view the attempt as futile and a waste of the country's dwindling foreign currency reserves.
Despite having previously called on Brazil to maintain currency stability, the I.M.F. issued a statement tonight calling the decision "a wise move to stop the loss of reserves."
Earlier in the day, Stanley Fischer, the first deputy managing director at the I.M.F., said he still expected Brazil to meet the fiscal targets it agreed to as part of the $41.5 billion international aid package negotiated last fall. Brazil's failure so far to enact the politically painful measures needed to reduce its huge budget deficit led to rapidly mounting pressure on the currency, the real, and to today's decision to let market forces set the currency's value.
Mr. Fischer said it was "very early to be drawing any firm conclusions" about how Brazil should proceed.
Mr. Fischer suggested though that I.M.F. officials would discuss with the Brazilians whether they should continue allowing the currency to float or whether they should attempt to stabilize its value through intervention in the foreign exchange market or by establishing a new trading range that the Government could try to enforce.
"Questions on exchange rate systems, on how to make them more flexible and when, is high on the agenda," Mr. Fischer told a conference at Harvard University.
Brazilian officials said they would disclose their plans for the currency on Monday, and President Fernando Henrique Cardoso said tonight that the Government would continue to defend the currency's value and believed that it would eventually be able to reduce interest rates.
In remarks to reporters in New York, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said it was unlikely that there would be any new aid pledged to Brazil this weekend. The solution to Brazil's problems, Mr. Rubin said, "lies in Brazil itself, in putting together an effective fiscal program and an effective foreign exchange regime."
But economists said it was an open question whether Brazil could restore enough confidence in the financial markets to avert a long economic slide. They said the country would probably have to keep extremely high interest rates in place to keep the currency from free fall, ultimately leading to a choice between a painful recession or dropping rates and allowing inflation to surge.
Officials from a number of countries said they remained concerned about the possibility of Brazil's troubles dragging down neighboring countries, including Argentina, and ultimately having an effect around the world.
The troubled search today for a response to Brazil's problems and to the broader issue of containing the financial turmoil that has swept around the world for the last year and a half prompted a new initiative today from Germany, France and Japan that is likely to exacerbate tensions between those countries and the United States.
After a meeting in Frankfurt, German, French and Japanese officials called for a new international system to limit the volatility of currencies. The nations provided few details of how such a system would work, but backed the creation of "an exchange rate regime among major currencies which would reduce excessive volatility."
The Clinton Administration has always viewed attempts to control currency fluctuations with skepticism if not hostility, and economists said it was hard to understand why Germany, France and Japan would call for such a system in the immediate aftermath of Brazil's failure to control its exchange rate. And American officials said the focus should be on Brazil's efforts to improve the soundness of its basic economic policies.
Roger W. Ferguson Jr., a Federal Reserve governor, said it was "now even more important that Brazil move as quickly as possible to implement a clearly sustainable fiscal position and regain the confidence of international markets and investors."
The World Bank said in a statement that President Cardoso "has consistently shown his commitment to implementing Brazil's reform package," but noted that further aid to Brazil was dependent on the changes actually being enacted.
Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, said the crisis of the last few days created an opportunity for Brazil to get back on track solving its underlying economic problems, particularly its budget deficit.
"The sense of urgency in Brazil began to evaporate after the agreement was signed with the I.M.F. last year because there was a feeling that things were looking better," Mr. Hormats said. "The question now is whether Brazil can use the greater sense of urgency created by the events of the past few days to move more boldly on measures to reduce the fiscal deficit."
Mr. Hormats said the experience in Indonesia last year suggested that it might be futile for Brazil to re-establish an exchange rate target for the currency until after it had proved to the markets that it was serious about dealing with its fiscal problems.
For the I.M.F. and the United States, Mr. Hormats said, one of the most difficult decisions will be whether to continue providing money to Brazil if it does not fully comply with the requirements of its agreement with the fund.
"If they provide the money without Brazil having complied with the measures, then they take the pressure off again," Mr. Hormats said. On the other hand, he said, the fund does not want to repeat its experience with Russia last year, when a breakdown of Russia's economic plan led the I.M.F. to cut off assistance.
"I think they will avoid at all costs a Russian situation," Mr. Hormats said.
But analysts are divided over Brazil's prospects. Desmond Lachman, an emerging-markets research analyst for Salomon Smith Barney and a former I.M.F. official, said Brazil had an opportunity now to run its economy with a more realistic exchange rate.
"If they do what the I.M.F. is telling them to do on the budget and restore people's confidence, they can bring interest rates down and not go through a crushing recession," Mr. Lachman said.
Guillermo Calvo, the director of the Center for International Economics at the University of Maryland, said he was very pessimistic about Brazil.
"The focus has shifted from a balance of payments crisis to an inflation crisis, from an international crisis to a domestic crisis," he said.
To avoid the inflation that a weaker currency creates, the I.M.F. will probably insist that Brazil keep interest rates high, he said. But high rates will push the economy toward recession, creating intense political pressure to reduce rates, he said, a move that would allow inflation to flare up as the currency falls again and import prices rise.
"This has always been the story in Brazil," Mr. Calvo said.
