HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN BRAZIL: THE OVERVIEW;
Exchange Controls Lifted; Brazil Stocks Rise by 33%

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The Brazilian Government, reeling under a hemorrhage of dollars from its foreign reserves in a losing battle to defend the nation's currency, lifted exchange-rate controls today and allowed the currency to trade at market value.
The move sent markets soaring in this country and through much of Latin America. Stocks rose, too, in the United States and Europe. 
 The announcement that the Brazilian central bank would allow market forces to determine the value of its currency, the real, came 24 hours after the bank had ruled out such a step -- fearing it would send the currency plunging in value. The shift appeared to signal at least some conflict over economic policy at the top levels of government.
But investors were relieved that Brazil had abandoned -- at least for today -- its policy of spending dollar reserves to defend its currency from selling attacks by speculators betting it would fall in value. The real did fall, but its descent was not as sharp as had been feared.
In Sao Paulo, Brazil's financial center, the benchmark stock index rose 33.4 percent after two days of punishing losses, reflecting the attractiveness of stocks that were viewed as having become bargains because of the currency's reduced value.
The effects from that turnaround were a tonic to other markets, which had been unnerved by the heavy selloffs in Brazil since Wednesday that suggested a return to the global financial turmoil that began in Asia in mid-1997. In New York, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 219.62 points, or 2.41 percent, recovering almost all losses the day before.
But the policy shift in this country raised fundamental questions about Brazil's previous reliance on a stable currency loosely pegged to the dollar to limit inflation in its economy, Latin America's largest. A few years ago, Brazil had been a captive of chronically high inflation and a weak currency.
In a televised speech to the nation late today, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, said he had abandoned the defense of the currency only as a last resort. "I could not let reserves keep going out and leave Brazil undefended in order to take precautions afterward," Mr. Cardoso said.
A weak currency does, however, have some redeeming features. It can, for instance, help stimulate exports by making them cheaper abroad. But a weak currency also reduces the purchasing power of consumers, particularly when buying imports, and puts downward pressure on the currencies of neighboring nations.
Brazil's central bank had hoped to keep its currency stable by maintaining high interest rates, which increase the returns on assets denominated in reais, and by using dollars to buy reals when the Brazilian currency weakened. But interest rates were getting so high and it was spending so much money defending the real that on Thursday senior officials of the Clinton Administration and the International Monetary Fund warned Brazil that it could not maintain such a policy.
Tonight, Finance Minister Pedro Malan and the new central bank president, Francisco Lopes, flew to Washington to meet with officials of the I.M.F., which
has been aiding Brazil with a $41.5 billion bailout package from various nations and international agencies.
Earlier in the week, the central bank had widened the currency's artificial trading range, which was seen by financiers as undermining the purposes of the I.M.F. aid package. This in turn unnerved investors who had bet on a stable currency.
In a growing exodus of dollars from Brazil, $1.8 billion was withdrawn from the country on Thursday alone. Brazil's foreign reserves, $75 billion last summer, have dwindled to $31 billion, a main reason officials felt forced to change policy.
Today, an announcement from the bank said, "The central bank of Brazil will not intervene in exchange markets today," and adding that "another communique in this respect will be released Monday." I.M.F. officials in Washington planned to discuss Brazil's future monetary policy with officials there this weekend.
Within minutes of the lifting of exchange controls, the real fell to a rate of 1.60 to the dollar from the previous 1.32, settling by day's end around 1.43 to the dollar. The real closed down 10.4 percent for the day and 18 percent since Wednesday.
But there was little sense that any long-term equilibrium had been found. "I think we still have a messy time for two months or so," said John Welch, chief economist for Latin America at Paribas in New York.
The move also had a healthy effect on short-term interest rates, which reached 71.65 percent on Thursday. They fell in half, to 36.11 percent.
By 7 P.M., just $173 million had left Brazil's foreign reserves, which had lost more than $5 billion in the first nine days of the year. Some analysts suggested that come Monday, the Government would establish a new exchange rate based on the free-market value of the currency established today.
With investors relieved, the stock market, which had faced double-digit losses for days, began climbing. By day's end, the blue-chip issues had recorded their second-highest increase in a single day's trading. Markets rose throughout Latin America. In Germany stocks were up 1.5 percent, and in France 1.4 percent.
Brazil's efforts to protect itself from the turbulence roiling emerging markets has been a preoccupation for Washington and other industrial nations since last summer, when Russia devalued its currency and defaulted on some debts.
Representing more than half South America's population and 40 percent of its economic output, Brazil was considered the most likely candidate for ushering the troubles of emerging markets to the United States' doorstep, by dragging down economies throughout Latin America -- a key trading region.
The Brazilian Government's earlier success in selling investors on Brazil's commitment to ending hyperinflation and modernizing the role of government had encouraged foreign companies to increase their stakes in Brazil through the four previous years of the Cardoso administration.
In 1994, foreign direct investment in Brazil totaled $2 billion. Now, it accounts for more than $36 billion, thanks in part to aggressive privatization of state utility, mining and telecommunications companies.
Brazil is also considered the locomotive of Latin America, which in total buys about 20 percent of United States exports. And the Brazilians owe more than $228 billion in foreign debt, according to its letter of intent laying out the terms of its bailout by the International Monetary Fund this past fall.
The current crisis broke out after the Governor of Minas Gerais, a large and wealthy Brazilian state, announced a moratorium on paying his state's debt last week. That caused a wave of dissent among other state governors and undermined confidence in Brazil's ability to deliver deficit-cutting reforms and ultimately, to pay its debts.
Even before Brazil's reversal of course today, the Government's credibility had been strained because of difficulties in legislating civil service and pension reform.
Brazil had sought to keep its currency relatively stable by permitting it to drop 7.5 percent a year against the dollar. That approach, along with moves to open the economy to imports, had been successful in controlling inflation.
Abandoning the exchange-rate band represents a step into the unknown for the architects of that approach. In the Government's letter of intent to the I.M.F., written in November, it called "continued low inflation" the "priority goal of monetary policy," and added, "The current exchange rate regime is an essential means to this end."
But with the jolts to investor confidence from Asia over the last 18 months, Brazil became subject to attacks on its currency, and paid high interest rates to attract investors who would otherwise shun emerging markets in favor of safer investments offering lower returns. Basic bank rates over 40 percent aggravated Brazil's burgeoning budget deficit, now swollen to $65 billion, more than 8 percent of the gross domestic product.
With consumer interest rates upward of 100 percent, and money for capital investment in short supply, the economy screeched to a halt. Official unemployment jumped to a 15-year high of 8 percent, with little relief in sight, and in the Sao Paulo industrial area, nongovernment analysts estimated the jobless at 19 percent.
Today, business leaders welcomed the devaluation, which they predicted would revive industry by making exports cheaper. At a trade show in Sao Paulo, leather manufacturers said the devaluation would help recovery of Brazil's depressed shoe industry.
Here in Rio, shopkeepers wondered whether inflation would return, and in what form. No one knows whether the reflexes of a culture practiced at dealing with hyperinflation, which ended five years ago, would return. Some stores said that business was already so bad that they could not increase prices without losing the few customers who remained.
Alberto Homsi, 63, the owner of Micro Plant Computers here, had already marked up prices on computer supplies like printer cartridges. "Fear of inflation, I don't have," Mr. Homsi said, "but my back is hurting from bending over to see which items I really do have to raise my prices on."

HEADLINE: THE TRIAL OF THE PRESIDENT: BEYOND THE BELTWAY;
Editor of A.M.A. Journal Is Dismissed Over Sex Paper

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
The American Medical Association dismissed the editor of its leading journal yesterday, saying that he had rushed through a paper on whether college students think oral sex is "having sex" to influence President Clinton's impeachment trial.
Dr. E. Ratcliffe Anderson, the executive vice president of the association, said the incident, which led to a firestorm of protest among medical researchers and journal editors, had followed what he called a steady erosion of his faith in the editor, Dr. George D. Lundberg. 
 Although Dr. Anderson would not be specific, others said Dr. Lundberg had nettled many in the medical profession over the years when he published controversial articles.
The paper that proved to be Dr. Lundberg's downfall was by Dr. June Machover Reinisch, the former director of the Kinsey Institute for Research in Sex, Gender and Reproduction, at Indiana University. In it, Dr. Reinisch reported that in an eight-year-old survey of 599 students at an unnamed university in the Midwest, 59 percent said oral sex did not constitute "having sex." The article, will appear in Wednesday's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.
Dr. Anderson, said in a statement that he had dismissed Dr. Lundberg because by publishing Dr. Reinisch's paper now, Dr. Lundberg "has threatened the historic tradition and integrity of the Journal of the American Medical Association by inappropriately and inexcusably interjecting JAMA into a major political debate that has nothing to do with science or medicine."
At a news conference, Dr. Anderson said "there was an acceleration of the timing" in the publication of the paper. He added, "I don't question the material in there, but I do very clearly question the judgment in publishing that article in the middle of the Congressional proceedings."
"I happen to believe that Dr. Lundberg was focused on sensationalism here, not science," he said. "It grieves me greatly that that magnificent journal that should be about science and medicine has been used to extract political leverage."
In his statement, Dr. Anderson also said, "Over time, however, I have lost confidence and trust in Dr. Lundberg's ability to preserve that high level of trust and credibility."
Dr. Lundberg, reached at home, said he could not comment other than to say that Dr. Anderson called him at 8:15 yesterday morning and told him he was no longer editor of the journal. "My attorney has me under wraps," he said.
Dr. Anderson said that it was his decision to dismiss Dr. Lundberg and that he made it despite an outcry from his own editorial board. A member of that board, Dr. Jack D. Barchas of Cornell University Medical College, said he and others called Dr. Anderson to try to stop him from dismissing Dr. Lundberg.
"We were begging him to reconsider," Dr. Barchas said.
"Many of us feel anger, outrage, and a sense of betrayal by the decision," Dr. Barchas said. Dr. Lundberg, he added, "has been fearless in publishing papers, even controversial papers, based on the best tradition of science and the best tradition of peer review."
The journal, in Dr. Lundberg's 17 years as editor, has taken strong positions on subjects like the dangers of tobacco and on violence as a public health threat. It has also published articles that made some medical professional wince -- like a recent series of articles on alternative medicine; a paper claiming, with what some said was weak evidence, that eating fish slashes the risk of sudden death from heart disease, and an essay by an anonymous doctor who told of how he took it upon himself to kill a cancer patient to relieve her suffering.
The paper by Dr. Reinisch is different from other controversial articles, however, because it is not even a new study. The paper made it clear that the survey's main conclusions had been published; the oral sex part was, apparently, leftover data.
Dr. Reinisch did not return calls to the Kinsey Institute seeking comment, but she told The Washington Times on Thursday that she had decided it would be irresponsible not to publish her data on oral sex. So she sent a paper to the Journal of the American Medical Association in September.
It was accepted in December, after revision. The paper went through normal peer review, Dr. Anderson said yesterday. He said neither he nor anyone else at the association had "any veto power over articles published in the journal."
"That is editorial independence," he said, "and it will continue."
l It typically takes six weeks to six months from the time an article is submitted until the time it is published, according to a staff member at the American Medical Association. The ones published in weeks usually are not revised.
Of course, the paper has a certain news value now that it would not have had if it was published before or after the Clinton sex scandal, medical experts said. But the question remains: Why did Dr. Lundberg decide to publish it now?
Dr. Uwe E. Reinhardt, an economics professor at Princeton University who is a member of the editorial board at the Journal of the American Medical Association, said he could think of two reasons. Both are tied into the impeachment hearings.
"One is that he has a genuine belief that this is the most important political decision in this century and every bit of evidence on it should be published," Dr. Reinhardt said. The other, he said, is that the subject is suddenly of news value. And the journal, like others, he added, "loves being noticed in the media."
Dr. Marcia Angell, editor of the New England Journal of Medicine, which is the chief competitor of the Journal of the American Medical Association, said her journal would never have published the sex survey paper because "it is trivial -- who cares what a bunch of college students say," about whether oral sex is sex, she said.
"It also is irrelevant to the Clinton case," Dr. Angell said. "He wasn't asked the question in that context."
But, she said, the decision to publish the paper "is not a reason to fire an editor who's been there 17 years and by almost anyone's estimation has put a small society that no one took seriously on the map."
But Dr. Anderson said his office had been deluged by callers expressing support. One was Robert W. Seligson, who is the executive vice president and chief executive of the North Carolina Medical Society. Dr. Anderson, he said in a telephone interview, "was careful and decisive in doing the right thing."
Dr. Harry L. Greene 2d, executive vice president of the Massachusetts Medical Society, also supported Dr. Anderson, saying it was a publisher's role "to take action" if he felt the journal's integrity was threatened.

LENGTH: 1371 words

HEADLINE: Where Oil Is Plentiful But Cash Is Short

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: KUWAIT

 BODY:
Oil, for so long the source of so much easy wealth, is now fueling hard questions along the Persian Gulf.
It is not just that its price, in real terms, has plummeted to levels not seen since the mid-1970's. Nor is the concern limited to the fact that the Saudis and other producers, so adept at muscle-flexing in the past, have failed dismally to push prices higher. 
 What lies behind the bleak numbers is a gnawing sense of vulnerability. For a quarter century, oil has allowed the gulf states a self-sufficiency and political leverage far in excess of what comparably sized countries could hope to achieve, and has formed a dependable pillar of legitimacy for the region's six monarchies.
But now, after years of declining oil prices, the monarchies -- which depend on oil for three-quarters of their incomes -- have watched revenues plunge by 30 percent in a year, a loss of $25 billion. And there is no rebound in sight.
Suddenly the arithmetic of big budgets and big spending no longer adds up, and the situation looks so gloomy that Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia warned starkly in December, "The boom days are over, and they will not come back."
The reversal has led even politicians to recommend adjustments -- belt-tightening, borrowing or inviting foreigners to help -- steps that would end the old ways of showering citizens with beneficence while keeping outsiders at arm's length.
In countries already prone to domestic discontent, and with fast growing populations of young people schooled in a sense of entitlement, all those options carry the risks of instability and of accusations that past riches have been squandered.
As Ahmed al-Thani, a 19-year-old Kuwaiti, put it, "With all our oil, why should life be harder for us than it was for our parents?"
Together, the six monarchies control nearly half the known oil reserves, and their exports account for 10 percent of the current supply. Even now, a sense of economic woe is not immediately apparent in places like Kuwait, where the signs of wealth so visibly on display include the brand new Corvettes and BMW's that teen-agers race up and down the seafront corniche.
But the depth of the new strain can be measured on balance sheets.
In each monarchy, emergency measures announced last summer cut government spending, by as much as 20 percent. But nowhere has that been enough to close yawning budget gaps. With a 55-gallon barrel of crude oil selling for about $12, about half of what it was a year ago, the cost to governments of providing the lifetime jobs, low-cost housing and other subsidies has soared well beyond what they can earn.
In Kuwait, with just over two million people, the budget gap is expected to reach $8 billion, more than all the revenues the country will take in from oil. In Saudi Arabia, where the crisis seems to be the worst, the deficit is expected to be $15 billion, and has already forced the national oil company to borrow abroad.
Qatar, Bahrain and Oman have also been pinched, as has the United Arab Emirates, an oil and commercial giant regarded as the most resilient economy in the region.
In trying to stave off a deeper crisis, governments are scrambling to cut spending further. Even Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest oil exporter, is trying to prepare the ground for tougher times ahead.
In an address in December, Prince Abdullah told fellow gulf leaders meeting in Abu Dhabi that their people "must get used to a new way of life that is not based on total dependence on the state."
Other gulf leaders have begun to echo Prince Abdullah. To try to gain control over bloated government payrolls, Saudi Arabia and the U.A.E. have tried to steer citizens toward more demanding and less lucrative private-sector jobs most often performed by foreign workers.
Kuwait has introduced legislation to promote privatization and to ease obstacles to foreign investment. The Saudis and others are also signaling a new willingness to court foreign investors.
But big obstacles stand in the way of change. Few industries apart from energy have demonstrated much potential for profit. And past successes mean that oil is now seen as so central that it could be difficult, if not impossible, for gulf countries to lure investment in other sectors.
In the United States in September, Prince Abdullah even met with chairmen of the biggest oil companies, dangling the prospect of a new role in the Saudi energy industry, which like most across the region was nationalized more than two decades ago. Then, in the heady days of oil embargoes and seemingly limitless cash, the foreign companies that had built the oil fields in the gulf region were driven out.
The reasons for the long decline in oil prices include a supply glut, brought on largely by new finds outside the Middle East. Advances in technology have allowed producers in the North Sea, Central Asia and West Africa to gain an increasing share of the market.
In the last year a number of passing factors, including a drop in Asian demand, have cut into prices further. And the prospect that ostracized Iraq, with the third-largest reserves, may one day resume full production has only added to the headaches.
By and large, however, governments in the gulf have continued to behave as they did when oil was king. Even now in Kuwait, for example, most citizens who work are employed by the Government, and the staggering costs of the salaries and subsidies account for the vast bulk of the Government budget.
For citizens and even foreign workers, health care is free. The price of electricity is a small faction of what it costs to produce. Upon marriage, citizens become eligible for a $230,000 interest-free housing loan.
And in one way or another, despite the talk of privatization, governments remain the dominant force. That means cuts in spending, like those rushed into effect last year, quickly translate into a broad economic slowdown and a crisis of confidence like one in Kuwait, where stock prices have falled 40 percent since July.
"In general, gulf governments have used their oil income as an excuse for inaction," said Henry Azzam, managing director and chief economist of the Middle East Capital Group, an investment bank based in Beirut, Lebanon.
Most private forecasters say oil prices will remain low at least at least through 1999. After the failure of their own efforts to push prices up, that view also seems to have taken hold among gulf governments.
But private economists worry that rather than make hard choices, governments will dither. "What we are telling the Government is that it must act now," said Rabah al-Rabah, a top official of the Kuwait Chamber of Commerce. "Otherwise, if there is delay, there will eventually be no other choice but to cut to the bone."
By any measure, the options for are unpalatable.
The easiest is to draw on foreign reserves. Kuwait, which has not taken that step since the Persian Gulf war in 1991, has already asked Parliament for permission to do so. But such a step risks adding to public uneasiness: the reserves in Kuwait are known as the Fund for Future Generations.
Another is to borrow, a step that Saudi Arabia has said it intends to take. But that could leave gulf countries even more strapped, and if it meant turning to foreign banks, it could require a degree of outside scrutiny with which the monarchies have never been comfortable.
A better course, economists say, would be for governments to seek foreign investment to revitalize their oil industries and to broaden their economic bases.
But despite the overture by Prince Abdullah, most governments still appear resistant to allowing foreign companies to reassert more than a peripheral role. One reason, particularly in Saudi Arabia, is that the Western military presence has ignited domestic criticism.
The best option would be realism -- to cut spending. But that could certainly provoke the kind of outcry that the monarchies do not appear eager to withstand.
"What is necessary will not be easy," said Amir al-Tamimi, president of the Economic Society of Kuwait. "Above all, it has become clear that these governments are going to have to find a way to cope with social pain."

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 16 about the effects of low oil prices on the Persian Gulf region referred incorrectly to a standard unit of measurement. The barrel, used throughout the world to measure crude oil and other oil products, is defined as a volume of 42 gallons. It does not correspond to any actual container, and has no relation to the 55-gallon steel drums that are widely used for shipping liquids.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1423 words

HEADLINE: Desperado

BYLINE: By Sarah Kerr; Sarah Kerr writes about Mexico for The New York Review of Books.

 BODY:

THE LIFE AND TIMES
OF PANCHO VILLA
By Friedrich Katz.
Illustrated. 985 pp. Stanford, Calif.:
Stanford University Press.
Cloth, $85. Paper, $29.95. 
 Though it raged for 10 shocking years, the Mexican Revolution has never been viewed as particularly central to the century that's about to end -- not like the Russian Revolution, or even the smaller-scale Spanish Civil War. Probably this is because Mexico's conflict blurred what we think of as the usual political divides.
The event that triggered it was straightforward enough: In 1910, President Porfirio Diaz, a quasi dictator who had "modernized" the economy with measures favorable to rich people and foreigners, went back on his pledge not to run for re-election one last time. (He'd already held office for 30 years.) Annoyance at this about-face turned into opposition, popular armies sprang up to fight the federal one and Diaz was forced to step down in 1911. So far so good, but what followed is much harder to describe.
After a brief period of promise, unity among the rebels went out the window. Leader after regional leader was assassinated, and even now, at a distance of many decades, it's hard to judge whether ideology or ambition or blood feuds were to blame. From such chaos -- part volcano, part musical chairs -- it's not surprising that the most celebrated fallen hero of the era should be the man with the simplest revolutionary program, and the clearest-cut record as a martyr. Emiliano Zapata fought on behalf of southern peasants to win back land that Diaz had taken away. His dream of a pastoral, proudly Indian Mexico was immortalized in utopian murals by Diego Rivera. His continuing relevance is obvious today in Chiapas, where a new band of rebels has taken his name.
But where does this leave Pancho Villa, commander of the greatest revolutionary army in the north? Once upon a time, he was the one who got top hero billing, with thrilling exploits that riveted people in the United States as well as in Mexico. If anything, Friedrich Katz's towering new biography, "The Life and Times of Pancho Villa," suggests that while he was alive Villa may have become too big a myth for his own good. To his adherents he was nothing short of a Robin Hood. To his enemies he was at best a mercenary bandit, at worst a bloodthirsty fiend, slicing through crowds with a machete. Katz calls these myths the Epic and the Black, and he finds both to be something of a stretch, but his own attitude toward Villa can hardly be called neutral. He is a historian by profession, and a rather passionate thesis runs beneath this book, to the effect that history has denied Pancho Villa his due.
Villa was a genius -- though his wild destiny was not as obvious in his youth as either myth would have us believe. Little is known about his early years. It's often said that he was driven to become an outlaw when someone raped his sister and honor demanded that he murder the rapist. Katz isn't at all sure that this tale is true; he's not even sure that the young Villa made such a great bandit. When war broke out in 1910, he was just another man corraled to fight the federal forces. Soon enough, though, he rose. Something he did made men want to follow him. Firsthand testimony invariably recalls his eyes, electrified with purpose. It's quite ironic, given the later prevalence of the violent Black myth, that early in his career Villa was famous for keeping impeccable order among his troops and safeguarding private property. Men wanted to fight with him, and villagers wanted his protection, because of all the leaders available he was the most responsible. (Not with women, though -- never with women. Villa coaxed countless lovers into bed by arranging fake marriages, and his courtship of at least one common-law wife was a quick, efficient rape.)
So what changed over the years? Villa reached his heyday in the second phase of the revolution, after the liberal president who replaced Diaz had been murdered in a coup. Loyal to the fallen man's memory, Villa led his huge northern army against the new illegitimate president and, soon enough, against competing factions in the revolution. Katz believes that several times Villa single-handedly saved Mexico from the reactionaries. At the same time, his heavy military responsibilities slowed the pace of political reform.
Compare Villa's task to that faced by Zapata in the south, for example. Zapata's fighters got to stay in their villages and fight in relatively minor local skirmishes. Villa's troops had to travel hundreds of miles and fend off heavy, constant federal attack. This was distracting, and required money. It also pushed Villa to postpone land redistribution, which he genuinely believed in, lest his hard-working troops miss out on the bounty. Add to this mix some meddling by the United States, a series of betrayals by men who had once been or even still claimed to be allies and Villa's utter failure to keep up with new military techniques, which put his troops in jeopardy. In psychological terms, Villa seems to have caved in to the stress. In pop psychological terms, you could say he "went bad."
As his power shrank, he misused it more. His judgment, never very steady, now spun like a roulette wheel. In a desperate (yet it has to be admitted, clever and daring) bid for attention, he reversed his pro-American policy and raided the small town of Columbus, N.M. And he became paranoid and punitive. For the first time in his career he began to kill large numbers of civilians, including women -- brutally, and in cold blood.
This is a very long book, at times repetitive in its obeisance to academic form. It should be noted, too, that Katz is Austrian by birth, and this book clearly is not written by a native English speaker. But the research here obviously represents decades of devotion, and it is formidable. Coming from the Eastern Hemisphere also appears to have given Katz a broader perspective on the revolution, one that is sorely needed. Partly owing to its uniqueness, and partly to neglect by the rest of the world, Mexican history can feel like quite an insular subject. Over and over, Katz strives to place Villa in a global context.
As a revolutionary who was written out of history by victorious rivals, Villa, Katz says, is a little like Trotsky vis-a-vis Stalin. As a guerrilla leader coming down from the mountains he can be compared to Fidel Castro. As the charismatic commander of a large army who grew overconfident in later years, he has something in common with Napoleon. His extreme loyalty toward his troops also calls to mind that tragically common 20th-century figure, the Latin American military dictator. What distinguishes Villa from Trotsky is that beyond thinking that a handful of rich ranchers had too much power, he was never terribly fussy about ideology. What distinguishes him from everyone else on this list is that he came up from peasant stock, he never really took advantage of his position to line his pockets (though corrupt sidekicks did, it's true) and on several occasions when he could have fought his way to the presidency he backed off. Villa didn't want unlimited power. All he wanted was to control his home turf in the north. This is important: Though he stopped short of greatness, he did have a curious sort of integrity.
His limitations must not be understated. Katz quarrels with the Black myth, but even if it's highly exaggerated, little about it is false. A rehabilitation of Villa simply cannot rest on the question of what he might have done if given the unlimited chance -- the question is too scary. But a rehabilitation can rest on questions of memory. At his height, Villa sparked the imagination more than any other revolutionary leader. His pivotal contributions are still celebrated in hundreds of popular ballads, but have been played down in history books.
In 1923, Villa went for a drive and was killed by a sharpshooter. His death was passed off as the inevitable downfall of a rascal with many enemies. In fact Katz convincingly implicates the president at the time, Villa's former military rival, Alvaro Obregon, in the murder, or at the very least in a cover-up. At this point, officially speaking, the revolution was over. Mexico had been reborn as a forward-looking, cooperative family. But even at this late stage, Villa represented some kind of possibility. He was a threatening potential, an open question. Debate over his legacy suggests that he still may be today.

HEADLINE: A Dirty Shame

BYLINE: By Keith Schneider; Keith Schneider is executive director of the Michigan Land Use Institute.

 BODY:

EARTH ODYSSEY
Around the World in Search of
Our Environmental Future.
By Mark Hertsgaard.
372 pp. New York:
Broadway Books. $26. 
 Mark Hertsgaard'S reputation as an astute journalist was made in the 1980's when as a magazine and book writer he explored politics, the press and pop culture. His best-known work, "On Bended Knee: The Press and the Reagan Presidency" (1988), described the way the Reagan White House deployed raw power and conventional wisdom to intimidate Washington's television newsrooms. In the 1990's, his attention turned to the even more formidable: the ecological fate of the earth. Hertsgaard embarked upon a seven-year global tour to investigate the environmental future. The journey spanned four continents, 19 countries and hundreds of interviews. Hertsgaard spoke with Vaclav Havel in Prague, he talked with industrial workers in soot-choked China and retraced Winston Churchill's steps in North Africa.
Hertsgaard's central question in 1991 was "whether the human species would survive the next hundred years." By the time he returned in the late 1990's to write in a cabin amid a majestic grove of California sequoias, he was convinced the answer was yes. But he finds few other reasons to be optimistic: The pace of global population growth, rampant air and water pollution in the developing world and the weakening resolve of the United States to lead the environmental revolution it fostered spell big trouble for the quality of human existence.
This, of course, is hardly a novel message. But Hertsgaard is after something different from the annual compendium of trends in the planet's failing health put out by Lester R. Brown's Worldwatch Institute, or the eloquent assessment, in Bill McKibben's "End of Nature," of the risks to the environment and the economy posed by global climate change. Hertsgaard's focus is the human dimension to global ecological decline, and in "Earth Odyssey," he displays an authentic talent for storytelling. By taking care to explain the technical, by including just enough of himself and by giving full breath to select characters, he has transformed a daunting subject into a stirring contribution to the growing literature on the global environment.
The path Hertsgaard takes around the world is full of surprises and unexplored places. Just as important, he does not berate or moralize. His tone is generally that of an interested and accomplished reporter seeking to understand communities and assemble a foundation of facts from which to draw conclusions.
The chapters on China are especially satisfying. In Chongqing, a southwestern industrial city, Hertsgaard investigates a chlorine plant that officials say is closed, but continues to operate and pour a toxic waterfall of raw chlorine and other chemicals directly into the Jialing River, a drinking water source for millions of people. But this was hardly the worst pollution he saw there.
Though residents of China's cities rarely see blue sky because of air pollution caused by burning coal, and rivers are so choked by raw sewage and chemical wastes that fish cannot survive, China's 1.2 billion people are still motivated by one concern. They want to make enough money to escape poverty, joblessness and cramped living conditions that Americans would never tolerate. Western environmental concerns seem so inconsequential as to be almost laughable. "You may complain about our contributions to global warming or the ozone hole," Hertsgaard is told. "But how much pollution we make, how many trees we cut or dams we build is nobody's business but ours."
"Social forces have been set in motion that will not be contained," Hertsgaard writes. "Electricity, telephones, running water -- once humans experience these things, they want more of them, no matter the ecological cost. As well they might. It is easy for outsiders to warn against the long-term costs of damming Africa's rivers, ruining its scenery, or destroying its woodlands, but it is akin to a glutton admonishing a beggar on the evil of carbohydrates -- he lacks a certain moral authority."
Where "Earth Odyssey" falters is its recommendations. Hertsgaard's survey of the potential fixes for a world being disfigured by the passion for wealth -- technology improvements, more efficiently using resources, minimizing waste, even shifting taxes to penalize pollution -- is so bogged down in statistics and theory that it's like breathing through a dishrag. Hertsgaard could have remedied this problem by focusing more intensely on the solution he knows the most about: politics and government.
It's been little more than a generation since the United States invented and enacted the program that cleaned the air, cleared the water and safeguarded millions of acres of wild lands. Presidents of both parties and bipartisan Congressional action provided the political foundation for visionary people to do something great.
In the 1960's, for example, Stewart L. Udall, the Secretary of the Interior during eight years of the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, established four national parks, six national monuments, nine national recreation areas, 20 national historic sites and nine national lakeshores and seashores. Udall also wrote the 1964 Wilderness Act, which preserved tens of millions of acres of wild land, and helped to gain passage of the 1968 Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. He championed Rachel Carson's warning about toxic chemicals and set the stage for the pioneering environmental legislation of the 1970's.
The question Hertsgaard needed to address is why Washington turned meek. It's not enough to spend pages criticizing Vice President Al Gore for failing to act on a vow to make the environment the "central organizing principle" of governance -- the conclusion of Gore's best-selling book "The Earth in the Balance" (1992). Gore works in an economic and historic context that has shrunk the political comfort zone for courageous policy making. Business owners, lawmakers, the press and ultimately voters are apparently satisfied with mediocre governing. Until the political market for inspired ideas and passionate leadership reawakens in the United States, what Hertsgaard calls "the material striving of the entire human family" will never be reconciled with the carrying capacity of the planet's environment.

HEADLINE: TriBeCa Dissent: A 'Postmodern Hulk'

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Block 214 Association represents the community living and working close to the development described on Dec. 6 in the "Posting" entitled "New TriBeCa Building Designed to Look Old."
We believe the building will impact negatively on this neighborhood, socially, economically and physically. In similar situations throughout the city, luxury residential developments have reduced a neighborhood's diversity, particularly by driving out artists and small businesses. 
 The surrounding neighborhood, designated mixed use, has a residential, office and studio population (representing all the arts), as well as a number of street-level businesses including shipping, restaurants and clubs.
Whatever the claims of the architect, the fact is that the building doesn't "fit into the neighborhood." Anyone who is at all familiar with the character of the neighborhood can see that while low- through mid-rise buildings line the north-south streets, the east-west streets, especially those between Hudson and Greenwich, are uniformly characterized by low midblock buildings. No. 3-9 Hubert Street will be the only midblock building in the neighborhood to rise above seven stories. With 12-foot ceilings (and 13 floors, including penthouse), it will be the equivalent of a 17-story building. On three sides of the site the buildings have ceilings of approximately 9 to 10 feet.
The proposed building is clearly out of character with the historic architecture of the area.
Many of us in the community are dismayed by the philistine concept of a new building having to emulate one from another period (the title of your article). Mr. Lombardi's dispiriting neo-Deco design (if that's what it is), is just another generic postmodern hulk, now all too familiar in downtown Manhattan.
The basis on which the Landmarks Preservation Commission approved the design is faulty. The premise that a new building is acceptable in a historic district because it "emulates" an existing one is specious. In fact, Mr. Lombardi's building will resemble no existing TriBeCa building.
In TriBeCa, a neighborhood that has so many styles from so many periods, covering at least 150 years of architectural history, there is no rationale for building a historical pastiche. We would much prefer a contemporary building by a fine architect, in scale with the district.
 
CAROLE ASHLEY
Block 214 Association
Manhattan

HEADLINE: FILM;
A Legend of French Film Whose Legacy Is Clarity

BYLINE: By DAVE KEHR; Dave Kehr is a New York film writer.

 BODY:
ROBERT BRESSON, the doyen of French filmmakers, keeps his Paris apartment at the western tip of the Ile St. Louis. From the small park in front of his building, a favorite site for cinephiles on Parisian pilgrimages, there is a magnificent view down the Seine, still a working river with its traffic of barges and tourist boats.
To the south, almost hidden behind a rise of buildings, looms the Cathedral of Notre Dame. Perhaps Mr. Bresson can see it from his window, but somehow one assumes that he would prefer not to. Like the realm of the sacred in many of his films, it is something to be felt rather than seen, while our eyes remain focused on the brute reality in front of us, on the world's commerce and commotion. 
 Now a fragile 97, Mr. Bresson no longer appears in public and has not made a film since "L'Argent" 15 years ago. Yet a poll of critics and filmmakers would almost certainly name him the most important living director; for the always quotable Jean-Luc Godard, "Bresson is French cinema, as Dostoyevsky is the Russian novel and Mozart is German music."
Mr. Bresson's complete work consists of a mere 13 features made between 1943 and 1983 (plus one odd, unclassifiable piece of juvenilia, the free-form 1934 short comedy "Les Affaires Publiques"), all of which will be shown in a complete retrospective that begins on Friday and runs through Feb. 7 at the Museum of Modern Art.
The series, organized by James Quandt of the Cinematheque Ontario, features newly struck 35-millimeter prints with new subtitles, promising a clarity absolutely essential for this most pristine of film artists.
An artist was what Mr. Bresson always considered himself to be. From the beginning, with the tentative, cramped "Les Anges du Peche," filmed under the occupation in 1943, the director's difference was evident. The highly melodramatic story -- a nun (Renee Faure) struggles to save the soul of an insistently ungrateful delinquent (Jany Holt) -- was treated with a restraint and sobriety far beyond the Greer Garson-ish standards of the time. "Bresson's nuns are true," wrote Roland Barthes in a prescient early review. "They know how to wear the habit, how to walk, talk and pray." Said Sacha Guitry, France's leading man of the theater, "It's much better than a movie."
Mr. Bresson relied on literary sources for his first few films -- "Les Anges" was written by Jean Giraudoux and the subsequent "Les Dames du Bois de Boulogne" by Jean Cocteau. "Journal d'un Cure de Campagne" ("Diary of a Country Priest," 1951) was taken from a novel by Georges Bernanos. With each film, Mr. Bresson's style became more austere, his thematic focus tighter. But it was with "Un Condamne a Mort s'est Echappe" ("A Man Escaped," 1956) that Mr. Bresson broke through to something startlingly new.
He began by tossing out conventional notions of film acting: the forced emphases, the exaggerated expressions, the gestures of what he came to define as "filmed theater." Instead of actors, he would henceforth use "models," nonprofessionals who would be instructed to read their lines with as little interpretive inflection as possible.
Resisting the illusion of "wholeness" created by the classical, Hollywood style of filmmaking, Mr. Bresson discarded the unified theatrical space reproduced by long shots in favor of a fragmented vision composed of close-ups -- and close-ups not just of faces but of inanimate objects, hands and feet as well. The world beyond the tight visual field of Mr. Bresson's camera was imaginatively imported by the soundtrack.
"Un Condamne" works almost as a metaphorical presentation of Mr. Bresson's new method. Based on the memoirs of Andre Devigny, the film tells the true story of a French resistance fighter's escape from the notorious Fort Montluc prison in German-occupied Lyons. The point of view, while not strictly and naively subjective, is tightly linked to the protagonist; the film restricts itself to the range of his perceptions. The world beyond the prison is, like the space beyond the limits of the shots, evoked by sound, suggestion and intuition.
The film is constructed as a series of Chinese boxes: within the world there is a prison, within the prison a cell, in the cell a man, and in the man a -- what? Call it a consciousness, a spirit or a soul, it's an unnamable something that yearns for escape.
All of Mr. Bresson's subsequent films tell essentially the same story of an individual searching, consciously or unconsciously, for a way out. The individual need not be a saint; in fact, Mr. Bresson's one explicitly hagiographic film, the 1962 "Proces de Jeanne d'Arc" ("The Trial of Joan of Arc"), is one of his rare failures. More often, the Bressonian protagonist is a morally ambiguous figure, attracted to damnation as much as salvation, to evil as much as good.
In "Pickpocket" (1959), the central character is an unemployed student, Michel (Martin Lassalle), who turns to petty crime, at first to test an abstract moral theory (the film is distantly based on "Crime and Punishment"), but soon because of the rapturous state it produces in him. Driven to more and more daring feats, he tests the limits of this strangely spiritual, profoundly antisocial experience. But the pickpocket only finds release in the film's famous final image, as he looks through the bars of a cell at the woman he suddenly realizes he loves.
Seeing "Pickpocket" in 1969 inspired a young critic named Paul Schrader to write a highly influential book called "Transcendental Style in Film"; it also inspired him, as a screenwriter, to create the figures of Travis Bickle in "Taxi Driver" and Jake La Motta in "Raging Bull." But Mr. Schrader's most fully developed Bressonian hero is Nick Nolte's Wade Whitehouse in the current "Affliction," a small town police officer who becomes a martyr to his own inner violence.
"A Man Escaped" and "Pickpocket" both include sequences of breathtaking formal beauty; the sequence in "Pickpocket" in which Michel and his colleagues descend upon a train station achieves a grace and perfection in its balance of camera movement and gesture. These moments become more and more rare in Mr. Bresson's later work, as if he puritanically saw in them too much pride and worldly exuberance.
Yet Mr. Bresson was never the stony minimalist he is often made out to be. There is almost no camera movement in his 1966 film "Au Hasard Balthazar" ("Balthazar"), but it overflows with incident. Using the life of a donkey, Balthazar of the title, as its core, the film weaves half a dozen story lines into a vivid and desolate portrait of rural life. Surrounded by pain and relentlessly victimized, Balthazar endures and is rewarded with one of the most sublime deaths on film. Exhausted, the animal kneels in a sun-dappled field, surrounded by a herd of sheep, as the bells around their necks ring out an Angelus. Nothing retentive there.
In Mr. Bresson's most disconsolate films, suicide offers the only practical escape route: the heroine of "Mouchette" (1967) drowns herself by rolling down a hillside into a pond; "Le Diable Probablement" ("The Devil Probably," 1977) was forbidden to minors in France because officials feared its brutal climax might incite teen-agers to kill themselves.
Yet the deaths in these films are as much ceremony as tragedy. The heroine of "Une Femme Douce" ("A Gentle Woman," 1969) considers killing her husband but kills herself instead; the protagonist of "L'Argent" (1983) murders an old woman and walks off impassively to his execution. In both cases, Mr. Bresson withholds the psychological factors that may have motivated the actions; their gestures are accomplished with a blank automatism that suggests an ancient sacrifice, a yielding to the gods.
In 1977, Mr. Bresson published a slim volume of aphorisms titled "Notes sur le Cinematographe," which has recently been reprinted in English by Sun and Moon Press under the misleading title "Notes on the Cinematographer." The book remains the best introduction to Mr. Bresson's work, the embodiment of his style as well as the most acute analysis of it. In a passage cited by James Quandt in his introduction to the critical anthology being published in conjunction with the retrospective, Mr. Bresson writes, "It is with something clean and precise that you will force the attention of inattentive eyes and ears."
More clean, more precise the cinema does not get.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 10; Column 4; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 120 words

HEADLINE: Who the Heck Is Buck Wiley and Why Is He Leaving?

 BODY:
Nicholas Weinstock's article on the exodus of American entrepreneurs from Russia (Dec. 27) is a chronicle not of Russia's economic failure but of America's moral one. Does a country where the majority lack basic health care really need a Gold's Gym? Does a populace so impoverished that most cannot afford to buy meat need a pricey steakhouse?
 Instead of helping Russia get back on her feet, entrepreneurs geared their goods and services to the wealthiest Russians, then cut and ran with the earnings as soon as the market tumbled. This may be capitalism, but it's capitalism without any concern for the welfare of ordinary people. No wonder Communism is making a comeback.
 
Katherine Marsh
Bronxville, N.Y.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: In the Region / Westchester;
Downtown Scarsdale Development Plan Advances

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

DATELINE: SCARSDALE

 BODY:
FOR more than 30 years, there has been endless discussion and analysis over what to do with two unsightly parcels of land on either side of Popham Road near this village's train station. Each lot measures about an acre. One has a nondescript retail building on it, the other an asphalt parking lot.
Several projects have been advanced over the years for the land, but all were scuttled because of concerns about the impact of any construction project on this affluent community's tranquil and prized quality of life. 
 "This land and what to do with it has been studied ad nauseam," said Mayor Edward Morgan. "I think everyone realizes that the time to do something is now. There's no going backward."
That sense of urgency, as well as several other compelling factors, have pushed a current project further along than any other before it, despite a campaign by those who oppose the plan and concerns voiced by the neighboring Town of Greenburgh.
Last Tuesday, the Village Board of Trustees approved by a 6-to-1 vote an environmental impact statement for a 90,500-square-foot project to be built on the two pieces of land, known as the Freightway and Depot Place parcels -- the former owned by the village, the latter by American Premier Underwriters, an insurance company based in Cincinnati. The company also owns the air rights over the track.
The project would include 45 to 60 housing units and about 30,000 square feet of shops and services in the two landscaped parcels. A 300-car underground parking garage would extend below both lots.
The board will now consider amending the zoning for the two sites to increase the permitted proportion of nonresidential or commercial use from 10 percent to 45 percent. "That will be necessary to achieve the right balance between something small enough not to create additional problems, yet big enough to have some critical mass in order to make something happen," said Dorothy Finger, a member of the board, who voted in favor of the project. "What's the point of just having another apartment building there, with little or no businesses. That wouldn't add anything."
The village center, which surrounds the train station, already has several apartment buildings with a total of 264 apartments, according to a citizen's advisory report on downtown development completed in 1995. "This project complies with all the principles set out in that report," said Amy Paulin, a board member. "We're using it to guide us in this process."
Among those principles were recommendations that the two parcels have a maximum of 100,500 square feet of development, with a mix of residential, retail and parking, and that they cover the tracks.
The approval process now moves on to site-plan approval, where questions of design and the actual positioning of buildings will be addressed. "I'd say we're looking at another year before this gets final approval," said Bradford Perkins, president of Perkins Eastman Architects, of Manhattan, which is principal architect on the project.
Mr. Perkins, who is a resident of Scarsdale, said he first got involved with redevelopment of the village's downtown in the late 1970's. "We were reviewing a prior proposal that got scrapped, but interest remained in doing something with the land because what's there now is so unattractive."
In a "fit of boyish enthusiasm," Mr. Perkins said, "I suggested combining the properties and developing them at the same time." This approach solved other inherent problems, as well, Mr. Perkins said.
"It has no frontage," Mr. Perkins said. "It's bounded by the railroad tracks and buildings and has no views." The solution, he determined, was to go over the tracks. "It's the only way out of that," he said. "Otherwise nobody would want to live there."
Development on the Freightway parcel would consist of retail, personal service and other similar uses at street level, and apartments in a building shaped like a U with one truncated arm that would span the tracks. The Depot Place parcel would be a shopping plaza with one-story retail, personal service and other uses fronting on Popham Road and Depot Place.
Zoning requires that at least 10 percent of the housing be designated for the elderly. "Other potential tenants would be corporate and diplomatic relocations," said Mr. Perkins. "There would probably be a few young families. But as a rule, families in Scarsdale don't live in apartments." This was a major concern to the board, Ms. Paulin said, due to potential overcrowding in the village's pubic schools.
IT has not yet been determined whether the apartments will be for-sale or rentals. "All we know is that they will be high-end, as will the shops," Mr. Perkins said. "The actual design has not yet been worked out in detail," Mr. Perkins explained, "but it will be compatible with the other apartment buildings downtown," which were built in the 1920's. "They're Scarsdale Tudor," Mr. Perkins said. "It's really what people think of when they think of Scarsdale. All of our buildings will have pitched roofs, and fit right in."
A landscaped plaza bridging the depressed railroad tracks will connect the two parts of the downtown, now divided by the tracks. The major connection now is the Popham Road Bridge.
"Trying to cross the bridge at almost any time of day, you're lucky if you don't get hit by a car," said Ms. Finger, the board member. "It's a mess. It wouldn't make any sense to build a project with an apartment building without the added dimension of allowing for pedestrian traffic to move back and forth."
Beverley Sved, who cast the sole opposing vote on the seven-member board, thinks that the project, rather than connecting the two parts of downtown, will provide more of a barrier. "It will have a wall-like effect, blocking out views from Garth Road," she said.
Paul Feiner, Supervisor of the Town of Greenburgh, has sent letters to Mayor Morgan outlining his concerns about the project's impact on traffic, especially along busy Ardsley Road. "If our concerns aren't addressed, we would consider litigation against the village," he said. "But we hope that it doesn't come to that and that we can find a solution such as having the developer pay for traffic improvements in Greenburgh."
A group called Scarsdale Responsible Citizens has also been critical of the project. The development would amount to "the urbanization of our charming village," said Michael Anastas, the group's chairman.
"We take exception to the board's approval of the environmental findings," he added. "We don't believe it has adequately studied what this project would do to the village."
Ms. Paulin, the board member, conceded that some problems still remain.
"We still have a number of concerns -- for instance, how the platform will look," said Ms. Paulin. "We still haven't gotten a list of all the development partners involved. That's probably the biggest open question."
The likely developers at this point is a partnership called the Scarsdale Depot Associates, which is comprised of Fairchild Properties, a real estate company based in Manhattan, and American Premier Underwriters. The company, formerly Penn Central, changed its name in March 1994 to reflect its role as an insurer, rather than a railroad. "We've been involved in this project in various forms for 15 years," said Sam Klein, president of Fairchild Properties.
Over the years, Mr. Klein said the project had been drastically reduced in size. The current scaled down plan "couldn't possibly be any smaller," Mr. Klein said. "As it is we need a few variables staying in place for it to succeed, such as today's low interest rates holding." He expects the completed project to cost around $17 million."
"Our next step is to present a formal site plan," Mr. Klein added. "We hope to have a shovel in the ground by the second quarter of this year. But realistically I know it could take longer."

HEADLINE: Another Stadium the State Still Needs to Fill Up

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
Is the Connecticut Tennis Center in New Haven a gigantic white elephant and monument to imprudent state spending -- or an ultramodern stadium that may yet fulfill its promise?
Whatever one's view, the center (which towers over the nearby Yale Bowl) was built on Yale University property with $18 million in state-issued bonds. The 15,000-seat center will be the site of a women's professional tournament for one week in August -- the only event scheduled so far this year. To many, it has become a grandiose venue built less than a decade ago for a tennis promoter whose weeklong men's tournament was lured out of the country -- two years after he had sold it to another promoter in what was regarded as a better financial deal. 
 At a time when many question the prudence of building a stadium in Hartford for the National Football League's New England Patriots -- at what is expected to be more than $400 million in state funds -- the track record of the Tennis Center may stand as a cautionary symbol.
"We can learn a lesson from what has happened," said Joseph McGee, a former commissioner of the state's Department of Economic Development and now a vice president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association. "It shows that we have to hold sports operators to a much tighter standard in the future."
Mr. McGee did not elaborate, but he could have been alluding to negotiations between the state and Robert K. Kraft, owner of the New England Patriots, which have produced what is generally acknowledged to be the best deal ever offered to a professional sports franchise.
Moira K. Lyons of Stamford, the state's new Speaker of the House, pointed out that if the Patriots decided to leave Hartford before their 30-year contract had expired, the team's owners would be obliged to pay "liquidation damages" (assuming the state had kept its part of the contract). Such money could be used toward the cost of the stadium. "A formula for that is being worked out now," said Ms. Lyons, who had initially expressed skepticism over the stadium plans.
No similar arrangement was ever established with the two tennis promoters in New Haven. "I expected the men's tournament would stay in New Haven for at least 20 years," said the New Haven Mayor, John DeStefano Jr., who was the first executive director of the Tennis Foundation of Connecticut Inc., which owns and operates the tennis stadium. When the Tennis Center was built in 1991, it was projected as a catalyst for rejuvenating a city whose image had been largely drawn by crime and poverty.
The tournament promoter, city officials, civic leaders and many others predicted that hotels, restaurants and other businesses would flourish with the coming of the Volvo International Tennis Tournament, which was first played in a temporary stadium alongside the Yale Bowl in 1990. But Volvo dropped out and Pilot Pen became the sponsor three years ago, and after last year's competition, the tournament left the city entirely, for Austria.
After William A. O'Neill, then the Governor, succeeded in luring the Volvo tournament from Stratton Mountain, Vt., in 1990 -- with the promise of building a state-financed stadium -- Paul H. Johnson, the first president of the Tennis Foundation, said he agreed with Mr. O'Neill that the tournament would have "enormous benefits" for the state. And John Daniels, then the Mayor of New Haven, predicted that the tournament would result in "great economic benefits" for the city.
In truth, while the men's tournament -- whose field was diluted somewhat each year because of a competing event in Indianapolis -- attracted media attention to New Haven, it had scant economic impact on the area. One reason, as several studies have shown, is that the vast majority of spectators have been from towns within about a 45-mile radius and rarely went to restaurants or bars in the city or stayed in its hotels.
Indeed, an economic impact study conducted by students at the Yale University School of Organization and Impact showed that during the tournament's first year in 1991, 85 percent of the $7.04 million in direct spending related to the tournament was spent at the new stadium itself.
That was far below the annual figure of $10 million that some members of the Tennis Foundation predicted would be generated for New Haven area businesses. Supporters had also estimated that the event would produce as much as $500,000 in annual tax revenue to the city from a 3 percent surcharge on tickets to the men's tournament. As it developed, the city has received far less.
Additionally, backers of the stadium proposal said that revenues from a 10 percent admission surcharge would be enough to pay the debt service on the 20-year general obligation bonds that, with interest, are expected to cost the state around $33 million. Over the first four years of the stadium's existence, revenue from the admission tax went to the legislature's general fund.
But at the request of Mayor DeStefano, then the executive director of the Tennis Foundation, the state agreed in 1993 (the year Mr. DeStefano was elected Mayor), to let the foundation keep all revenue from the 10 percent admission surcharge.
"If that hadn't happened, the foundation could no longer have operated," said Christopher Perillo, the current executive director of the Tennis Foundation and its lone full-time employe.
In the last year, Mayor DeStefano has asked the city's Board of Aldermen to waive the 3 percent surcharge so that the current promoter, Butch Buchholz -- who sold the men's tournament but plans to keep the women's event in New Haven -- does not have to pay the surcharge. (Such a waiver would, of course, deprive the city of tax revenue from the women's event.)
Mr. Perillo, Mayor DeStefano and the current president of the Tennis Foundation, Richard Nelson, all agree that the Tennis Center has been vastly underused. "We definitely have to expand the usage," Mr. Perillo said, and Mr. Nelson added, "We're always trying to get more events."
Before the bond issue was approved for the center, the promoter of the Volvo International, Jim Westhall, said his company, Jewel Productions, planned to stage several concerts each summer. But less than a dozen have been held, and none since 1994 when performers such as Patti LaBelle, Bonnie Raitt, James Taylor and Julio Iglesias appeared.
"We were hurt by the expansion of the Oakdale Musical Theater in Wallingford and by the opening of the Meadows" -- an outdoor concert theater in Hartford -- Mr. Perillo said. "And I can't see concerts being held at the Tennis Center again. For one thing, the costs of putting up a stage and erecting a sound system, among other things, make it prohibitive. But then you have to look around and realize that other tennis stadiums in the country are also just used for tennis."
The Tennis Foundation still has the Pilot Pen International women's tournament, which was held at the Tennis Center for the first time last year and drew an outstanding field of players including Steffi Graf and Lindsay Davenport.
But that is not enough. Mr. Nelson noted that the Tennis Foundation has considered staging volleyball games, boxing matches and professional figure skating.
Mayor DeStafano, a Democrat in his second term, said "Concerts never developed as we had hoped they would. But I think men's tennis will be back. After all, this is a great tennis facility, one of the best in the world."
The president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce, Matthew Nemerson, said that "there have been some real lessons there for us to learn, but it's been a good training program. We thought we'd get more people from Fairfield County, but found out that it's such an appendage of New York, which has to get out of the shadow of New York City. And the stadium definitely was built too big."
Still, Mr. Nemerson and Mayor DeStefano are convinced that tournaments at the Tennis Center have focused attention on New Haven and been good for the city. "Building a tennis stadium is not going to cure poverty or end crime, but that's not what it was was postured to do," Mr. DeStefano said. "New Haven has a lot to offer, and the stadium is just one more part of a larger puzzle that includes Yale, the Shubert Theater, the Long Wharf Theater and the New Haven Symphony, among other things."
"As far as we're concerned, the investment made sense," the Mayor said. "It's helped create community pride and enhanced our quality of life." As for repayment of the bond money, Mr. DeStefano said, "There was never any commitment for us to repay the bonds. It was just assumed that revenues generated would raise enough tax money to make up for the bonds."
But that has not been the case.
Joseph McGee, Commissioner of Economic Development under former Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and a strong proponent of the Tennis Center -- with its 22 field courts built or renovated at a cost of an additionl $3 million in state bonds -- said that the plan for the center "was not structured effectively."
"Everyone was overly optimistic, and it's certainly not turned out to be everything it could have been," he said. "But there's a learning curve here. Building the Tennis Center was not a mistake, but we learned that we have to keep a close eye on sports promoters in the future."
