HEADLINE: The Turnpike in Mid-Life Crisis

BYLINE: By SUSAN BANFIELD 

 BODY:
SIX ex-governors, as well as the then-current Governor, Abraham Ribicoff, were present at formal ribbon-cutting ceremonies held in Greenwich and Killingly Jan. 2, 1958. Clergymen representing the three major faiths gave their blessings. And the Connecticut Turnpike was opened.
Governor Ribicoff hailed the new highway as "a great construction achievement" that would "spur the growth and development of a large area of the state and relieve traffic congestion." 
 Today, 41 years later, the turnpike, now named the Gov. John Davis Lodge Turnpike and carrying the Interstate 95 designation on its busiest stretch along the shoreline, is the source of countless commuting horror stories. The notion that it once offered relief from southern Connecticut's traffic problems is laughable.
The story of the turnpike's coming of middle age is one of the futility of trying to foresee all future needs -- and at the same time a testament to the perseverance of planners and state officials who continue to work on solutions for the state's most heavily traveled roads.
The building of the turnpike was a mammoth project, first conceived in 1942, the object of bitter political controversy for years -- Governor Lodge, for whom it was ultimately named, held office from 1951 to 1955 -- and finally, in what Governor Ribicoff described as an "impossible timetable," constructed from start to finish in less than three years.
Construction required the acquisition of 4,688 pieces of property, the building of 274 bridges, and the pouring of 2.3 million barrels of Portland cement. Initial construction costs came to nearly $500 million.
The hopes that rode on the new highway were as grand as the project itself. Route 1, the Boston Post Road, was choked with traffic, specifically post-war truck traffic banned from the Merritt Parkway when it was built in the 1930's. A typical truck trip from the New York State line to New Haven, via Route 1, took more than three hours.
Another, more ambitious goal for the new turnpike was to revitalize the economy of the areas it passed through. Normally, highway expansion follows economic growth. However, in this case legislators hoped a new turnpike would stimulate economic development, especially in the eastern part of the state.
With the decline of the textile industry, Windham and New London counties had large pockets of unemployment, and by 1950 their population had fallen to just 10.2 percent of the state's total -- half of what it had been 100 years earlier.
At first, it went like a dream. Congestion on the Post Road was greatly relieved. The towns along the new road also demonstrated impressive growth. Between 1960 and 1970, Stamford grew from a population of 92,713 to 108,798, Westport from 20,956 to 27,414, and Orange from 8,547 to 13,524. And the economy of the eastern part of the state made a noticeable turnaround.
A 1962 study by the University of Connecticut's Department of Agriculture entitled "The Connecticut Turnpike: A Ribbon of Hope" reported that manufacturing employment in the area served by the turnpike increased by 27 percent between 1956 and 1962, compared to no increase for the state as a whole. The motel and summer home business also grew dramatically in the area, with the total capacity of motels and cabin courts up 64 percent from 1957 to 1962. The study gave the turnpike much of the credit.
By the mid 70's, however, the wave of benefits flowing from the turnpike had crested, and problems with the road began to develop.
The economy and population of southern Connecticut had indeed grown -- so much so that the turnpike was operating at close to full capacity. (It would reach the full mark of 70,000 vehicles a day in 1983.) Yet the unprecedented growth of the entire northeast, southern Connecticut included, continued.
Several life style changes helped put even more cars on the road. Stuart Leland, the Connecticut D.O.T.'s director of inventory and forecasting, says these included a dramatic increase in car ownership (from a norm of one car per family in the 1950's to today's norm of a car for each adult) and the greatly increased number of women in the work force. More women working mean more people commuting to job sites.
The D.O.T.'s Fairfield County bureau chief, Harry Harris, adds that the growth of on-time delivery services like Federal Express, and a dramatic increase in other truck traffic as the railroads declined, have also had a major impact.
By the mid- to late 70's, toll plazas were clogged with vehicles, leading to accidents, air pollution and frustration at time lost. In 1983, galvanized by a seven-fatality accident at the Stratford tolls, and facilitated by the fact that the tolls had paid off the bonds used to build the turnpike -- more than a decade ahead of schedule, the toll plazas were taken down.
That led to some easing of congestion, yet at the same time paved the way for more. Trucks that had formerly used Interstate 84 to avoid the tolls switched to newly toll-free I-95.
In the mid-1980's, the D.O.T. conducted a study of transportation in the 40-mile corridor from Greenwich to New Haven. The study concluded that if current trends continued, in order to accommodate the travel demands of the 21st century, I-95 would need up to three additional lanes in each direction, and the Merritt up to two additional lanes in each direction.
In years past, this sort of obvious solution to traffic problems was viable and successful. In the 1930's, and then again in the 1950's, entire new highways had been built. By the late 1980's, however, such projects were no longer practicable. In 1988 officials from the state D.O.T. and the Federal Highway Administration declared the proposed widening of the Merritt unfeasible. In the case of I-95, even a -- by comparison -- modest construction project such as converting the shoulder to an extra travel lane was put on the back burner because of the time and costs involved. The estimated cost of such an expansion is nearly twice that of the entire initial construction of the turnpike.
Meanwhile, congestion on the turnpike continues to worsen. Currently, with more than 120,000 vehicles a day using it, the highway is operating at 185 percent of capacity. The accident rate, 1.94 per million vehicle-miles of travel, is 12 percent higher than the state average for six-lane urban expressways. There are at any given time half a dozen ongoing construction projects in process between Greenwich and New Haven.
"You can never count on being able to make even a short trip on 95 without running into some kind of delay," said Susan McGovern, a Milford resident who for a year commuted to New Jersey and who now commutes to Westport. "If it isn't rush hour, then there's an accident, or there's lane closures due to construction."
On a scale from A (best) to E (worst), the Connecticut Turnpike at rush hour has been given an 'E' rating.
Yet, state transportation officials and area business leaders have by no means given up on the situation. In fact, they are markedly optimistic.
Construction is inevitable on a 41-year-old road. "A road system is something that wears," said James Byrnes, the D.O.T.'s chief engineer. However, the DOT tries to schedule as much road work as possible during the night. Almost without exception, he said, the major construction projects that entail lane shutdowns are now being done at night. Some types of work have to be done during the day for technical reasons, and normal maintenance activities such as pot-hole patching are also done during the day. Still, 90 percent of road work is scheduled for the period from 8 or 10 P.M. to 5:30 or 6 A.M., Mr. Byrnes says.
There is, of course, a down side to the limited work schedules. That is, projects seem to go on forever.
Actually, the aim of much construction work is to make the highway safer. Fewer accidents mean less congestion. Head-on collisions resulting from cars jumping the barrier on the central divider have been virtually eliminated by replacing metal guard rails with far more effective Jersey barriers. Many rainy day accidents have been prevented by upgrading drains.
The installation of a new $20 million intelligent transportation system is playing a major role in reducing congestion due to accidents that do occur. "Since we're not building our way out of congestion, we're trying to better manage what we have," said Mr. Byrnes. "This allows people to respond more intelligently , more quickly to incidents."
Then too, since in recent years trucks have been involved in 25 percent of turnpike accidents, the state police have recently made organizational changes to make truck traffic safer. In early September, new legislation shifted responsibility for highway traffic from the central office to three local districts.
According to Sgt. Frank Sawicki, in charge of the truck enforcement unit for the Western Connecticut District, this has enabled him to bring in additional staff. The same new legislation also increased the operational hours of the Greenwich weigh station to eight eight-hour shifts per week. In addition, the district has established roving scale teams which set up randomly in parking lots and do inspections. "We're able to address more issues than we were before," said Sergeant Sawicki.
Currently, the accident rate on the turnpike compares favorably with those of other major urban expressways. For example, the 64-mile stretch of I-94 which runs from I-80 up through Chicago and then to the Wisconsin border -- an urban area similar to that traversed by the western section of the Connecticut Turnpike -- has a rate of 2.238 crashes per million vehicle miles. The turnpike's is only 1.94.
Accident prevention has been stepped up. Construction has been limited. But what can be done to deal with rush hour? In February 1998, the D.O.T. published a 14-point plan designed to reduce traffic in the Greenwich to New Haven corridor by 5 percent by the year 2002.
After years of analysis, it had become clear that there was no silver bullet solution for the problem. But state officials are convinced that if they can succeed in getting 8,600 vehicles off the road during rush hour -- the 5 percent reduction specified -- many problems would be solved.
"Five percent doesn't fix it so traffic at rush hour goes 60 miles per hour," said Joseph McGee, vice president for public policy at SACIA (the business council of southwestern Connecticut). "But there's a tipping point. Five percent really makes a difference."
One of the biggest items on the current wish list is to increase intra-state train commuters. Between 80 and 90 percent of commuting trips to New York City are already made by train. The problem is with commutes within the coastal corridor, only 6 percent of which are by train.
Various measures, including a $57 million program to increase railroad station parking, and revisions in the fare schedule that make intrastate commuting more attractive, are being implemented.
A program called the Guaranteed Ride Home program is also being introduced. Under this program, anyone who purchases a monthly, or even a 10-trip railroad pass will be driven home by taxi free of charge in the event of an emergency. The Guaranteed Ride program is designed to alleviate the very real fears of commuting parents about being stuck at work without a car when something happens to their child.
Other items in the Department's 14-point plan include increasing ridesharing and van pooling, increasing interregional bus ridership, increasing telecommuting and work schedule changes, and promoting the use of the new Long Island ferries for trips to Manhattan and La Guardia.
Will the plan work? "You've got to do them all to get this 5 percent reduction,' says Joe McGee.
"The train goal" -- to attract 1,750 new daily riders -- "is well achievable," says Harry Harris. "The one thing I get most concerned about is the level of commitment from the business community that is going to be required to make these things happen. Businesses don't like to interfere with the personal lives of employees -- for example, getting people to switch their hours, or getting people to work at home. There has to be a corporate culture that supports these things."
Another example that underscores the critical role of business involvement is a new Federal program called Transit Chek. Under the new program, employees who use public transportation to get to work can have their commuting expenses deducted from their paychecks before taxes. The catch is, a company has to be willing to set up such a program.
"If everyone did something other than drive their single-occupancy vehicle to work one day a week -- work from home, carpool, take the train -- we'd have a dramatic reduction in congestion," says Mr. Harris. "Traffic would flow. It wouldn't be perfect, but it would flow."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 6; Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1304 words

HEADLINE: Just Whose Millstone Is It?

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
INFLUENTIAL groups and public officials on the East End of Long Island are stepping up a determined campaign to close the Millstone nuclear power plant in Connecticut, even as its operators await permission to restart the second of its three reactors after a three-year shutdown.
But the people who probably stand most to lose from any Millstone accident -- the Connecticut residents who are the plant's closest neighbors -- are mostly absent from the campaign. 
 The Long Islanders insist that they are no Don Quixotes, but rather carriers of a compelling message to residents on both sides of Long Island Sound about a rogue nuclear plant that must be placed in mothballs before a catastrophe occurs.
"We are going to shut it down by June," said Dr. Helen Caldicott, a well-known opponent of nuclear power and the president of Standing for Truth About Radiation, or Star, a group based in East Hampton, N.Y. "We have to," she said. "It's an emergency."
The opposition from Long Island's rural, resort and agricultural East End is a sharp contrast to a general, if sometimes uneasy, acceptance of the plant in an area of southeastern Connecticut around New London where jobs are at stake.
"I don't think the people of Long Island have anything to fear," said Thomas A. Sheridan, the First Selectman of the Town of Waterford, where the Millstone complex is situated and many the the plant's 2,800 employees live. "Do they think the thousands of people who live and work around here would put their families at risk?"
But Long Island officials and groups said last week that a series of shutdowns at the 1,200-megawatt Millstone Three reactor that had occurred since July, when the Nuclear Regulatory Commission allowed Millstone's operator, Northeast Utilities, to restart the reactor, showed it was unsafe and should be shut down immediately.
A spokesman for Northeast Utilities, Terrence V. McIntosh, said recent shutdowns showed the utility's heightened sensitivity to safety.
Neil A. Sheehan, a spokesman for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, also described the shutdowns as precautionary. "It's not unusual for a plant that has been down this long to run into a few bugs," he said.
Mr. Sheehan said none of the shutdowns had occurred when the plant was at or near full power.
But the Long Island groups and officials said the plant's continued operation and Northeast Utilities' plans to reopen the adjacent, 800-megawatt Millstone Two reactor later this year posed an extreme and largely unrecognized threat to southeastern Connecticut, eastern Long Island and beyond.
Dr. Caldicott said that even routine water and air emissions from Millstone may have contributed to higher cancer rates on eastern Long Island.
Mr. McIntosh, the Northeast Utilities spokesman, said environmental monitoring showed that the plant's emissions were no danger to the Sound or areas downwind.
William N. Smith, the executive director of Fish Unlimited on Shelter Island, said this was untrue. "They suck in a million gallons of water every minute and kill every organism, every shrimp, every plankton in it," said Mr. Smith, who said the plant also killed large numbers of juvenile flounders and blackfish.
The plant site on Millstone Point in Waterford is about 11 miles north of the North Fork of Long Island, and about 25 miles north of the South Fork. Northeast Utilities has pledged to inform Long Island and New York officials of plant incidents and has offered technical advice for an evacuation plan. But last week Representative Michael P. Forbes. whose Congressional district includes all the East End of Long Island, charged that the company failed to notify him about a Jan. 4 spill of 800 gallons of water containing low levels of radioactive tritium.
"I don't want to wake up one morning and read in the newspaper or hear on the radio that that we have a gigantic problem over there," Mr. Forbes said. "The fact is they have had four or five shutdowns, and that says to me they should not have gone back on line in the first place."
Last week Mr. Forbes wrote to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission chairwoman, Shirley Jackson, demanding that the plant be shut.
While Mr. Forbes and others on the East End criticized the commission, Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Democrat from Bozrah whose district includes Millstone, was confident that the commission "has demonstrated the utmost concern for safety," said his press secretary, Jon Lenzner.
Some in Connecticut were bemused by Long Island's reaction to the reopening of Millstone.
"I always thought it was curious that Long Island didn't wake up to the fact that there was a nuclear plant not too far away, and that they needed to be as watchful and careful as Connecticut communities," said Maura J. Casey, an editorial writer for The Day in New London.
Ms. Casey said most people living near Millstone appear to have come to terms with it. "The area around Millstone is replete with people who are highly sophisticated about the nuclear industry," she said. "They don't push the panic button here."
Maybe they should, suggested Dr. Caldicott, a pediatrician and founding president of Physicians for Social Responsibility, who shared a Nobel Peace Prize in 1985. She said that residents around Millstone had been seduced by tax benefits and inured to dangers. "People there have psychic numbing," said Dr. Caldicott. "They need our help. People here are not psychically numbed. Some of the most wealthy and influential people in the country are out here, and if they can be educated we will close the plant down."
Last week, Southampton became the second East End town to call for closing of the Millstone complex. The town board noted the plant's poor safety record and the absence of an evacuation plan for 110,000 year-round East End residents. (The Town of East Hampton passed a similar resolution last year.)
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission closed all three reactors in the Millstone complex in late 1995 and early 1996 because of safety violations and a pattern of retaliation against employees who reported safety problems.
The commission imposed a $2.1 million fine on Northeast Utilities and ordered an overhaul in safety programs and corporate culture before allowing Millstone Three to reopen. Its decision on reopening Millstone Two is expected during the first quarter of this year. Millstone One, the oldest of the three reactors, has been retired.
In a poll published in The Day last spring, half of New London County residents who responded said they thought Millstone Three was a safety threat and should not be reopened. But the poll also showed that more than two-thirds of respondents trusted the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to assure the plant was safe.
Ron McKeown, director and founder of Friends for a Safe Millstone of East Lyme, Conn., said there was a widespread belief the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had corrected Millstone's problems.
"It is very clear the mainstream public now believes the N.R.C. is in firm control and that the page has been turned on Millstone," Mr. McKeown said. He said his group wanted contacts with Long Island opponents of Millstone. "We all want the truth, so it's silly not to communicate," he said.
Others read the mood in southeastern Connecticut differently. Nancy Burton, a lawyer from Redding representing Fish Unlimited, said she believed faith in the commission and support for Millstone was much thinner than plant supporters asserted. "Scratch the surface and people are scared," Ms. Burton said. "But they feel powerless because there is so much economic and political pressure applied to their communities."
Ms. Burton said she was delighted with Long Island's involvement in Millstone. "We are reaching our arms across the water to each other," she said.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1467 words

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
Redeveloping a Polluted Raritan Center Parcel

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
FOR the last seven decades, a grubby swath of polluted land along Industrial Highway in the southwestern edge of Woodbridge Township has lain fallow and forgotten.
Now RPS Inc., a Pittsburgh-based small-package carrier, has started to clean up the contaminants from the 81-acre site and redevelop it into a 435,000-square-foot distribution complex that will eventually grow to 620,000 square feet. 
 The site's redevelopment is the result of six years of discussions involving RPS, local officials and the property owner, Federal Business Centers of Woodbridge. Recent changes in state law regarding the cleanup of contaminated sites that, among other things, provided buyers of such sites protection from liability helped cement the deal, as did a 30-year tax abatement the township granted the project in November.
"Tracts like this," said James E. McGreevey, the Mayor of Woodbridge, "will never become competitive unless the local or state government provides a financial incentive to offset the cost of the cleanup."
RPS -- whose parent is FDX, a holding company whose other subsidiaries include Federal Express -- broke ground in November for the initial phase of the project, estimated to cost $70 million. At its expected completion in 18 months it will become part of Raritan Center, the state's largest business/industrial park, which has three hotels as well.
The center, once part of an Army arsenal that served as a major munitions port in the two World Wars, covers 2,350 acres along the banks of the Raritan River in Woodbridge and Edison Townships in Middlesex County. Since its conversion to a commercial center 35 years ago some 13 million square feet of office, light industrial, warehouse and research space has been built at the center, which has a potential for an additional 4.3 million square feet.
RPS will lease the site for 30 years, with three 10-year renewal options, from Federal Business Centers, which owns half of Raritan Center; the other half is owned by Summit Associates of Woodbridge. The contaminant on the site is arsenic in silt dredged from the Raritan River from the 20's through the 40's and dumped on the site. The arsenic was used by the Army for rodent control. The cost of the cleanup, whose plan has been approved by the state's Department of Environmental Protection, is estimated at $5 million, which RPS will recoup as a result of the tax abatement.
The cleanup plan permits capping the site with an impervious surface. The foundation of the new building, along with the blacktop that will cover much of the site for parking, will serve as the cap.
RPS became interested in the site in 1992 because of its location. It is accessible to a host of highways, including the Garden State Parkway, the New Jersey Turnpike and Interstates 95 and 287. The site also is close to colleges, like Rutgers and Middlesex County College, which can provide a labor pool willing to work part-time and at odd hours, said James M. Maxwell, director of real estate for RPS. But "the environmental problems stalled us from moving forward," he said.
IN the intervening years RPS looked at about 75 other sites and winnowed the list to two, both free of environmental concerns. With those sites, however, "there was not as much municipal support as with the Woodbridge site, which provides us with the lowest operating cost because of the highway access," said Mr. Maxwell.
But getting the project to this point required all the economic redevelopment stars -- from financial incentives to regulatory changes -- to be in alignment for reclaiming so-called brownfields like the Woodbridge site.
From a real estate perspective "the site's location was so good that the parties involved were willing to work together," said Paul D. Cohen, executive vice president at SBWE Inc., a commercial brokerage with offices in Hasbrouck Heights and Edison, who represented RPS in the transaction.
There has been an ongoing effort in New Jersey to make the regulatory climate more flexible and offer more incentives to reuse land left from the state's industrial past. In the last 13 years the state has overseen the cleanup of 9,500 to 10,000 sites, according to the Site Remediation Program, which is part of the state's Department of Environmental Protection.
Yet nearly 10,000 contaminated sites -- excluding those on the Federal Superfund list -- remain. Of them, about 1,130 are brownfields -- which the state defines as former commercial or industrial sites that are underutilized or abandoned, contain known or perceived contaminants -- that are being cleaned and redeveloped.
The latest change in the state's environmental cleanup laws came last January with the passage of the Brownfields and Contaminated Sites Redemption Act. It provides, among other incentives, matching grants to small developers who test new technologies for sealing off or eliminating pollution, as well as reimbursement for up to 75 percent of the cleanup cost. Projects must generate new tax revenue that exceeds the cost of the cleanup to qualify for the reimbursement incentive.
But the most important provision of the 1998 law is that it protects buyers of tainted sites from private lawsuits related to past contamination problems if they agree to clean the properties according to state requirements.
Essentially, the state requires different standards depending on the planned new use of the site, with a residential reuse requiring a higher level of remediation than commercial or industrial uses. The standards also permit alternative methods, including impermeable caps to stop waste from seeping out instead of requiring the removal of such industrial residue.
Once the site is cleaned according to its standards, the state's Department of Environmental Protection will agree not to sue. The law also exempts buyers from any new cleanup costs once state environmental officials approve the cleanup job.
"The granting of a covenant not to sue is helpful in convincing lenders to lend and raising the consciousness that brownfields are O.K," said Richard Greenberg, president of Environmental Waste Management Associates, an environmental consulting firm in Parsippany.
FOR RPS, that safeguard was crucial in its decision to go forward with the Woodbridge project. "It gave us comfort that the liability issue would be manageable," Mr. Maxwell said, adding: "The law also lets us know exactly what we need to do to clean the site."
Jerry C. Swart, RPS's director of environmental services, said earlier changes in the state's regulations that permitted the capping of contaminants on sites also made the property's redevelopment more feasible.
Then the issue became making it more economically feasible. Six years ago the cost of the cleanup would have exceeded the value of the real estate, said Mr. Cohen, the broker. "The key to any of this is getting the economics to work," he noted.
The site is in an area Woodbridge designated in 1996 as in need of redevelopment. As such the township tapped an amended 1992 state law that allowed it to use the abatement to help develop projects in that area. The abatement on the property, which now generates $15,000 in annual taxes, is structured as a payment in lieu of taxes. That means Woodbridge will receive annual payments from RPS based on 15 percent of the fair market value of the rent for the building. Those payments are to begin at an annual $410,204 and increase to $717,009 over the 30 years of the lease, or a total of $16.9 million. Conventional taxes would have yielded $21.9 million over this period.
James M. Davey, business administrator for Woodbridge, said the $5 million difference will be offset by the fact that RPS will use that $5 million to clean the property, which when redeveloped will create 1,400 jobs and increase in value. In addition, he said, RPS has agreed to make a $1.5 million contribution to Woodbridge to support community projects.
The new RPS building, which will serve the New York metropolitan area, initially will process 35,000 packages an hour, and grow to 45,000 as the structure expands. It will be the largest "hub" in the company's network of 27 hubs and 343 pick-up and delivery terminals, most of them in the United States, with some in Canada. Mr. Maxwell said the first 435,000-square-foot phase will meet the company's expansion needs for the next five years.
The RPS parcel sits within a 600-acre redevelopment area, one of two such areas in the southern half of the township; the second comprises 200 acres. Both are polluted former industrial sites.
Mayor McGreevey said the new RPS building "has triggered substantial commercial interest in adjacent sites in the redevelopment area," adding that he was hopeful similar projects would follow.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1489 words

HEADLINE: In the Region / Long Island;
The Movies Are the New Stars of the Mall

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
THE recent selection of developers for three state-owned properties that once housed retarded and mentally ill patients could bring hundreds of residential units and thousands of square feet of industrial and office space to western Suffolk County, where the three sites totaling 1,107 acres are situated.
The parcels -- all of which all contain former hospital buildings, some closed for years -- comprise 655 acres at the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in Islip; 408 acres at the Long Island Developmental Center, which straddles Melville and Dix Hills, and 44 acres at the former Central Islip Psychiatric Center. 
 "These properties, which have been sitting there doing nothing, will now be put into the hands of the local communities that will have the power to decide what they would like on the properties," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. The corporation, which is the state's economic development agency, is selling off surplus hospital sites throughout the state.
"We are returning mothballed properties, which are costing the state millions of dollars a year to maintain, back to productive use," Mr. Gargano said.
The state is selling off only the unused portions of the hospital properties. At Pilgrim, which covers a total of 778 acres, about 20 buildings will be kept for various uses including patient care.
At the 458-acre Developmental Center, 50 acres containing 34 group homes serving 350 mentally retarded people and the Sagamore Children's Psychiatric Center will also remain state property.
But in Central Islip, the sale of the 44 acres will mean the last phaseout of the psychiatric hospital, which once housed more than 10,000 patients on 1,000 acres. Most of its buildings were purchased by the New York Institute of Technology in the mid-80's for use as a college campus.
Developers for the three properties were selected in a bidding process. Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville won the Pilgrim State parcel with a bid of $32 million and SBJ Associates, a partnership of the Benjamin Development Company of Garden City and Jobco Inc. of Great Neck, secured the Developmental Center for $16.1 million. Arlen Contracting Corporation, which is owned by Benjamin Development, made the $2.22 million high bid for the Central Islip site.
The total of $50.3 million will more than offset about $39 million in outstanding bonds on the three properties, which must be paid off. The sales still must be ratified by Empire State's board of directors, which is scheduled to meet next Thursday.
The properties are being sold subject to the existing zoning. The zoning at the Developmental Center site in Melville and Dix Hills allows one house on two acres; Pilgrim State in Islip has one-acre residential zoning and the Central Islip parcel is zoned for institutional use.
DEVELOPERS must also address environmental issues -- the Pilgrim State and Developmental Center sites are over groundwater recharge areas, for example -- and they must demolish existing buildings, most of which contain asbestos.
The $16.1 million offered for the 408 acres at the Developmental Center comes to just under $40,000 an acre in Melville and Dix Hills. "But you have to realize that this property is being sold on an 'as is, where is' basis, so our bid had to be structured based on our risks," said Michael F. Puntillo, Jobco's vice president.
The Pataki administration's program to dispose of the state's many surplus hospital properties was started last July, when 12 sites including the three on Long Island were offered for sale through a sealed bid process with a November deadline.
The 12 -- in 10 counties and all at one time used for long-term care -- total 3,200 acres and contain more than 10 million square feet of buildings. To date, only four bids -- the three on the Long Island properties and a fourth for the 131,000-square-foot Bernard Fineson Developmental Center Corona Unit on 1.22 acres in Queens, for which the high bid was $4.61 million -- have been accepted for ratification.
Two other bids, one for the Hudson River Psychiatric Center in Poughkeepsie, the other for the Wilton Developmental Center in Saratoga County are being reviewed.
The only other state-owned facility on Long Island, the 596-acre Kings Park Psychiatric Center in Smithtown, has not yet been approved for sale because extensive environmental reviews are still under way, Mr. Gargano said.
The Developmental Center in Melville and Dix Hills, which is surrounded by single-family houses, has been recommended for housing.
A task force for the Pilgrim property has recommended a mix of office, industrial and residential development along with recreational facilities. And in Central Islip, recommendations include, among others, educational facilities, a health-care facility, a nursing home and recycling the three existing buildings for housing for the elderly.
At the Pilgrim site, the one-acre residential zoning insures that a developer who wants to build anything other than low-density housing must secure approvals from the Town of Islip, said Thomas A. Isles, the town's chief planner and a member of a task force convened three years ago to study potential uses for the property.
The task force recommendation was for 500,000 square feet of office space, 360,000 square feet of industrial buildings, 90,000 square feet of commercial space, a million- square-foot recreational center, athletic fields and a nine-hole golf course, Mr. Isles said. A 100-acre portion of the 655-acre site lying east of the Sagtikos Parkway was proposed for up to 500 housing units.
The 70-year-old Pilgrim State Hospital, with its imposing but grim red-brick buildings, was once the largest psychiatric center in the Western world, serving as many as 13,875 patients at its peak in 1954. The hospital population is now just over 1,000. In 1983, considerable community controversy surrounded the conversion of one of its buildings to a prison. One of Mario M. Cuomo's campaign promises was to close the prison if elected, a promise he kept in 1985.
For Reckson, which specializes in office and industrial projects, the Pilgrim site offers tremendous opportunity, said Gregg M.Rechler, its executive vice president.
"This was the last major piece we have seen come on the market in western Suffolk since my grandfather purchased the 600-acre ITT/Radio Free Europe site in 1961," Mr. Rechler said. Now called the John V. N. Klein Industrial Park after a former Suffolk County Executive, it is now one of the largest industrial parks in the country.
MR. RECHLER declined to be specific about the company's plans for Pilgrim, citing the need to meet first with town officials and local residents.
But Reckson, which is a real estate investment trust, has announced it intends to invest about $250 million in the property, which is midway between Melville and Hauppauge. "Hauppauge is the best industrial market on Long Island, and Melville the best office market, so with this location a tremendous synergy could be created on this site," Mr. Rechler said.
Kurt Mohr, the vice president of Benjamin Development, also declined to discuss plans for the Central Islip and Developmental Center properties pending the ratification vote Thursday.
The Long Island Developmental Center, which opened in 1965 and housed 1,768 mentally retarded people at its peak in 1972, closed in 1993 with the exception of the small residential buildings on the eastern and western ends of the property and the children's hospital on the easterly end.
The property being sold is mostly open land with a heavily treed perimeter.
In 1993, the Cuomo administration proposed leasing 53.7 acres on the eastern end of the property to Olympus America, the camera company, which wanted to build a headquarters of up to 292,000 square feet. But the state withdrew its proposal in a settlement of a lawsuit filed by the Town of Huntington, which contended that it violated local zoning. Olympus ultimately built its headquarters elsewhere in Melville.
Subsequently, the Pataki administration gave residents, represented by the Triangle Civic Association in Melville and the House Beautiful at Dix Hills Homeowners Association four seats on a 17-member task force tostudy alternative uses.
Two plans developed by Saccardi & Schiff, land planners in White Plains called for about 1,200 units of housing, 85 percent of which would be for people 55 or older, with one including a golf course. Richard Machtay, the Huntington Planning Director, said he assumed that one of the two plans would be implemented. "But," he added, "until someone comes to the town with an application I don't know what will happen."
"What this story is all about," said Sheila Saks, president of House Beautiful, "is protecting your most important investment -- your home and your community.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In / Freeport, L.I.;
Maritime Breezes, Canals and Diversity

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
UNLIKE areas of Long Island that are homogeneous or nearly so, the maritime and suburban Village of Freeport on Nassau County's South Shore is a community that takes its identity, in part, from its economic and ethnic mix.
"This is basically a middle-class community of two-income households with a fairly high level of disposable income," said Mayor William F. Glacken. "At the same time I am proud to say we have 62 distinct cultures and everybody gets along. There's a cosmopolitan air that is very unusual for Long Island." 
 Longtime residents say Freeport is an upwardly striving village, a model community for ethnic harmony that is unabashedly rolling out the red carpet for newcomers drawn to a housing market that offers real bargains in detached homes, condominiums and co-ops.
The village is a place where the pale light of winter glints off canals and adds a deep, tawny gold tone to wide open wetland spaces, and where a village-operated power company charges rates that are half what most Long Island residents pay. Freeport also has its own municipal water company and village police force.
John Jeffries, the manager of the village's recreation center, described Freeport as "a multiracial community that, quite frankly, is always looking for people who can add something."
"It's the place of the future," he said. "It's how it's going to be and how it should be."
The message may be getting through. Larry Grebinar, a sales agent at Century 21 O'Connor & Matthews in Freeport, said the housing market was strong last year. "Prices are going up and most neighborhoods are improving," he said. "People are making big investments to update and improve their homes."
In the low to moderately priced housing market, detached houses predominate, in styles ranging from older, roomy colonials in inland areas to Cape Cods, bungalows, ranches and eclectics nearer the water, including some dwellings whose back doors open directly onto a canal's bulkhead.
Unlike many costly areas in Nassau where $200,000 buys virtually nothing, in Freeport it is still enough for a house with three bedrooms, one-and-a-half to two baths and a swatch of lawn.
According to village figures, there are about 1,000 co-op units, 240 condominiums and more than 2,000 rental apartments in Freeport.
A two-tier for-sale apartment market is divided between older former rental buildings near downtown, with two-bedroom units for as little as $55,000, and two-bedroom units for around $135,000 in newer co-ops and condominiums built in the mid-80's.
At one of the larger co-ops, the 160-unit, canalside Anchorage at Freeport built in 1985 on 14 acres with views over the Cow Meadow wetlands, a duplex sold in December for $159,500. Monthly maintenance of $711 includes real estate taxes.
The 17-building, gated complex includes a clubhouse, two tennis courts and an outdoor swimming pool. There are 80 boat slips with 24-hour security for residents only with an annual rent of $40 per foot of width of the boat.
The largest condominium is the 152-unit Wharfside Condominiums, where prices range from $80,000 for a one-bedroom unit to $130,000 for a two-bedroom.
SUNRISE HIGHWAY and Merrick Road, the main east-west thoroughfares, are fast-moving, nondescript commercial strips, but with a full array of retail services including a shopping mall, Meadowbrook Commons. There are more shops on Main Street, which runs north to south.
But these road corridors are far less evocative of Freeport's essence than Woodcleft Avenue's Nautical Mile. There, restaurants, marinas, and a slew of water-related enterprises line the canalside avenue, which ends at a scenic village park looking out to wetland islands.
There are ballfields, basketball courts and playgrounds at four village parks. Two of them -- Martin Luther King Jr. Park and Randall Park -- have outdoor swimming pools.
The village recreation center, a large complex that almost looks like a high school, has one indoor and three outdoor pools, a gym, saunas, an ice rink, community meeting rooms and a wealth of sports and other programs "from the cradle to the grave," said Mr. Jeffries, the manager. The annual family fee is $295 for residents and $460 for nonresidents.
Cow Neck Park, which is owned by Nassau County, has a nature trail with vistas reminiscent of a miniaturized Florida Everglades, minus alligators.
The park also has ballfields and handball, basketball and tennis courts. County residents pay $10 for a three-year pass to gain admission.
About 7,350 students attend Freeport public schools and there is a community night school for teen-agers with 236 enrollees.
The district has one high school, one junior high for grades 7 and 8, a separate school for grades 5 and 6, four magnet schools for grades 1 through 4 and one school for prekindergarten and kindergarten.
Some 87 percent of the 364 June graduates at Freeport High School went on to higher education. Average S.A.T. scores for the 1996-1997 academic year, the most recent scores available, were 456 in verbal and 448 in math, both about 40 points below state and national averages for that year.
The high school offers a science research program in cooperation with the State University of New York at Stony Brook and was state champion last year in Future Problem Solving contest, a title it has won every year since 1988.
The contest, which was initiated in 1973, engages students in solving community problems involving such matters as a cashless society, increasing life spans and medical ethics.
The high school was also a pioneer in establishing a distance-learning center enabling students to take courses at other high schools by television hook-up. It offers eight advanced placement courses, including calculus, computer science, biology and physics.
A magnet-school program allows parents to choose from among four elementary schools, each with programs built around distinct themes. The Archer Street School, for example, is called a Microsociety and Multimedia school where students produce videotapes, publish a newspaper and work in a general store that serves customers in "Archerville."
The Bayview School for the Arts and Sciences turns classrooms into studios, to encourage children to become professional artists and into laboratories designed to pique the curiosity of budding scientists.
The Leo F. Giblyn School teaches globalism, and the staff of the New Visions School of Exploration and Discovery is trained at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, whose consultants help the school develop special programs for young aspiring explorers. The overwhelming majority of children are accepted at the school parents select.
Beginning in prekindergarten, selected students take part in a dual language program in which Spanish-speaking and English-speaking students alternate learning separately and together. A goal is fluency in both languages for all students.
FREEPORT'S colorful history is on display at the Freeport Historical Museum on South Main Street, which is open on Sundays from April through December and by appointment. Admission is free but donations are appreciated.
In Colonial times, the Freeport area was a sparsely settled outback of the Town of Hempstead. It was originally called Raynor South or Raynor Town after the family that settled there in 1659. The current name was adopted in 1853 to commemorate the area's history as a free port of entry for vessels seeking to avoid landing fees in New York City and Sag Harbor.
"They found that if they sailed through Jones Inlet to Freeport then there was no charge," said Isabelle Drach, the president of the Freeport Historical Society. Jones Inlet is the most westerly inlet piercing Long Island's South Shore barrier islands to reach the Atlantic Ocean.
During prohibition, rumrunners in fast boats sped from the Woodcleft Canal through the inlet to meet suppliers.
By the end of the 19th century, wetland-filling on Freeport's low-lying and marshy southern edge had created home sites, and a system of canals was in place. The village incorporated in 1892.
Freeport was a favorite of vaudevillians, who founded the Long Island Good Hearted Thespian Society in the 20's, said Mrs. Drach, the historian. But the most fondly remembered celebrity-in-residence was the late Guy Lombardo, the legendary band leader who waved to children as he motored his mahogany speedboat, Tempo, from Woodcleft Canal to engagements at Jones Beach. A street along the east side of Woodcleft Canal is named for Mr. Lombardo, who died in 1977.
Playland Park, a smaller version of Coney Island, drew crowds until it burned down in the early 1930's.
After World War II, new housing and new residents, including many from Queens and Brooklyn, transformed Freeport. A period of decline in the late 60's and 70's struck the once-bustling downtown area, but even chronic flooding couldn't stem development in shoreline areas.
"I kind of resented the development," said Barbara Jagnow, owner of Otto's Sea Grill on Woodcleft Avenue. "It used to be you could see the Jones Beach tower from here. You can't anymore. But it's still the best place on Long Island. I wouldn't trade it."

ROAD RAISING: Flooding has always plagued parts of Freeport, and nowhere has it been worse than along Woodcleft Avenue's Nautical Mile. Now the village will address the problem in a novel fashion. What is planned, said Mayor William F. Glacken, is a $5 million project to raise the avenue by two feet, replace sidewalks with brick walkways and add ornamental lighting and a canalside esplanade. Business owners will be asked to do village-assisted improvement projects of their own. "Once it's all done it's going to revitalize the waterfront," said Mayor Glacken. He said a major project to revitalize the downtown area was next.

HEADLINE: Habitats / West 63d Street;
Furnishing a Home As a Scavenger Hunt

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
FURNISHING a place in New York City is not like furnishing a place in the suburbs. People don't zip over to the nearest megastore and load up their oversized vehicles with rugs, tables and chairs. Nor do they spend summer weekends cruising by yard sales in search of wicker chairs and mixing bowls. Like everything else, matters here are more complicated. And often more expensive. When a tiny table at a chic little joint on Bond Street is $600, the cost of living seems unfairly high. In the presence of so many objects costing so much, it is easy to feel impoverished, even on incomes that would be considered ample anyplace else.
But to Alec Massey and Diena ten Broeke, who live near Lincoln Center in a one-bedroom apartment on West 63d Street with their 2-year-old daughter, Elsie, furnishing their home is just a game, a big scavenger hunt in a place with great pickings. 
 It's not a matter of refusing to buy retail. For them, even wholesale is no bargain. They buy second-hand, choosing tables, beds, bureaus, clothes and the like that are in good condition but for whatever reason no longer wanted. Ms. ten Broeke, wearing black leggings that cost 75 cents and a striped turtleneck that cost a quarter, says she never buys new clothes. That's one of her tactics for saving money in a city that seems to suck $20 bills out of pockets like so much lint into a vacuum cleaner.
Another has to do with bypassing those small luxuries that add up. She would never, for instance, buy a cup of coffee at Starbucks, and not because she is rebelling against the homogenization of the urban landscape. It's simple economics. At $1.40 a cup, she says, she can do better buying and grinding her own beans.
Ms. ten Broeke, who works in the box office at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, and Mr. Massey, who sings opera with small regional companies and models for print advertising, say they spend between $5,000 and $6,000 a year on furniture, clothes, food, travel and entertainment -- basically, everything but rent. In exchange for the apartment, Mr. Massey works as the superintendent of the 25-unit building.
BECAUSE they spend so carefully, Ms. ten Broeke says, she has been able to invest about 70 percent of her $27,000 salary in mutual funds. (Naturally, when she goes to her brokerage company's office, or anyplace else that is not miles away, she walks. To her, buses, cabs and subways are an unnecessary expense.)
Recently, they discovered the glories of Loot, a newspaper costing $1 that offers hundreds upon hundreds of objects for sale, all listed at no expense to the seller. It's the Manhattan version of a yard sale, filled with possibilities for furnishing apartments cheaply.
"They're selling stuff that they would normally sell on the front lawn," Ms. ten Broeke says. From a recent issue, they managed to buy a new bedroom set for Elsie, with two beds and a bureau, for $500; a Murphy bed for their living room that folds down with one simple hand motion, for $800; and a marble-topped bistro table with two wrought-iron chairs, for $100. Their second child, a daughter, is due in March, and the Murphy bed has allowed them to create the space they will need in a living room that has only one object bought in a regular store: a Chinese rug purchased on sale at Macy's.
Getting what they want for less, Ms. ten Broeke says, "is very much part of a life style." When she was pregnant with Elsie, she posted notices in nursery schools looking for second-hand equipment, and was deluged with possibilities. "People wanted to give their cribs and bedding a good home," she says. They paid $150, rather than the $700 it would have cost new, for a crib and $20 for an almost-new stroller.
Clearly, the hunt is something they enjoy. Mr. Massey holds up a down jacket from London Fog that he found for Elsie for $5 at the Salvation Army on West 46th Street and 10th Avenue. "We call it the mall," Ms. ten Broeke says. When he has to wear a suit for modeling, Mr. Massey says, he dresses in a custom-made suit from Hong Kong that he bought for $45. "Everything we have is second-hand," he says. "There's no reason to buy new. I'll get a $250 sweater there for $8."
Is it any surprise, then, to discover that they met nearly a decade ago at a sample sale? Ms. ten Broeke was working as a sales clerk, and Mr. Massey was looking. He bought two sweaters that day, for $50 each, and they have been together ever since.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 768 words

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Pregnant (Yet Again), but Hardly Barefoot

BYLINE: By DEBRA GALANT 

 BODY:
LET me make one thing perfectly clear. I am not having a baby.
My husband once entertained notions of raising a large brood, but that was before he became a parent. Once that happened and we saw what we were up against, we settled on one hard-and-fast rule: never let them outnumber you. 
 A lot of people, apparently, have not heard this rule. There's some major breeding going on in suburbia these days, at least in my little corner. Two summers ago, a woman on the other side of the street had her third baby. Last summer, the woman across from her had one. Another is due any day, and one more is expected this summer. That puts the fertility rate at this end of the block up to 2.6, meaning that we all have .6 of a child over the national average.
Now demographers tell me that it's hard to bump the fertility rate up like that -- at least when you talk about the entire United States. But if you look at the kind of people who live around me -- baby boomers in their late 30's or early 40's -- the increase in fertility is rampant. Stephanie Ventura, a demographer for the National Center for Health Statistics, crunched a few numbers for me and discovered an amazing thing. The number of third babies born to women aged 35 to 39 jumped 29 percent from 1990 to 1997, and the number of third babies born to women aged 40 to 44 jumped 57 percent.
In other words, the baby boom, which one might have expected to stop booming once it reached a certain age, booms on.
Now the only reason I can imagine these people are all producing third-borns is that their first two children are not sufficiently challenging. Either that, or they have not -- like myself -- long ago reached their level of incompetence. All I can say is that, if I had one more set of snow boots and mittens to be responsible for, I think I would just go berserk and take the whole family with me.
It could be that I am a bit too tightly strung to deal with children in vast quantities. (It could be that I am too tightly strung to deal with children in limited quantities.) I have noticed a sort of nonchalance that parents of large flocks exhibit. One friend of mine, who is expecting his third in March, called me up to relate a third-baby story he'd heard from another father of three. "If your first baby puts dirt in his mouth, you run to the hospital," he said. "If your third baby puts dirt in his mouth, your reaction is, 'It better not be my potting soil!' "
This very same expectant father talked my husband into going to a movie theater 30 minutes away -- just hours after a recent snowstorm. Although the snow had turned to slush, I was certain the expedition would end in both their deaths, and leave all those children -- born and unborn -- fatherless. When I asked his (pregnant) wife what she thought about the outing, she just laughed and said, "I'm not a worrier." You see?
Of course, these heavy breeders must have their reasons. James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University who is an expert on New Jersey demographics, thinks it may be pent-up demand. You know, the dream deferred: all these women were so busy building careers in their 20's that their mothering instincts are now boomeranging. Michael Mulvey, an assistant professor of marketing at Rutgers, says it could be an upper-middle-class status symbol. The third child is "not exactly bought by money, but it says something about your financial status," he suggests.
But for a real expert, I talked to Gail Wagner, owner of an upscale baby outfitter in Upper Montclair called Baby Boom. When she started the store 10 years ago, babies were hot, but the trend was expected to peter out by the mid-90's. It didn't, thanks to people like my neighbors, who are having more children later in life. "Not just thirds," she says. "We see people having fourths."
Reasons? "Part of it's the economy," Ms. Wagner says. "Things are good." Then there are people with two boys hoping for a girl, and vice versa. Second marriages account for some of it. My favorite reason: it's a way to keep a full-time nanny. "It's almost better to keep having children so you can hold onto your help," Ms. Wagner explains.
One neighbor put it this way: "If we waited any longer, we'd probably never do it. And we weren't ready to decide that." I'm still trying to figure that one out. Of course, you can't really expect logic from people who voluntarily go back to the diapering stage when their kids are old enough to toddle downstairs by themselves on Saturday mornings and turn on the television.

HEADLINE: When Welfare Ends and Work Steps In

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
RHONDA McFADDEN rises before dawn, readies her children for school and, joining others in Yonkers who are on their way to work, walks with a sense of pride to the bus stop.
In Port Chester at the same early hour, Evelyn Rivera kisses her 12-year-old daughter's cheek, steps jauntily into her 1990 Pontiac Grand Prix and heads for a nearby Interstate, similarly pleased to be on her way to work. 
 Both women -- former welfare mothers -- used to rely on public assistance and Federal food stamps but recently joined the growing number of welfare recipients entering Westchester's work force.
The 29-year-old Ms. McFadden is one of 1,277 welfare clients who were required last year to find jobs under the county's newest effort to reduce its public assistance rolls. The mother of four began work last year as an administrative assistant earning $8.25 an hour.
"I have to keep reminding myself how I got here," she said. "I have to tell myself, 'Wow, I really made it off welfare!' "
Ms. Rivera, who is 32 and returned to school seven years ago under a county program designed to put welfare mothers to work, has since earned an associate's degree in accounting. Several years ago, she began work as an accounts payable clerk for ANS Communications, an Internet company in Elmsford, which has moved to Purchase and is now called Uunet Technology. She has received three promotions, so that she now earns $26,500 a year.
"I have been wanting this for a long, long time," she said recently.
Both women's stories follow President Clinton's decision announced in August 1996 to "end welfare as we know it" and a Federal law passed that December to limit public assistance benefits for most welfare recipients to five years. Some states, but not New York, have adopted more restrictive time limits. (Florida and Virginia limit welfare benefits to 2 years, and Connecticut has a 22-month limit.)
The county, hoping to remove another 1,335 public assistance cases to save taxpayers $10.4 million this year, recently announced that it would spend $3 million to hire three employment concerns that specialize in finding jobs for welfare clients.
The companies -- two private ones (America Works and Opportunity America) and a nonprofit one (Westchester Community Opportunity Program) -- were awarded performance-based contracts to provide job counseling, pre-employment training and job placement along with intensive follow-up programs to insure that people keep their jobs.
"The point is to teach people to be self-sufficient so they can get off welfare and stay off," County Executive Andrew J. Spano said. "Not only will these firms find people jobs but also they will teach them skills for life: how to prepare a resume, prepare for an interview, how to keep a job."
Mr. Spano described the county's latest program as "a get-tough policy with compassion." In addition to job training and placement, Westchester also provides transitional child care allotments for mothers returning to work and Medicaid benefits for up to a year after the start of employment.
The companies placing welfare clients in jobs will be paid in increments, with the final checks written by the county on a per client basis only when a person has remained on the job for six months.
"The good part is that this gives the vendor an incentive to be successful," said Dennis J. Packard, a deputy commissioner for the county's Department of Social Services. "You can't raise the flag and declare victory once they get the job. You have to make sure they keep the job."
Opportunity America placed 87 percent of its Westchester clients in jobs last year, saving the county about $607,000 in 1998. For this year, the county will pay Opportunity America $1.9 million to serve clients referred by the Yonkers, White Plains and Mount Vernon offices of the Department of Social Services. America Works will be paid $1 million to find jobs for welfare clients termed the most difficult to place. And the nonprofit Westchester Community Opportunity Services will be paid $100,000 to work with clients served by the Peekskill office.
"There's clearly a need for a strong and focused methodology enabling welfare clients to transition to jobs," said Richard T. Schwartz, Opportunity America's president and a former senior adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Schwartz designed New York City's welfare-to-work program before starting his own company two years ago.
Ms. McFadden, who began her employment training last year with Opportunity America, which is based in Manhattan and has offices in Mount Vernon, Brooklyn and Newark, was eventually hired full time by the company. As an administrative assistant, she answers phones, serves as a data entry clerk and does other clerical duties.
Like many other welfare mothers, Ms. McFadden never completed her high school education. She left high school after the 11th grade, giving birth to her first child when she was 16 and her second three years later. During those years, her main concern was whether her young family's food stamps would last until the end of the month.
Now, thinking ahead, she said, "Maybe someday my children will go to college and have even better jobs." She is married now and has two more children.
Ms. Rivera was raised by her mother, whose sole income was a welfare check. Now a single mother herself, Ms. Rivera returned to school seven years ago after a letter arrived from the County Department of Social Services, telling her that her case was being re-evaluated and that she must either go to school for career training or get a job. Her benefits were about to end.
As Kevin P. Mahon, the county's Commissioner for Social Services, explained it, his department's mission has been changing, with the overall number of those receiving public assistance dropping steadily since 1992. The goal no longer is to help the needy receive benefits but to help them not receive them, the Commissioner said.
Deputy Commissioner Packard said that in August 1992 there were 11,984 active welfare cases on the county's rolls; five years later in August, that number was 10,172. The latest count, for November 1998, was 8,695 cases.
Despite the county's position on welfare, which in effect says that everyone capable of working must do so, there will likely always be some unemployable people, Commissioner Mahon said. For example, the current caseload in the county's Mount Vernon, White Plains and Yonkers offices is 8,075, but of those, only 5,217 are considered active cases. Some welfare customers are in drug or alcohol treatment, some have medical or psychiatric problems and some have children younger than 1, rendering them ineligible for employment.
In recent years, part of the effort to reduce the welfare rolls has focused on reducing fraud. Statewide, New York's crackdown on welfare fraud has netted more than $440 million since January 1995, according to figures released in the fall by Gov. George E. Pataki.
Under New York's Fugitive Felon Match, a program of reform legislation begun in 1997, taxpayers in the state saved $10 million when nearly 1,800 people were taken off public assistance. The Fugitive Felon program also resulted in 255 arrests of felons and parole and probation violators.
Under that program, the state matches its welfare rolls against warrant lists compiled by the State Division of Criminal Justice Services. Names of people who are receiving welfare and are wanted as felons or are parole or probation violators are referred to the fraud units in their respective social services districts. Since the program began late last year, 1,787 people have had their cases closed.
Separate county figures for saving under the Fugitive Felon program were not available. But the state's fingerprinting system, which is used to ferret out those who are receiving benefits in more than one jurisdiction, resulted in 2,726 case closings and a saving of $5.9 million for Westchester, Jack Madden, a spokesman for the Governor, said recently.
Under another program, the Front End Detection System, which sends workers into the field to verify the eligibility of recipients, Westchester closed 1,867 cases, saving $10.6 million from April 1997 to last March. In a related effort, the county's Social Services Department also runs computer matches of its recipients with databases of agencies like the Internal Revenue Service and state unemployment offices.
The county's workfare program, which began in 1989, requires able-bodied welfare recipients not yet ready for full employment to spend 20 hours a week in workfare, or as it is more formally known, Pride in Work public improvement projects, to retain their subsistence eligibility.
Under state law, welfare clients can be ordered to help county, city, town and nonprofit organizations perform clerical, maintenance, security, painting, repair and debris removal jobs, among other things.
The philosophy behind the latest initiatives in Westchester to train able-bodied welfare recipients for employment is that rather that taking advantage of government largess "most people want to achieve independence and take pride in what they do," said Mr. Schwartz of Opportunity America.
Lee A. Bowes, chief executive officer of America Works, which has offices in Manhattan, Albany, Indianapolis and Baltimore, observed that in a tight labor market the newest laws requiring most welfare clients to work also benefit employers who are seeking access to a broader labor pool.
