LENGTH: 3219 words

HEADLINE: Finding a Home Inside the Golden Door

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
BEAMING with pride of ownership, Jose and Paula Lora stood before their dark-red, split-level home in Teaneck, N.J., last weekend, a long way from the city of Santiago in the Dominican Republic and -- if not geographically, at least in their minds -- nearly as far from the cramped Bronx rental apartments in which they had lived since arriving in the United States a decade ago.
The house cost $170,000 and, after several years of saving, the Loras managed to make a down payment of $25,000. "It has four bedrooms, a study and a small basement for the kids to watch TV," Mr. Lora said, "you know, to do the mess, the games, the toys." Jorge is 9, and Ruth is 8. 
 The Loras occupy one band on the spectrum of experience faced by immigrants in dealing with the intricacies of real estate in the New York area.
In a three-story walk-up on Orchard Street in Manhattan's Chinatown, a 37-year-old man from China's Fujian province hides his face behind a newspaper. His name is Mr. Liu; he did not want to give his full name. Mr. Liu occupies a far distant band on the spectrum.
He is one of eight men who share a 12- by 12-foot space, sleeping on slapdash, raw-lumber bunk beds. Together, the eight men pay $640 a month for the room, as do eight men living in each of the two other rooms in the same apartment -- all sharing the filth-encrusted bathroom and kitchen. There are about 70 people living in the building's three apartments.
Mr. Liu has lived there six of his 10 years in America. "Not used to it," he said through an interpreter, "but what can I do?"
For all sorts of reasons -- both imposed and, to a degree, self-imposed -- some immigrants succeed in their quest for decent housing in and around New York City, some don't.
In effect, the tens of thousands of newcomers -- and their numbers are increasing -- must navigate a nuanced web of factors in finding a home: the language barrier, jarring cultural differences, the complexity of the rental and mortgage-acquisition systems, lack of credit histories, lack of banking services in their communities, incomes off the books, the driving urge for family reunification, loyalty to two countries, sending money home, being treated as intruders, racial discrimination and being cheated -- sometimes, even, by their own countrymen.
Through all that, more and more new Americans -- like the Loras -- make it.
In 1996 (the last year for which data were available), according to the New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey, 37.7 percent, or 1,048,000, of the 2,780,000 households in the city were headed by immigrants. That represented an increase from 1991, when 33.2 percent, or 924,600, of all households were headed by immigrants. And over the same period, the number of immigrants who purchased homes increased from 257,000 to 276,000, so that, as of 1996, 26.3 percent of all immigrants in the city were home owners.
There are no numbers to gauge the impact of immigration on the city's suburbs. But one hint is that the Loras now belong to the year-old, dozen-member Dominican Home Owners Association of Bergen County, N.J. "We were living in the Bronx, near Lehman College," Mr. Lora said. "Our rent was $550. It went to like $650. Then we moved, and we paid there $720 -- the last rent we paid."
Like so many other tenants, Mr. Lora -- who in 10 years here has worked his way from restaurant cashier to accountant -- did the math and wondered: Why pay someone else? That was four years ago.
Not that it was easy securing a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage at 8.5 percent. "At the beginning, they made life impossible," Mr. Lora said of the lender. "We dealt with the mortgage company for five months."
Asked if he thought he was being discriminated against, Mr. Lora said, "I don't think it was that."
"It was the first time we bought a house," he said. "We didn't know how. At one point you think maybe because you are Mr. Lora, not Mr. Johnson, that they are making life impossible to give you the loan. Now that I know the process, I would know if they are trying to bother me or if they just need to know."
For lack of understanding of the system, Mr. Lora said, many immigrants "don't have the documentation together."
"They think the person they tried to get the loan from is trying to take advantage," he said. "I don't say that doesn't happen, but sometimes it's misunderstanding."
Or utter unfamiliarity.
"There is no tradition of mortgages in India," said Vanitha Venugopal, housing director in the office of Queens Borough President Claire Shulman -- a point made by representatives of other ethnic groups.
"We come from a cash-based economy," said Hugh Hamilton, a Guyanese native, speaking about members of the Caribbean community. "Most Caribbeans are unaware of the criteria that must be met in order to qualify for mortgages." Mr. Hamilton is legislative director for City Councilman Lloyd Henry, a Brooklyn Democrat.
In November, during a conference on immigrant housing at the New York University School of Law, one participant raised his hand to say, "When Latin American immigrants see 30-year mortgages, we get scared and limit ourselves to short-term loans" -- sometimes from unscrupulous lenders who, knowing that the buyer knows no better, charge exorbitant rates. Sometimes the real estate agent and the mortgage broker are in cahoots, and the guileless buyer appreciates what seems like one-stop shopping. Victor Morisete-Romero, executive director of the Community Association of Progressive Dominicans, a social service agency, said immigrants often pay 24 percent over a seven-year term.
Cultural norms "often clash with the American-dream mentality," he said. "In the Dominican Republic, when you buy a home the deal is done; there aren't additional expenses. Here, with taxes, water bills, fire inspections, boiler inspections, building regulations, amortizing the mortgage, they look at a $140,000 investment for 30 years at 7.65 percent, do the numbers and basically say they don't really own it."
That is, if they have got that far in the mortgage-buying process -- no mean feat for most immigrants.
Some newcomers, particularly professionals and established business people, arrive in the United States with considerable wealth, education, connections and access to the system.
Others, arriving for the raft of reasons that have impelled immigration to America for generations -- political, religious, racial persecution; yearnings for a better life, hopes of easing the economic burden of those in the old country -- come ill-equipped to deal with real estate. The difficulties are compounded, of course, if the immigrant is here illegally.
"There is no such thing back home as rent regulation," said Ms. Venugopal. "So, at least for the first few years, they may live in terrible conditions because they are unaware of the protections available to them."
A participant at the N.Y.U. conference, which was sponsored by the law school's Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy, said that besides being unaware of the rental protections, many immigrants avoid filing a complaint, fearing that an appearance in Housing Court will leave them with a police record.
Christopher Kui, executive director of Asian Americans for Equality, a nonprofit community and housing development organization, pointed out that just as immigrant renters are unaware of their rights, "some Chinese landlords are ignorant of their responsibilities under the law, so housing codes are not enforced."
At the same time, Mr. Kui said, Chinese immigrants "often buy houses with basements to rent them, only to find that it is against the law, after they have calculated mortgage payments based on that income."
Many new arrivals must, of course, take menial jobs in factories or restaurants, where they are paid off the books, rendering it impossible to start building the credit histories indispensable for eventually working their way up the rental ladder and, perhaps, purchasing their slice of the proverbial American pie.
To save, they live together -- extended families and strangers alike -- doubling and tripling up, or crammed like Mr. Liu into barracks-like hovels. "I want to buy a house or rent a house," he said, "but not without my family."
Mr. Liu fled from the Chinese population police in 1986. "Because I have five children, the government gave me trouble," he said. "Before I got arrested, I went away." He has seen his family once in 10 years.
"I save to bring them here," he said.
Poorer immigrants forgo buying a car, going to the movies, medical insurance. Accustomed to all-cash economies, many keep their savings at home, exposing themselves to further risk. To pay the rent, they go to the Post Office and buy a money order.
Erika Rodas, assistant coordinator of minority lending in the Westbury, L.I., office of the Skyscraper Mortgage Company, told the tale of a Salvadoran couple with three children who kept $7,000 under a mattress in the dilapidated one-bedroom apartment for which they were paying monthly rent of $1,400. Ms. Rodas said the father, a pizza cook, could not read; the mother worked in a factory. They dreamed of a decent home.
"We prequalified them to see how much they could really afford for a house," Ms. Rodas said. "We took them to open a bank account. We finally found the house they needed -- a cape, four bedrooms, in a much better area of Westbury."
The house, appraised at $140,000, was facing foreclosure, Ms. Rodas said, "so they got it for $90,000 and they have a lot of equity now." The 30-year mortgage had a fixed rate of 8 percent.
Three months after the family moved out, fire gutted their old apartment house. "They were very grateful," Ms. Rodas said. "They would have lost their savings."
The immigrant housing quest can come up against "cultural quirks" -- Ms. Venugopal's phrase -- that sometimes act like ruts in the road, sometimes smooth the way and even on occasion profoundly change the communities in which the newcomers settle.
Some immigrants from the Indian subcontinent are adherents to Vastu Shastra -- a code, similar to Chinese Feng Shui, that guides one toward the most spiritually propitious way of laying out a home.
"I know one person who told a realtor he wanted the master bedroom facing east, so the morning sun will wake him," Ms. Venugopal said.
At the N.Y.U. conference, a man from Nigeria said that in his country most people live in inherited houses, or build their own, so buying someone else's home is a foreign concept.
Many ethnic groups, denied access to banking services, form networks of relatives and friends -- buyers' clubs, in effect -- to exchange information and pool their resources. Mr. Hamilton, the native of Guyana who is now a city official, said that in Caribbean communities such a network is called a "sou-sou" -- an informal system of rotating credit based on African tradition.
"Let's say six of us decide to set aside $200 every month," Mr. Hamilton said. "It would take six months for any one of us to get $1,200, but by pooling our contributions, each person is able to get $1,200 from any single pool." The contributors pick the order of beneficiaries. "In terms of buying a house, of course, you multiply it significantly, involving as many people as necessary."
The language barrier can literally change the face of the city.
It may be apocryphal but, by some accounts, Sunset Park in Brooklyn became a haven for Chinese immigrants after several settled there and put the word out: get off at the Blue Sky Station -- the BMT stop after the train comes out of the tunnel. "It illustrates the barriers people face when they can't read signs," said Mr. Kui of Asian Americans for Equality.
The No. 7 line from Flushing to Times Square is known by some as the New Orient Express.
AND in the 1970's, immigrants from Odessa, Ukraine, then part of the Soviet Union, chose to settle in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, because, like Odessa, it is by the sea -- sowing seeds for the still-blossoming Russian enclave in southern Brooklyn.
Among the more recent buds are Ilya and Inessa Rubenstein and their 4-year-old son, Samuel. The Rubensteins were fortunate: someone told them to start building credit soon after they arrived from the former Soviet republic of Belarus in 1993.
Mr. Rubenstein had worked for a Jewish organization in the city of Minsk. And when the collapse of Communism released pent-up right-wing extremism, he said, "it was, of course, anti-Semitic."
"Sometimes," he said, "we had letters that Jews should go back where they came from, threatening phone calls and many things that forced us to leave."
Relatives of Mrs. Rubenstein had already fled to the United States. "And the minute we came," Mr. Rubenstein said, "they told us to start our credit history. So I got credit cards almost immediately."
Six years later, the Rubensteins -- he now the administrative director of the Jewish Community Council of Kings Bay in Brooklyn, she working toward a degree in medical technology -- have passed muster with the co-op board of Sheepshead Bay Terrace, a 168-unit building, and are awaiting final approval of their mortgage from Chase Manhattan to buy a $45,000, two-bedroom apartment.
They are part of the burgeoning middle class of immigrants moving toward home-buying that developers like Joshua Muss, president of Muss Development -- a company that has built 20,000 housing units in the city since 1906 -- are tapping into.
"We're talking about probably a million immigrants who have come within the last decade," Mr. Muss said. "Many are improving themselves and aspiring to better housing, and there's nothing available."
After several Soviet emigres bought $200,000 to $300,000 houses at Captain's Quarters, a 270-unit Muss development in the Princes Bay section of Staten Island, "there was word of mouth and we started advertising, targeting them in Russian newspapers in Brooklyn," Mr. Muss said. "And of the last 100 homes, half went to former Soviet emigres."
Within months, he said, his company will begin construction of an 850-unit complex on the site of the old Brighton Beach Baths. And the company is considering construction of 1,200 units on a 100-acre expanse of downtown Flushing recently rezoned by the City Planning Commission. "The market there is enormous," Mr. Muss said, "a huge community of Korean, Chinese and Indian immigrants, very anxious for housing."
Immigrants are vital to the city's housing health, said Michael Schill, director of the N.Y.U. real estate center. "They maintain the city's population."
Between 1990 and 1997, according to Census Bureau estimates, the city's population increased modestly, by 0.3 percent, or about 20,000 people. And while the city experienced a net loss of 1,073,500 people to other parts of the country during that period, the city gained 677,200 people through immigration and 421,200 more by natural increase -- meaning more births than deaths. "So without immigration," Professor Schill said, "the city would have lost 9 percent of its population."
"That would have had a tremendous effect on the city's economy, its retail, the labor force and its neighborhoods," he said.
On one hand, immigration tightens the housing market and contributes to higher rents for all New Yorkers, Professor Schill said. But without it, he said, rents at the bottom of the market would be insufficient to enable owners to maintain buildings, "which would lead to disinvestment, tax delinquencies and, ultimately, abandonment."
"So, while immigration is a mixed blessing," he said, "in my view it is ultimately a positive because without it neighborhoods would be scarred by vacant and deteriorating housing."
Naomi Bayer is director of the New York office of Fannie Mae, the federally chartered funding source for issuers of mortgages. "Much of our work is aimed at breaking down barriers and providing the information immigrants need," Ms. Bayer said. In cooperation with the Queens Borough Public Library system, Fannie Mae has started a series of home-buying workshops in a variety of languages. It has adopted policies allowing lenders to use alternate forms of credit -- rent stubs, phone bills -- as parts of a buyer's credit record, and to accept "sou-sous" as an alternate down payment source.
It has also created low down payment products -- 3 percent for single-unit properties, 5 percent for a two-family and 10 percent for a three- or four-family home. And it has adopted a formula for two- to four-unit properties in which rental income can count far more significantly than in the past in allowing a lower-income family to afford a mortgage.
FRANK AND JENNY GAO are about to join the ranks of American home owners. Newly arrived from China in 1990, the Gaos first lived with relatives in Newport News, Va., then moved to a rental in Philadelphia, then doubled up with strangers in Flushing -- the "new Chinatown," Mr. Gao called it -- then moved into a second-floor bedroom in another Flushing home, sharing the kitchen and bathrooms with the owner.
"My landlord had a baby," said Mr. Gao, a shipping clerk for an import company, "so I need to get a new place." The Gaos took a homebuyers workshop from Asian Americans for Equality. Then, it all seemed so foreign. "In China, we don't need to buy," Mr. Gao said. "Government gave me the apartment; just pay like $3, a few peanuts."
At the buyer's workshop, "they taught me the difference between buying an apartment or a house, a condominium and co-op -- condominium you own the space, co-op just share the stock," Mr. Gao said proudly. "They say for a mortgage we need to pay no more than 30 percent of the expenses every month. They told me to save in the bank, and put in every month." On Wednesday, the Gaos will close on a two-bedroom, $50,000 co-op in Briarwood, Queens, with a 30-year mortgage at a fixed rate of 6.875 percent.
"I want privacy," Mr. Gao said. "I want space. I have lots of books."
The apartment is on the seventh floor, with a westward view. "I like this place," Mr. Gao said. "It's very beautiful from the living room. I can look at the Manhattan skyline."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
City-Bound Traffic Hit Record Volume Last Year

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
Those who have come to expect to spend 45 minutes approaching the toll booth would not be surprised at a figure released last week by Port Authority of New York and New Jersey: the number of vehicles crossing the Hudson River from New Jersey to New York City grew by 2.9 percent last year to a record 121.4 million crossings.
There were 3.4 million more crossings of the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels in 1998 than the year before, said Greg Trevor, a spokesman for the authority. 
 Fourty-three percent of tolls were paid by electronic EZ-Pass last year, which may account for some of the increase, he said But, he added: "The biggest thing we can attribute it to is the economy." STEVE STRUNSKY

HEADLINE: BABY PULSE;
Bottom Creams, Top Prices

BYLINE: By ELLEN TIEN

 BODY:

Kate Spade and Prada turned the diaper bag into a $300 knapsack from a $20 tote. Now, diaper ointments are undergoing similar style and price inflation. Last month, Bubbe's Best, started by three mothers in Garrison, N.Y., came out with Special Cream for Special Tushies, touted to be made of the "purest, finest" ingredients. At $12.50 for three ounces (Zitomer, 969 Madison Avenue at 76th Street) compared with about $3.50 for a four-ounce tube of an old standard like Desitin, it had better be. This month, Burt's Bees introduces Baby Bee Diaper Ointment, a mere $7 for 1.75 ounces (800-849-7112). And Kiehl's, skin care's gold standard, offers a Soothing Diaper-Area Ointment at a platinum price of $18.95 for two ounces (at its store, Third Avenue and 13th Street). This spring, Origins will offer Diaper Service, $10 for a 3-ounce tube, and Bobbi Brown is starting a Baby Essentials line with a Diaper Balm, $14.50 for 2.5 ounces. 
 Are they worth it? "They're all just moisture barriers for the skin," said Dr. Philip Orbuch, a pediatric dermatologist at New York University Medical Center. "Provided the cream is free of fragrance and preservatives, it's a matter of personal preference. Frequent diaper changes are more important than what kind of cream you use." Bummer. ELLEN TIEN

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
When Doing Nothing Accomplishes Plenty

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
EVERY year around this time, the cry is heard on Capitol Hill: Let's put aside partisan politics and get down to dealing with the issues of real concern to the American people.
It is an especially forceful cry this year. Democrats are eager for a debate on any policy issue that will turn attention away from President Clinton's impeachment trial and all that led to it. And Republicans are petrified of going into the 2000 elections looking like a party with no agenda beyond hounding the President. 
 Clearly, when it comes to education, health care, the environment, national security and other pressing issues, Congress and the Administration have powerful reasons of both substance and politics to act, and act they probably will, no matter how the impeachment proceeding plays out.
But when it comes to a crucial economic issue -- what to do with the growing Federal budget surplus -- there's a case to be made that the best thing would be continued Congressional gridlock.
BY demanding last year that the spare cash be set aside until Congress and the Administration could agree on a plan to shore up Social Security, Mr. Clinton thwarted Republican attempts to use the surplus to finance a big tax cut. His "Social Security first" strategy also beat back demands from Democrats in Congress for more spending on social programs.
In the end, neither party could resist spending some of the surplus. In a flurry of last-minute deal-making, the White House and the two parties in Congress agreed to spend $20 billion out of this year's surplus for "emergencies" like aid to farmers and an overhaul of the Government's computers to avoid Year 2000 software problems.
But the surplus for the year ended last Sept. 30, some $70 billion, was left untouched, and the current fiscal year's surplus is now likely to be at least $76 billion, even after accounting for the spending spree. The bottom line is this: Washington appears to have left nearly $150 billion on the table over two years, reducing the Federal Government's borrowing needs and thereby freeing up more capital for private investment at lower interest rates.
Credit for this bit of serendipitous thrift is due less to well-thought policy than to the political system's difficulties in climbing out of a long rut of deficit-mindedness to embrace an era of surplus. Nonetheless, many economists, including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, believe that it is just what the economy needs to improve productivity and promote more long-term growth.
If, in the aftermath of impeachment, the two parties remain unable again this year to agree on how to divide up the spoils of the nation's new-found fiscal health, so much the better, many economists say.
"We've got a political situation that is so evenly balanced between Republicans and Democrats that you can't really do anything unless you can get everyone to agree," said L. Douglas Lee, the chief economist for HSBC Securities in Washington. "That would be difficult to do under any circumstances, and right now you have an extremely partisan atmosphere."
The resulting decision by default -- to allow the surpluses to accumulate at the Treasury and begin eating into the $5.5 trillion national debt -- "may not be a political choice, but a happy accident," Mr. Lee said.
Continued deadlock over big tax cuts or spending increases could also prove to be good policy if the economy continues to hum along as it has for the last several years. Although most economists expect a slowdown this year, the buoyancy of the stock market and other indicators suggest that analysts may have again underestimated the resiliency of the expansion. In such an atmosphere, fiscal stimulus in the form of broad-based tax cuts or spending increases might be unnecessary or even harmful.
"By accident, we have the right fiscal policy in place by doing nothing," said Stan Collender, a budget analyst for Fleishman-Hillard, the consulting firm. "I'm not sure we could set up this policy if we tried, but since we've got it, we should go with it."
THE wild card this year is Social Security. Both the White House and the Republican leadership say it is still possible to reach a bipartisan deal on overhauling the retirement system so it is financially prepared for the aging of the baby-boom generation. However desirable such a deal might be on its own merits, it would mean open season on the surplus, with plenty of pent-up demand for tax cuts and spending increases -- good politics, perhaps, but not necessarily wise economic policy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Warmth, but No Walls, in This Incubator

BYLINE: By WILLIAM R. LONG 

DATELINE: FORT COLLINS, Colo.

 BODY:
MAURY WILLMAN says her start-up ergonomics company is receiving valuable services from a local business incubator group, even if they don't include one usual benefit: office space at reduced rents.
The nonprofit group, the Fort Collins Virtual Business Incubator, started in March and is intended to nurture new companies and help create jobs in this city of 110,000 at the foot of the Rocky Mountains. Through it, Ms. Willman's company, Ergonomic Health Systems, obtains the services of a lawyer, an accountant and a marketing firm at one-fourth their usual fees, as well as free managerial advice and encouragement from volunteer experts and business people. 
 "That's why I got into the incubator, to surround myself with knowledge and excitement," said Ms. Willman, 41.
What she does not get from the incubator is a place to run her company. Unlike more traditional business incubators, which provide low-rent floor space, often in factories or warehouses left vacant after larger companies move out, the Fort Collins group is an "incubator without walls." It does not deal in real estate -- a policy that has resulted in both praise and criticism.
There are about 550 incubators in the United States, up from 12 in 1980, according to the National Business Incubation Association. It says the groups have nurtured nearly 19,000 companies that now employ more than 245,000 people.
To qualify as a business incubator -- as opposed to another kind of business development program -- a group must employ a manager, provide a comprehensive assistance program and require clients to graduate -- to operate eventually without the program's help. About 30 of the newest programs are incubators without walls, like the one in Fort Collins, said Susie McKinnon, the association's director of member services.
Ms. Willman and her partner, Robin Herron, a Colorado State University expert on ergonomics, develop and sell software to help companies improve workplace safety and prevent health problems like repetitive stress injuries. In November, the business moved from Ms. Willman's home into a 1,000-square-foot ground-floor office on a busy street, College Avenue, where the rent is $1,300 a month. Discount space from the incubator would have been a big help, Ms. Willman said. Still, she declared herself happy with the assistance she receives.
Kathy Kregel, director of the Fort Collins incubator, said she is glad she needn't worry about mortgage payments and empty real estate. "We are very selective," Ms. Kregel said of the committee that approves start-up clients for the incubator. "I have definitely turned down some candidates. If I was sitting on a big mortgage, I might not be doing that."
By not offering floor space, the virtual incubator is also avoiding the problems that shut the Eastview Technology Center, a high-technology incubator in Westchester County, N.Y. Its landlord, the White Plains school board, has sued the center's management company, seeking $450,000 in back rent. A countersuit, seeking $659,000, contends that the school district reneged on an agreement to provide adequate space. The start-up companies in the center had to move out last November.
THE incubator in Fort Collins is a joint project of the city, Colorado State University and the Fort Collins Economic Development Corporation. The city, the university, local businesses and the state have each contributed $15,000 to defray the first year's costs. But not everyone in town thinks the money has been well spent.
Donald C. Bishop, a high-technology recruiter and business consultant in Fort Collins, says the incubator is merely a channel for recruiting new clients for local banks and professional firms. A big problem for start-ups is raising capital for real estate, personnel and equipment, he said, but the incubator offers "no facilities, no real cash, so it is a major failure as an incubator."
Clients of the incubator disagree. Kristin Romberg, director of sales for Infusion Technologies, which makes custom software for call centers like those used by telemarketing and customer-service units, said the incubator's services were "a tremendous value" for the company. "They have even gone and talked to venture capitalists for us," she said. In September, she added, Infusion signed its first big contract with a call-center operator, for $375,000.
Frank Bruno, an assistant city manager in Fort Collins who wrote the original plan for the incubator, said he had initially hoped it would provide office and laboratory space, but there was not enough money to do so. Now the incubator is better off without real estate, he said, because "we're much more focused on the program."
A sharp focus has brought rapid growth to the Central Florida Innovation Corporation, a three-year-old virtual incubator in Orlando, with a 1999 budget of $1 million and a selective approach to helping technology start-ups. If prospective clients are not expecting annual revenues of at least $2 million in two years, "they're thinking small, and that's a disqualifier," said Richard Fox, the incubator's president.
Sponsors include the city of Orlando and the University of Central Florida. Three big companies that operate in the area -- Lockheed Martin, Thermo Electron and Nationsbank -- contribute to the budget. The incubator wants to help create businesses with $1 billion in revenue by 2002, Mr. Fox said.
It has raised $57 million in out-of-state venture capital, mostly for Triton Network Systems, which uses Lockheed Martin technology in a high-speed wireless system for transmitting data. In a year and a half, the company has grown to employ 77 people; it occupies 37,000 square feet of its own space.
Brick-and-mortar incubators still have fans. Jerry Donahue, executive director of the Boulder Technology Incubator in Colorado, with 15 resident clients in two sites, said, "I prefer to have them in our facilities, where I can do more for them, because you're seeing each other every day."
Dinah Adkins, executive director of the National Business Incubation Association, said another benefit of close proximity is that clients learn more from one another in a "synergistic environment." And the clients' rent payments, even if below market rates, are a useful flow of revenue, helping to keep incubators in business when subsidy sources dry up, she said.

HEADLINE: A Conga Line From Rio to Cafe Wha

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY

 BODY:
ON a doleful Monday night, so cold even the tourists were hibernating, a faint tropical beat cut through the wind in Greenwich Village. The rhythm led around a corner, down some stairs and smack into Carnaval in Rio.
Monday is Brazil Night at Cafe Wha, a cozy basement at West Third and Macdougal Streets. Beneath ceilings strung with Christmas lights, arms waved, hips swayed, bedroom eyes flirted and waitresses carried rounds of caipirinhas, the Brazilian cocktail of ice, lime, sugar and the national firewater, cachaca. 
 Brazilians and wanna-Brazilians came to drink, dance and listen to Rio jazz, Sao Paulo rock and Bahian drumming. After the first chords from the nine-piece band Brazilian Beat, the place erupted into a gyrating party. Inevitably, tabletops became dance floors. Not even a group of well-groomed Italian tourists could match the smooth undulations of the dexterous Brazilians, who made up the majority of the audience. Or so it appeared, as they sang along in Portuguese, acting like old friends.
"So many Brazilians have moved to New York," said Marianne Ebert, a singer with the Brazilian Beat. "Eventually, they end up at Cafe Wha. When I went to Brazil for Christmas, everyone knew everyone on the plane. It was a huge party. Like high school in the air."
Many in the warm and sexy crowd are part of a wave of talented young Brazilians who can't seem to get to New York fast enough. Musicians, artists, night-life promoters, filmmakers, designers, restaurateurs and boutique owners have all flocked to the city in recent years. Its once muted Brazilian presence has blossomed like an Amazon orchid.
Five years ago, the city's Brazilian culture was pretty much limited to the club S.O.B.'s, where Astrud Gilberto sang about that "Girl From Ipanema," and Little Brazil, a restaurant row on West 46th Street, where the most sizzling offering was often a limp feijoada, Brazil's national stew.
Today, however, a pipeline from Brazil to Manhattan of creative and ambitious young people has added a more authentic and prominent new flavor to the city's cultural mix. In 1995, the Zagat guide listed just four Brazilian restaurants in New York. Now, there are 17. They range from in-spots like Cafe Colonial on East Houston Street to upscale churrascarias like Plataforma on West 49th Street, a shrine to meat.
In addition to Cafe Wha, there are at least six bars in Manhattan featuring Brazilian parties, including weekend afternoons at Coffee Shop (on Union Square West) and Saturdays at the Zinc Bar (80 West Houston Street). A Web site that keeps track of the action includes information on Lambateria NY, a dance school; photographs of Brazilian parties like Bahian Music Mondays at the Elbow Room (144 Bleecker Street), and for the homesick, a virtual tour of Rio's Sugar Loaf Mountain: www.inergy.com/sambagirl.
The immigrants jetting back and forth between New York and Brazil are not doing so to escape poverty and despair. The shuttle of young, creative people began earlier this decade, a result of financial self-confidence in one of the world's largest economies. (It is uncertain how the devaluation of Brazil's currency last week, which sent economic jitters around the world, will affect emigration, but one possibility is that talent could continue leaving Brazil.)
Typical of this generation of hipster emigres are the Lee sisters from Sao Paulo, a triumvirate of Brazilian fashion, food and music. They have Korean surnames, Amazon-Indian first names, Portuguese accents, expensive cell phones and Manhattan addresses. Jupira Lee, a restaurateur, arrived in 1988. A year later, she was followed by her sisters, Iara, a record producer and film director, and Jussara, a clothing designer.
The three spoke over strong coffee and cigarettes at Casa, a spare Brazilian eatery that Jupira opened four months ago on Bedford Street. Primitive portraits by Geova Rodriguez, another Brazilian living in New York, decorate the walls.
The Lee sisters make adjusting to New York sound smooth as a samba. Their native Sao Paulo "is a city of attitude -- it's all about money, just like here," Jupira said, adding, "So, understanding New Yorkers is not hard for us."
Iara agreed that Sao Paulo is much like New York, except for the chill, both literally and figuratively. "What we miss is the social warmth," Iara said. "It's the complaint you hear most from Brazilians here, the lack of warmth. At least at first, New York is cold. But that's the price you pay."
The Lee sisters roll their eyes at stereotypes of their country. "We are more than just parrots and Carmen Miranda, you know," Jupira said. "People always come in and ask for avocado stuffed with shrimp. We don't eat that in Brazil."
What they do eat, she said, is Brazilian stroganoff and pan-fried pollack in coconut milk, two of Casa's specialties. "It's all home cooking," Jupira said. "It's all about Mama."
And capairinhas, one stereotype the sisters do embrace. They enjoy initiating New Yorkers into the ritual of the powerful sugary green drink at parties. They gave one for Casa's opening, and for the 1996 premiere of "Synthetic Pleasures," an independent film directed by Iara.
Iara, who is married to George Gund 3d, an arts patron and owner of the San Jose Sharks of the National Hockey League, also started a record label in 1997, named -- what else? -- Caipirinha Music. Her next film, based on a 19th-century Brazilian novel, will be shot on location in Brasilia.
The costume designer for her films is often her sister the designer. Jussara's line, is sold in her Greene Street store, which resembles a 19th-century hacienda. The current collection, inspired by Bahia, the predominately African region of Brazil, features skirts that wrap around the body and gauzy fabrics in earthy tones. The designs are surprisingly demure. "I want my clothes to convey the sensuality of Brazil," she said. "But not that overtly sexy thing, with tight leather and little cut-outs."
Jussara now has more competition from home. Last year, Tufi Deuk, a Sao Paulo designer whom Vogue magazine has called the "Calvin Klein of Brazil," expanded in New York. He has opened a showroom, and his line is available at Language, a boutique on Mulberry Street that carries unusual clothing and housewares from around the world and that has a gallery in back for artists.
"We are Latins who share the ethos of the American dream, only with a different flair," Mr. Deuk said. "There is certainly a degree of nostalgia and glamour associated with Brazil that just feels so right at the moment -- an exoticism and sense of style that is based on familiarity. Brazil can be seductive that way."
Such familiarity can be an obstacle for Brazilians trying to adjust to New York's frostier social clime. "New York went against my natural being for the first six months," said Lipe Medeiros, a co-owner of Language. "I had to learn not to be Brazilian to get by." Mr. Medeiros said that meant not looking people in the eye, and holding himself back from making faces at cute babies in the subway, which he once did, causing the mother to scream.
Mr. Medeiros is a Paulista, as Sao Paulo residents are known, who designs furniture from scaffolding equipment and sells it in the store, which he runs with his wife, Ana Abdul, a painter from Brasilia. Among the Brazilian items in the shop are feather and mother-of-pearl Amazon warrior masks and steel and nylon chairs, designed by two Brazilian brothers, that were recently on exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art.
Now, Mr. Medeiros worries that he is assimilating too much. "When I went to Sao Paulo, I looked completely like a gringo, with baseball cap and all," he said. "Everyone tried to speak English to me."
One language spoken fluently in both New York and Brazil is music. New York is where bossa nova landed 40 years ago. With the current nostalgia for 1950's cocktail culture, the smooth Brazilian lounge rhythms are again popular.
Andre Alves, a promoter, began Brazil Night at Cafe Wha two and a half years ago. "It became an instant success," he said. "They even know about Cafe Wha in Rio." He now has a New York-area mailing list of 18,000 people, about 80 percent of whom he says are from Brazil. Mr. Alves, 37, brings live Brazilian music to New York, and next month plans to start TBB magazine, a monthly roundup of Brazilian culture.
The new generation of Brazilian musicians includes Bebel Gilberto, who has performed at Lincoln Center, at the Bottom Line and at Cafe Wha. A soft-spoken, black-haired woman, she is cutting an eclectic album that mixes Brazilian acoustics with techno and other modern influences.
"Brazil is a bit conservative with its music," she said. "I wouldn't have the courage to do what I do here." Ms. Gilberto comes from a venerable Brazilian musical family; her father, Joao Gilberto, is a singer who was once married to Astrud Gilberto. "I'm the stepdaughter from Ipanema," she said. "When I'm there, I feel a lot of pressure to carry out that tradition. It's too much baggage. But in New York, I feel free."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 815 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
What's Weighing on Buffett's Stock?

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
WARREN E. BUFFETT, the investment sage, has often said he welcomes market declines because they put some good-quality merchandise "on sale," letting him shop for bargains.
These days, however, it is the price of Mr. Buffett's own company, Berkshire Hathaway, that has been reduced, and some people are wondering why. 
 It's not that they think that Mr. Buffett, 68, has lost his touch. But how to explain that Berkshire's class A shares have lost more than 7 percent of their value, falling to $65,000, in just the first two weeks of the year? And that they are down 19.7 percent from their all-time closing peak of $80,900 last June 19? (Class B shares, which give holders limited voting rights and are not convertible to A shares, have fallen at a similar pace, and are now at $2,128.)
Not to worry, say those who follow Berkshire most closely. Yes, two of its biggest holdings, Coca-Cola and Gillette, have suffered from economic turmoil abroad. But this is the wrong way to look at Berkshire, according to Robert Hagstrom, portfolio manager for Legg Mason Focus Trust and a Buffett aficionado. Indeed, Berkshire is often misperceived by casual investors, and even the arbitragers, as little more than its huge portfolio of publicly traded stocks, concentrated -- at last report, which means the 1997 annual report -- in eight issues. (In addition to Coke and Gillette, those are American Express, Freddie Mac, Wells Fargo, Disney, Citigroup and Washington Post.)
"It is not correct to analyze as a closed-end investment company," said Mr. Hagstrom, whose fund has 22 percent of its assets invested in Berkshire. The main business of Berkshire is property and casualty insurance; the "float" generated by these subsidiaries including Geico, the seventh-biggest auto insurer, is then invested elsewhere -- in stocks and directly into other Berkshire operating businesses.
Investors say Berkshire's relative weakness is mostly a temporary result of its $22 billion acquisition, announced last summer, of General Re, the giant reinsurance company. As it turned out, General Re stockholders did not jump at the chance to become Mr. Buffett's investment partners by exchanging their shares for those of Berkshire.
That has led to some weakness in Berkshire shares. Thomas A. Russo, a partner at Gardner Investments in Lancaster, Pa., which has long held sizable Berkshire stakes, said: "The real impact is from the massive rotation of owners. You're now asking insurance investors to own a company that has a lot of other things," including a portfolio of stocks now carrying high price-earnings multiples and an increasingly large stable of other interests ranging from candy to executive jets. In his view, the pressure on the stock from the exodus of these owners is temporary.
A Wall Street analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity, however, estimated that only about one-third of General Re holders will wind up keeping Berkshire stock.
Disenchantment spread when Standard & Poor's chose not to include Berkshire in its 500-stock index, the widely used benchmark whose components are must buys for index funds. Lack of liquidity was seen as the reason -- expensive Berkshire shares do not trade much -- though rumors persist that S.& P. may reconsider. A spokesman for S.& P. declined comment on Thursday.
Another factor weighing on Berkshire's price is softness in the world reinsurance market as overcapacity forces down rates. But Mr. Hagstrom, Mr. Russo and others regard the acquisition of General Re as nothing short of a coup. General Re's huge size figures to add flexibility to Berkshire's insurance operations as well as to throw off huge amounts of cash that can be invested.
Geico, which flirted with bankruptcy in the 1970's, is thriving. As a low-cost provider of auto insurance, it could become the industry's second-biggest company, trailing only State Farm, in five to seven years, said Alice Schroeder, a Paine Webber analyst.
Christopher C. Davis, portfolio manager of Davis New York Venture fund and Selected American Shares, said the crucial variables for analysts sizing up Berkshire are how the insurance properties are valued and what opportunities exist for Berkshire to invest the float they generate. Mr. Davis has long admired Mr. Buffett without owning Berkshire itself. Now he counts himself a Berkshire bull and is keeping shares he received in exchange for General Re stock.
Martin Sosnoff, chief investment officer for Atalanta/Sosnoff Capital, has reservations. He argued recently in Forbes magazine that the collapse of oil prices had dimmed Berkshire's prospects by threatening political disruption in emerging markets, undermining their ability to buy Coke.
Buffett fans don't agree. "He'll make more money for his shareholders in a bad market," Mr. Davis said. "In a high-flying market he may have to bide his time."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2540 words

HEADLINE: The End of the Line;
As the Swingline Factory in Queens Closes, Veteran Workers Wonder What's Next for Them

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
TO Sal Melendez, the Swingline stapler factory in Long Island City, Queens, has been, for the most part, like a benevolent parent. It has fed and clothed him for nearly 21 years. It has watched him mature from a shipping clerk with limited English to a supervisor shepherding the next generation of immigrants into the company. It even introduced him to his wife, Juana, an assembly-line worker he met in the company cafeteria.
But Mr. Melendez said that the good will ran out in the spring of 1997 when company officials announced that they planned to shutter the 50-year-old plant and move operations to Nogales, Mexico. 
 Juana Melendez was laid off in October, and Mr. Melendez expects that he'll be standing in line at the unemployment office next month. That, he said, is when he has been told the factory will ship its last boxes of stapler parts and staples.
A spokeswoman for the company, Wendi Kopsick, declined to give a closing date for the factory but said that the 225 employees still working there would be "gradually phased down" and that the factory would be shut by the end of May. About 225 other workers have lost their jobs in the last 18 months.
"I got nothing against the company, because it gave me a wife and a good-looking kid," Mr. Melendez said, referring to his son, Sal, 14. "But right now they're not treating the people there -- good, decent people -- with dignity." He was especially bitter that even as the company laid off workers, it assigned others to work overtime. "People are working their last days there, and they just keep pushing and pushing them like slaves," he said.
When Swingline closes completely, 450 jobs will be gone. That is the largest single job loss in New York City from the North American Free Trade Agreement, or Nafta, the 1994 pact that lowered trade barriers among the United States, Mexico and Canada. Since 1994 about 800 workers from 17 companies in the city have registered with the Federal Department of Labor for unemployment and retraining benefits related to Nafta.
When officials from Swingline's parent company, Acco U.S.A., in Wheeling, Ill., announced that its Queens factory had become too costly to maintain and said the only way to increase profits was to move to Mexico, where labor and overhead are much cheaper, Mayor Giuliani declared that New York could do without a company that did not want to pay workers a decent wage. "The city comes out of this quite well," he said, adding that new companies were sprouting up and expanding in Long Island City and that Swingline workers probably would not have trouble finding new jobs. At the time, the Mayor was running for re-election, and his critics called his comments about the Swingline workers' job prospects insensitive and overly optimistic. Today, as hundreds of those workers grapple with unemployment, many complain that the Mayor painted far too rosy a picture. They worry that few companies will hire middle-aged, unskilled factory workers, and that even if they find new jobs, working back up to their old pay, an average of $10 an hour, will be next to impossible.
"The only jobs they have at unemployment are for fast food and for a foot massager, and that's at $5.50 an hour," said Nancy DeWendt, 48, who started at Swingline some 20 years ago, attaching staplers to their bases. "When you're used to a certain standard of living, that's like taking a gun and shooting me in my head."
For Sal and Juana Melendez, losing just one of their two Swingline incomes has already seriously shaken the routine and order of their lives. While Juana Melendez, 41, who is recovering from a slipped disk, will soon return to school to study English as a second language, Mr. Melendez, 46, has begun sniffing around for another job. Despite more than a decade of management experience at Swingline's loading bays, he said, his prospects were not good.
"I already asked around at a few warehouses where they might need someone with shipping experience, but they don't want someone like me," said Mr. Melendez, who immigrated from El Salvador when he was 17 years old. "It's going to be hard, because they're always looking for younger people."
His son, he said, has had to make sacrifices. "I explained what's going on at work, and I know he's not asking me for things he wants because of that," Mr. Melendez said. Last fall, to save his parents money, Sal enrolled at Queens Vocational and Technical High School in Long Island City instead of continuing in parochial school.
The Melendezes said they never minded putting in long hours at Swingline because it always meant more money for rearing their son. "Our main goal is him," Mr. Melendez said. "Always has been. But I worry for him, because you have to know 10 times more than me in order to survive now."
 
Small Manufacturers Opening and Growing
While Swingline's closing represents another major blow to the old-style heavy manufacturing that once dominated Long Island City, the neighborhood has experienced a recent industrial rebound with the opening and expansion of a number of smaller manufacturers.
Mana Products, for example, a cosmetics manufacturer across the street from Swingline that makes lotions and powders for high-end retailers like Neiman Marcus as well as make-up for K-Mart and private beauty salons, has grown to more than 500 employees from about 200 five years ago. And Schick Technologies, a nearby company that makes computerized dental X-ray machines, started with three workers in 1993 and now has more than 450.
If anything, local officials say, the shutdown of Swingline's assembly line runs counter to an overall trend in job growth. The number of manufacturing jobs in Queens increased to 50,300 in early 1998, from about 49,400 in early 1997, they say.
Thomas P. Knierim, executive director of the Long Island City Business Development Corporation, said that after decades of local job losses, as familiar manufacturers like Silvercup Bakery closed for good and others, including Eveready, Sunshine Biscuits and Chiclets, shuttered plants and moved elsewhere, the neighborhood has recently experienced something of a renaissance.
"As space gets too tight in Manhattan, many firms that are growing look at Long Island City because of its traditional role of being a premier industrial neighborhood that's just outside Manhattan," Mr. Knierem said. Long Island City's appeal, he said, lies in its quick access to highways, which makes it easier to transport goods, and the six subway lines and many bus lines that converge there.
Smaller manufacturers seem to be lining up to take over Swingline's industrial space. Lawrence T. Smith of Sholom & Zuckerbrot Realty, the broker handling the leasing of the Swingline buildings, said he expected leases to be signed within the next month. He would not give any details, but said that several smaller manufacturers were likely to move into the main building and that one company was to take over the annex building across Queens Boulevard.
 
Years of Climbing, Loss of the Ladder
Many Swingline workers like Elsa Vega are unskilled, lack a high school education and speak little English. They are wary of the new companies cropping up because they typically offer nonunion jobs, often without health benefits. And they dread starting again at the minimum wage.
Even those who are skilled see themselves as footnotes to a time when assembly-line jobs were plentiful and workers could expect to spend all their productive years at one company, moving up to jobs with more responsibility and higher pay.
Most of the workers found out about jobs at Swingline through friends and relatives, and the vast majority are immigrants from South America, Haiti, India and Russia. There is also a sizable community of Southern blacks who moved to New York in the 1960's for the work the company offered.
Aston Diedrick, a die maker who operated the machines that molded molten metal into stapler parts, has scoured newspapers for job openings since he was laid off two months ago. "I don't think there is anything like this left in New York," he said. "There's no more die casting in the city, so I don't know what I'm going to do."
Mr. Diedrick shakes his head in frustration as he ponders how he will support the five children he left behind in Jamaica nine years ago to take the Swingline job. "At the unemployment office, they only bring up this thing called Nafta," he said. "They talk about giving you two years of retraining, but what's your family supposed to do for two years while you're out of work?"
Besides retraining, the Government provides workers whose jobs have become casualties of Nafta with a year of unemployment benefits in addition to the six months most laid-off workers are entitled to get. Yet, while unemployment pays up to $365 a week, Swingline workers brought home an average of $650 a week with overtime, said officials of Teamsters Local 808, which represents about 400 Swingline employees.
The company spokeswoman, Ms. Kopsick, acknowledged that closing the plant has been "a difficult and emotional process for everyone," but insisted that it could not be avoided because in recent years, "Swingline had become only marginally profitable." She declined to give specific figures.
The union local's secretary, Chris Silvera, argued that when the plant closing was announced in 1997, internal company documents showed more than $10 million a year in profits. "They never lost any money," he said. "They told us at the time that it was simply they wanted to make a greater profit."
Workers say that stapler production in the factory's main building, on Skillman Avenue in the shadow of the elevated No. 7 train, stopped about a year ago. Since then all but the basement and third floor have continued operations, mainly producing stapler parts that are shipped to Nogales for assembly. Staples are still being made and packaged in the annex building.
Mr. Melendez said that in the days when the assembly lines were at full power, 20 to 40 people worked at the various stations, many shouting in different languages over the plop-plop-plop of machines spitting out stapler parts. "It was like the United Nations," he said. "Now when you walk through there, all you hear is quiet."
Swingline workers became experts on loading machines that make and piece together stapler parts or that shape 90-pound spools of wire into neat rows of staples. But now that many of them are middle- aged, they are skeptical that going back to school or enrolling in retraining programs will really help them compete with people half their age who probably have twice their energy and many more times their promise.
"I'm too young to retire and too old to start over," said Ms. DeWendt, who has been on disability since she threw out her back during a shift in late 1997. As a union shop steward, she has followed the factory's gradual closing very closely. She says Nafta retraining hasn't meant much to people laid off. Many hoped retraining would mean a chance to learn a trade. But most have been sent into courses to earn a high school equivalency degree or to learn English as a second language. "And before they do that, they make you take all these tests that are something else," she said.
Betty Gorham, who worked at Swingline for 20 years, took those tests. Despite finishing the 11th grade before moving to New York from North Carolina in 1965, she was told that before testing for a high school equivalency degree, she would first have to take literacy and basic math classes. So for the last year, the 52-year-old former assembly-line leader and production clerk has been going to school three hours a day, five days a week to relearn things as basic as addition and subtraction and what constitutes a long and short vowel sound.
"It's hard sitting there and trying to get all this stuff in your head after 34 years out of school," she said.
And after a lifetime of 12-hour work days, rearing two daughters and making a home for her family, Mrs. Gorham said, sitting down at night to write a 200-word essay about the city she lives in or to calculate square roots has proved to be much more of a challenge than she ever expected.
"Your mind don't function like it did when you was younger," she said. "But I do my homework and I do it good."
Mrs. Gorham said she opted to take the Nafta training because after all her years on the job, "I thought I would go to school to better myself and rest for a while."
Dave Engelhardt, her teacher at the Goodwill Industries Family Learning Center in Astoria, where she attends classes with two other Swingline workers, said that she entered with fourth-grade reading and math skills and after a year had progressed to an eighth-grade level. "Betty grew up at a time when people were routinely moved up in school strictly for a quota's sake, and lots of students were forgotten," he said. "But she's moved very quickly."
Mrs. Gorham hopes to earn her high school equivalency degree in May, which is about when her Nafta benefits run out. Besides basic education classes, she also has been taking some computer training classes. Shortly before being laid off, she had been entering stapler orders into a computer, so she hopes to find some kind of computer data entry work. But failing that, she said she would look for a job monitoring children on a school bus. "I figure I'll just watch the newspapers, but I know there ain't no jobs out there like there used to be," she said. "I'd come out of school right quick if I could find a job."
Mrs. Gorham said she has managed on unemployment benefits -- less than half of her Swingline take-home pay -- by careful budgeting. She lives in Jamaica with her husband, one of her daughters and three grandchildren. "My husband works in construction," she said. "But he counts on me, too; they all count on me."
As tough as surviving on unemployment benefits may be, Ms. DeWendt noted that Swingline's wages were hardly lavish. Many people worked 30 years to get to $10.75 an hour. But almost everyone routinely worked about 18 hours of overtime each week, she said, staying an extra two hours each day and working Saturdays when possible.
"Some people would do double shifts if they could get it," she said. "That's how people would get over and make money. That's how a lot of us could come to own a house and have a decent life."
Most workers have slowly come to terms with the upheaval. Julia Edge, who started at Swingline one week after moving to New York from North Carolina in 1965, figures that because of seniority she'll be one of the last workers at the factory. Mrs. Edge started in the packing room, worked her way up to the assembly line, then to the shipping room and to customer service. She spent the last 18 years as a supervisor. "I really don't know what I'll do when the factory closes," she said. "I'm just going to take it one day at a time.
"It was a family," she said of her co-workers. "There were husbands and wives, aunts and uncles, sisters and brothers who all worked there, and I had looked forward to retiring there with all my friends, but what can you do? When it's over, it's over."

HEADLINE: Saying Goodbye, Good Riddance To Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: MENLO PARK, Calif.

 BODY:
UNTIL last year, Geoff Goodfellow was a Silicon Valley Wunderkind, a pioneer in the field of wireless electronic mail. Now, as a resident of the Czech Republic, he wakes up each day and gazes from the balcony of his loft over a jumble of rooftops at the Prague Castle on a nearby hill.
Half a world away from Silicon Valley, Mr. Goodfellow has become a member of a small fraternity of engineers and entrepreneurs who have dropped out and walked away from ground zero of the Internet economy. 
 Mr. Goodfellow's departure is an exception to the popular notion that working in Silicon Valley, the world's high-technology capital, is its own reward. He left with a darker vision of life there and a disdain for the corrosive human effect of the region's workaholic, dollar-obsessed culture.
"In the Valley, it's all about power and money and work, work, work, work, and this expectation among your peers that you're going to do the next big thing," he said recently. "Eventually I saw that was a false god."
The different path taken by Mr. Goodfellow and a handful of others who have left Silicon Valley is particularly striking, because for the best and the brightest, dropping out or even retiring early has become increasingly rare.
Making a huge fortune in a high-flying Internet or semiconductor stock, which would be a life-changing event for most Americans, has in Silicon Valley become merely an occasion for, say, buying a new house or car and then transferring to a new start-up company.
In this former agricultural region, it has become typical to find "serial entrepreneurs" -- hardware engineers, scientists, marketing managers and software programmers who often feel that they work not for a given company but rather for Silicon Valley Inc. Changing jobs has become as simple as turning into a new driveway when you head for work.
And for many of these people, each successive job demands an intense commitment that squeezes out any outside life, whether it is family or recreation. Like the Apple Macintosh team of the 1980's whose members wore T-shirts that read "Working 90 hours a week and loving it," many people who work here now wear this workaholism as a badge of courage.
The modern role models are those who have founded a string of successful companies, like Jim Clark, founder of Silicon Graphics and Netscape Communications, or Federico Faggin, a former Intel engineer, co-inventor of its first microprocessor chip and founder of the Zilog Corporation and Synaptics Inc.
Indeed, the popular Silicon Valley career goal has become graduating to "corporate angel" status -- wealthy enough to emulate the venture capitalists who have long been the lifeblood of the Valley. Entrepreneurs like Andreas Bechtolscheim, a co-founder of Sun Microsystems who is now a computer designer at Cisco Systems, and Mark Andreessen, co-founder of Netscape, have become start-up investors while keeping their day jobs.
To find the Valley's most celebrated dropout, by contrast, it is necessary to reach back more than two decades. Robert J. Widlar, a legendary chip designer at the National Semiconductor Corporation, quit and moved to Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, in the 1970's, saying he "didn't like the water" in Silicon Valley. His idyll was cut short in 1991, when, at the age of 53, he died while jogging on a Puerto Vallarta beach.
It was Steven P. Jobs, a college dropout, who brought to Silicon Valley the mantra that "the journey is the reward."
Mr. Jobs was a co-founder of Apple Computer in 1976. After leaving Apple in 1985, he founded Next Computer and almost simultaneously bought Pixar, at the time an ailing supercomputer company.
A decade later, Mr. Jobs had transformed Pixar into a digital animation studio and became a billionaire overnight when he took it public. Then, in late 1996, he returned to Apple as interim chief executive and has orchestrated a stunning turnaround.
So it is that, with technologies advancing at the headlong pace known as Internet time, one accomplishment can often blur into the next.
"When you think of Jean-Paul Sartre's observation that there are no second acts in life, you realize that it simply doesn't apply in Silicon Valley," said Fred Hoar, a longtime public relations executive and a founder of the Band of Angels, a group of independent private investors in the Valley.
For some people, however, Silicon Valley's rewards come at an unjustifiable cost. Most of them share a passion for the technology that sustains the industry, but somehow lose their sense of fun in this work. They also become alienated from a culture driven by values they consider shallow.
Following are the stories of three men whose second act was to walk off the stage.
 
An Epiphany
In Heaven, in a Loft In Beautiful Prague
For Geoff Goodfellow, 42, a tall, thin man with short blond hair, life after Silicon Valley unfolds far from the world of endless business meetings, late nights and 90-hour weeks.
As a teen-ager, after discovering the Internet's predecessor, called the Arpanet, Mr. Goodfellow asked for free access to the computers of SRI International, the Menlo Park research center that helped give birth to the Internet, and began spending time there, helping to maintain the SRI computer systems. He became a computer hacker, dropped out of high school, never to return, and in 1988, from a spare bedroom in his Menlo Park apartment, started the Radiomail Corporation with the goal of providing nationwide wireless electronic mail.
But in 1996, after working first as chief executive and then as chairman, and after a long struggle with his investors, Mr. Goodfellow left Radiomail. Although his shares in the company had not made him fabulously wealthy, he walked away with enough money to live well. Working as a consultant, he immediately made plans to start several new companies, each of which he thought could grow into new industries related to music and the Internet.
Then, last year, while on vacation, Mr. Goodfellow, who is single, made a brief stop in Prague that changed his life. It was, he said, like meeting someone and knowing immediately that this was the person he would marry.
"When you have found the most beautiful and cultured city on the planet, it changes your view of the world," he said. He reflected on his life and work in Silicon Valley, and even though he had a network of friends there, he sold his home and rented a loft in a city he had visited for only a few days. "I've arrived in heaven," he said, "and I didn't have to die first to get here."
Mr. Goodfellow's disaffection with life in Silicon Valley had been building for some time. In 1996 he moved to a loft in San Francisco and began commuting to the Valley, spending his evenings frequenting the city's fine restaurants and taking in the underground music scene.
Life in Prague has changed his outlook on many things, he said. "In the Valley there are these nervous battles for power and money," he said. "And the hype -- it is a culture that has no culture."
Not that Mr. Goodfellow has totally abandoned his old world. He typically wakes at 6 A.M. and shuffles to his portable computer. By then it is 9 P.M. in Silicon Valley, and he catches up on technology developments by way of E-mail and a complex set of electronic tools that monitor the news services.
Still an inveterate news hound, he reads four newspapers each morning on the Internet and at lunch catches up on two more, The International Herald Tribune and The Financial Times.
He left Silicon Valley a wealthy man, by Czech standards, and in Prague he has become a full-time investor, with the booming United States stock market making him richer. He returns home from lunch by 3:30 each afternoon to track before-hours American trading and then uses the World Wide Web to do research and to make investments until leaving at 6 or 7 for dinner. Later each evening, he returns to monitor the New York market close.
He now calls Prague home, has a new set of mostly Czech friends and says he is far more at peace with himself.
"If you can imagine life with zero hassles, zero bureaucracy and zero conflict," he said, "that's the environment I live in."
He still believes that "the journey is the reward," but with a twist. "That was my goal," he said. "But sometimes when you start a journey your goal changes in midcourse and the currency in the reward can change as well."
 
A Re-evaluation
When Happiness Is A Suburban Forest
Steven Edelman is more philosophical than bitter about the intense world he left behind six years ago.
Having succeeded in two eras of the personal-computer industry, Mr. Edelman lives today in a forest in Beaverton, Ore., a suburb of Portland. His decision to leave Silicon Valley, after founding and successfully running a disk-drive and graphics company, was prompted partly by a desire to get away from the urban bustle. But in a sense, Mr. Edelman, 45, who once had a waist-length ponytail but now favors short hair, jeans and T-shirts, was dropping out even when he arrived in the Valley.
For him, as for Mr. Goodfellow, computing began as a passion and only later became a profession.
Mr. Edelman, a native of Long Island, graduated from Cornell and then got into the personal-computer industry on the East Coast in the mid-70's, when it was still a business for hobbyists. Just as Steve Jobs had phoned David Packard, then chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, to ask for parts for the original Apple computer, Mr. Edelman called Mr. Faggin to ask him for a microprocessor chip to help get him started.
His first company, Ithaca Intersystems, sold an early microcomputer and software. But the hobbyist era of computing was soon over. And as the industry started growing rapidly, Mr. Edelman, fascinated by new design tools for developing ever more complex semiconductor chips, moved to Silicon Valley.
With a small amount of savings to survive on, he spent his days at the electrical engineering department at Stanford University, often sitting in on courses on the design of advanced circuits. He was there so often that Stanford officials mistook him for a junior professor. After learning that he had no official ties to the university, they tried to persuade him to become a graduate student, but ultimately gave up and provided him an office and access to a computer in exchange for the work he was doing in designing chips.
In early 1984, while he was involved in yet another design project at Stanford, Apple introduced the Macintosh. "I went to a friend's house, and we took it apart," he said. "I thought to myself, 'My God, this machine can be upgraded!' "
The AST Research Corporation was already thriving as a maker of peripheral equipment for I.B.M.-compatible personal computers, and Mr. Edelman knew there would soon be a similar peripheral market related to the Macintosh. He became a co-founder of Supermac Inc., and it grew rapidly by selling components like expansion disks and graphics adapters for the Mac.
Over the next five years the growth of Supermac made Mr. Edelman a multimillionaire, but it also left him disenchanted about a world that seemed to have much in common with the power and wealth of New York and Los Angeles. For him the Valley seemed to be the new Hollywood, full of stars and with its own pecking order that forced people to play social games that didn't interest him.
"Silicon Valley had become the kind of place where if you wanted to be somebody you had to be wildly successful," he said.
When the Macintosh market began to lose ground to Windows and Intel-based PC's, Mr. Edelman's company did not make the leap to the PC-compatible market and began to shrink, eventually merging with Radius Inc., another Silicon Valley company. He decided that it was time to re-evaluate more than just his business. "So many people were making so much money I found myself wondering how I was doing," he said. "I began to wonder, 'Is this a good way to spend my life?' "
His answer was no. So he and his wife, Hyun Suh, who is a physician, moved to the forest near Portland.
He now spends part of his days as an entrepreneurial investor, freely discusses business ideas with callers and still does some tinkering with computers. But he does not miss the rat race, or what he sees as the Silicon Valley idea that your worth is measured by the success of your last start-up. Instead, he has a life, with lots of time to rub shoulders with the nondigerati while engaging in activities like hiking, water-skiing -- in a wetsuit, no matter the season -- and white-water kayaking.
"Getting away from the Valley," he said, "gave me a fresh appreciation of the fact that there are a lot of Americans who make $22,000 a year and they're worth something."
 
A Distant Freedom
Redoubt With Crane In the Swiss Alps
Like Steven Edelman, John Walker, founder of Autodesk Inc., the software publisher based in San Rafael, Calif., has his roots in the first personal computers. But eight years ago, he left the country because he had decided that the prospect of starting another company "wasn't fun."
A first-generation computer hacker, one who helped create the personal-computer industry, Mr. Walker, 49, was co-founder of a microcomputer business, Marinchip Systems, in the 1970's. But by 1981 an industry shakeout was under way and Marinchip was running short of capital.
So, in 1982 he and a small group of programmer friends struck on the idea of creating Autodesk Inc. Their flagship product, Autocad, grew out a pooled investment of $60,000 and became a general-purpose drafting and engineering program.
Along the way, he became worried about his weight problem, leading him to write a book called "The Hacker's Diet: How to Lose Weight and Hair Through Stress and Poor Nutrition." In the introduction, he noted that he had gone from 215 pounds to 145. Today he looks the part of the studious computer researcher, with dark-framed glasses and a pale complexion.
Autodesk blossomed into a multibillion-dollar enterprise, with several thousand employees, and it still holds a commanding share of the market for a variety of design tools used by engineers and architects. Mr. Walker, though, remained involved in the day-to-day management only through the company's first years, and readily acknowledges now that he had no particular skill or interest in managing such a large company. In 1986, a year after the company went public, he stepped down as chief executive.
Several years later, he also relinquished the role of chairman; around that time, his Autodesk holdings were worth more than $30 million. In 1991 he left California and took up residence in Switzerland with his wife, Roxie, and three dogs, two cats, a horse and an undetermined number of goldfish. They live near Zurich in a house adjoining a former hydraulics factory that he has converted into an office-workshop, a rambling space that came with everything from a generator that could power a small city to an industrial-strength crane. "Until you have a crane," he said recently, "you never knew that you needed one."
At first, he tried to run a remote research and development laboratory for Autodesk from his hydraulics castle, but an effort to help the company enter the factory design and automation software field fell short.
As a prolific writer, and with a wide range of technical and scientific interests, he has dabbled in a variety of projects. He maintains a Web site (www.fourmilab.ch) that offers everything from his history of Autodesk to his diet book (which he says has been downloaded 4.6 million times) to an Internet telephone program called Speak Freely that he wrote after the Internet took off.
Mr. Walker keeps his connections to the original Silicon Valley hacker community, returning for the annual Hackers Conference, which is attended by some of the nation's best programmers.
He has also engaged in a wide variety of personal projects, including using the World Wide Web to test theories of parapsychology. He is not a believer but takes a scientific interest in this field, with one current test trying to determine if humans sitting at computers connected to the Internet can exchange messages through mere thoughts.
Like both Mr. Goodfellow and Mr. Edelman, he maintains that his distance from the Valley has given him a freedom he would never have had amid the intense competition there.
Mr. Walker says he does not understand the passion that drives many in the Valley to start over again and again, whether they are successes or failures. He still remembers the struggle of starting Autodesk in the early 1980's and being turned down, he says, by every venture capitalist in California.
"What surprises me, is the compulsiveness of it," he said. I didn't find it enjoyable enough that I'd want to do it again."
And what about all those who keep coming back for more? The answer may be that the Valley is an ego-driven place and that many simply cannot tear themselves away.
As Paul Saffo, an industry consultant at the Institute for the Future, a research center in Menlo Park, put it: "There is this pressure to prove yourself over and over again in Silicon Valley. People wonder, 'Was it me or was it luck?' "
