HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Learning to Ride the Brazilian Roller-Coaster

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE lesson of Brazil's two devaluations last week is simple: If you are invested in emerging markets, accept the roller-coaster ride and make them only a small part of a well-diversified global portfolio. Or get out and stay out until you are sure that the uncertainty and volatility have settled down to a manageable level.
But what happened in Brazil last week is precisely the kind of reversal that tempts some investors to ignore such advice. 
 Yes, that's right, two devaluations: A limited, 9 percent devaluation on Wednesday, which sent the Brazilian stock market down 14.5 percent in two days. And a full devaluation on Friday, allowing the real to float freely. That made investors believe that Brazil's high interest rates could fall, opening the way to a 33.4 percent rebound.
It's anyone's guess what happens from here, though it is clear that Brazil's problems are not over.
Desmond Lachman, the director of emerging-markets economic research at Salomon Smith Barney, said the full devaluation was positive, because lower interest rates would slow the economic decline that has started in Brazil. Even so, he said, the Friday rally was in part a pop, because investors were caught expecting the stock market to fall further. The future, he added, depended on whether the Government could impose the spending cuts and tax changes still needed to reorganize the economy.
Brazil is in a position to build upon this devaluation, Mr. Lachman said. "But can they deliver on the budget?" he asked. "Can they get the implementation process back on track?"
There is also uncertainty about how the United States and the International Monetary Fund will react. The devaluation violated Brazil's agreement with the I.M.F. that brought the country $41.5 billion in aid last fall. But the I.M.F. did say on Friday that letting the real float freely was better than trying to defend a limited devaluation. The devaluation also raises the threat of debt defaults, because it increases Brazil's repayment costs.
Warren Howe, vice president of the international equities division of Bankers Trust, said he and his colleagues were waiting to see what happened next. "You certainly don't want to do it in a rush," he said of jumping backing into Brazil and the rest of Latin America. But then, Bankers Trust decided some time ago to reduce its exposure to the region.
That process began in June and July of last year. At the time, Mr. Howe said, $250 million was invested in Latin American stocks through Bankers Trust's international, emerging-market and Latin American-focused funds. Now the amount, aside from funds dedicated exclusively to the region, is down to "very little."
While Bankers Trust money managers were getting out, mutual fund investors were fleeing, too. During the same period, there was a net outflow of $661 million from Latin American funds followed by AMG Data Services. That was 40 percent of the total decline in assets in those funds. The rest was from the plunge in the stock markets.
Both Bankers Trust and those risk-averse mutual fund investors looked pretty smart until October and November, when Latin American stock markets began to rebound in the wake of interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve and the assembling of Brazil's big rescue package. Both moves helped stave off what investors worldwide feared the most at the time: a devaluation of the Brazilian currency.
And up those Latin American markets went. The Morgan Stanley Capital International index of Latin American funds surged 38.7 percent from its low on Sept. 10 to Jan. 7, the day Brazil's stock market began the collapse that resulted in last week's currency devaluations. Brazil's Bovespa index of 56 stocks climbed even more -- 54 percent.
But in the six trading days through Thursday, Brazil was off 31 percent.
Then there was Friday. But don't kick yourself too quickly for missing the 33.4 percent rebound. That rally was in Brazil's suddenly cheaper currency, the real. In dollar terms, the Friday gain was 23 percent. Or, put another way, the Brazilian market on Thursday was down 31.7 percent in dollar terms for the year -- and after Friday's rally was down just 16 percent.
So Mr. Howe and many mutual fund investors who got out of Latin America still look smart. "It's been a very good move in the end," Mr. Howe said. But he acknowledged that "we were hurting in October and November, when the markets moved up 40 percent or 50 percent."
There was another twinge on Friday, but he still said, "I don't think you should have gotten too excited."

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Representative James A. Traficant Jr.;
Burping Cows and Space Toilets. Beam Me Up, Mr. Speaker!

BYLINE: By TOM KUNTZ 

 BODY:
PEOPLE just tuning in to Washington over the past year of sex, pizza and judicial racing stripes could be forgiven for wondering: Is Government usually this diverting?
Of course, it's all in the eye of the beholder. But don't decide for yourself until after you've sampled the one-minute House floor speeches of Representative James A. Traficant Jr., Democrat of Ohio. 
 One-minute addresses are a House tradition, affording members the opportunity at the beginning of the day to hold forth briefly on any topic they wish -- yielding a sound bite and added verbiage for the Congressional Record regardless of whether anybody present is paying much attention. The speeches will resume shortly when the new Congress takes up normal business.
When they do, rest assured that Mr. Traficant will rise to be recognized. Over his more than 11 years in the House, the pro-labor, pro-school-prayer ex-county sheriff has turned the short address into his trademark, a verbal blunderbuss loaded with inanities to blast what he sees as Washington's absurdities.
Usually he punctuates his remarks with a request to be "beamed up," a la "Star Trek," to someplace where there's more intelligent life. Here are excerpts. TOM KUNTZ
 
On the Economy
 Let us tell it like it is: When you hold this economy to your nosey, this economy does not smell so rosy. If there is any consolation to the American workers, I never heard of anyone in America committing suicide by jumping out of a basement window. I yield back all of the propaganda on this great economy.
--June 10, 1997
 
On Nike's Asian Factories
 Mr. Speaker, I say it is time for the American consumers to tell Nike to take a hikey and buy some American shoes before, so help me God, we are all working in some sweatshop.
--Aug. 2, 1996
 
On Nafta
 Mr. Speaker, the White House says Nafta the North American Free Trade Agreement is creating new and exciting jobs. I did some research on those jobs: zipper trimmer, brassiere tender, jelly roller, bosom presser, chicken sexer, sanitary napkin specialist and a pantyhose crotch closer machine operator. That is what I call exciting jobs, Mr. Speaker.
--May 13, 1997
 
On Regulation
Mr. Speaker, the Lord's prayer is 66 words, the Gettysburg Address is 286 words, the Declaration of Independence is 1,322 words. U.S. regulations on the sale of cabbage -- that is right, cabbage -- is 27,000 words. Now, if that is not enough to give Hulk Hogan's dictionary a hernia, check this out. Regulatory red tape in America costs taxpayers $400 billion every year, over $4,000 each year, every year, year in, year out, for every family. Beam me up.
--July 29, 1998
 
On Foreign Policy
 Let us check this out: China gets $60 billion in M.F.N. most-favored-nation status from Uncle Sam. Russia gets $15 billion in foreign aid from Uncle Sam. In exchange, Uncle Sam gets nuclear missiles pointed at our cities, two tape decks and three cases of vodka. Beam me up. I say our national security brain trust needs a proctologist on staff.
--April 1, 1998
 
On China
 Mr. Speaker, I think it is time to tell it like it is. When it comes to China, we have gone from "Speak softly and carry a big stick" to "Take the fifth and carry a toothpick." Beam me up.

 Mr. Speaker, the Vice President said America needs to reinvent Government. To find out why, the G.A.O. called the R.T.C., the I.T.C. and the P.M.S. They did not know.
The G.A.O. then called the D.O.D., the D.O.T. and the D.D.T. They did not know. The G.A.O. then called the C.I.A., the D.I.A., the E.P.A. and the I.U.D. They did not know. Most of these absent-minded professors cannot find the toilet. Mr. Speaker, I have one question for these wise guys to constipate over: How can some thing come from no thing?

Mr. Speaker, in 1993, Boris Yeltsin fell off a stage in Germany. In 1994, Boris could not get off his plane in Ireland. Mr. Speaker, in many cities and towns across America it is illegal to kiss in public. It is illegal in some places to ride a skateboard. It is illegal to burn trash or leaves. However, in America, it is completely legal to burn the flag, completely legal to desecrate the flag. It is even legal, Mr. Speaker, to urinate on Old Glory. In the words of a Russian comedian, "America -- What a country."
--June 7, 1995
 
On Belching Cows
Mr. Speaker, talking about garbage, the E.P.A. is spending $210,000 to study cow belching and its effects on global warming. Here is how it works.
Cows will wear backpacks and have hoses connected to their mouths.
Tell me, Mr. Speaker, what happens if the backpack is so tight and instead of an oral emission, Elsie goes 7.0 on the Richter scale? Will the President declare a garbage emergency . . .? Or how about maybe appoint a Congressional Bovine Burp Task Force. Or maybe the E.P.A. will require -- think about it -- scrubbers on udders, bag hoses on nostrils. I think we ought to take a cattle prod to the E.P.A.
--Sept. 26, 1991
 
On Radioactive Beagles
 Madam Speaker Barbara B. Kennelly, the Connecticut Democrat filling in as Speaker , the remains of 800 beagles and 1,700 tons of their radioactive urine and feces will be buried at a nuclear site in the State of Washington.
The dead dogs have been in freezers since 1950. They were part of a study to assess the damage of radioactive fallout. The study is now conclusive: Radioactive fallout is fatal, and canines subject thereto died. But the point is, Madam Speaker, the funeral is going to cost $22 million.
Tell me, are they going to ship the bodies by limo? Are they going to have gold tombstones for every hound?
With 37 million people in America without health insurance, 9 million people unemployed, I would like to say that our Government is spending $22 million to erect a giant fire hydrant as a mausoleum to dead beagles.
I think that says it all, Madam Speaker: America's domestic priorities have gone to the dogs.
--Oct. 9, 1991

 Mr. Speaker, something does not add up. . . . Experts say, "Don't worry, America. If the Federal Government shuts down, only nonessential workers will be furloughed." . . .
Now the dictionary says nonessential means not necessary. Now, if that is the case, did anyone around here ever stop to think that if Congress did not borrow money to hire nonessential workers, Congress would not have to borrow more money to pay nonessential workers and Congress would not have to shut down?
Beam me up, Mr. Speaker. Maybe, just maybe, the Congress of the United States is a little nonessential.
--Nov. 13, 1995

HEADLINE: The World: A Case of Open and Shut;
As the World Takes a New Look, It's the Same Old Cuba

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
AS he traveled from one end of Cuba to another a year ago, often with Fidel Castro at his side or sitting attentively in the audience, Pope John Paul II had one overriding message. In its most succinct form it was that Cuba "needs to open herself to the world, and the world needs to draw closer to Cuba."
Since then, the world has heeded the Pontiff's directive, often using his words as justification; even the United States took a few modest steps in that direction on Jan. 5, making it somewhat easier for Americans to send money and food to Cuba. 
 Mr. Castro and the Cuban Communist Party, on the other hand, have largely ignored the first half of the papal exhortation.
Early this month, Mr. Castro marked the 40th anniversary of his seizure of power with a speech in which he defiantly maintained that "the revolution has just begun." Under him, Cuba's human rights record remains dismal. Economic reforms like those carried out by China are stalled too; this promises only additional austerity for the average Cuban, and it has made the country less attractive to foreign investors.
After the Pope's visit, Mr. Castro freed more than 300 people held in Cuban jails, and at the time optimists suggested that the move might be the start of a relaxation. But as is so often the case when Mr. Castro is involved, there was less to the action than met the eye.
Many of those released were common criminals, not political prisoners. And many, human rights groups say, were freed on condition they leave Cuba, a procedure the authorities often apply against dissidents after a spell in prison.
Furthermore, 18 months after they were arrested on charges of sedition, Cuba's most prominent political prisoners remain in jail, still awaiting trial and refused habeas corpus. Felix Bonne, Rene Gomez Manzano, Vladimiro Roca and Marta Beatriz Roque, leaders of the Internal Dissidence Working Group, were jailed after publishing a document titled "The Homeland Belongs to Us All," in which they urged Mr. Castro and the Communist Party to allow "an independent and impartial legal system that would protect the liberties and rights of the individual and the practice of political pluralism."
OTHERS, who were released after having been held on trumped-up charges, could face jail again, since Cuba's legal system continues to lack even the most elemental guarantees of due process and no effort is being made to provide such protections. Hector Palacios Ruiz, for instance, had been imprisoned for possessing "enemy propaganda." His crime was to attempt to distribute copies of a declaration Mr. Castro signed at a Latin American summit meeting, promising steps toward full representative democracy.
"I do not see any will, sign or political gesture showing that the Cuban authorities are willing to move forward to make some serious progress," said Jose Miguel Vivanco, executive director of Human Rights Watch in the Americas. "The harassment against dissidents, human rights activists or anyone else attempting to exercise the most basic rights of association and expression continues exactly the same."
Even in the area of religious freedom, where some progress has taken place, significant restrictions remain. Mr. Castro's decision to allow the celebration of Christmas was treated by the state-controlled press as an act of revolutionary generosity. But such gains for religion result from case-by-case negotiations, not a blanket recognition of a right to worship freely. Parish priests find many local authorities still unwilling to allow processions on the feast days of saints.
Nor has the Government offered much latitude for the incipient private sector that the Clinton Administration said its new measures are intended to help. In 1996, more than 200,000 people were officially listed as "self-employed," and Government officials were suggesting that hundreds of thousands more would be encouraged to take that course.
Since then, though, the number of people working for themselves with the official approval of the Government has declined substantially, perhaps by nearly a quarter, and some occupations that were formerly approved for free enterprise have now been proscribed. Confiscatory tax policies have been used to drive out of business many of those who were beginning to compete with the state, like owners of small private restaurants called paladares.
"They've let everything play out, but they have not added any new openings," said Philip Peters, author of "Islands of Enterprise," a study of the Cuban private sector. "Certainly, there is no interest in letting it expand, at least not immediately."
THE obsession with control helps explain the strongly negative reaction to the Clinton Administration's limited initiative. Jose Luis Rodriguez, the Minister of the Economy, initially dismissed the moves as "crumbs," as if to deny their significance. But Ricardo Alarcon, head of the rubber-stamp parliament and Mr. Castro's favorite mouthpiece on relations with the United States, later described the measures as a "subversive and counterrevolutionary" attempt to destabilize the Cuban Government by going around it -- "a way of manufacturing traitors."
Based on the oration Mr. Castro delivered in Santiago on Jan. 1 to mark his 40 years in power, Cubans have no choice but to look forward to more of the same. Of Cuba's 11 million people, 7 million have been born since 1959, Mr. Castro proudly pointed out in the speech. But they are led, as he also noted, by someone "who dresses the same, who thinks the same, who dreams the same" today as he did when he came down from the Sierra Maestra."

HEADLINE: The World;
Brazil Topples Off the Verge

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Tall and tanned and young and lovely
The girl from Ipanema goes walking
And when she passes
Each one she passes
Goes "Aaah"
--"The Girl From Ipanema"
LIKE the sensual strains of that old bossa nova tune, Brazil enchants. And it has been attracting treasure hunters of all stripes for centuries. 
 From the Portuguese who colonized Brazil between 1500 and 1822 to the Wall Street money managers who made the country a darling of emerging market investors during the last several years, Brazil's economic promise is a perennial lure. But, as Brazilians like to joke, theirs is the country of the future -- and always will be.
Brazil's most recent bid for economic stardom ended in disappointment last week. On Wednesday, the country devalued its currency, the real, and announced the resignation of its central bank president, as it continues to struggle with excessive debt, sky-high interest rates and fiscal austerity measures mandated by the International Monetary Fund.
In so doing, Brazil became the latest victim of the global financial contagion that broke out in Southeast Asia about 18 months ago and spread to Russia last summer. As was the case when those economies went into a tailspin, Brazil's travails touched off international concern about whether its problems will spread to Argentina and Mexico and ultimately damage the United States economy.
By the end of the week Brazil's stock market, showing all the effervescence of a bottle of champagne, had bubbled back up again. Even so, this huge, resource-rich country, which shares a border with every South American country except Chile and Ecuador, never quite seems to realize the gilded dreams imposed upon it.
"The quest for El Dorado has been a feature of Brazilian life ever since it was controlled as a colony by Portugal," said Larry Birns, director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a research group in Washington. "Every generation there are miraculous expectations for the Brazilian economy. Brazil's financial barons have shared these dreams, but they haven't been based on economic reality."
Although Brazil is home to the world's eighth-largest economy, it is hobbled by widespread poverty and unequal distribution of wealth. And Brazilians, long accustomed to Government corruption, typically expect little from the grand economic schemes launched over the years.
Back in the 1970's, when the Nixon Administration trumpeted Brazil as the next great superpower, huge state projects sponsored by the World Bank and others were seen as one way for Brazil to tap its hidden riches. For example, the Trans-Amazonian Highway, stretching from coast to jungle, was built to exploit the wealth of the interior. But it was rammed through without regard for its impact on the rain forest or the indigenous population. And those Brazilians who migrated to the interior on the highway found largely useless tracts of land.
EVEN with such huge miscues, Brazil enjoyed relatively robust economic growth from about 1965 to 1980, when oil price shocks and the Latin America debt crisis helped bring an end to Brazil's flirtation with superpower status. Foreign investment shriveled and the Brazilian Government continued to run up huge debts as inflation spiraled out of control, soaring as high as 2,400 percent in 1993, according to Jeffrey Schott, a specialist in international trade at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
With inflation strangling the economy, the newest method for realizing Brazil's economic promise was unveiled in 1994, when the Government effectively pegged the real to the dollar. The idea was to control inflation by keeping a tight rein on the money supply. Tight money, Government cutbacks and open markets, of course, constitute the miracle cure being peddled all over the world by American politicians and financiers. But while inflation has been brought under control in Brazil, some economists see another ill that has been overlooked time and again -- wealth inequality.
DESPITE decades of economic experimentation, much of Brazil remains desperately poor. The wealthiest 10 percent of Brazilians receive about 48 percent of the country's income, according to the World Bank, while the poorest 10 percent receive less than 1 percent.
And Brazil has tied its weak domestic economy to exports and fickle overseas investors -- a dangerous dependence in a world in which financial crises are quick to take hold.
"Brazil has changed a great deal superficially, but for the poor, who represent the bulk of the population, life has changed very little," said Gillette Hall, an economist at the University of Oregon in Eugene. "Economic liberalization for Brazil, as for many other developing countries, has meant an increasing dependence on world export markets and international capital flows. That in turn has left it prey to the vagaries of the global economy, which are now coming home to roost."
Brazil found itself in a corner last fall after the Russian economy collapsed. Investors fled Brazil and speculators took aim at the real. Brazil raised interest rates to defend its currency, choking domestic growth and causing its foreign exchange reserves to dwindle.
Brazil hopes that letting the real fall against the dollar will boost exports and bring interest rates down. The flip side of this strategy is that Brazilian borrowers owing dollar-denominated loans will find it more expensive to pay off debts, raising the specter of messy defaults.
So, for now, Brazil's vaunted economic promise is as it has always been. Elusive.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
The Case of the Spies Without a Country

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT this murderous century, diplomats and dreamers have envisioned a world in which nations would transcend their boundaries, dispel their differences and band together to preserve peace against dictators and despots.
This vision of world federation helped create the United Nations. And it engendered the United Nations Special Commission, charged with disarming Iraq after the 1991 gulf war. The commission, known as Unscom, became an international intelligence service for the new world order. It was the first of its kind -- and, it now seems, maybe the last. 
 For the more secret its work became, and the more estranged the enforcers of disarmament grew from each other, the less Unscom could withstand accusations of serving the last superpower, its main supplier of spycraft: the United States.
More than 7,000 weapons inspectors from around the world served Unscom over seven years, spying on Iraq, surveying its military and industrial plants, trying to do what smart bombs could not: destroy nuclear, biological, chemical and missile programs hidden by Saddam Hussein.
Ideally, intelligence can achieve victory without war. But espionage is a uniquely national enterprise. While nations may share interests, spy services rarely do. "There are friendly states, but no friendly intelligence services," notes a spokesman for Russia's foreign intelligence agency. When spies from two countries shake hands, they are often trying to pick one another's pockets.
When the going got tough for Unscom, it sought American spy technology. American intelligence gladly provided it but would not share it with the world. The more secretive Unscom's work became, the less open it could be with its member nations.
"If secret information is open to all member states, it won't work," said Gordon C. Oehler, former director of the Central Intelligence Agency's Nonproliferation Center. "If you let in the French, the Chinese, the Russians -- that would kill it."
So much for international cooperation. In March the special commission adopted an American eavesdropping system so secret that only a handful of Americans, British, Australians and New Zealanders had full access to it.
This, understandably, led to tensions, notably between the Americans on one side and the Russians, the Chinese and the French on the other.
The special commission began as a unique experiment. It was assembled quickly after the 1991 gulf war, when Iraq was shattered and powerless and the world seemed united in the determination to disarm that country. It assumed unconditional power to do its work. "It brought together communities -- intelligence, military, non-proliferation -- from around the world, and it brought new thinking about how to do inspections," said David Albright, president of the Institute for Science and International Security, who served as a nuclear-weapons inspector in Iraq. Its leaders thought they could disarm Iraq in no time -- "possibly as little as a year," its chairman, Richard Butler, said last week.
But, as Mr. Butler conceded, "it has taken eight years, and the job is still not completely finished."
Not until 1995 did the inspectors understand that Iraq had an extraordinary system to hide its secret weapons programs. Now three more years have gone by trying to pierce that shield. And as it turned out, the secret weapons -- the foundation of President Hussein's power, the ace in the hole with which he might someday trump the world -- were hidden by the same soldiers and spies whose duty it is to make sure that the Iraqi dictator dies peacefully in bed. That made piercing the Iraqi veil far more difficult than anyone had expected, and prompted the Americans to roll out the particularly sophisticated and sensitive equipment that yielded a a product they were reluctant to share too widely.
"Iraq is a sovereign nation, and there are limits to what you can do if that nation wants to hide things from you," Mr. Oehler said. "The best you can do is make it very painful for them if they won't go along." Iraq has endured great pain -- including perhaps $150 billion in lost oil revenues -- to defy disarmament.
"The lesson is you can't disarm a country unless you're willing to occupy it and forbid them the trappings of a sovereign nation, such as a military force and the right to built that force," Mr. Oehler said.
But no one has been willing to conquer Iraq in the name of world peace. And America's French and Russian partners on the Security Council are increasingly eager to resume business with Baghdad, which owes them billions of dollars.
Now the international coalition assembled by President Bush for the gulf war has dwindled to two nations: the United States and Britain. Their four-day attack on Iraq in December was "the first time in history that a nation has gone to war to stop the spread of weapons of mass destruction," said Joseph Cirincione, director of the nonproliferation project at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
If so, it failed, said Scott Ritter, the former marine who resigned from Unscom in August to protest what he called a lack of American support. His accusations have helped raise suspicions that the Americans used information supposedly gathered for Unscom to precisely target Iraqi units closely linked to Saddam Hussein.
THE attack was a final blow with which "the U.S. killed Unscom," Mr. Ritter said. "The U.S. brought its own credibility and objectivity into question. And the U.S. lost a lot of its moral authority to lead on this issue."
Now Unscom is banished from Iraq and bloodied by international infighting. The United States is back to taking potshots at Iraq, playing Globocop, a role that alienates it from much of the rest of the world. America's allies in the region are fed up with Mr. Hussein, but their patience for American bombing raids is wearing thin.
Mr. Butler bravely hopes for a new and improved Unscom. But now the French and the Russians are proposing lifting the oil embargo on Iraq in exchange for a new system of overseeing Iraqi weaponry -- and the Russians want to abolish the special commission altogether. The United States is against those proposals. In any case, Iraq will not submit to more inspections unless it is freed entirely from the eight-year-old economic embargo.
The experiment in international intelligence is over. No one knows how a new arms control regime can be installed in Iraq. And no one knows how much more pain Iraq is willing to endure to hide its secret cache.
Today, on the eighth anniversary of the launching of the gulf war, Iraq's chances of rebuilding a secret arsenal look good. The future for world federations devoted to disarmament looks bleak.

HEADLINE: The World: Raising the Stakes;
American Pay Rattles Foreign Partners

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
AS the global economy spawns more mergers of American and foreign companies, inequities in the pay of top executives quickly become apparent. In the spirit of compromise that marks a new marriage, the lower-paid officers see their pay rise to the levels of their better-paid colleagues -- almost always the Americans -- and American-style capitalism claims a little more foreign turf.
The American way of compensating top executives -- with opportunity for tremendous riches from bonuses and incentives tied to a rising stock price -- certainly pays better. Some experts view American-style pay as a vitamin that can jump-start the performance of sluggish economies abroad. But others see it as a virus that spreads greed and excess. 
 A growing number of companies are joining the experiment. When Daimler-Benz announced in May that it would acquire the Chrysler Corporation, the chairman of Daimler, Jurgen E. Schrempp, was earning much less than Robert J. Eaton, his counterpart at Chrysler, a substantially smaller company. Last week, Daimler-Benz announced a new system for paying its top 250 executives: About 25 to 30 percent of their compensation would be fixed and the rest would be in performance bonuses and other incentives.
Many companies are grappling with the issue. Last year, Bertelsmann, the German publisher, acquired Random House; Amoco agreed to a takeover by British Petroleum; Deutsche Bank made a deal to buy Bankers Trust, and Scottish Power agreed to buy Pacificorp.
These foreign buyers generally have little choice but to adopt American ways of compensating all their top executives. Key executives from each of the merging companies expect to get roughly the same pay. Chrysler executives, for example, would quickly start job-hunting around Detroit if they were forced to take a cut.
In a sense, the richer executive payroll for foreign companies is the price of entry for joining the United States economy, where Daimler-Benz and others presumably expect to get better returns than if they had invested elsewhere.
These simple economic explanations certainly help foreign executives deflect suggestions that they may be motivated to merge with an American partner to help boost their own pay. But many consultants who advise companies on compensation matters say that many foreign executives are uneasy about the shift, even though they may benefit personally.
"There is movement, but there is resistance as well," said Robert J. Freedman, a compensation expert at Towers Perrin, a consulting firm.
Proponents of American-style pay packages for top executives say they are a big reason the American economy and the stock market have been so vibrant this decade. Executive pay is high, they typically concede. But chief executives in the United States, like professional athletes, generally have short careers. And talented executives, they argue, can often add so much value to a company that their outlandish pay, in the grand scheme of things, amounts to a small tip.
"If you pay your management with stock-based incentives, they will be very motivated to do everything they can to get it right," said Ira T. Kay, the head of the global compensation practice at Watson Wyatt, a consulting firm.
An implicit message in this model, however, is that an honest day's pay for an honest day's work is not enough to get executives to do their best; they have to have a gold carrot dangling in front of them.
IN fact, many companies, in their filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, justify high compensation for top officers with that argument. For example, McDonald's executive compensation program, according to a recent filing, "has been designed to attract, energize, reward and retain superior talent." If the pay packages were any smaller, this language suggests, the executives would somehow be less energized, and more willing to bolt for a higher-paying competitor.
Some public companies have tried a different way. Ben & Jerry's, the ice cream company, and Herman Miller, a maker of office furniture, used to say that there should be a limit to the gap between the highest- and lowest-paid workers (at the ice cream company, it was 7 times higher back in 1994; at Herman Miller, it was 20 times higher in 1996). But they have since tossed out these rules and joined the bidding war for executive talent.
The cult of the American business superstar, which has delivered hundreds of millions of dollars to professional managers (who, in some cases, send the tab for personal financial planning advice back to their company), has historically offended the sensibilities of people in many foreign countries, where the best and the brightest pursued careers in fields other than business.
In Britain, for example, executive pay has moved further toward the American system than most other countries. A study of the 20 largest companies in the United States and Britain by William M. Mercer, a consulting firm, found, among other things, that the base salaries of the top American executives were 38 percent higher, bonuses were more than five times higher and the value of their stock options was incomparably higher.
"There's a lot of widespread public unease about the levels of pay in the U.K.," said Tony Groom, a principal in Mercer's executive compensation practice. Business, after all, has not historically been considered a particularly high calling there.
OXFORD University, for example, only recently built a business school, over objections from many quarters that the quest for an M.B.A. was not a legitimate scholarly pursuit.
There are many reasons why executive pay is lower in other countries. Careers and performance, for example, tend to be measured over a much longer term than at American companies. Stock options that last 10 years are called long-term incentives in the United States; many foreign companies use a decade to measure short-term goals.
There is also less jockeying for pay raises outside the United States. James A. Hatch, a partner at Arthur Andersen, recounts the story of a United States office of a Japanese company, where the American secretaries and support staff found that their Japanese bosses were soft touches for tales of personal financial hardship. Pretty soon, Mr. Hatch said, many of the workers were getting salaries two and three times those of workers in other offices.
On a global scale, the marketplace for executives remains quite skewed. But even with pay rising for foreign executives, it seems unlikely that it will catch up to American levels, which are setting new records every year.
"The notion of closing the gap is laughable," said Graef Crystal, editor of the Crystal Report, a newsletter on executive compensation. "When you're 200 laps behind and driving a supercharged Audi, how do you catch up with an American car with 5,000 horsepower?"

HEADLINE: The Gas Company as Social Worker;
Brooklyn Utility Tries Softer Approach to Pursue Unpaid Bills

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

 BODY:
Two years ago, Joy Chatel appeared in Civil Court in Brooklyn to account for her $7,000 unpaid gas bill. A contractor had bilked her out of $40,000, she told the judge, forcing her to close her beauty parlor. She had no income and four grandchildren to raise. When her husband died about this same time, she had to barter two years of free hairstyling for a proper funeral.
The judge instructed the lawyers from Brooklyn Union Gas Company to work out a payment plan with Ms. Chatel, and the lawyers handed her account to Kristen Yontz. Ms. Yontz, though, is not a bill collector. She is a social worker, part of the utility's experiment in getting people to pay their bills by helping them straighten out their lives. 
 She has met regularly with Ms. Chatel, advising her on low-interest loans, enrolling her in a support group for grandparents, steering her to Federal emergency heating funds and, significantly for Brooklyn Union, placing her on a flexible repayment plan. Ms. Chatel is still struggling, but she has reopened her beauty parlor and soon plans to rent the top two floors of her building.
"They help me manage," Ms. Chatel said.
Utilities, which for decades have operated as regulated quasi-governmental entities, have offered some aid and emergency help to their low-income customers. Many provide fuel funds, which are emergency grants for customers about to be cut off, as well as weatherization programs and other services. But in these last few years of shrinking government benefits, Brooklyn Union and a small group of other utilities across the nation have gone one step further, into a realm once reserved for nonprofit social service agencies.
At Brooklyn Union, Ms. Yontz is one of four certified social workers in what the utility calls its On Track program; in three years, its clients have reduced their arrears by an average of 27 percent.
In Wisconsin, which has one of the nation's first and most extensive welfare-to-work programs, Wisconsin Gas works with nonprofit agencies to offer a variety of social services for low-income customers in Milwaukee.
And since 1994, a staff of 15 at Baltimore Gas and Electric, including several social workers, has offered counseling, job referrals and other services to about 3,000 low-income Maryland families every year. "As the social service community began to scale back in some of the services they had provided, we began to develop some of the needed assistance programs," said Don Dasher, the utility's director of customer assistance.
But if these initiatives are admired, they are not necessarily imitated. Nationally, as the industry undergoes deregulation, many utilities that once operated as regional monopolies are now cutting costs to prepare for competition. Because low-income programs often do not pay for themselves, some utilities are quietly eliminating them.
Michigan Consolidated Gas Company in Detroit recently discontinued a program much like the one now offered by Brooklyn Union, in part, a company official said, to prepare for deregulation. Last year, the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, an upstate utility, proposed eliminating one of its two low-income programs.
After criticism from advocacy groups, the New York Public Service Commission, which regulates utilities in the state, required the upstate company to continue and expand the program. But advocates for low-income customers warn that other utilities could also try to eliminate such programs.
"What could happen is that an outside supplier of natural gas who is located in, say, Texas, is not committed to the people Brooklyn Union has been serving for the last 20 years," said Jim Benfield, executive director of Campaign to Keep America Warm, an advocacy group for the poor in Washington. "In order to stay competitive, Brooklyn Union is going to have to get out of the social service business."
Despite a buoyant national economy, advocates say, large numbers of low-income customers continue to struggle to meet their utility bills, particularly during the bitter cold of winter. For competitive reasons, Brooklyn Union refused to release the dollar amount of unpaid bills due the company. But in Ohio, which collects such statistics on a statewide basis, the dollar amount of unpaid bills by all low-income utility customers has risen to about $110 million in 1998 from $48 million in 1994.
One explanation, advocates say, is Congress's cuts in the Federal emergency relief program for the poor, known as the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program. Its funding has fallen to $1.1 billion this year from $2.1 billion in 1986.
Brooklyn Union, which supplies natural gas to 1.1 million customers in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, began On Track in late 1995 as part of a rate agreement with the Public Service Commission that also created the utility's current holding company, Keyspan Energy. Before On Track, company officials commissioned an internal study in 1992 and 1993 that found that 43 percent of the company's delinquent residential customers were considered low income, or about 150 percent of the Federal poverty level.
Today, On Track is two-pronged: 1,500 delinquent low-income customers are selected each year. Most of these customers receive telephone counseling, money management advice, a video cassette recorder, a series of instructive videos and a magenta box to help organize their bills. As an incentive, participants in the program are forgiven $400 against unpaid bills. Of the overall group, 250 customers, usually with debts greater than $1,000, are assigned a social worker.
The program costs slightly more than $1 million a year, said James M. Jacob, the manager of Brooklyn Union's consumer advocacy division. He said the program essentially pays for itself by reducing the company's overall collection costs. Under the auspices of Keyspan, Brooklyn Union merged last year with the Long Island Lighting Company, and has since taken the On Track program to Long Island.
Consolidated Edison, which serves three million gas, electric and steam customers in New York City and Westchester County, does not offer a similar program for its low-income customers. Con Edison is the only utility in the state that does not participate in a low-income fuel fund, though company officials say they are considering one.
Ms. Yontz, the 27-year-old daughter of an Illinois farmer, knew very little about utilities when she joined Brooklyn Union in October 1995. She had decided to become a social worker after a job in a soup kitchen, and was completing her master's degree in social work at Columbia University when she heard about the job at Brooklyn Union.
"It's really strange," Ms. Yontz said. "I feel like I say all the time, 'Yes, I am a social worker, and yes, I work for the gas company.' "
She now rattles around Brooklyn in a company sedan, calling on about 50 "clients" in a job that seems equal parts cheerleader and trouble-shooter. Usually, the people she meets hover just above poverty line: grandparents on fixed incomes or people like Ms. Chatel, whose modest income falls short of her monthly expenses.
"The goal is to teach people not to live in crisis, and maybe learn different behavior so they are not living crisis to crisis and month to month," she said.
Ms. Yontz describes part of her duties as "advocating," or navigating the social service system, whether Government or nonprofit, to find any and all benefits that a client might qualify for without knowing it. In the case of Ms. Chatel, Ms. Yontz recently brought her an application for the Federal emergency assistance program, which should earn her a few hundred dollars to meet winter bills.
In her role as adviser, Ms. Yontz says she often has to help people make difficult decisions. When she and Ms. Chatel discussed ways to earn more income, they decided to rent the two floors atop the beauty parlor to help meet the mortgage. But doing so meant telling Ms. Chatel's 26-year-old son to move out and find a job.
Gerald A. Norlander, deputy director of Public Utility Law Project, an advocacy group for low-income customers based in Albany, commended On Track as a responsible collections program. But Mr. Norlander said the Public Service Commission needs to place as much emphasis on rate reductions for the poor as on collection programs. In Massachusetts, he said low-income customers qualify for rate reductions of up to 25 percent.
"Fundamental affordability is a major issue that must be addressed, and it has not been addressed by the Public Service Commission," Mr. Norlander said. "They're only giving it lip service." The commission has planned a two-day forum in late April to discuss the potential problems facing low-income customers in a deregulated marketplace.
Dave Flanagan, a spokesman for the commission, said that officials were aware of the possible effects of a deregulated environment on poor customers, adding that the commission was experimenting with pilot programs in two upstate counties to find ways to hold down rates.
For Ms. Yontz, deregulation and its potential problems are just distant, unheard noise by the people she serves. Last week, she visited Samuel Wilson, a 92-year-old Jamaican immigrant, now an American citizen, who lives alone in a small apartment in Canarsie, Brooklyn. Mr. Wilson had received $129 every month in food stamps for more years than he can remember when, last year, the benefit inexplicably stopped.
Ms. Yontz intervened, discovering that Mr. Wilson had either failed to fill out necessary paperwork or the form simply had not been sent. She quickly organized his application and appeared at the welfare office on his behalf. While Mr. Wilson waited two months for his food stamps to be restored, Ms. Yontz and social workers from an agency for the elderly arranged for meals from a food pantry.
When Mr. Wilson's landlord recently sold the Canarsie row house, Ms. Yontz helped Mr. Wilson navigate the social-service bureaucracy, finding him a subsidized studio apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens. He will probably move later this month. "You can't imagine how happy I am to have you here today," Mr. Wilson told Ms. Yontz before she left last week. "I wish you were here all day to talk to, to cheer me up."

HEADLINE: After Whittling Income Taxes, Whitman Turns To Popular Cut

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
When Christine Todd Whitman was trying to decide between seeking an income tax cut or property tax relief during her 1993 gubernatorial campaign, her top political advisers said lowering property taxes would earn the most points with voters.
But her economic advisers, including her childhood friend, the publisher Steve Forbes, pushed for the income tax cut, arguing that it would best help the state recover the jobs lost to the recession. 
 Mrs. Whitman's plan for a 30 percent income tax cut helped her win the election that year and made her the darling of the national Republican Party. But her decision not to provide direct property tax relief during her first term angered enough voters that she nearly lost her re-election bid four years later.
By proposing last week to use $1 billion from the state budget to reduce local property taxes over the next five years, Mrs. Whitman said she had now addressed voter concerns well enough that she might just ask for a recount. Yet, she said, she has no regrets about adopting the income tax cuts first and waiting to propose the more politically popular property tax relief plan.
"It certainly would have made my life easier 18 months ago," she said in an interview at her State House office. "But the time is right now. It is because of what we have done over the last five years that we are in a position to do something more. The economy is doing well. The state is doing well."
From the moment Mrs. Whitman proposed cutting New Jersey's income tax rates in 1993, supporters and critics have debated the role that tax cuts play in stimulating the state's economy. The Governor herself concedes that the booming national economy played a major role.
"Absolutely, the national recovery helps," Mrs. Whitman said. "There is no question about that. I would be the last person to ignore that or claim that it did not have a role. But what you have to look at is the relative positions of the states, and that their internal policies and tax policies make the difference."
She pointed out that by June 1997, New Jersey had recovered all the jobs lost in the recession, something New York did not achieve until a year later.
Economists agree that Mrs. Whitman's tax cuts, including reduced corporate taxes, reinforced her message that New Jersey was "open for business."
"It is clear that New Jersey has led the region in terms of job growth and recovery," said John L. Wieting, regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The reasons are multiple and varied. It is very difficult to separate out the factors that contribute to growth. But something like tax cuts would give a perception that it is a friendly place to do business."
Joseph J. Seneca, chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisers and a vice president of Rutgers University, said that all economic indicators, from personal income growth to retail sales, have been up in the last two years.
"It is difficult to disentangle the causes of the state's strong economic performance," he said. "But there is no question that the improvement in the business climate, broadly defined, has been a significant, positive factor in the strength of our economy. The income tax cuts were an important component of that."
Jon Shure, a former top aide to Gov. Jim Florio who now runs a public policy group, New Jersey Policy Perspective, takes a different view. He said the national economic boom was coming to the state, regardless of New Jersey's income tax rates.
"When she cut the income tax, she fixed the one tax that wasn't broken," Mr. Shure said. "That helped the politician's image as a tax cutter, but the income tax in New Jersey was never so high that cutting it would have had any large economic impact."
Mr. Shure said that Mrs. Whitman should have addressed the state's heavy reliance on property taxes for local school costs. The state now pays a little more than 40 percent of the cost of public education. The national average is 50 percent.
That is the approach that Mr. Florio adopted. He raised state taxes by $2.8 billion, poured money into local schools, and found himself in the midst of a taxpayer revolt. Property taxes remained low for a couple of years, but then they began to increase.
Despite dire predictions from Democrats that Mrs. Whitman's income tax cuts would lead to skyrocketing property tax increases because fewer state dollars were going to cities, towns and schools, property tax collections statewide have slowed in the last few years. Even so, the average property tax bill in New Jersey is $4,000, the highest in the nation. There are many contributing factors, including the longstanding tradition of home rule: 566 municipalities, 611 school districts, 21 counties and 188 fire districts.
Mrs. Whitman said she decided to send rebate checks directly to homeowners rather than to dole out extra state dollars to local governments because she wants to keep pressure on them to reduce their costs.
To pay for her income tax cuts during her first term, Mrs. Whitman used several fiscal maneuvers, like a massive pension borrowing program, which raised questions among some Wall Street analysts and conservatives about the state's fiscal management.
But New Jersey, like many other states, is now flush with cash from the booming economy. The state is expected to end the fiscal year on June 30 with a budget surplus exceeding $800 million.
So both state officials and Wall Street analysts say that the Whitman administration can probably afford to pick up the cost of the property tax rebate checks in the new fiscal year.
But the size of the program raises questions about whether the next governor and future state legislatures would be able to afford it. Mrs. Whitman's second term ends in 2002, two years before the five-year program is to be fully implemented at a cost of $1 billion a year.
Under Mrs. Whitman's proposal, which is similar to the Pataki administration's property tax rebate program in New York, the average check to 1.9 million homeowners would be $600 a year, beginning in 2004. The plan would also provide tenants with an average check amounting to $100. There are no income limits. In New York, homeowners do not get rebate checks; they get a credit on their property tax bill.
Mrs. Whitman promises that if the Legislature approves the plan by April 15, she will send out the first checks by Labor Day. This year the average check would be $120, 20 percent of what a homeowner would get once the plan is fully phased in. The amount of the rebate checks would increase by 20 percent each year until 2004. The amount of local school taxes paid determines the size of the rebate checks.
The cost to the state budget begins at about $200 million in the coming fiscal year. It climbs by $200 million each year until it reaches the full cost of $1 billion annually by 2004, about 5.5 percent of the state's total budget.
Despite concerns about paying for the plan in future years, Democrats and Republican lawmakers are expected to adopt it.
Economic analysts seem to approve.
"Given the economy, and the structure of the tax system, they are generating pretty large surpluses," said Timothy Blake, vice president of Moody's Investors Service. "They seem to be disposing of the surpluses prudently. We changed our outlook from negative to stable in September 1998 and that was in reflection of the fact that structural balance has improved."
Mrs. Whitman said she did not think future lawmakers and governors would consider eliminating the rebate checks. "I believe that this is going to be a priority for state government because it is going to be a priority for the people," she said.

HEADLINE: Thomas Binford, 74, Executive Who Guided Indianapolis 500

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
Thomas W. Binford, an Indianapolis businessman who was a co-founder of that city's Urban League and who helped steer the Indianapolis 500 through two crises, died on Thursday in Indianapolis. He was 74.
The cause was a cerebral hemorrhage. Mr. Binford was stricken on Wednesday at the downtown Indianapolis office of Binford and Associates, his management consulting firm, and died at Methodist Hospital. 
 Mr. Binford, an Indianapolis native, was one of the city's leaders in civil rights, education and downtown development. As chairman of Indiana National Bank, which was purchased in 1992 by NBD Bancorp of Detroit, he saw it through a rocky period in the mid-1970's caused by failed real-estate loans.
After helping establish the Urban League of Indianapolis in 1965, he was its chairman twice, and also was chairman of numerous companies.
From 1956 to 1969 he was president of the United States Auto Club, which was the Indianapolis 500's sanctioning body, and was chief steward of the race from 1974 to 1995. In each role, he helped keep the race going.
After an accident killed more than 100 spectators during the 1955 24-hour sports car race in Le Mans, the American Automobile Association decided to end its role as overseer of auto racing competition in the United States. The pullout left the Indianapolis 500 with no sanctioning group to set the rules and see that they were enforced. To fill that void, the United States Auto Club was formed, with Mr. Binford as one of its founders.
Mr. Binford was called back to the Indianapolis 500 after the chaotic, rain-delayed 1973 race, which included crashes that killed two drivers and a crew member and injured 11 spectators. Public sentiment ran strongly against the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, with some newspaper editorials questioning whether the track should be shut down. The blame fell upon the chief steward, Harlan Fengler, although the speedway itself had safety shortcomings outside his control. Six days before the 1974 race, Mr. Binford was chosen to replace Mr. Fengler.
Mr. Binford made procedural changes that, along with upgrades to the track, eased safety concerns. And he did not hesitate to make decisions that might cause an uproar, as two episodes demonstrated.
The day after the 1981 race, Mr. Binford penalized the apparent winner, Bobby Unser, one lap for an illegal pass, a ruling that gave the victory to Mario Andretti. It would have been the only time since the race began in 1911 that an apparent winner had his victory taken away. But in October of that year, Mr. Binford's ruling was overturned on appeal, and Mr. Unser was reinstated as the winner.
"It wasn't hard to call," Mr. Binford said later of the penalty, "except you knew the minute you called it you were in for a lot of problems."
In his final race as chief steward in 1995, Mr. Binford gave a black flag to the leader, Scott Goodyear, with a handful of laps remaining after Goodyear passed the pace car too soon. That gave the victory to Jacques Villeneuve and brought bitter criticism from Goodyear. Videotape replays supported the ruling.
Mr. Binford is survived by his wife, Kai; a son, Wilson C. Binford of Zionsville, Ind.; a daughter, Florence W. Kichler of Carmel, Ind.; a stepdaughter, Linda Kai Miller; a stepson, Bryan Irwin, and a sister, Virginia Binford Turner.

HEADLINE: Double-Edged Economic Crisis Whipsaws Brazil Workers and Companies

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SAO BERNARDO DO CAMPO, Brazil, Jan. 16

 BODY:
For 22 years and 4 months, Luiz Porfirio Diniz reported daily to the bustling Ford do Brasil automotive plant here, where three different car models are manufactured. But then just before Christmas, he got the bad news he had been fearing ever since Brazilian interest rates shot to nearly 50 percent four months ago: He was one of 2,800 assembly-line workers being laid off.
Employees took over the plant on Jan. 5 to protest that move, so Mr. Diniz still spends his day on the plant floor, playing dominos with his fellow workers. The stoppage means that Ford is no longer producing its daily quota of 1,000 cars, but the company has not moved against the workers -- perhaps because car sales are declining so dramatically in Brazil that Ford has the equivalent of nearly two months of production stockpiled in storage areas here. 
 "Everybody wants to work, so all they have to do is give us the word," said Valdecir Aparecido de Souza, another laid-off worker. "But if nobody is spending any money, management is not going to take us back, and we're not going to be able to find jobs anywhere else. It's a real mess."
The crisis that has shaken Brazil in recent months, culminating this week in a 21 percent devaluation of a country's currency, the real, is first and foremost a threat to workers and their families. But for that very reason, it also represents a growing danger for the hundreds of multinational companies that have flocked to Brazil and invested billions of dollars in recent years, lured by a market of 165 million people with sustained growth and stable prices.
Though all of Brazil is now reeling, the once-flourishing automobile industry, centered here in the industrial suburbs south of Sao Paulo, which produced as many as two million vehicles a year at its peak, was hit early and particularly hard. Car sales in Brazil, the world's seventh-largest auto market, slumped 27.5 percent last year, falling from 1.64 million to 1.19 million, with Ford registering an even larger decline, 33.8 percent.
James R. Cain, a Ford spokesman in Detroit, said the elimination of a shift at the factory here and the resulting layoffs were driven by the conclusion that "we did not believe there would be any substantive improvement in the market in 1999." The company lost money in Brazil in 1998, Mr. Cain said, and it indicated to Wall Street analysts at a briefing on Jan. 7, even before the major devaluation announced Friday, that it was unlikely to earn a profit in Brazil this year either.
Brazil's top car maker, Volkswagen, is also suffering from a sharp decline in demand, but last month negotiated an agreement with its workers here to reduce pay by 15 percent rather than cut jobs. .
For Brazil's 275,000 auto workers, once considered the elite of the working class, that means hard times after years of hard-won improvements in their standard of living. "Yesterday, I was dreaming," reads the bumper sticker on a car parked outside the Ford factory here. "Today I can't even sleep."
Mr. Diniz, 44, who is married with two children, is typical. Born in the impoverished northeastern state of Paraiba, he, like millions of others hoping for a better life, came to Sao Paulo as a teen-ager, and by working hard and scrimping, he managed to buy his own house and car.
"I love Ford and think of it as family," he said as he other workers gathered at the Bar do Pascual, outside the plant's gate. "I grew up with this company, so being in this situation is enough to make me cry."
Recent years had been especially good, he and other workers said. The Government's Real Plan, announced in 1994, tied the value of Brazil's currency to the dollar, forcing a level of fiscal discipline that cut inflation from over 1,000 percent a year in the early 1990's to single digits.
"Bringing down inflation made it easier for people like us to buy food, clothing and appliances," said Adailton Coelho dos Santos, 55, who works on the same line as Mr. Diniz and also came from the northeast. "For the first time in our lives, we were able to figure out what our money was worth."
As a result, millions of Brazilians could finally afford to buy televisions, refrigerators, furniture and other consumer goods, secure in the knowledge that their monthly payments would not outstrip their wages. But measures taken by the Government over the past six months, especially the dramatic interest rate increase, have driven the Brazilian economy into recession and forced consumers to economize.
"We have lots of members who can no longer meet their rent or mortgage payments, let alone think about buying appliances," said Luiz Marinho, president of the metalworkers union of Sao Bernardo, which represents auto workers. "We have guys who have had to postpone their weddings because they don't have a cent to spend anymore."
For American companies, the belt-tightening by working-class Brazilians is nothing but bad news. Brazil is the United States' 15th-largest trading partner, and in recent years it has been one of the fastest-growing markets for American-made goods, importing more than $14 billion in 1997, ranging from equipment for heavy industry to potato chips.
American banks also have a heavy exposure. As of mid-1998, they had about $16.7 billion in loans and other assets outstanding in Brazil, with Citicorp, Chase Manhattan Bank and BankAmerica each reporting more than $3 billion in assets here.
The situation is especially alarming for the estimated 2,000 American businesses operating in Brazil, which has Latin America's largest economy. American concerns have more than $27 billion invested here, giving them a higher profile here than in other troubled areas like Russia or Southeast Asia, and weak results this year, now expected to be the general rule as a result of this week's economic turmoil, could affect their profit statements back home.
Whirlpool and General Electric, for instance, manufacture appliances like refrigerators, stoves and microwave ovens. Companies like Johnson & Johnson and Procter & Gamble make a wide variety of toiletries and cosmetics.
At their factories north of Sao Paulo, Motorola, Lucent, Qualcomm and other companies turn out telecommunications equipment like cellular phones, whose availability has increased dramatically as the result of the privatization of Brazil's telephone system last year. With the market for computers here having grown by as much as 30 percent a year recently, computer makers like Compaq and Dell have also installed themselves in Brazil.
But the sudden and dramatic downturn raises the question of whether American, European and Japanese companies that have flocked here in recent years may now have too much manufacturing capacity installed in Brazil. Or as Pedro Reis Correa, a 39-year-old assembly line worker, put it: "If all of us are unemployed, who is going to buy the products these companies make?"
For Christmas, Mr. Correa, who earns a salary of about $1,000 a month, had planned to buy a computer, mostly for use by his two children, ages 8 and 11. He had even obtained a bargain price through a nephew who works for a computer manufacturer and saved up the down payment that would have allowed him to buy the $1,600 machine on an installment plan.
But when he received the layoff notice, he had to tell the children that "this is going to have to wait for some other time," he recalled sorrowfully. "I am trying to cut expenses as much as I can, and that means no more car trips to the interior on weekend or movies or candy bars for the kids."
Antonio Carlos Santos knows only too well the effects of decisions like that. For the past four years, he has parked every day outside the entrance to the Ford plant here, and from the back of his beat-up station wagon, sold items like kitchen knives, watches, videocassettes and toys to the workers, with gross sales of about $1,300 a month.
"My sales are down 50 percent in the past month, so of course I am very worried," he said on Friday morning, as a constant drizzle added to his woes by driving his few potential customers indoors. "If the money of the workers here dries up, then people like me are going to go bust. This situation affects everybody."
Mr. Santos said his family too has begun economizing, anticipating that the situation is going to worsen before it improves. "We're eating less meat and more rice and beans, buying cheaper brands of shampoo and soap, doing everything we can to save a penny here and there," he said.
That is not what companies like Coca-Cola or Nabisco, which derives about 17 percent of its worldwide sales from Brazil, want to hear. Brazil is Coke's second-largest overseas market, accounting for about 5 percent of its worldwide profits.
As recently as 1995, Coke's sales in Brazil expanded by a spectacular 34 percent. But growth was estimated at only 1 percent for last year, and with people like Mr. Santos and his family determined to drink less, the most optimistic projection for this year is flat sales. Furthermore, the money Coca-Cola takes in here is earned in the now drastically devalued local currency.
It is not clear how Friday's decision by the Brazilian Government to allow the real to float freely against the dollar will affect other companies. In theory, the long-urged devaluation of the real should make Brazilian exports cheaper across the board and therefore more attractive than those of competitors, while also encouraging investment by making Brazilian companies available at bargain prices to foreign purchasers.
But economists have expressed concerns that the devaluation of the real could set off a chain reaction across Latin America and the rest of the developing world, with country after country trying to gain a competitive advantage by lowering the value of its currency. In addition, the price of the components, raw materials and finished goods that Brazil buys will now go up, fueling inflation here and cutting consumer purchasing power further.
Thousands of Brazilians who bought cars on installment opted for financing terms pegging monthly payments to the exchange rate between the dollar and the real. They now must pay much more each month or try to sell their cars before they are repossessed, and the crisis is likely to drive many potential buyers out of the market altogether.
"When the population is frightened and stops consuming, things can only get worse," Mr. Marinho said. "That's what we are confronting right now, a moment that threatens to erase all of the gains we have made."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Kelly Maintains Loyalty as Twins Disintegrate

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
A few years ago Jim Leyland grew tired of losing with no break in sight and parlayed his unhappiness into a World Series championship and then a $2 million-a-year job. Tom Kelly is no less tired of losing than Leyland was, but as loyal as Leyland was initially, Kelly has remained so loyal he is going down with the ship.
It's not a Viking ship. The Vikings are the successful Minnesota team, the one playing in a conference championship game in the Twins' ball park today. Kelly didn't plan to be at the game, but it wasn't a case of sour grapes. 
 "Many years ago Jerry Burns and I were pretty close friends," Kelly related, referring to a former Vikings head coach. "I used to go to all the games. The last game he was coaching, they were playing the Packers and both teams were around .500. It was the man's last game. The Packers were ahead, 20-0, at the end of the first half, and the Vikings, in my mind, didn't show up. I thought that was a sad display of football. I left the building and never went back to another game. I just had a bad feeling that day. I couldn't understand the effort that day."
Effort has always played a major role in Kelly's style of managing. It will be an even bigger component during the coming season.
"There's still a lot to be said about playing the game the right way, doing things right on the field," Kelly said. "We're going make sure we do all of those things. I don't know if that's going to put people in the building, but the ones who show up deserve that."
The Twins, who last season had the third-poorest won-lost record in the American League, aren't expected to fare any better in 1999. Kelly, whose 12-year tenure in Minnesota is the longest of any current professional manager or coach, could have thrown himself on the mercy of the owner, Carl Pohlad, and asked out. But he did not.
"Some people call it stupidity; some call it loyalty," Kelly said. "I haven't decided which it is with me."
To make the manager's plight even more dire, his team became worse not long after Kelly reaffirmed his intention to remain with the Twins.
"A couple weeks after the season, the owner asked me to stay," the 48-year-old Kelly said. "He outlined a little plan he had. It was my understanding we were going to keep the shortstop, and we didn't do that. That was the only thing I was disappointed about.
The shortstop is Pat Meares, who last year had a $2.5 million salary and would have gained about a $1 million raise through salary arbitration. But when the Boston Red Sox gave Jose Offerman, a free-agent infielder, $26 million for four years, the prospect of a much bigger raise prompted the Twins to sever ties with Meares, who has yet to sign with another team.
A hefty salary for their shortstop would have made it impossible for the Twins to reach Pohlad's desired payroll level of $10 million to $15 million. That was the "little plan" the owner outlined after the season for Kelly, who said he understood the reasoning. Their $24.5 million payroll didn't get the Twins anywhere last season, and raising it to $30 million or so would not have made a difference, Kelly said.
So why did he decide to keep his job?
"We're comfortable here," Kelly said, referring to himself and his wife, Sharon. "We enjoy it here. My wife has family here. My son lives here. Personally I have a lot of money tied up here. My people explained if I move, I'm going to lose a lot of money that's tied up in bonds and different things. So you add it all up and ask is it economically important to move? No."
Yes, Kelly acknowledged, he probably would have a better chance to win elsewhere. But, he added, "I weighed everything and decided we'd stay here and do what the owner asked me to do."
But he really would like to have had Meares's stabilizing leadership in the infield. "I'll try to remedy that situation," Kelly said. "I'll see what we have in spring training."
Kelly, who also has lost Paul Molitor's overall team leadership, will have plenty to scrutinize in spring training. Will Denny Hocking, a good utility player, be able to replace Meares on an everyday basis? Is Doug Mientkiewicz ready to play first base regularly? How about Corey Koskie at third? Can Torii Hunter win the center field job?
Perhaps most important of all, can Marty Cordova, who has salaries totaling $6.75 million the next two years, find the bat that made him rookie of the year in 1995 and an even better hitter the next season but has deserted him the past two years?
Then there's the team's No. 1 pitcher, Brad Radke, whose record plummeted from 20-10 to 12-14. The Twins have been reported to be considering trading Radke, but Kelly said Terry Ryan, the team's general manager, had not said anything to him about such a plan.
"He might be afraid to," Kelly said, still able to joke in the face of adversity.
 
Mystery Buyer He Isn't
 The anonymous telephone caller to the sports department of The New York Times said he knew who bought the $3 million baseball, the one Mark McGwire hit for his 70th home run that had been auctioned the night before. Who was it? Allan Byer, the called said.
Because the person who made the winning bid -- via telephone -- had chosen to remain anonymous, this tip was worth pursuing.
Allan Byer is a limited partner in the ownership of the San Francisco Giants. He also owns a clothing company and is in real estate. A call was placed to his home in the San Francisco area. His wife answered and said he wasn't home. Did she know if he bought the McGwire ball?
"If he did," she replied, obviously amused by the idea, "he hasn't told me. That's funny, but the answer is no. I'm sure he hasn't gone completely insane over baseball, just a little."
Another call was then placed to Byer's son, Alex, who also is a Giants limited partner.
"You got to be kidding me," Alex Byer said, laughing. "Oh, that's absurd. That is outlandish. Maybe if the ball was 100 bucks."
When Allan Byer was finally reached, he didn't laugh but said it was not he who won the bidding. Why would someone think he could be the $3 million man?
"I collect baseballs," Byer said. "I have about 900."
To put his collection in economic perspective, Byer said he had never determined the value of his collection but added, "If it's $100,000, that would be a lot."
His baseballs, he explained, are mostly from the 1940's through the 70's, the time when baseball most magnetically held his interest. His most valuable ball ($5,000, he estimated) is one with Mel Ott's autograph.
"For me," he said, "that's an expensive ball. I'm not about to spend $3 million for a baseball. Even if I could afford it, I wouldn't do it. It doesn't make any kind of sense."
At least Mrs. Byer knows her husband.
 
A Jordan 2-Pointer
 Michael Jordan will be remembered for far different reasons, but he may have an unusual position in sports history: He most likely is the only player to retire from two sports during labor disputes.
Although Jordan didn't announce his basketball retirement until after the lockout had ended, he knew during the work stoppage that he would not resume work when the league did. Nearly four years ago, he retired from his short-lived baseball career during the players strike and as a direct result of it.
Jordan went to spring training with the Chicago White Sox minor leaguers in 1995, but he became increasingly uncomfortable because it appeared he would be labeled a replacement player, a designation and a reputation he wanted no part of.
"That's just not what I'm here for," Jordan said on his first day in camp when the subject of replacement games arose. "I've always said I wouldn't be a replacement player. I don't consider myself one being here. I consider myself a minor leaguer. That's why I'm here."
But as exhibition games approached and it became clear that major league players would consider anyone who played in them replacement players, Jordan decided it was time to go. And he went -- back to the National Basketball Association, whose commissioner, David Stern, nearly four years later tried to frighten the locked-out players by threatening to use replacement players.
 
Phillips Fallout?
 Ever since their general manager was accused of sexual harassment in November, a charge Steve Phillips denied, the Mets have been ultra-sensitive. They recently conducted employee seminars, for example, on club policies, including sexual harassment.
There was also a rumor last week that the Mets plan to ban sex magazines, including the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue, from their clubhouse. David Howard, the club's senior vice president for business and legal affairs, declined to confirm or deny the rumor.
"I cannot comment," he said, "about how our policies would be applied in any instance."
If the Mets do plan a ban on sex magazines, they most likely will encounter opposition from the Players Association.
Asked if the union had a position on such club actions, Gene Orza, the No. 2 official, said: "If magazines of any kind were allowed previously, if one of their working conditions was that magazines were allowed, this would be a change and would have to be negotiated with the union. They can't stop serving free food or not allow employees to have cell phones. They can negotiate those things with us, but they can't make unilateral changes."
The players could always sneak the magazines into the clubhouse and read them under cover of politically correct periodicals.
