SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 971 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Click for Customer Service. Then Wish You Hadn't.

BYLINE: By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
IF on-line retailers steamrolled their way into the spotlight during the past holiday season, one thing is clear: They crushed a few toes along the way.
Consumers have long lamented the state of customer service on line, but perhaps never as vociferously as in the last two months. Stories abound of vendors that shipped products late, sent the wrong item and then ignored complaints, or that required customers to pay the cost of returning goods and then tacked on restocking charges. And then there's the loathsome E-mail "auto response," with advice on everything but what the customer asked about. 
 Asked to summarize on-line customer service in a word, David Cooperstein, senior analyst with Forrester Research, an Internet consulting firm, responded: "Pathetic."
Web sites have the powerful advantage of making companies seem accessible and easy to interact with. It's an appearance that all kinds of companies, not just retailers, can have trouble living up to. Brightware, an E-mail software company, reported in a study released on Thursday that when it tried to reach the 100 largest American public companies by E-mail, 26 either did not accept E-mail or made it so difficult to find the E-mail forms on their Web sites that the surveyors gave up trying. Of the remainder, only 15 responded within three hours; 10 didn't reply at all.
Matthew Garelick of Somerville, Mass., knows the frustration of unrequited E-mail. In early December he ordered the movie "Out of Sight" on DVD from Bigstar Entertainment, an on-line retailer. Between Dec. 28 and Dec. 30, Mr. Garelick sent E-mail to Bigstar three times, asking why the movie hadn't arrived. "I would've been fine with an auto response," said Mr. Garelick, who eventually received the disk in January. "I just wanted an assurance that they were at least working on it. From now on, I'm not doing business on line with anyone who doesn't have a phone number."
Having a number to call was small comfort to Duke Nguyen of Cincinnati. Mr. Nguyen said he ordered three items from the Internet site of Intuit in early December and then tried to change his order by phone. "Every time, after 20 or so minutes of waiting, I gave up," he said. He tried faxing in his order change. But, he said, the original items were delivered. "Finally, I called and just put on my speaker phone while I waited," he said. After an hour someone answered and he was able to arrange a return. But then Intuit credited him for less than the full value of the goods, he said. He tried a new E-mail button on Intuit's site but got an automated response suggesting, among other things, that he call customer service.
"I'm computer literate," Mr. Nguyen said. "But when it comes to service, these things scare the heck out of me."
Analysts and industry leaders say problems often occur because companies rush to get products and prices onto their Web sites while underestimating the time and resources needed for customer service.
But David Levipsky, executive vice president of Bigstar, said that wasn't the case with his site. The company had anticipated a holiday rush by installing a "very cutting-edge" E-mail system, he said, adding, "So it's surprising to me that this happened."
As for Intuit, Larry Wolfe, senior vice president for the company's tax software division, said the company does the best it can. "Often in December and January, there are times when people wait longer than we'd like them to wait," he said. "But we take it very seriously, and we work very hard to keep call times down."
Analysts say poorly designed Web sites draw complaints. "If a site is designed well, most of the complaints don't happen," said Mr. Cooperstein of Forrester, noting that many sites fail to offer enough information so that customers can help themselves.
THE good news for consumers, analysts say, is that Internet merchants are learning two lessons: that ignoring E-mail is the best way to turn customers into enemies, and that improving Web sites is more cost effective than dedicating battalions of employees to answer complaints.
"The E-mail deluge everybody was worried about we looked at as a total gift," said Matt Hyde, director for on-line sales at REI, a retailer of outdoor goods. "We've made hundreds of changes to our site based on customer service data."
A result: The ratio of E-mail to orders at REI dropped sharply, he said, and so did payroll costs for customer service.
Dell Computer uses both software and employees to answer most of its 10,000 weekly E-mails within a day of receipt, said Manish Mehta, a senior on-line support manager. Its Web site features self-service information like technical support tips.
Shoppers are becoming less tolerant of poor service from on-line retailers. "Consumer expectations have definitely grown, because certain sites have set a high standard," said Jakob Nielsen, a site design expert and publisher. "Fair or unfair, other sites have to live up to that standard."
Perhaps so. But Kent Krueger, co-founder of the Sitstay GoOut Store, said sites that are honest with consumers can weather service problems. Sitstay, which sells specialty products to dog owners, was the only Web site to get a five-star rating for customer support among 500 rated in December by Bizrate, a market research company that surveys on-line shoppers. "We started selling doormats with little Yorkies on them and got a huge number of orders that we weren't prepared for," Mr. Krueger said. "So we got in touch with everyone and told them who we were, what had happened, and we were working on it." As a result, he said, no customers canceled orders.
"The fact is, if you're honest and have a little fun, people will have a good attitude," he added. "But it could also be that dog owners are just a different breed."

HEADLINE: Treasury to Auction Just Bills This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills. The financial markets are closed today in observance of Martin Luther King Jr. Day.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.31 percent and a six-month bill was 4.27 percent.

HEADLINE: Just What Constitutes a Consumer Stranglehold?

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The Microsoft trial is a high-stakes exercise in legal warfare and the witnesses are foot soldiers. On each side they are advocates, committed to winning and thoroughly coached.
And no one expects that honesty will be presented in its undiluted form -- "the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth." Instead, the witnesses generally offer their facts and opinions selectively. 
 So when a moment of unbiased honesty occurred at the trial last week, it seemed almost endearing.
The Government's final witness, Franklin M. Fisher, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist, was asked if there was any present harm to consumers as a result of Microsoft business practices.
That is difficult to measure, Mr. Fisher replied. But after pausing a moment, this Government witness added, "On balance, I'd think that the answer is no up to this point."
Later, Mr. Fisher did say that he thought that Microsoft's restrictive contracts with computer makers and Internet service suppliers had the effect of reducing choice in the market for software used to browse the World Wide Web by unfairly blocking its rival, Netscape Communications, from key channels of distribution. Yet his main point was that most of what he believes will be the damage to consumers -- in higher prices and reduced choice -- from Microsoft's actions will come in the future.
Still, Mr. Fisher's comment did underline where the two sides differ on key issues. The Government contends that Microsoft has a "choke hold" on software distribution and that consumers will be harmed unless it is reined in. Microsoft replies that the Government has produced no real proof on either front.
Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson must sift through the conflicting assertions and evidence from both sides to reach a verdict, guided in large measure by antitrust doctrine and the case law that has built up around it. The challenge, though, is that just how the doctrine and the case law apply to the Microsoft case is by no means clear cut.
Take the issue of consumer harm. Microsoft's leadoff witness, Richard L. Schmalensee, dean of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management, testified last week that there was no evidence of consumer damage from Microsoft's conduct and the suggestion that there might be in the future was "sheer speculation."
In court, the Government did produce evidence showing that the price Microsoft charges computer makers for its Windows operating system had increased in recent years, even as the price of other PC components had declined. But Windows still accounts for less than 5 percent of the price of most PC's and, as Microsoft asserts, it has improved Windows over the years.
Showing measurable harm to consumers, antitrust experts say, is less important in a Federal antitrust suit than it would be in a private case. The Justice Department and 19 states suing Microsoft, unlike a private plaintiff, are not seeking financial damages. Instead, they are seeking court-ordered sanctions to curb what they say is Microsoft's abuse of its monopoly power.
To do that, the Government must convincingly show "the power and conditions from which injury can be inferred," according to Herbert Hovenkamp, a University of Iowa law professor. "Under antitrust law, we assume that markets operate more efficiently for the benefit of consumers under competition," said Mr. Hovenkamp, a consultant to the Government in the Microsoft case.
The Justice Department charges that Microsoft's contracts with computer makers and others unfairly limited Netscape's access to key channels of distribution. Microsoft replies, as Mr. Schmalensee testified, that it does not have "any significant market power over software distribution," noting that Netscape distributed more than 100 million copies of its browser last year.
Exclusive distribution deals, in most cases, are not illegal providing they do not foreclose rivals from a significant share of product distribution. Microsoft's argument is that despite its deals, Netscape could widely distribute its browser over the Internet, by direct mail and in its own deals.
A Federal appeals court ruling in 1997, Omega Environmental Inc. v. Gilbarco Inc., does seem to support that stance. The defendant, Gilbarco, a leading producer of gas pumps, had exclusive deals with nearly 40 percent of the nation's gas pump distributors. But in ruling for Gilbarco, the court noted that gas pump makers had other possible channels of distribution, like selling directly to gas stations. If competitors can reach consumers by other means, it wrote, "it is unclear whether such restrictions foreclose from competition any part of the relevant market."
The Government, however, argues that when a company, like Microsoft, has a powerful monopoly position,the prosecution does not have to show the company tied up, say, 40 percent or more of the distribution. For monopolists, the Supreme Court in 1985 endorsed a stricter standard, ruling in Aspen Skiing Company v. Aspen Highlands Skiing Corporation that a contract is illegal if it "unnecessarily excludes or handicaps competitors."
The Government also asserts that expense, difficulty and quality of access to distribution are issues in determining whether Microsoft's contracts unfairly exclude rivals. Downloading a browser for an hour from a Web site is an alternative distribution channel, but it is no match for getting a browser bundled with Windows on a new PC.
"Microsoft is pointing to all the other paths of distribution and undoubtedly takes comfort from the Gilbarco case," said William Kovacic, a professor at the George Washington University Law School. "But its contracts could still be found to be significantly anticompetitive. The law is by no means absolutely clear."

HEADLINE: Martin Luther King Jr.'s America

 BODY:
For many young Americans, the heroic life and tragic death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. are historical artifacts from the turbulent 1960's, distant chapters in the multi-volume history of the American experiment. In the decades since then, the ranks of those with vivid memories of the human rights struggle Dr. King waged in the South and up North have thinned. Yet neither of these circumstances should nudge Americans toward allowing each year's observance of his birthday to morph into another three-day get-away weekend.
Today's religious ceremonies and commemorative speeches have value in and of themselves. But in the long run, it is more important for Americans of all classes, colors and creeds to recommit themselves to Dr. King's unfinished human rights agenda. From Jasper, Tex., where a black man was dragged to death behind a pickup truck to the abyss between whites and blacks in income and wealth, one does not have to look far to find the damage done by intolerance and discrimination. 
 It is not possible to divine how Dr. King would assess these United States in 1999. Yet his words remind us that continuing to inch toward a color-blind, equitable society requires so much more than court rulings and laws. In a 1968 essay, published posthumously and entitled "A Testament of Hope," he dissected the riddle that bedevils American society to this day.
"Why is the issue of equality still so far from solution in America, a nation that professes itself to be democratic, inventive, hospitable to new ideas, rich, productive and awesomely powerful?" Dr. King asked. "The problem is so tenacious because, despite its virtues and attributes, America is deeply racist and its democracy is flawed both economically and socially. All too many Americans believe justice will unfold painlessly or that its absence for black people will be tolerated tranquilly."
Fresh evidence of the persistence of racism is visible in the predicament of Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi. The Senate majority leader has fumbled numerous opportunities to clarify his links to the white separatist group called the Council of Conservative Citizens. Rather than apologize for giving speeches to a racist organization or explain why he allowed the Mississippi group to use his name, he chose the path of obfuscation.
Through a spokesman, Mr. Lott said he had "no firsthand knowledge" of the C.C.C.'s thinly veiled white supremacist agenda. Mr. Lott's uncle, Arnie Watson, said otherwise. Mr. Watson told The Times's John Kifner last week that his nephew, the Senator, was "an honorary member" of the group and had spoken at its meetings. Others with ties to this group include Gov. Kirk Fordice of Mississippi and Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, both Republicans. Representative Bob Barr of Georgia has also been criticized for speaking before the group.
After a month of questions, Senator Lott released a statement that broadly condemned bigotry, declaring "I have made my condemnation of the white supremacist and racist view of this group, or any group, clear. . . ." His shifting explanations suggest that he knew it was wrong to appear before the group, but did so to curry favor and political support. To preserve respect for his office, Senator Lott needs to repudiate the C.C.C., a direct descendant of the Citizens Councils that opposed the Supreme Court's 1954 school desegregation decision. Until he does so, he will inevitably raise questions about his fairness in leading the United States Senate, an institution that ought to be wholeheartedly committed to Martin Luther King's unfinished agenda.

HEADLINE: 'Pentagon Maverick' Sounds Alarm

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Not much has changed in the small office in the Pentagon where Franklin C. Spinney has worked ever since he gained a bit of notoriety in the 1980's with this jolting argument: All the money President Ronald Reagan was pouring into defense would not make the military any stronger.
Congress held hearings. His bosses made him a celebrity by trying to quash his views. Time magazine called him a "Pentagon Maverick" on a cover in 1983. Still, Mr. Reagan's military spending spree went on. 
 Now, nearly two decades later, President Clinton has proposed the first increase in the Pentagon's budget since 1991 and the largest since those heady days: $12 billion in new spending in 2000, and $110 billion over the next six years. And Mr. Spinney, still a mid-grade analyst in the Pentagon's Office of Program Analysis and Evaluation, is once again raising an alarm.
"This is a horrible thing that's going on," Mr. Spinney said in an interview in his cramped, cluttered office deep inside the Pentagon's concentric rings. "All it's going to do is reward the pathological behavior that's creating the problem."
In the weeks since Mr. Clinton announced his plan to raise the Pentagon's budget, criticisms like Mr. Spinney's have been rare, exceedingly rare within the government.
At a recent hearing before the Senate's Committee on Armed Services, no senator spoke out against the increase. In fact, the loudest criticism of Mr. Clinton's proposal on Capitol Hill has come from Republicans who have argued that the President needs to pledge more to defense.
"I don't understand what all the crowing is about," Senator Robert C. Smith, Republican of New Hampshire, said at the hearing.
Before the Administration and Congress open the defense spending spigot, though, Mr. Spinney and a diverse group of advocates and analysts have begun to make a case against an increase.
Some of them argue that increasing defense spending is unnecessary since no new threat like the Soviet Union has emerged. Others say new spending will ease pressure to cut the Pentagon's inefficiencies and waste. Still others say that in a time of relative peace, the nation should devote its resources to education or other social causes.
A group called Business Leaders for Sensible Priorities began broadcasting a 30-second television commercial calling for just that. The first advertisements appeared on Friday and more are scheduled to run on Monday and Tuesday, coinciding with Mr. Clinton's State of the Union message to be delivered on Tuesday evening.
Ben Cohen of Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., a longtime critic of large defense budgets and one of the leaders of the group, said the White House, the Pentagon and the Congress were spending money as if the cold war had never ended.
"The United States is now, literally, in an arms race with itself," Mr. Cohen said.
Mr. Clinton's proposal, which will be outlined in detail when he submits a budget proposal to Congress early next month, would increase the Defense Department's budget to about $268 billion in 2000.
That is only $4 billion more than the currently projected level of $264 billion, but Mr. Clinton has also agreed to let the department keep an additional $8 billion in savings freed as a result of fuel savings and lower-than-expected inflation.
Mr. Clinton, a Democrat who has had an uneasy relationship with the military, agreed to an increase after Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen and the nation's military commanders warned that dwindling resources since the collapse of the Soviet Union had strained the military's "readiness."
Mr. Spinney and other critics say that a political consensus has formed around having an increase, even though there has been very little debate about the need for one.
Andrew F. Krepinevich, executive director of the Center for Strategic and Budgetary Assessments, a research organization in Washington, said the Pentagon's budget still reflects a military preparing for major regional conflicts with the most advanced jets, tanks and ships.
Future enemies, however, are not likely to match the United States technologically. Instead, he argues, they will confront American forces with cheaper weapons, like missiles or mines, that are harder to counter.
"To me, the greatest challenge isn't a budgetary one," Mr. Krepinevich said. "It's a strategic one."
What makes Mr. Spinney's criticism unusual is that it comes from inside the Pentagon, where politics, bureaucracy and military obedience discourage most public dissent.
Mr. Spinney's argument -- his apostasy -- is that the Pentagon plans to spend billions of dollars to build new weapons that have become so complicated and costly that it cannot buy enough of them to replace today's arsenal. That means tomorrow's military will have to get by with fewer new weapons, while relying on older weapons to last longer. Meanwhile, the cost of operating the advanced new weapons keeps rising.
He calls this the "defense death spiral."
Mr. Spinney does not dispute reports that the armed services face readiness problems caused by backlogged repairs, shortages of parts and growing wear and tear. Instead, he blames the underlying strains caused by the increasing costs.
"Spending more money the same way isn't going to fix anything," Mr. Spinney said.
Mr. Spinney, 53, has broken with orthodoxy almost from the day in 1977 that he arrived at the Pentagon's Office of Program Analysis and Evaluation, an office first conceived by Robert S. McNamara in 1961 to provide independent assessments.
His own career began in the military, making him an unlikely firebrand. He spent eight years in the Air Force after graduating from Lehigh University in 1967 with a degree in engineering.
Early on, though, he fell in with a band of like-minded people, who became well-known on Capitol Hill and in the media for challenging conventional wisdom at what Mr. Spinney calls "Versailles on the Potomac."
At the peak of President Reagan's buildup, he argued that the Pentagon persistently underestimated the future costs of weapons, thus saddling the nation with ever-growing defense budgets. After appearing before the House and Senate, he lost his parking permit and, for a time, access to budget figures, but his notoriety and civil-service rules protected his job.
The end of the cold war allowed the Pentagon to reduce the size of the military and its budgets. Mr. Spinney, like others, believes the Pentagon did not take full advantage of the opportunity to reconsider plans to modernize its arsenal with weapons originally conceived to fight a superpower like the Soviet Union.
The Air Force, he says by way of example, now plans to spend $35 billion to build 339 F-22 fighter jets, even though there is no real challenger to America's best jets today. By comparison, the force spent only $45 billion to build 1,094 F-15 fighters, which are still considered to be among the best jets in the air. Likewise, he argues that the Navy has retired aging, though still usable attack submarines to make room for fewer, more expensive versions.
Within the Pentagon, Mr. Spinney has little official influence. He is rarely called on to provide officials with critiques of programs. One official, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity, said he had made the same arguments for so long that it was easy for officials in the hierarchy to dismiss them.
"They basically ignore me," Mr. Spinney said.
Still, he gets his views out -- by E-mail. His electronic critiques on budget and other matters ricochet around the Pentagon and Congress. Christopher Helman, senior analyst at the Center for Defense Information, another research group that has opposed the spending increase, said Mr. Spinney's critiques had a purpose nonetheless.
"He serves to generate some critical dialogue that would not otherwise occur," Mr. Helman said.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Is Dome Plan For West Side Doomed?

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
BEFORE discussing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's new plan for a domed stadium next to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, I should disclose a conflict of interest. Three years ago I proposed using that West Side waterfront for a different urban renewal project: the New York XXXposition Center.
That proposal, to create a red-light district by moving all of the city's adult businesses into the Javits Center and the adjoining land, was not immediately greeted with public enthusiasm. At the time, I wondered if it was too bold and impractical, but now I see that the XXXposition proposal was too timid. The project seems pitifully mundane compared with the Mayor's. 
 Mr. Giuliani last week proposed erecting a domed football stadium, plopping a new and bigger Madison Square Garden alongside it, and extending a subway line to it. He didn't bother estimating its cost, but he was sure it would make money. The stadium would be linked to the Javits Center, Mr. Giuliani explained, and used to hold enormous conventions that "alone would pay for the cost of this development."
The convention angle was a good public relations move, because stadiums purely for sports can be a tough sell. Voters have often rejected them in referendums, and studies by both liberal and conservative economists have demonstrated that new stadiums provide few, if any, economic benefits.
But convention halls are not necessarily any better. The typical convention center is empty more than half the time, and even the busy ones don't provide enough benefits to justify their costs, said Heywood Sanders, a professor of urban studies at Trinity University in San Antonio.
Although the Javits Center is fully booked, it still barely covers its operating expenses, leaving taxpayers stuck with the debt incurred in its construction. The multitude of hotel rooms and restaurants it was supposed to bring to the neighborhood still aren't there, in part because many of the people attending the shows come in only for the day.
Javits officials say the solution to their problems is to add more exhibit space, which would enable New York to attract bigger shows and more visitors from afar. It is the same strategy being followed at convention centers in Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington and Boston -- and a formula for still bigger losses, according to Dr. Sanders.
"The amount of convention space on the East Coast is going to at least double in the next few years," Dr. Sanders said, "yet the convention business isn't growing. It's been essentially flat for five years. Before they make another bad investment, New Yorkers ought to consider what happened to Los Angeles. It expanded its convention center expecting to double attendance, but the numbers have stayed about the same."
Mr. Giuliani may dismiss these other cities, believing that New York has special advantages in attracting convention business. But the city also has special disadvantages. "Conventioneers don't like New York's $200-a-night hotel rooms," Dr. Sanders said. "The convention centers doing the most business are in resorts with plenty of cheap hotel rooms, like Las Vegas, Orlando and New Orleans."
ANOTHER skeptic concerning the Mayor's proposal is William J. Stern, who oversaw the construction of the Javits Center when he was chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation. Mr. Stern now considers Javits a waste of money, and opposes the Mayor's idea of financing the domed stadium with a tax on Manhattan businesses.
"The Mayor wants to take money away from all these other companies," Mr. Stern said, "and put it into the convention and sports business. Since when is Rudy Giuliani a smarter investor than everyone else in New York?" The Mayor should at least choose an industry with a good track record, Mr. Stern said sardonically. "Why not use that land on the West Side for a tax-free corridor for Internet companies? Instead of building a stadium, pay Yahoo a billion dollars to move there."
The problem with that, of course, is that there's always a chance that people's enthusiasm for Internet companies will prove to be a passing infatuation. Computer programmers may not be any more dependable investments than pro athletes or conventioneers. But when you consider something that all of them have in common -- a longstanding interest in sex -- what could be a safer investment than the XXXposition Center?

HEADLINE: For Blacks and Jews, Hopes for Renewed Link

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
The words spoken at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem yesterday morning were probably much like those delivered from many pulpits on the day before the Federal holiday honoring the nation's most celebrated civil rights leader.
"The situation of the poor in America is our plight, our sickness," the speaker said, quoting a close friend and ally of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. "To be deaf to their cry is to condemn ourselves. Martin Luther King is a voice, a vision and a way." 
 What was unexpected for a Baptist church setting became clear as the quotation continued:
"I call upon every Jew to hearken to his voice, to share his vision, to follow in his way. The whole future of America will depend upon the impact and influence of Dr. King."
That call was first delivered on March 25, 1968, by Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel in a talk to a meeting of rabbis 10 days before Dr. King was assassinated. The words were reiterated yesterday by Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon, who along with Rabbi Marcelo R. Bronstein and 100 members of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, the Conservative synagogue on the Upper West Side, snapped up the limited number of seats reserved for them at the Harlem church.
They had come in response to an invitation issued on Jan. 9 by the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the church, when he delivered a sermon to the synagogue as a possible first step in forging an alliance between the congregations to fight racial, social and economic injustice.
"At last there is a chance, maybe not to stretch hands across the sea but to begin to close a chasm," one of the synagogue's members, E. M. Broner, a writer, said as she stood in line outside the church yesterday.
The B'nai Jeshurun rabbis and Mr. Butts repeatedly invoked role models for cooperation in their talks from the pulpit. They cited Dr. King, who would have turned 70 on Jan. 15 and whose birthday celebration provided the theme of the service, and Rabbi Heschel, the Jewish theologian who marched with Dr. King in Selma and who persuaded him to become involved in protests against the Vietnam War. Rabbi's Heschel's 26th yahrzeit, the anniversary of his death, was observed last week.
In his sermon, whose title, "Moral Grandeur and Spiritual Audacity," was taken from Rabbi Heschel, Mr. Butts said, "This church celebrates Abraham Joshua Heschel, who helped to guide Martin Luther King, and now we have the opportunity to move forward to better the city, the state, the country, the world.
"Martin Luther King and Abraham Joshua Heschel were hit by the spirit, and they joined hands. They knew the storm troopers were out there. They knew there was a bullet that had King's name on it, but the spirit of audacity brought them together."
In his talk on Jan. 9, which won a standing ovation, Mr. Butts said of the two men he called prophets: "It didn't matter that one was a rabbi and one was a Christian clergyperson. What mattered was that they shared the same experience with God and were willing to run the risk of facing violence arm in arm in Selma on the bloody Sunday when marchers were beaten into the ground."
"Do we have to do that again?" he implored. "Do we have to stand in the face of that kind of ugliness? Eventually, if not today, we're going to have to start walking together."
But will the impassioned words delivered in sermons translate into tangible action for onetime allies whose relationship has been sorely tested?
"Many of us have for a long time felt the cooling off of black-Jewish efforts," Rabbi Matalon said the other day. "There was a time when blacks and Jews collaborated in significant projects bringing about social change. Then a number of factors divided and separated those communities, all sorts of issues, some having to do with affirmative action, South Africa, the Middle East and the emergence of a vocal sector in the Jewish community that is much more politically conservative. The majority of American Jewry fell into silence and acquiescence. Now it is time to rebuild those coalitions to move forward together."
Robert E. Pollack, a professor of biology at Columbia University and the president of the Jewish Campus Life Fund, who described himself as "probably the only member of B'nai Jeshurun to know Reverend Butts longer than I know my own rabbis," seemed optimistic.
"I met Reverend Butts 15 years ago when I was the dean at Columbia College and he was the mediator to end the blockade of Hamilton Hall protesting the investment in South Africa," he recalled. "This is not merely a political event between blacks and Jews, but is a coming together of serious Jews and serious Christians. This morning is a statement of shared commitment."

HEADLINE: More Realistic Defense Budgeting

 BODY:
President Clinton wants to increase military spending by $110 billion over the next six years, the first significant increase in the defense budget since Ronald Reagan's cold-war buildup of the mid-1980's. Congressional Republicans want to spend even more. But soaring spending is unnecessary to assure that America's armed forces remain strong, decently paid and appropriately equipped for the battlefields of the 21st century. Most of what the Pentagon legitimately needs can be paid for by trimming pork from acquisition programs, closing unneeded bases and reducing America's nuclear arsenal from excessive cold-war levels.
For next year, Mr. Clinton will request $269 billion. That is $4 billion more than he originally planned to seek. But he will also let the Pentagon retain and spend an additional $8 billion in savings from lower than expected inflation. Although a detailed breakdown is not yet available, the White House has already indicated that $2.5 billion will go for well-deserved pay and pension increases, an additional $2 billion will support peacekeeping in Bosnia, and most of the remainder will be used for spare parts and recruiting. In the five following years, most of the new spending will be for new weapons programs, including $7 billion to be set aside for possible later construction of a limited missile defense system. 
 In the future smart weapons will shape the battlefield and defense priorities will include shielding vulnerable computer and telecommunications networks and protecting civilians from biological and chemical attack. Unfortunately, much of the new money Mr. Clinton seeks will go to advanced fighter aircraft and nuclear attack submarines, areas where the United States is already far ahead of any prospective foe.
Under the 1997 balanced-budget agreement, any increase in defense spending must be paid for by tax increases or reductions in domestic programs. The White House hopes to get some defense money from a new cigarette tax. But if the Republicans approve such a tax, the money should be used for health programs. Meanwhile, the Administration has failed to identify any domestic programs it would cut. Some compensating savings will have to be found, and the first place to look should be elsewhere in the defense budget. New weapons spending should be cut back. America does not need three separate advanced fighter plane programs. Two would be more than enough. The production of additional attack submarines, which serve no current military need, could be slowed.
Congress has blocked two more rounds of base closings proposed by the Pentagon that could save as much as $2 billion a year. Legislators also shamelessly fatten defense budgets to benefit home districts, last year adding $5 billion for weapons, research and military construction the Pentagon had not requested. Further savings can be achieved by reducing America's nuclear arsenal to the target level of 2,500 warheads Washington seeks in the next arms reduction agreement with Russia. Even without a treaty, financial pressures will lead Russia to match America's cuts. Together, these savings could finance more than half of the increased spending President Clinton is proposing.
The post-cold-war world has not turned out to be as peaceful as Americans originally hoped and the United States needs to maintain a strong and ready military. But it should do so by reallocating existing defense spending, not by raiding already threadbare domestic spending programs.

HEADLINE: Mayoral Free-for-All in Philadelphia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
Appearing here recently as the Wizard in a stage show of "The Wizard of Oz," Mickey Rooney stopped in at City Hall to present Mayor Edward G. Rendell with a special souvenir.
As he accepted a ceremonial key to Oz, Mr. Rendell took a moment to congratulate the 78-year-old actor for a lifetime of charitable work. Mr. Rooney was taken aback by the Mayor's remarks. "I'm not through yet," he insisted, prompting Mr. Rendell to cut him off. 
 "I keep telling people here I'm not through yet, either," Mr. Rendell said.
Embarking upon the last of his eight years as Philadelphia's Mayor and foremost cheerleader, a period of major economic and psychological turnaround for the city, Mr. Rendell, a Democrat, hardly seems ready to relinquish his reputation for drawing a spotlight to cities as the economic engine of a metropolitan region. (Mr. Rendell cannot run for re-election; Philadelphia has term limits.)
There is a budget to balance. Policing strategies under a new commissioner are still evolving. Thousands of untrained and illiterate people are coming off the city welfare rolls this year. Public schools need more money. And the city still needs to attract businesses to sustain seven years of economic development.
"These are the five things I want to do this year," the Mayor said in an interview the day after Mr. Rooney's visit, finishing off a blueberry muffin in his cluttered office.
But if Mr. Rendell's achievements reflect a job well done, they also stand as a formidable challenge for his potential successors.
Five Democrats and one Republican are searching for issues to run on this year while not appearing critical of a politician so popular and effective that investors who watch municipal bond ratings are beginning to wonder if his successor can match his performance.
"No one wants to distance themselves from what has happened over the last six or seven years," said John F. Street, who resigned as City Council president last month, after 18 years on the council, to run for mayor.
For all the candidates' desire to continue the momentum built by Mr. Rendell, the election comes at a critical time for Philadelphia, whose population, 1.47 million, reflects the loss of nearly 90,000 people to the suburbs and beyond since 1991.
Like other big cities with eroding populations and constant social-service needs, Philadelphia is learning to do more with less. It also finds itself competing with cities in the same predicament for new industries, Federal grants, even conventions.
Philadelphia's successful pitch for the Republican Party's Presidential nominating convention in 2000, beating out New York and several other cities, was considered a major victory for a city with a strong Democratic Mayor, a Democratic majority in the City Council and more than three times as many registered Democrats as Republicans.
Philadelphia won the prize in part because of its enormous economic development in recent years: the new hotels, restaurants and cultural institutions that have bloomed throughout the downtown and waterfront areas. This year alone, 13 big hotels are scheduled to open.
But with those projects in the works, along with others like a planned Disney entertainment complex and renovations for Independence Mall, Mr. Rendell's successor is not likely to have as many glamorous ventures to promote. The next mayor is almost certain to confront decidedly unglamorous issues like revamping the public school system, expanding downtown development into neighborhoods and figuring how to accommodate the 60,000 city residents who will begin to lose welfare benefits this year.
"Ed Rendell needed to be part cheerleader," said Charles P. Pizzi, president of the Greater Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce. "But now the ship is under wind, and the next mayor is going to have to go below the deck to make sure it's still sailing."
As Mr. Rendell's partner on countless initiatives over the years, Mr. Street has won the Mayor's endorsement, which makes him one of the favorites in the Democratic primary this May.
But just as Mr. Rendell conceded that "any of the candidates would make a good mayor," the Democrats, at least, are expecting a lively battle over the next few months. As the lone Republican, Sam Katz, an expert on municipal finance, has no opponent in his party's primary.
For the most part, all the candidates are focusing on improving the school system and public safety and on lowering a hated wage tax. And the ways they approach those challenges are not altogether different.
As a result, they are largely selling experience and leadership qualities as much as solutions.
Mr. Street, 55, who was council president for the last six years, presents himself as Mr. Rendell's partner in the city's leap from an accumulated deficit of more than $200 million in 1991 to six consecutive years of surpluses, each a city record, including the current $169 million. Mr. Street shepherded through many major pieces of legislation that changed the city's physical as well as fiscal condition.
But other Democratic candidates contend that they have skills that are just as valuable. Happy Fernandez, 59, the only woman running, has been a member of the council since 1991. She describes herself as "a valued member of the Rendell-council team" responsible for the city's fiscal recovery.
Martin Weinberg, 61, is a former city solicitor and was a close adviser to former Mayor Frank Rizzo. Now the head of a large law firm, he has made the overhaul of the school system a priority, proposing that the school board become more accountable to the mayor. He also wants to give police officers more training and educational opportunities.
As the only state legislator in the Democratic field, Dwight Evans, 44, has also made the school system a priority. He claims to have the best leadership skills among all those running, pointing to his role in inviting the former New York City police commissioner William J. Bratton to Philadelphia to discuss crime fighting. The invitation ultimately led to the city's hiring last year of John F. Timoney, Mr. Bratton's deputy, as its commissioner.
The other Democrat, John White Jr., 49, has served in a variety of public service roles. He has been a member of the State Legislature and the City Council and most recently was the executive director of the Philadelphia Housing Authority.
Now an executive with a real estate development firm, Mr. White has made improvements to the school system a cornerstone of his campaign, promoting safety, after-school programs and an education guaranteed to prepare students for a job or college.
Mr. Katz, 49, who was a financial adviser to Mr. Rendell in his first term, is facing the daunting task of becoming the city's first Republican mayor since Bernard Samuel won election in 1947.
Mr. Katz is an enthusiastic supporter of Mr. Rendell. But he points out that the city's population decline reflects problems that have to be corrected, especially the crime rate and the underperformance of children in the public school system.
Mr. Katz lost in previous races for mayor and governor. But, pointing to Republican mayors like Rudolph W. Giuliani in New York and Richard J. Riordan in Los Angeles, he contends that the time is right for a Republican in Philadelphia.
"People say all the time that a Republican can't win here," he said. "That's silly, self-serving Democratic poppycock. You put the better candidate out there, and it won't matter what the party label is."

HEADLINE: Trade Trash For Culture? Not Virginia

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Virginians are struggling to decide what odors wafting out of New York City smell more foul -- mushrooming mounds of garbage or uppity pronouncements from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Nostrils flared across the Old Dominion last week at news of a possible tripling of deliveries of New York City garbage. Up to 2.2 million tons a year, Virginians learned, could soon be plodding up the James River, bound for landfills in a state that already is embarrassed to place second (behind Pennsylvania) as America's top garbage destination. 
 Noxious as the news was -- Gov. James S. Gilmore 3d called it "highly unacceptable" and spoke of his duty to ban garbage barges on state rivers -- its perceived toxicity was quickly exceeded by the Mayor's statement about why non-New Yorkers have garbage obligations.
In exchange for the top-drawer culture that visitors soak up in New York, the Mayor asserted, they should be willing to bury some trash back home. A "reciprocal relationship," he called it.
In this state where people take pride in their manners, that reasoning has incited widespread outbreaks of incivility. Long-simmering suspicions about Yankees -- their arrogance, their pushy politicians and the unspeakable nature of their garbage -- are suddenly boiling over.
"Now let me see if I got it right," said State Senator William T. Bolling, a Republican and longtime critic of out-of-state trash. "I come up to New York and I spend my hard-earned money and somehow in exchange for that privilege, I am supposed to take your trash? This represents a certain arrogant attitude that is not consistent with the way we do business in Virginia. I can't think of a single issue that has made my blood boil more than this."
In an interview today at the governor's mansion, Mr. Gilmore, a Republican, said he was offended by the Republican Mayor's reasoning, which he described as "really an outrageous statement."
"To come out and basically try to further the discussion by saying we had a moral obligation because some Virginians from time to time visit New York is not proper," he said.
The Governor said he was concerned that the image of Virginia was being unfairly maligned by the trash issue.
"We are very much on the rise and we don't want anyone to get the impression that Virginia is only good as a garbage repository," Mr. Gilmore said.
The Mayor's office has dismissed such comments, which resounded here in the state capital during last week's opening of the General Assembly, as mere carping from "pandering politicians trying to achieve their own agenda."
Not just politicians are peeved. Business leaders with multimillion-dollar investments in garbage importation speak bitterly of the public-relations disaster they say the Mayor has created.
"After this past week, when people here say Yankee trash, they think it's redundant," said Charles H. Carter 3d, an 11th-generation Virginian whose family owns Port Tobacco at Weanack, a state-of-the-art facility for containerized garbage on the James River.
Mr. Carter finds it hard to believe that Mr. Giuliani is entertaining thoughts of running for national office. "Giuliani couldn't have said anything that could have harmed his own cause more," he said. "He is definitely not presidential material."
If Virginia's Governor and the Legislature follow through on last week's threats to ban garbage barges on the river (and there are constitutional reasons why such a state ban might not hold up in court), Mr. Carter stands to lose lots of money. He says his family does not have the resources to take the state on in a long court battle.
Mr. Carter's advice to the Mayor: "We'll take the trash, but keep your mouth shut."
The largest company that disposes of New York's garbage in Virginia is Waste Management Inc. of Houston. It has invested $15 million in Port Tobacco and had planned to begin barge shipments there in April. Asked whether the Mayor had helped Waste Management in its delicate negotiations with the Governor and the Legislature, a company spokeswoman, Christine Meket, who has been dispatched to Richmond for damage control, said, "No."
For years, environmental groups, investigative reporters and a few lawmakers in Virginia have tried to raise public awareness of what they see as the ecological and road-safety risks of the state's rapidly increasing importation of garbage. The business has boomed here in the last decade, creating giant landfills located mostly in land-rich, cash-poor African-American communities in central Virginia.
New York City, driven by the legal deadline in 2001 to close its landfill at Fresh Kills on Staten Island, has become Virginia's fastest-growing source of garbage.
Garbage-truck accidents, complaints about putrid odors and state records documenting the arrival of untreated syringes and vials of human blood have all raised public awareness here about trash rolling into this state from New York. A poll released last week by Virginia Commonwealth University's Center for Public Policy found that 87 percent of Virginians want to cap trash shipments into the state.
But Matthew Higgins, a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani, said today that at least some Virginians welcomed New York's trash. "Simply put, this is a business that creates jobs and generates economic activity," he said. "New York City has already been contacted by a number of communities in Virginia that want this trade." He would not say which communities wanted the city's garbage. But he said that the city had no choice but to find alternatives to Fresh Kills, which it is committed to closing by Dec. 31, 2001.
Judging by comments this weekend from shoppers at a mall outside Richmond, Mr. Giuliani has been uniquely effective in crystallizing attitudes toward big-city garbage in the minds of average Virginians.
"I had not been thinking about it until Giuliani made his remarks," said Kitty Jones, 55, a school secretary from Henrico County who was having lunch on Saturday outside the Chick-Fil-A booth in the food court at Virginia Center Commons mall in suburban Richmond.
Since reading about the Mayor in the papers and watching him on television in the past week, Ms. Jones said she had found herself wondering why Mr. Giuliani would say such a thing and what kind of town would support such a man.
"When you think of New York, you think of arrogance," Ms. Jones said, adding that it was probably unfair to judge a whole city on the basis of its Mayor's behavior. "I'm sure they are all not like that, are they?"
In the Virginia Legislature this year -- an election year here -- garbage is emerging as the hot-button issue. On one side, there are quality-of-life complaints, especially from lawmakers in affluent Northern Virginia, where highways in the Washington suburbs are inundated with out-of-state garbage trucks.
On the other, there is the deepening dependence of central Virginia counties on revenue from landfills. In Charles City County south of Richmond, $32 million in revenue from a landfill that takes New York City garbage has allowed county supervisors to build a new school system and an industrial park and to cut property taxes by 40 percent.
Adding to the legislative mix, according to state records, is an increasing flow of campaign money from waste industry companies.
Given the volatility of the garbage issue, state legislators on both sides of the aisle here said they were stunned by both the content and the timing of Mr. Giuliani's remarks.
"The Mayor should realize that this is a hot political topic and the general approach should not be to fan the flames," said Delegate Kenneth R. Plum, chairman of the State Democratic Party. "But this is effectively what he has done."
Down in Charles City County, whose 934-acre landfill is operated by Waste Management, school leaders and county planners reacted more in sadness than in anger to the Mayor's theory of interstate garbage-culture reciprocation.
They said that the county, which has a population of about 7,000 people, 62 percent of whom are black and who are among the poorest residents of Virginia, simply cannot afford a huge, politics-driven reduction in the amount of garbage coming into the landfill. It is ready to begin receiving New York garbage from the new port on the James River -- if the barges are not banned by the State Legislature.
"The landfill is the biggest boon to Charles City County in modern times," said Bill Britton, the county planning director. "Every tax since 1988 has either stayed the same or has been lowered. At the same time, we have been able to build a whole school system -- not just one school -- but a $21 million school system."
The county's school board chairman, Charles E. Giles, agreed wholeheartedly with Mr. Giuliani's statements last week that any attempt by Virginia to ban barge shipments of garbage would be overturned by Federal courts.
"We don't want anyone to interfere with interstate commerce," Mr. Giles said. "It is a constitutional right."
Both he and Mr. Britton declined to comment on the Mayor's invocation of a garbage obligation in this state.
Mr. Carter, managing director of the family-owned port that faces financial ruin if garbage barges are banned on the James River, had no such reticence.
He said that before last week's comments by the Mayor, he had heard sketchy reports of a similar public-relations debacle in New Jersey. In December, the Mayor surprised and infuriated Gov. Christine Todd Whitman with a plan to ship trash to transfer stations there.
"Is the Mayor always such a wonderful and wise person in all his comments?" Mr. Carter asked.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Dotting the I's Hard; Camps May Open Late

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Just when you thought the National Basketball Association was back in business, the league and the players' union are dueling again.
Lawyers for both sides are continuing to work on putting the terms of the new collective bargaining agreement into writing, but a disagreement over a crucial economic issue now threatens to delay the start of training camp and the free-agent signing period on Tuesday. 
 "There are a lot of issues still open," Jeffrey Mishkin, the league's chief legal officer, said yesterday. "We're trying to get it done by Monday night, but I don't know if that's going to happen."
Neither the league nor the union would give specifics, but officials on both sides said the biggest stumbling block was over the maximum length of contracts under the mid-level salary exception.
The exception starts at $1.75 million, rises to $2.25 million by the third year and becomes whatever the average salary is in the league in the fourth year.
The union contends that the two sides agreed that mid-level contracts could be signed for up to six years.
The league says the length of mid-level contracts was not settled at the 12-hour negotiating session that saved the N.B.A. season from cancellation 10 days ago.
The management has proposed that players be able to sign a contract for three years under the exception.
These are among the other issues the two sides are still haggling over:
*The definition of basketball-related income, which is split between the league and the players.
*The sharing of television revenue.
*Several conduct issues, including the details of a new antidrug program.
The lockout remains in effect until an agreement is signed, meaning that training camps and the signing and trading period may not begin until later this week.
 
Kerr Talks With Spurs
 Steve Kerr, a 3-point specialist and free agent who was an important member of three consecutive Chicago Bulls championship teams, is near a deal with the San Antonio Spurs, his agent said yesterday.
"We haven't agreed to anything," the agent, Mark Bartlestein, said. "Nothing is done as of yet. We're close, but there are some things we're trying to finalize.
"The Spurs are a team we're really interested in. We're working hard and something could happen."
Several teams have shown interest in Kerr, a 10-year veteran who is one of the most proficient 3-point shooters in National Basketball Association history.
"I wouldn't say the other teams were out of the loop," Bartlestein said. "We're just seeing if we can finalize a deal with the Spurs."
Kerr's departure is just another sign that the Bulls are preparing to break the team up after Michael Jordan's retirement last week.
The free agents Scottie Pippen, Luc Longley and Dennis Rodman are also expected to leave the Bulls, which was dominant team of the decade. A Spurs spokesman did not return a call seeking comment yesterday. (AP)
 
Geiger Near Deal With 76ers
 Matt Geiger is close to signing with the Philadelphia 76ers in a six-year contract worth $54 million.
Geiger, who played the last three seasons with Charlotte, is expected to make the deal as soon as the new collective bargaining agreement is put into writing, which would be as early as Tuesday, someone close to the negotiations said on Saturday.
Geiger would get the maximum salary allowed under the new labor deal with the signing. (AP)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: BORROWERS BEWARE: A Special Report;
Suits Say Unscrupulous Lending Is Taking Homes From the Poor

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
By all appearances, the loan agreement Gloria Knight signed in 1995 was a classic transaction between savvy mortgage salesmen and an unsophisticated borrower in a poor Brooklyn neighborhood.
Ms. Knight, a retired teacher, says the salesmen who knocked on her door persuaded her to put her house up as collateral for an $88,000 loan, at 13 percent interest, to help with bills and a previous loan -- even though she had no income and no way to make the $973 monthly payments. 
 But when she defaulted on her loan, leading to eviction notices last year, she ended up in the grip of something far larger than Delta Funding, a relatively obscure Long Island mortgage company that solicits business from poor homeowners. Delta's partner in trying to take her home is Bankers Trust Company, America's eighth-largest bank.
High-interest lending in poor neighborhoods has long produced high profits for lenders and, often, equally high burdens for homeowners. But the entry of big banks like Bankers Trust is part of a growing trend in such lending and has changed the equation. Over the last several years, Delta has converted hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of its mortgages into securities much like bonds, which it sells to investors through Bankers Trust.
In turn, Bankers Trust has provided Delta with hundreds of millions of investors' dollars, allowing it to make more loans and become a major player in high-interest lending in New York and 21 other states.
But there is a problem: a high percentage of the homeowners can't afford Delta's mortgages. Many say they were duped into taking the loans and now may lose their homes as Delta and Bankers Trust try to reclaim the money for their investors.
Delta and Bankers Trust defend their activities. But Delta's business has recently produced civil lawsuits in three states, and advocates for the poor and social-services agencies say the company has generated more complaints of abusive lending than any other high-interest lender in New York City. They contend that Delta has taken advantage of scores of homeowners and violated Federal and state laws.
Ms. Knight, 55, who has since been found to be delusional by a psychiatrist for the city's Protective Services for Adults, cannot even afford electricity. She keeps warm with a kerosene heater and cooks over a makeshift grill in her backyard. But she had something that made her attractive to lenders like Delta: her row house in East New York, which was fully paid for and which served as security. Legal Services lawyers say she will now almost certainly lose it.
Last month, Chief Judge Charles P. Sifton of the Federal Court for the Eastern District of New York stopped the foreclosure sales of homes of three people who defaulted on Delta loans, because, he wrote, the mortgages "on their face" violated Federal law, and so the borrowers showed a good chance of winning their lawsuit.
The homeowners have sued Delta and Bankers Trust, claiming they violated, among other laws, a Federal prohibition on making loans based solely on equity in a house and not on a homeowner's ability to repay. The suit seeks to represent tens of thousands of other Delta borrowers who lawyers say are in similar circumstances.
Officials with Bankers Trust, which is being acquired by the German banking giant Deutsche Bank, declined repeated requests for interviews. On Friday, William McBride, a bank spokesman, said in a statement: "Bankers Trust's sole responsibility in these situations is to safeguard the interests of investors. We have no other connection to these actions."
Marc E. Miller, Delta's general counsel and a son of its founder, vigorously denied that the company engages in deceptive lending, saying it made no sense financially for the company to make loans it knew would fail. "There is sometimes this myth that's spread around that lenders do make money" from foreclosed properties, Mr. Miller said. "And it is a myth."
While refusing to comment on cases that are in litigation, he added that "if a loan simply doesn't make sense for a borrower, we won't do it."
But city real estate records show high foreclosure rates on Delta mortgages in some neighborhoods. In Brooklyn, where the company is most active in the city, a search of records found that 48 of 363 loans made by Delta in 1995 -- or about 13 percent -- have ended up in default, and Delta has begun foreclosure actions. For 1996 loans, the records show, the figure is 99 of 923 -- more than 10 percent.
In its annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission last year, Delta reported that 4.65 percent of all its loans were in foreclosure, calculated by the dollar amount of the loans.
According to Inside B&C Lending, an industry newsletter that reports statistics from several large lenders, about 2.65 percent of the high-risk loans nationwide, by dollar amount, were in foreclosure as of September 1998, the most recent date for which information was available. An additional 1.9 percent were 90 days delinquent and in danger of foreclosure.
Delta's critics contend that the company has devastated the lives of many working-class homeowners, most of them elderly. "These folks not only lose their homes, but lose every dime of equity they have built up, and in most cases this is all they have to show for years of hard work," said Josh Zinner, a lawyer with the Foreclosure Prevention Project for Seniors, a branch of South Brooklyn Legal Services set up last year to pursue claims of abusive lending.
Anna Dawson, a 67-year-old Brooklyn widow who is fighting Delta and Bankers Trust in state court for her home, may get help from prosecutors. The Brooklyn District Attorney's Office is investigating an independent broker who refers business to Delta and who, she contends, falsified her mortgage application without her knowledge to make it appear she could afford a $99,000 mortgage with monthly payments of $1,017. In reality, her only income was roughly $700 a month in survivor's benefits from her late husband. But her application included a letter saying she was an office manager at United Equities in Brooklyn and a lease that made it appear she rented out a floor of her home. The company does not exist at the address on the letter, and Ms. Dawson said she has not worked in more than two decades. She has no renter. And the signature on the lease is not hers, she said.
Her loan became part of $340 million worth of 1997 Delta mortgages put into a trust managed by Bankers Trust and sold to investors.
In a lawsuit filed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, her lawyers contend that the mortgage broker and a home-improvement contractor came to her house uninvited several times, persistently pushing her to get a loan for repairs to her house.
In the end, she was unable to make her payments, and Delta and Bankers Trust have begun to foreclose against her. Meanwhile, she said she was left with almost no proceeds of her loan -- after paying Delta's fees, settling a previous low-interest loan and paying the same home-improvement contractor, who she said did little work.
The Growing Trade
Of High-Risk Loans
High-interest lending became a big business in low-income neighborhoods nationwide after 1986, when a change in the Federal tax code gave a break to homeowners who took out second mortgages. But complaints about abuses began almost immediately. Unscrupulous finance companies often singled out homeowners, many of them elderly, who had substantial equity in their homes; in case of default, lenders could recoup the loan by taking the home.
In 1993, New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs reported that finance companies, usually working with crooked home-improvement contractors, had "fleeced thousands of lower-income and minority New York City homeowners" out of equity in their homes by tricking them into loans for repairs. The report added that the lenders often researched homeowners before approaching them, studying credit reports to determine whether they had paid off their first mortgage.
Many finance companies resold their mortgages to big banks. But Delta -- founded in 1982 in by Sidney A. Miller, a former planner for insurance companies -- was one of the first to see a vast untapped resource beyond the banks: the investment market. By converting loans into securities and selling them to investors, finance companies could generate a faster profit and have access to much more capital, and make many more loans.
Over the last decade, the market in asset-backed securities like those issued by Delta has grown from $9 billion to more than $140 billion, as investors pursued the rapidly expanding trade in high-risk auto loans, credit cards and home-equity loans. The size of the high-risk home-loan industry alone reached more than $120 billion in loans issued nationwide in 1997, according to industry estimates.
Recently, big lenders like Chase Manhattan, Norwest, Nationsbank, General Electric, Keycorp, Countrywide Credit Industries and others have expanded their involvement in high-interest lending.
Delta began selling loans as securities in 1991, giving investors the right to share in mortgage interest payments, and Bankers Trust's California branch soon began to manage the trusts that held these securities. Delta's business zoomed. In 1994, it made about $100 million in loans. By last year, according to its Federal securities filings, its loans increased to more than $1 billion. It grew from about 150 employees to more than 1,000. In 1996, it went public, on the New York Stock Exchange, and in 1997 it reported profits of more than $30 million.
William J. Brennan, a lawyer for the Atlanta Legal Aid Society who specializes in lending abuse cases and is familiar with lawsuits against Delta, criticizes Bankers Trust as Delta's "enablers."
"Bankers Trust would never make these kinds of loans themselves," he said, "but they put themselves in the position of enhancing the power of Delta Funding to engage in abusive lending. And they do it because there's lots of money to be made."
But in the view of Marc Miller, whose family runs Delta, based in Woodbury, N.Y., "there are many people who want and need a loan and can't get one. From that standpoint we fill a very legitimate niche in the consumer finance field."
 
An Incompetence Ruling, And Then Default
 Gertrude Menzel, an elderly Queens woman who had lived in her two-story row house in Ridgewood since she was a teen-ager, took out an $81,000 Delta mortgage in the summer of 1994, when she was 78. Five years later, Bankers Trust and Delta say Ms. Menzel owes more than $123,000 in principal and interest, and they are trying to take her house.
There is no dispute that Ms. Menzel signed the loan papers. But little else is clear, including her motivation, since the first mortgage on the house was paid off and she appeared to have no debts. Her lawyer said that she was talked into the loan by an acquaintance who had previously taken financial advantage of her and ended up taking the proceeds of her loan for himself.
But questions remain about whether she was competent when she closed the mortgage in Delta's offices. Workers at a Queens center for the elderly, who saw her almost daily, said they noticed memory lapses and confused behavior well before the summer of 1994. By Thanksgiving, six months after she got the mortgage, she "was wearing house slippers out into the cold and was not taking care of herself," said Thomas Crossman, who ran the Ridgewood Older Adult Center at the time.
In 1995, according to court papers, two psychiatrists hired by the center found symptoms of dementia and memory loss. One reported that she "does not have any knowledge of her assets or income."
By May 1995, Ms. Menzel was ruled legally incompetent in State Supreme Court, and she later defaulted on the mortgage.
But Bankers Trust argued in court papers that her mortgage was valid because Ms. Menzel had not been ruled incompetent before the closing. Partly for that reason, a State Supreme Court judge, Edwin Kassoff, declined to let Ms. Menzel out of the mortgage. Bankers Trust and Delta continue to fight her in court.
Delta's critics say that the company commonly works with aggressive, often unscrupulous mortgage brokers and home-improvement contractors who canvass poor neighborhoods, looking for elderly homeowners willing to put up their homes as collateral for loans to help with bills or home repairs.
A search of court records and Delta loan documents found that at least two people who have referred loans to Delta -- John Gizze, the owner of a mortgage consulting firm in Hempstead, N.Y., and Gary Feldman, a Queens home-improvement contractor -- have pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit bank fraud in Federal court in cases unrelated to Delta. Both men admitted in court that they had falsified papers to exaggerate the income of borrowers.
Mr. Gizze's lawyer, Allen Drezin, said Mr. Gizze has subsequently had "some dealings with Delta Funding," but they "have been up to the standards of the industry." Mr. Feldman is now a defendant in a Federal civil suit filed by Mary Lewis, a Queens woman who claims he and Delta deceived her when she took out a home-equity mortgage in 1997.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Feldman said that he has closed few loans with Delta, and denied engaging in deceptive lending practices in his dealings with the company.
Delta officials said they were unaware of the criminal past of either man, but they added that they do not routinely perform criminal background checks on brokers.
"Dealing with thousands of different brokers," said Mr. Miller, the general counsel, "it would, frankly, be impossible for us to stay on top of every broker at every instant."
The company is now the target of at least four Federal civil suits, three of which seek to represent classes of thousands of homeowners who lawyers allege were deceived or mistreated by Delta.
The suit filed late last year in Federal District Court for the Eastern District, which includes Brooklyn and Queens, accuses Delta of consistently lending to people based on the equity of their homes and not on their ability to pay, a practice the plaintiffs' lawyers say has led to scores of foreclosures.
The suit also accuses Delta of breaking Federal law by charging exorbitant extra interest once a loan goes into default. (A review of Delta loan papers for several borrowers found that the interest commonly jumps to 24 percent after default. In New York, interest rates over 25 percent are prohibited by criminal usury laws.)
Delta and Bankers Trust, represented by a single law firm in the case, have not yet responded to the allegations in court.
In Mississippi and Georgia, two Federal civil suits allege that Delta is one of many high-interest mortgage lenders paying fees to mortgage brokers, which would violate Federal law. The suits allege that these fees are, in reality, a kickback to brokers for steering borrowers to the lenders, even though it may not be in the borrowers' best interest.
Delta officials deny the accusations. But in a similar Federal class-action case in New York, Delta recently settled with the plaintiffs in a confidential agreement, according to reports Delta filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Mr. Miller said in a written statement that all such suits contain "accusations, rather than fact" and have been filed "solely for the purpose of delaying or preventing Delta Financial from protecting its rights."
 
Allegations of Deceit And Finder's Fees
But Delta has not always been successful in challenging claims of abuse. In November 1991, Theresa Leonardi went into the hospital with thyroid and heart problems, only a month after the death of her husband of 50 years. Three days after she was released from the hospital, according to a lawsuit she filed against Delta, she was taken to the lender's offices, then in Great Neck, N.Y., by a stockbroker who later pleaded guilty to mail fraud against her in a separate case and served time in prison.
Mrs. Leonardi took out a $95,000 mortgage on her home in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, but she said later in a lawsuit against Delta that she was never told she was signing loan papers and believed she was signing investment papers.
The papers described her as a 68-year-old self-employed investor making $7,000 a month. In fact, she was almost 73 and was living mostly on Social Security.
In giving the loan to Mrs. Leonardi, according to court documents, Delta waived its written policy stating that income tax returns should be used to verify the income of loan applicants.
In the end, her lawyers say, all her mortgage proceeds went directly to the stockbroker, and Mrs. Leonardi never made a single loan payment. By December 1992, the bank began a foreclosure.
Carl Felsenfeld, a former Citicorp vice president who was an expert witness for Mrs. Leonardi, said in a deposition that the case showed "clear and convincing evidence of Delta's participation in the fraud perpetrated on Mrs. Leonardi."
Delta denied the accusations and pointed out that Mrs. Leonardi had chosen the unscrupulous stockbroker herself. "It is a sad commentary on our society," Marie Klasa, a Delta vice president, wrote in a letter in 1995, "that people must seek to blame others for their own errors in judgment."
But as the trial approached last summer, Delta agreed to pay Mrs. Leonardi $200,000 -- more than twice the amount of her mortgage -- in a confidential settlement in which Delta admitted no wrongdoing.
Mr. Miller said the company settled because it believed it would be less costly than pursuing an appeal.
"The actual facts," he said, "are that Delta made a loan that made sense at the time to a woman who knew what she was doing at the time."
Mrs. Leonardi remembered it differently. "At no time did any of these people explain to me that I was signing papers for a mortgage on my home," she stated in court documents. "They merely pointed to the lines, and I signed or initialed as directed. At the time I was so weak that I couldn't walk without assistance and could not read any of the papers that I was asked to sign."
