HEADLINE: Dead Dream: Brazil's Plan Is Blocked

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 17

 BODY:
On the trading floor of the Sao Paulo stock exchange, it led to a breathtaking buying spree. In Washington, officials were relieved. But in Brazil, the Government's decision to stop protecting the currency that beat hyperinflation signaled the end of a celebrated monetary plan that promised to transform Latin America's biggest country into a modern nation.
The dream has been personified by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a multilingual former sociology professor and finance minister who has roamed world capitals and financial centers for the last four years, selling his vision of a modern Brazil, intent on reform and backed by a stable currency, the real. 
 He told Brazilians, most of whom had never lived without runaway prices, that inflation was the cruelest tax of all, striking the poor whose salaries lost value by the hour.
It complicated long-term investments and planning, so industry failed to modernize, relying instead on trade barriers to keep out cheaper imports. Brazilians rewarded Mr. Cardoso for his Real Plan's success in beating hyperinflation by voting him President twice -- a first for Brazil.
Foreign investors signed on, seeing in Brazil a huge, untapped market of 160 million for everything from telephones to refrigerators, and a potential base for exports to the rest of South America. Direct foreign investment, $2 billion at the start of the Real Plan, totaled $36 billion by last year.
On Friday, Mr. Cardoso stood before his nation on television for just two and a half minutes, to say that he had done all he could to protect the real by intervening on currency markets, but could no longer spend foreign reserves that had dwindled to $30 billion from $75 billion in five months. The real would be free to float on world markets.
The immediate reaction was frenzied buying, which gave the Sao Paulo Bovespa index its second-biggest rise in a single day, 33.4 percent.
Significantly, the only higher increase, 36.05 percent, occurred on Feb. 4, 1991, when the second phase of former President Fernando Collor de Mello's economic plan was announced. He left office one step ahead of impeachment.
Now, while economists and industrialists debate the size of price increases likely to hit stores this week and the possible nature of "Real Plan II," there is little disagreement about the cause of the current failure.
The Real Plan foundered on the same rocks that sank a half dozen other plans to transform Brazil over the last 15 years: the Government's inability to maneuver reform past vested interests that enjoy benefits and breaks Brazil cannot afford.
Mr. Cardoso said a year ago that his predecessor, Mr. Collor de Mello, was drummed from office not so much for corruption as for angering the elite by going too fast with reform. This President learned the lesson, and navigated reform measures through Congress cautiously.
Ten months into office, he turned his attention to winning a constitutional amendment to permit his re-election, a complicated process that cost political capital needed he would need later. In doing so, he put off the further economic and political change needed to make Brazil the modern nation of his vision.
Now, Mr. Cardoso has been brought up short by the refusal of a political rival, Itamar Franco, Governor of the second-largest of Brazil's 26 states, to make his state's payments to the Federal coffers. Mr. Franco's default has whipped up a wave of discontent among opposition governors, who are now demanding that the Federal Government renegotiate the terms of their debts.
Much as Mr. Cardoso and his Government may try to portray the move on Friday as a simple shifting of gears to juggle the concerns of those who favor growth and those who want a stable currency, there is little sign that the President had any option but to surrender stability he could no longer sustain.
On Friday, the financial markets appeared pleased that Brazil would no longer drain foreign reserves to bolster its currency. But there was a sense of betrayal among those who had believed Brazil's leaders when they repeatedly ruled out devaluation. What other elements of his vision will Mr. Cardoso surrender?
"Unfortunately, it's the emperor has no clothes syndrome," said Riordan Roett, director of the Western Hemisphere Programs at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.
To be sure, the Cardoso administration has made important progress. It pushed through measures to force Government to lay off public workers if a state's payroll exceeds 60 percent of its budget, and has had partial success adopting laws that should trim the deficit left by pensions that are more generous than the state can afford. It has privatized state-owned mining, telecommunications and utility companies, and cleaned up state-owned banks notoriously used as political kitties by state Governors.
But the heart of the Real Plan, indeed its raison-d'etre, was its goal of curbing inflation that topped 2,500 percent a year before the plan's creation in July 1994. Brazilian administrations in the last 40 years had either proved powerless to fight inflation or embraced it to kindle growth, or at times its illusion.
Mr. Cardoso's dream for Brazil grew more expensive each year that it remained unrealized, because -- without the fig leaf of inflation -- the Government has had to borrow to cover its overspending.
Before the Real Plan, the Brazilian Government had no deficit to speak of, Demosthenes Madureira de Pinho Neto, the Central Bank's director for international relations, said in October. Government agencies would rely on inflation to cure shortfalls, delaying adjustments in salaries for inflation and using money saved to cover overspending elsewhere.
Without inflation, the budget deficit has ballooned, lumbering now toward $65 billion, or 8 percent of the gross national product.

HEADLINE: Why Won't Clinton Cut Taxes?

BYLINE: By Bruce Bartlett; Bruce Bartlett, a senior fellow with the National Center for Policy Analysis, was a Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary in the Reagan and Bush Administrations.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
One of the main things that frustrates President Clinton's enemies so much is his skill at identifying the issues Americans care about. So it is somewhat surprising, given the budget surplus and the magnitude of the current Federal tax burden, that Mr. Clinton has not moved to co-opt the Republicans in this area, as he has in so many others, by proposing a big tax cut.
A consequence of a long economic expansion is that taxes tend to rise. As real incomes grow, as unemployment declines, as corporate profits hit record levels, individuals, households and corporations inevitably expand the Federal tax base. Indeed, many families find themselves pushed up into higher tax brackets in the same way that inflation caused bracket creep in the 1970's. As a result, almost every measure of taxation shows Federal taxes at record levels. 
 * In the third quarter of 1998, total Federal receipts hit 21.8 percent of the gross domestic product, according to the Commerce Department. This is the highest level recorded in American history, exceeding even the percentages reached in World War II (19.9 percent), the Korean War (20.1 percent) or the Vietnam War (20.7).
* According to the Census Bureau, the average household paid 24.9 percent of its income in combined Federal, state and local taxes in 1997, up from 22.2 percent in 1992 and 21.8 percent in 1983. Of this, by far the greatest component was Federal income taxes, which consumed 14.9 percent of its income, $9,445 on average, more than twice what the average household paid in 1985. As recently as 1992, the average household paid just 12.1 percent of its income in Federal income taxes.
* According to the Treasury Department, a four-person family with the median income -- $54,900 -- will pay 30.3 percent of each additional dollar it earns to the Federal Government this year in the form of income and payroll taxes. Although down from the peak of the early 1980's, this is a sharp increase from the 19 percent marginal tax rate such families faced in the early 1970's.
To be sure, there does not appear to be any great popular clamor for tax cuts, as there was 20 years ago. Nevertheless, voices not known for being fervent tax cutters are saying that a major tax cut is needed at this time. This is true even among some liberal economists, who have traditionally argued that higher government spending, not lower taxes, is the way to spur economic growth.
For example, the liberal Jerome Levy Economics Institute has warned that policy makers are not factoring into their forecasts the contractionary effect of budget surpluses. Unless the surplus is quickly eliminated, either through tax cuts or spending increases, the institute believes that the economy will quickly run out of gas.
So why doesn't Mr. Clinton propose a broad-based tax cut? There are several reasons. First is that budget rules adopted in 1997 make enacting a tax cut prohibitively difficult. Under the so-called pay-go provision of the budget law, all tax cuts must be offset either with increases of other taxes or cuts in entitlement programs like Medicare. The law specifically prohibits use of the budget surplus or appropriated spending programs like the military to pay for tax cuts.
The "pay-go" law is, in fact, the main reason that most of Mr. Clinton's latest initiatives have involved tax credits, like that for long-term care, rather than direct spending. Such initiatives can be offset by the proposed increase in cigarette taxes, thus avoiding the budget caps on appropriations and the pay-go provision.
Mr. Clinton's second problem is fear that opening the door to an across-the-board tax cut would open a Pandora's box of tax initiatives from Congressional Republicans. A small Clinton tax cut might quickly grow into a large bipartisan tax cut that he would be powerless to forestall.
Finally, Mr. Clinton is still boxed in by his demand that the surplus be used first to "save" Social Security. Absent a plan to accomplish this, he will look like a hypocrite if he now proposes to use the surplus for some other purpose, even though he in fact used a big chunk of last year's surplus for various "emergency" spending programs, like more money for the International Monetary Fund.
It would be clever politics for Mr. Clinton to pre-empt Congress and call for across-the-board tax relief. If forced to choose between a popular tax cut and pressing forward with a politically unpopular impeachment trial, there is little doubt Republicans will select the former over the latter. A tax cut could become the President's secret weapon.

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

COMPANY: US DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE (56%); US DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE (56%); US CENSUS BUREAU (55%); US CENSUS BUREAU (55%);

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Nomura Securities Posts a Loss Tied to Japan's Economic Woes

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The Nomura Securities Company, Japan's largest brokerage firm, said today that it lost money in the last three months of 1998, as Japan's economy and stock market sagged.
The Daiwa Securities Company, the second-largest brokerage firm, and the Nikko Securities Company, the third biggest, said one-time gains from two of Japan's biggest-ever stock sales helped them avoid a similar fate. 
 Daiwa managed the sale of a block of shares for the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, and Nikko co-managed the listing of NTT Mobile Communications Network Inc., the mobile phone company.
Nomura had a loss of 7.656 billion yen ($67 million) for its fiscal third quarter, after a 7.1 billion yen profit the previous quarter.
Daiwa earned 11.9 billion yen, and Nikko had profit of 8.98 billion yen for the period. Both companies lost money during the previous quarter.
All three brokers reported a fall in stock trading commissions for the nine months through December. Nomura said stock commissions dropped e 27 percent from last year. Daiwa reported a 72.6 percent fall and Nikko a 41 percent decline.
"One-time factors helped tide the brokers over, but I'm not sure they're on track," said Sadateru Nishimura, an analyst at Fitch IBCA in Japan. Stock commissions, which had been a major source of profits, "aren't even covering costs."
Daiwa said it would take a 115 billion yen ($1 billion) charge for the year through March to cover losses at three nonbank affiliates.
Overseas, Daiwa said it posted a total pretax loss of 50.3 billion yen in the nine months. In the United States, Daiwa lost 24.4 billion yen on bond trading and 1.7 billion on severance pay and other restructuring costs. In Europe, Daiwa lost 19.1 billion yen on emerging market bonds and 2.4 billion yen on restructuring.
Nomura said current profit fell 33.7 percent, to 14.23 billion yen, in the nine months to December.
Nomura said it lost 21.4 billion yen overseas in the third quarter. The figure includes 15.4 billion yen in the United States.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Culture City Talks Trash To Visitors

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
THERE is a way to keep the Great Trash War from spinning out of control and landing in court as Giuliani v. All States:
Insist that visitors to New York take their garbage with them when they go back home. The city could even make money on the deal. 
 This and other revenue-generating ideas percolated yesterday, the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. No disrespect, but on the day of tribute to the martyred civil-rights leader, many New Yorkers were more interested in tax deals that they could get on clothing purchases than in his reflections on the human condition.
They took advantage of another week of tax-free shopping, and looked forward to a permanent reduction of more than 50 percent, scheduled to go into effect in December on sales under $110. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would like to eliminate every last tax on clothing, and it is hard to imagine many New Yorkers' putting up an argument.
But since pendulums tend to swing, what will happen when the economy heads south, causing store sales to slump, retail jobs to shrink and municipal revenue to sag? The day may yet come when city and state governments wish they had not waved goodbye to that sales tax.
Although recommendations on fiscal policy are not normally the province of this department, the battle over New York's garbage exports inspired a thought or two, offered here free to municipal planners.
Virginians, as you may have heard, got their noses out of joint just because the Mayor said they should be thrilled to bury our trash in their soil. We give the outlanders Broadway and the Met, and what do they do? They add to our mountains of garbage. There should be more give and take, Mr. Giuliani suggested, a call for a "reciprocal relationship" that fell on many deaf ears in Virginia.
How about a different tack?
If Virginia and other states refuse to help out, why not impose a garbage-handling fee on the 32 million visitors a year to the city? You could start with a small surcharge, say, $3 a day, on each of the city's 60,000 hotel rooms, which are filled these days almost to capacity.
Three dollars would entail no hardship for guests already paying close to $200 a night on average. But the fee could produce about $65 million, roughly 10 percent of the Sanitation Department's annual budget.
True, it does smell like a new tax, which may cause the Mayor to wrinkle his nose. In that case, to return to the idea at the top, why not make visitors cart their garbage home?
Trash bags could be handed out at airports and train stations, with prominent signs informing arriving out-of-towners what is expected of them. Since most Americans consider themselves more polite and, over all, more virtuous than New Yorkers, they could be counted on to comply. They could be charged 25 cents or so per bag, an inconsequential sum that should cover the cost of the program and just might yield a profit.
AND if the city only breaks even, there will be other benefits.
When the guests are ready to return home, many will inevitably ask hotel attendants, apartment-house doormen, taxi drivers and airport skycaps to help them carry the filled bags. That means extra tips and more money for New Yorkers. The result could be an income-tax bonanza.
But even if they do not declare these tips, thousands of workers will have more to spend, which means more sales-tax revenue and smaller municipal budget deficits in hard times. Everyone benefits.
Please note that New Jersey, too, has crudely told New York what it can do with its trash. "Drop dead," Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said.
Does she not know that two can play that game?
New Jersey drivers are notoriously aggressive, and every day thousands of them bring their road rage into Manhattan, blaring horns and brushing back pedestrians in the crosswalks. They are easily identified by their license plates. Why not order a police crackdown? Public safety and the municipal treasury would both be better off.
Perhaps the most vexing part of the trash wars is a suggestion from some in Virginia that Mr. Giuliani has been acting a bit loopy. That is a slur. Maybe it would help if an affirmation that the Mayor makes sense, and New Yorkers support him, were written into any garbage-disposal contract.
Yes, Virginia, there is a sanity clause.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
A Global Rally as Worries on Brazil Recede

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Receding worries about Brazil's economic problems touched off a global rally in stock markets today as the country's central bank announced it would continue to float Brazil's currency, the real.
The steepest gains took place in Europe, with London's blue-chip Financial Times Stock Exchange index up 3.08 percent, or 182.9 points, to 6,123.9. Other world markets, however, remained volatile. 
 "There is still a lot of uncertainty out there, and I would not advise people to be investing in shares right now; these gains are simply not sustainable," said Michael Derks, senior market strategist for Nomura Securities in London.
Brazil caused a panic in world financial markets last Wednesday when it devalued its currency by 8 percent, setting off fears that the country could succumb to an Asian-style currency crisis. A crisis in Brazil's economy, the largest in Latin America, could drag down other countries in the region. Today, however, the Brazilian stock market rose 5.43 percent, or 366.58 points, to 7,113.32.
Stocks made strong gains across Europe and North America. The DAX index in Frankfurt rose 2.07 percent; the Paris CAC 40 index ended 2.39 percent higher; the Mibtel index in Milan rose 2.41 percent, and the IBEX-35 index in Madrid was up 4.95 percent.
The Mexican stock market rose about five-tenths of 1 percent, or 20 points, to close at 3,637.77.
Market watchers credited the gains to a recovery last week on Wall Street and other world stock exchanges after moves by the Brazilian Government to stabilize its economy.
United States financial markets were closed today for Martin Luther King Jr. Day. On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 2.41 percent when it became apparent that Brazil's Government would stop spending its dwindling foreign reserves defending its faltering currency.
Asian exchanges opened sharply higher today, although many fell back by the end of trading.
Tokyo's benchmark 225-issue Nikkei stock index was higher at the start but lost much of its steam, finishing up about half of a percent.
The Hang Seng index opened sharply higher in Hong Kong. By the end of trading, the blue-chip register had soared 2.51 percent.
And the Korea composite stock price index in Seoul closed up 1.27 percent.
Markets gained a hefty 4.4 percent in Manila; the Straits Times index in Singapore was up 2.7 percent, and the NZSE-40 capital index in New Zealand advanced 2.2 percent.
One weak spot was China, where the two stock markets opened largely unchanged. Traders said prices could fall because of growing numbers of Chinese companies warning of low profits.
Shares in Taiwan also ended lower on profit taking after.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 651 words

HEADLINE: State of the Agendas

 BODY:
By tradition and the tense circumstances of the moment, this is President Clinton's day. In the evening, Mr. Clinton will march into a House chamber torn by emotion and partisanship over impeachment to deliver his seventh State of the Union speech. The address is to follow, by a few hours, the opening of Mr. Clinton's defense in the Senate. The President is not the only figure on the spot, however. Today the Republican Congressional leadership must begin a year of engaging a President with high approval ratings on something more than his personal scandals.
Mr. Clinton has always seemed most at home in these addresses, and the White House has skillfully leaked details in advance. There will be aid for the elderly, disabled and schoolchildren, with tax credits the preferred mechanism. Projected budget surpluses should be set aside to "save Social Security first," a mantra that proved effective last year in fending off Republican tax cuts. The speech is to call for more teachers, more strict Federal education standards, more police and more money for military readiness and to preserve open spaces, but not too much more money. It all has a familiar centrist ring. Riding the crest of a gravity-defying economic boom, Mr. Clinton must feel that there is no sense in abandoning what works politically. 
 As they brace for an address centered on these issues, the Republicans are a picture of fractious internal dissent. Dennis Hastert, the genial but untested House Speaker, has yet to articulate his priorities, beyond declaring that he is not Newt Gingrich. In the last couple of weeks, alarmed Republican leaders have been hit by new polls and complaints from top fund-raisers that voter impatience with the impeachment process has sent the party to its lowest standing in a generation. They know that they must put together their own legislative agenda as soon as everyone can agree on what it is.
Republican strategists say they want this Congress to concentrate on five broad areas: tax cuts, primary and secondary education, crime and drugs, national defense and Social Security. But the word is that they will try, at least at first, to be conciliatory to the White House and see if some agreements can be reached on things like school construction and aid for special education. Some party leaders seem to fear that the wounds will be so raw after the Senate trial and verdict on Mr. Clinton that they must seize on something, anything, to show they can cooperate with the White House.
Whether Mr. Clinton will be in a mood to cooperate and compromise is another question. Some Democrats will advise the White House that more confrontation with Republicans will better position the party's candidates in the 2000 election. Social Security is certain to be the early test. Last week Democrats and Republicans said a Social Security deal, leaving the system basically intact but making room for voluntary private investment accounts, is already being discussed.
Mr. Clinton, for his part, would like to prove wrong those who are predicting that the impeachment process will leave him politically immobilized even if it leaves him in office. He seems to want to settle the Social Security problem first, rescuing the system from insolvency as baby boomers start to retire in 15 years. The Administration wants a commitment on using some of the projected budget surpluses -- $1.5 trillion over the next 10 years, by some measures -- to keep Social Security functioning, and later decide whether to make additional surplus money available for other priorities, like tax cuts. Republicans are likely to want tax cuts to be a part of any Social Security deal.
Mr. Clinton has an excruciating balancing act to pull off tonight. But so do the Republicans. They are now at war over impeachment. Soon they will have to decide whether to continue that war on the legislative front.

SECTION: Section A; Page 9; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1335 words

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Christopher S. Wren

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
GERMANY: U.S. TO HAND OVER SPY FILES -- The United States has agreed to hand over East German foreign intelligence files believed to include lists of the names of agents who spied for East Berlin, the German Government said. The files were bought by Central Intelligence Agency agents nearly 10 years ago in the aftermath of the fall of the Berlin wall. Bonn has repeatedly asked the agency to return the files, which it says are vital for identifying public figures who spied on their fellow citizens. (Reuters)
 
RUSSIA: ENVIRONMENT IMPROVES -- Environmental conditions in Russia have improved in recent months because of the fall in industrial production since the August financial crisis. Viktor Danilov-Danilyan, head of the state committee for the environment, said industry now gives off 35 percent less air pollution than in 1991, and 15 to 18 percent less water-borne and other pollutants. (Reuters) 

NORTHERN IRELAND: BLUEPRINT BACKED -- Taking opponents of the Belfast peace accord by surprise, a strong majority of Protestant and Catholic politicians in Northern Ireland's new legislature voted to support a blueprint for a compromise government. The 74-to-27 vote endorsed a document presented by two politicians, David Trimble, a Protestant, and Seamus Mallon, a Catholic. It details 10 new government departments, with Protestants and Catholics sharing top posts equally. (AP)
 
BRITAIN: EARLY FREEDOM FOR PRISONERS -- Britain is seeking to control its soaring jail population by releasing thousands of prisoners early with electronic tags to monitor their movements. The first prisoners will be released on Jan. 28, a Home Office spokesman said, and up to 4,000 petty criminals will be freed over the next few months. (Reuters)
 
TURKEY: KURD STILL AT LARGE -- The Italian Prime Minister, Massimo D'Alema, said Turkey had lost out by rejecting an international trial for the Kurdish guerrilla leader Abdullah Ocalan, who left Rome over the weekend for an unknown destination. The Russian Government said it was checking reports that Mr. Ocalan had passed through Russia en route to a third country. (Reuters, Agence France-Presse)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: FOREIGN INVESTMENT FALLS -- After several years of steady growth, foreign investment in Israel fell 40 percent in 1998 from the previous year, the Bank of Israel reported. Total foreign investment in Israeli companies, including purchases in concerns listed on stock exchanges in the United States, fell to $2 billion from $3.45 billion in 1997. (Agence France-Presse)
 
KUWAIT: TRIP TO ISRAEL DEFENDED -- The editor of the Kuwaiti newspaper al-Seyassah, Ahmad al-Jarallah, defended one of his journalists who was detained for visiting Israel, telling prosecutors he would have gone. The reporter, Hamid Buyabis, was released last week on $3,500 bail after state security officials questioned him for three days. Kuwait's Parliament and the Journalists Association condemned Mr. Buyabis's visit to Israel, with which Kuwait is technically still at war. (Reuters)
 
YEMEN: MORE FOREIGNERS KIDNAPPED -- Two British and four Dutch citizens were kidnapped Sunday in northern Yemen, an Interior Ministry official said. Less than three weeks ago three Britons and an Australian were killed when Yemeni soldiers tried to rescue 16 Western hostages. (AP)
 
ASIA
 
INDIA: FUROR OVER CRICKET -- While militant Hindus in New Delhi, left, demonstrated against the Government's decision to let Pakistan's cricket team play in India later this month, a rampaging mob in Bombay attacked the offices of the Cricket Club of India, breaking windows and smashing furniture. Authorities believe the assailants were members of Shiv Sena, an ultra right-wing Hindu political group. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
JAPAN: OPPOSITION LEADER RE-ELECTED -- The opposition Democratic Party of Japan re-elected its popular leader, Naoto Kan, by a wide margin. Mr. Kan, who tops polls as the politician Japanese would most like to see become Prime Minister, easily beat out his only rival, Shigefumi Matsuzawa. (AP)
 
NORTH, SOUTH KOREA: NEW TALKS STARTING -- The fourth round of talks between North and South Korea, China and the United States to hammer out a formal peace for the divided peninsula are set to resume in Geneva. They follow inconclusive discussions last weekend about access to a North Korean underground center suspected of being the site of nuclear weapon activity in violation of a 1994 agreement. (NYT)
 
MALDIVES: MOSES MOVIE ATTACKED -- The Indian Ocean nation has banned the Hollywood animated movie "The Prince of Egypt," calling its portrayal of Moses offensive. Officials said the account of the flight of Jews from Egypt to Israel was based on "pure biblical propaganda" and ran contrary to the teachings of the Koran. Muslims consider Moses and Jesus prophets. The Maldives previously banned "The Ten Commandments" and "Ben Hur." (Agence France-Presse)
 
AFRICA
 
ZIMBABWE: EX-PRESIDENT SENTENCED -- Former President Canaan Banana was sentenced to 10 years in jail, nine of them suspended, for sodomy and indecent assault. Mr. Banana, 62, was convicted last November, but fled before he could be sentenced. The former Methodist minister and Zimbabwe's titular President for seven years, returned home on Dec. 15. Mr. Banana was given leave to appeal. Suzanne Daley (NYT)
 
CONGO: PEACE PACT REPORTED -- Leaders of countries involved in the civil war in Congo have agreed to sign a cease-fire to end five months of fighting, President Sam Nujoma of Namibia said. But rebels battling Congo's President, Laurent Kabila, expressed skepticism about a breakthrough. Neither Mr. Kabila nor the rebels were invited to the talks in Namibia. Chad, Namibia and Zimbabwe are fighting alongside Mr. Kabila against a rebellion backed by Rwanda and Uganda. (Reuters)
 
CONGO REPUBLIC: CUBAN FIGHTERS ARRIVE -- Some 300 Cuban mercenaries have arrived in Brazzaville to support President Denis Sassou Nguesso, the Vatican news agency Fides said in Rome. The agency said the Cubans were siding with Government troops already backed by Chadians and Angolans. (Agence France-Presse)
 
SOMALIA: THE STARVING ABANDON HOMES -- Thousands of people fighting hunger in southern Somalia have abandoned their homes and are heading to towns or border areas in search of food, aid workers said. Rates of malnutrition among children have risen to more than 20 percent in the drought-stricken Bay and Bakool regions, Somalia's traditional breadbasket, where fighting between militia groups has added to the crisis. The United Nations says 300,000 people are at "very high risk" of starvation in the area. (Reuters)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
GRENADA: VOTERS GO TO POLLS -- Facing allegations of corruption and defections from his party, Prime Minister Keith Mitchell went to the polls against a loose and fraying coalition of opposition parties. Voters turned out before dawn. Mr. Mitchell was forced to call the election 18 months early after he lost a majority in Parliament. (AP)
 
MEXICO: 5 MILLION CHILD WORKERS -- At least five million children are working in Mexico, and about half of them have dropped out of school, according to a study by the Legislative Assembly's Employment and Social Welfare Protection Commission. About 70 percent of the child laborers work between five and 14 hours a day, the daily La Jornada reported. (AP)
 
VENEZUELA: A WARNING TO CONGRESS -- President-elect Hugo Chavez warned that he might dissolve Congress if it blocked his plan to call a referendum to create a popular assembly with the power to rewrite the Constitution. The former paratrooper, who scored a landslide victory in presidential elections last month, attacked legislators who argued that his proposal required a previous constitutional reform. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Bennett Harrison, 56, Urban Economist, Dies

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Bennett Harrison, a leading radical economist, vocal critic of United States economic policy and the co-author of the 1983 book "The De-Industrialization of America," died at home on Sunday of complications from cancer of the esophagus. He was 56 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.
Professor Harrison was professor of urban political economy at the New School for Social Research and had just completed the latest of a dozen books that shared one common message: the need, in his view, for Washington to play a bigger role to counter what he saw as the dark side of the Wall Street economy. 
 A native of Jersey City, Professor Harrison grew up in an atmosphere of ethnic tensions; his father changed the family name from Horowitz to Harrison to get a job at a radio station. An ambitious student, he relied on scholarships -- first at Brandeis University, then at the University of Pennsylvania, where he earned a Ph.D. in economics in 1970.
In his heart, though, he never entirely left Jersey City. His academic career reflected an interest in the fate of cities and their inhabitants, especially blacks.
His first book was about economic development in Harlem, and his latest academic research, mostly financed by the Ford Foundation, concerned community development and job training.
He helped found the Union of Radical Political Economists in the late 1960's but revered the progressives of the 1930's rather than Marx.
A lively teacher and a popular thesis adviser, he spent most of his career as a member of the urban studies and planning department at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He only gave up his full professorship there to follow his then-wife to Carnegie Mellon in Pittsburgh in 1991.
Professor Harrison was very much a public intellectual. For upward of 30 years, he played this role mostly in a duet with his best friend and frequent collaborator, Barry Bluestone, an economist at Northeastern University in Boston. Mr. Harrison devised economic development plans for a series of left-leaning Democratic Presidential contenders, starting in 1972 with Senator Fred Harris of Oklahoma. The plans addressed segments of the economy where in his view Government could play a greater role -- public works, environmental clean up and mass transit. His prescription scarcely changed in subsequent campaigns and with subsequent candidates. While he believed that markets could produce wealth efficiently, he doubted that they could share it equitably, and he believed that government somehow could.
A writer with a breezy style and an eye for big ideas, more popular with readers of editorials than with members of the economics fraternity, Professor Harrison was one of the first to articulate the middle-class malaise, a recurring theme of the 1980's. In "The De-Industrialization of America," written with Professor Bluestone during the deep recession of 1981-82,, he argued that plant closings and layoffs, not the strong dollar, were weakening American manufacturing and the blue-collar communities that depended on factories. By urging Washington to follow Tokyo's lead and adopt a policy of subsidizing favorite industries like autos and aircraft, he helped stimulate a national debate. The New York Times reviewer, an economic adviser to the Carter Administration, called the book intensely irritating but important.
Five years later, in 1988, Professor Harrison, again in tandem with his best friend, turned his attention to inequality, a topic that was to become hot during the 1992 Clinton-Bush contest. In "The Great U-Turn," Professor Harrison argued that the gap between high- and low-wage workers was exploding largely because of shrinking factory employment and the collapse of the power of the unions.
While Professor Harrison's analysis was not widely accepted -- economists pretty well agree that inequality reflects the growing demand for educated workers by an economy increasingly dominated by services -- he had once again succeeded in striking a nerve.
Known for his willingness to engage people of varying views in friendly debate -- from the competitiveness guru Michael Porter to Housing and Urban Development Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo -- Professor Harrison was not afraid to change his mind.
While he and Processor Bluestone were routinely introduced as Drs. Doom and Gloom in the 1980's, his penultimate book, "Lean and Mean," celebrated the vitality of large corporations like I.B.M. and Intel. And his last book, which Professor Bluestone was promoting in Europe last week, is a paean to America's resurgent economy. Still, says his co-author, a central theme is that only Washington, not the private sector, can insure that the wealth is spread around.
Besides economics, Professor Harrison's passions were baseball and jazz. In college, he pitched for Brandeis by day and played tenor saxophone in cafes around Boston by night. At one point, he dropped out of school for a year to tour jazz clubs around the country. He was delighted to get a job offer from the New School in 1996 partly because it meant he could immerse himself in the New York music scene. When he learned he was dying, he arranged to donate his instrument, a 1939 Martin, to the New School's jazz program to pass along to a younger, impecunious musician.
Professor Harrison is survived by his wife, Joan Fitzgerald, an urban planner at the University of Illinois at Chicago, whom he married just days before his death; his father, Leo of Springfield, N.J.; his sister, Deborah Kuperman of Highland Park, N.J., and his former wife, Maryann Kelly, a sociologist in Washington.

HEADLINE: Clinton's School Plan Praised for Goals, if Not Means

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
President Clinton's proposal to use Federal education money to hold public schools accountable drew a mixed reaction from Republicans and educators yesterday. While almost all said they shared his goals, some opposed his means: the increased role of the Federal Government in local schools.
The proposal, expected to be prominent in Mr. Clinton's State of the Union speech tonight, would financially reward school districts that adhere to Federal guidelines that will be drafted on the training of teachers, enforcement of classroom discipline and an end to the the promotion of unqualified students. Schools that fail to meet the guidelines would be penalized. 
 Accountability has become the focus of many politicians and educators who favor increasing money for schools that produce results. But the President is likely to run into strong opposition from many Republicans who argue that the Federal Government should leave these matters to the states and local school districts.
"The President has proposed a national school board," charged Lamar Alexander, the former Education Secretary and Tennessee Governor, who is expected to seek the Republican Presidential nomination in 2000. "But we should go exactly in the opposite direction -- liberating the schools, not regulating them. We should send the money to the parents and let them choose where their children attend school."
Linda Chavez, president of the conservative Center for Equal Opportunity and a former senior official in the Reagan Administration, disagreed. She said it was a good idea to tie accountability to financing, because it is generally the schools that fail that receive more aid, not those that succeed.
"I like to see success rewarded, and I say that as long as there are Federal dollars going in to the school system, keeping it accountable is a good idea," she said. "I don't see any point in being overly ideological on this question of local control. I would urge Republicans to do what they did with welfare control -- seize on it and take it further."
Last year, President Clinton failed to persuade Congress to authorize uniform testing of fourth and eighth graders and money for fixing up schools in disrepair, in both cases because Republicans argued that these issues should be handled locally. On the other hand, they agreed on a plan by the president to spend $1 billion to help local districts hire 100,000 more teachers by compromising on how the money would be distributed.
Federal aid to education is quite limited, amounting to about 7 percent of overall spending on schools. It comes largely through the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, first passed in 1965 and due to come up for renewal this year.
The debate over renewal is likely to be contentious. Some $8 billion is disbursed to poor schools through the act, and conservatives have expressed doubts about the effectiveness of the program.
Like Mr. Alexander, some conservatives have been arguing that the public school system needs to be drastically altered through the expansion of charter schools and the use of school vouchers.
Adam Urbanski, a vice president of the American Federation of Teachers, said Mr. Clinton's proposal was an effort to combat the growing voucher and charter movements by improving all public schools.
"Vouchers and charters are most likely to thrive when there is no accountability, when there is no way to determine whether public schools are succeeding," he said. "President Clinton is sending the message that public schools are salvageable. The best way to restore confidence in public schools is to get better results in public schools. And that comes about through tough love."
The President's proposal calls for schools to meet several criteria, among them:
*States would have to distribute to all parents annual report cards for each school and school district;
*Schools would have to end what is called "social promotion," or moving pupils to the next grade irrespective of their performance;
*Schools would have to increase the quality of teachers by insisting on ongoing training for experienced teachers and high scores on tests for new ones;
*And schools would have to adopt tough discipline policies such as uniforms, enforcing truancy laws and imposing curfews.
A number of states have already adopted some or all of these approaches, and the President's advisers say his plan aims to complement those efforts. "We're saying that states and school districts must be accountable in helping all students reach high standards," Secretary of Education Richard Riley said at a Washington briefing yesterday. "It's really a way to help states and school districts see that that's done."
Marc S. Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, a strong advocate of national standards, said the argument over local control seemed to have little meaning as long as the Federal government is spending money.
"As long as the Federal government is providing billions of dollars to schools, taxpayers will reasonably ask what they are getting for their money," he said. "This should be a proposal that Republicans who are so interested in results can embrace."
But Charles L. Glenn, a professor of education policy at Boston University, who for 21 years directed urban education for the state of Massachusetts, said there was good reason to be concerned about more Federal regulations on local schools. "It sounds like a terrific idea but unanticipated consequences crop up," he said. "I consider Federal funds to be an awkward instrument for these policies. This will tie the hands of folks at the local level."
Chester E. Finn, Jr., an assistant secretary of education under President Reagan, said he did not see how the Federal Government could "micromanage 15,000 school districts." He added, "The test of this debate will be to see whether Republicans have a better idea how to do this."

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN BRAZIL: THE LENDERS;
Approval of Rate Policy, But No New Financial Aid

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund and the United States said today that they were heartened by Brazil's pledge to keep interest rates high and slash its budget deficit. But they offered no new financial aid and made clear that Brazil's economic fate is largely in its own hands.
As they shuttled around Washington seeking to explain and build support for their Government's decision to allow its currency to float in value, Brazilian officials said they had heard the message and were prepared to do what it took to re-establish the country's credibility in the ultimate court of economic policy, the financial markets. 
 Even before Brazil's central bank announced tonight that it was increasing overnight interest rates, Pedro Malan, Brazil's Finance Minister, told a news conference here that President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's administration was determined to take whatever steps necessary to avert a crippling new round of inflation. And he said the Government would intensify efforts to push through a package of tax increases and spending cuts intended to bring the budget deficit under control.
"We know additional measures may be required" to improve the country's fiscal condition, keep the economy on track and maintain the confidence of investors, Mr. Malan said.
Mr. Malan met today with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary.
Afterward, a senior American official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there was a "shared judgment that the most important thing in Brazil was the pursuit of strong policies, which especially meant carrying through on deficit reduction measures, strong anti-inflation monetary policies and continued structural reforms."
The American official said Mr. Malan "made clear his own determination and President Cardoso's determination in a very complex political environment to carry through effectively; that was certainly something we welcomed."
Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, also offered encouraging words. "I am personally very satisfied with the conversations that I.M.F. staff and management have had over the last weekend with Minister Malan and the Brazilian team," Mr. Camdessus said.
Mr. Malan said after arriving in Washington on Saturday that Brazil might ask the I.M.F. and individual countries, including the United States, to speed planned aid payments due to Brazil under a $41.5 billion assistance program negotiated last fall. The next set of loans, about $9 billion, is scheduled for release next month.
Brazilian and American officials said today, however, that there were no discussions about granting the loans ahead of schedule. Economists said that since Brazil was no longer daily defending the value of the currency, the real, the country had less immediate need to bolster its foreign currency reserves.
But Brazil, which took the first steps last week toward abandoning its old stable exchange rate policy without informing the I.M.F. and the Clinton Administration, will now have to accept closer scrutiny by the international lending organizations and the countries providing it with aid, including the United States.
In a statement issued here today, Mr. Malan said Brazil would "intensify its dialogue" with the organizations and countries providing aid and would "establish new and more intensive procedures of continuous consultation" with the I.M.F., including the possible opening of an I.M.F. office in Brasilia.
With financial markets around the world reacting favorably again today to Brazil's new currency strategy, and with the United States and the I.M.F. providing their stamp of approval, Brazil appears to have come through what could have been a disastrous collapse of its old strategy without any serious damage.
But the true test will come only when the country hits its next economic bump, as it inevitably will, or when an outbreak of the financial turmoil that has plagued the world since mid-1997 next sweeps through the markets.
Economists and policy makers see two possible outcomes for Brazil. Under the optimistic version, a temporary increase in interest rates and quick action to rein in the budget deficit restores confidence in the markets, allowing the currency to stabilize without dropping much further. Interest rates then come down, and the devalued currency allows Brazil to export more easily, helping economic growth without fueling inflation.
Under the pessimistic version, continued downward pressure on the value of the currency forces the central bank to keep interest rates cripplingly high. The economy stalls, forcing politicians into an agonizing choice between weathering a painful recession or reducing rates, a move that could send the currency plummeting and inflation sharply higher.
In 1992, Britain abandoned a policy of keeping the pound stable in value relative to the other main European currencies after a speculative attack of the sort that has become increasingly common in countries with underlying economic problems. Britain's finance minister at the time said the collapse of the stable exchange rate policy had him singing in the shower because it allowed him to reduce rates and give a boost to the domestic economy without worrying about the currency.
Given its history of hyperinflation and doubts among investors about its willingness to deal with its fiscal deficit, Brazil does not have that luxury. Mr. Malan, to the relief of the I.M.F. and the United States, explicitly said as much in his statement today, a message reinforced by the central bank's quick move to raise interest rates to help prop up the currency.
"In the new exchange rate regime, fiscal and monetary policies will have to play an even more crucial role in insuring price stability and conditions for sustained economic growth," Mr. Malan said.

HEADLINE: In Race to Develop Blue Lasers, Japanese Star Surges Ahead

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
A lone Japanese inventor has outrun some of the world's largest and most advanced high-technology corporations in the race to develop a new generation of short-wavelength lasers. The achievement is likely to hasten the introduction of high-definition digital video disks, higher-resolution laser printing and inexpensive and highly efficient light bulbs for use in the home.
The inventor, Shuji Nakamura, is a semiconductor researcher who has worked for more than a decade in relative isolation and has excelled in finding innovations in material science. Last week his small company, Nichia Chemical Industries, announced that it had begun shipping sample quantities of violet lasers with a life span of 10,000 hours, the level of reliability required by consumer electronics companies. The samples are going to a variety of companies planning to develop prototype products. 
 Such lasers, in the blue and violet part of the spectrum and with a shorter wavelength than the infrared or red light that is now commonly used to read compact disks, have been pursued for years by companies including United States and Japanese giants like 3M, Hewlett-Packard, Sony and Toshiba. In digital storage, such an advance is particularly impressive because each time the wavelength of laser light is halved, the beam can then store four times the data.
That the race has so far gone to Nichia (nih-KEY-uh) is a payoff for its long-term investment in pursuing this technology, which many corporations deemed a high risk. It may also indicate how Japanese and United States companies have reversed roles in recent years. Officials of United States companies said yesterday that they still thought they could win the race to incorporate the technology into products and bring them to market first. From the 1950's through the 1970's, Japanese companies successfully commercialized technologies invented in the United States.
The next barrier will be reducing the cost of producing the lasers and devising technical standards that will provide compatibility with existing applications.
Mr. Nakamura first burst onto the scientific stage in November 1993 when Nichia announced that he had succeeded in fabricating a bright blue light-emitting diode, another kind of widely used light source.
His advance came just two years after the International Business Machines Corporation had decided to scale back its effort in laser research, partly in the belief that the market would not be large enough in the near future. Yesterday, I.B.M. researchers said they were impressed by the Nichia achievement.
"I'd call it a piece of technical work that is absolutely remarkable, and it stands on its own," said Bill Lenth, manager of science and technology at the I.B.M. Almaden research laboratory in San Jose, Calif.
But other American competitors refused to concede the international race to commercialize the technology. And further breakthroughs in short-wavelength lasers -- like blue lasers, which could lead to higher-resolution computer displays -- have yet to be achieved.
"He's really a leader in this field," said Waguih Ishak, director of Hewlett-Packard's Communications and Optics Research Laboratory in Palo Alto, Calif. "He's ahead, but it's a marathon and we've just started."
Hewlett-Packard ramped up its multimillion-dollar research program in lasers and light-emitting diodes (L.E.D.'s) shortly after Mr. Nakamura's breakthrough in 1993. Mr. Ishak said the company had now caught up in the L.E.D. market, and he said he was pushing hard to catch Nichia in the laser race.
"This is something I can't fail in," he said.
The commercial application of the new lasers is expected to have substantial impact. For example, they will make possible high-definition digital video disks, or HD DVD's, a step beyond the current digital video disks. The new disks will deliver HDTV-quality movies, concerts and stage presentations. In addition, music publishers could publish entire anthologies on a single HD DVD, carrying more than a dozen hours of music on each side.
Besides DVD applications, Mr. Nakamura said by E-mail that the violet semiconductor lasers would enable a new generation of digital tape recorders that will be similar to today's VCR machines but able to store high-definition video images.
While the most sought-after commercial applications for short-wavelength lasers are in the area of digital storage, there are many other practical uses, ranging from laser printers with twice the resolution of today's best-quality products to a new class of household lighting that could be 2 to 10 times as energy-efficient as today's fluorescent and incandescent light bulbs.
The Nichia researcher's breakthrough came from exploring an unusual class of materials known as gallium nitrides. Other companies had previously tried to use other materials to construct blue semiconductor lasers.
"He took an unorthodox, high-risk route, and he won," said Richard Doherty, president of Envisioneering, a computer and consumer electronics consulting concern based in Seaford, N.Y.
In addition to near-term digital storage applications, Mr. Doherty and other researchers said that inexpensive short-length lasers might make possible such futuristic technologies as optical computers, laser-based computer or television displays and perhaps a new generation of optical fiber communications systems or even ultra-high-speed laser optical communications sent directly through the air rather than by fiber optic wires.
In "The Blue Laser Diode," a book about his technology published in 1997, Mr. Nakamura wrote that the chairman of Nichia, Nobuo Ogawa, had originally invested $3.3 million in the laser diode project, or about 1.5 percent of the company's annual sales at that time. The amount is much higher than what companies usually invest in the work of one researcher.
Despite the acclaim for Mr. Nakamura's achievement, executives of one small United States company that is a close competitor of Nichia predicted that they would win the race to commercialization.
"I think there are still huge questions to be answered about pricing and volume production," said Neal Hunter, chief executive of the company, Cree Research Inc. of Durham, N.C.
In the race to build inexpensive L.E.D.'s, Nichia was first to market, but others ultimately managed to produce them more cheaply, he argued, saying that the same economics might hold true in the semiconductor laser race.
Cree is gambling on a technology using silicon carbide, rather than gallium nitride, and Mr. Hunter said the company believed that it would make products easier to manufacture and with better heat dissipation -- properties that will be crucial in low-cost applications.

HEADLINE: Environmentalists Battle Growth of Ski Resorts

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, Colo., Jan. 18

 BODY:
Next weekend, skiers here are to inaugurate the world's highest chair lift. Whisking 1,200 skiers an hour to a 12,700-foot ridge, the lift will offer sweeping views of the Rockies and challenging runs down the Continental Divide.
But in a sign of changing times in the nation's most popular skiing state, a Colorado environmentalist is suing, asserting that Loveland Ski Area, owners of the lift, violated its Federal permit for building on national forest land. 
 After fighting logging, mining and cattle grazing on national forest lands, environmentalists declared open season this winter on ski areas, once a seemingly wholesome presence in the landscape. The expansion of ski areas, mostly on public land, that once aroused little opposition is now being fought by groups who are angry over growing real estate development on adjacent private land.
Increasingly run by publicly traded corporations, ski areas are turning to mountain real estate as a source for big profits in the future. In contrast, the number of lift tickets sold nationwide each winter has been stagnant for a decade, at around 53 million. In that period, ticket sales in Colorado increased by about 20 percent, but the state has seen its ski ticket sales drop 11 percent this season as some resorts endured their scantiest Christmas season snow in 40 years.
"It is not about skiing, it is about real estate development," said Jonathan J. Staufer, a shop owner in Vail who is chairman of the Ski Area Citizens Coalition, a new environmental group. "Industrial tourism is posing the next major threat to wild places in Colorado and America."
Here in the High Rockies, signs of growth abound.
Directly below Loveland's new Continental Divide chair lift, but muffled by a quarter mile of granite, traffic on Interstate 70 regularly slows to a crawl in the Eisenhower Tunnel, a major link between Colorado's busiest ski areas and the two million people in greater Denver. In 25 years, traffic has quadrupled in the tunnel, 60 miles west of Denver.
In the 75 miles between here and Eagle-Vail Airport, enough home construction is planned to double the populations of several towns in five years. A rural airstrip in 1990, the airport is Colorado's second busiest this winter, offering direct jet service to 13 cities, including New York and San Francisco.
On public lands, recreation is shaping up as the new battleground. In the last decade, while the volume of timber cut in national forests fell by two-thirds, the number of recreational visitors jumped by 40 percent With hikers, hunters, bikers, campers and skiers increasingly dominating forest policy, the United States Forest Service predicts it will record one billion recreational visits a year by 2010.
"Now we see lawsuits, not only against oil, gas and mining, but also to stop recreational use," the chief of the Forest Service, Mike Dombeck, said in Denver recently, after encountering protesters objecting to a 2,000-acre expansion of Vail into National Forest land.
In Colorado, where most skiing is done on national forest land, the conflict flared into the public eye in October when an amorphous group, the Environmental Liberation Front, protested the expansion of Vail's ski slopes by burning three buildings and damaging four lifts.
But in less dramatic fights, Colorado environmentalists are lobbying Federal agencies to block new ski trails at Keystone Resort and Breckenridge Ski Resort. Nearby, at Arapahoe Basin, they are trying to block the installation of a snow-making system that would fulfill that area's dream of becoming the nation's first to offer skiing year round.
Two weeks ago in Colorado, in the face of strong local opposition, a consortium of Vermont and Colorado developers abandoned plans to build a ski area 10 miles south of Steamboat Springs, which would have been called Catamount. In addition, the developers planned 3,700 new homes and 1,000 hotel rooms.
"They had the resources and they had the permits," said Susan Otis, executive director of the Yampa Valley Land Trust. "But they knew that in the community there no longer was a desire to have a new ski area."
Census figures show that Colorado has the third-fastest-growing population in the nation, after Nevada and Arizona. Now, defenders of the fragile lands in the Rockies are also worried that out-of-state demographic pressures will result in a proliferation of second-home developments and swelling crowds at ski areas.
On one end, the average age of a second-home buyer in the United States is 51. Over the next 18 years, 78 million Americans are to turn 51. Their children number 72 million and are expected to pack ski areas again. The intermediate group now in their 20's and 30's numbered only 44 million.
At public hearings in Vail last spring, one resident drew applause when he said, "We want to look at trophy elk, not trophy homes." At the hearings, most speakers spoke against the expansion plans of Vail, the nation's largest ski area.
Critics noted that within 40 miles of Vail, eight ski areas are already operating, with 126 lifts and 850 trails covering almost 15,000 acres. Vail Resorts is expanding its ski terrain by 19 percent, even though lift ticket sales dropped 5 percent last winter, to 1.6 million.
Two weeks ago, a company close to Vail Resorts, Turkey Creek LLC, successfully bid $42 million for a 2,900-acre parcel of private land that is a mile from the resort's new expanded area. The ski company has an option to buy half of Turkey Creek.
And Vail Resorts and the Intrawest Corporation, a Canadian company, are partners in the construction of 4,600 housing units at the Keystone ski area. Intrawest has a total $1 billion in construction planned at the nine ski areas it owns in the United States and Canada.
"The trend is to focus on real estate, while quietly selling some ski tickets on the side," said Sandy Shea, a director of High Country Citizens' Alliance, a group that opposes a 300-home development planned for private land next to Crested Butte Mountain Resort.
Noting that Crested Butte offers free skiing early in the season to fill company-owned hotel rooms, Mr. Shea added: "I don't think any ski area is making money off tickets. Most of the money is made from real estate."
When the Forest Service approves ski slopes near private land, the value of the private land jumps. Looking at ski lifts that serve mediocre slopes near vacation homes, some Colorado environmentalists derisively call them "real estate lifts."
"Ski-in, ski-out real estate commands a 25 percent premium," said Neil Adams, a real estate broker in Crested Butte. "When you, your wife and your five kids decide to go skiing, do you want to play taxi driver? Your kids can come home for lunch, no problem. Just ski right up to the door."
The ski industry describes as minuscule the 20,000 acres of ski area expansions planned on national forest lands around the nation. About one-quarter of the nation's 525 ski areas operate on Forest Service land, leasing about 190,000 acres out of total national forest holdings of 190 million acres.
"That means that on one-tenth of 1 percent of Forest Service land, 30 million people enjoy a winter recreation experience," said Michael Berry, president of the National Ski Areas Association, an industry group based near Denver.
While ski areas are magnets for growth, not all of the growth in second homes in the Colorado high country is tied to skiing.
"You can go to other areas of Colorado, where there are no ski areas, and trophy homes are being built," said Lyle Laverty, the Forest Service's top official for Colorado.
In the lawsuit against Loveland, the environmentalist, Steven Hannon, asserts that the Forest Service awarded permit for a 1,700-foot surface lift, then allowed the ski area to nearly triple the length of the lift and to change it to a chair lift.
Ken Abrahamson, the general manager of the ski area, which is fighting the suit in Federal District Court in Denver, said: "The Forest Service approved putting skiers on top of the ridge. We followed the process from A to Z."
Greg Walcher, Colorado's newly appointed director of the State Department of Natural Resources, has watched the Rocky Mountain economy shift dramatically to tourism from mining, grazing and logging, partly because of environmental opposition to extractive industries on public lands. Now he worries, Mr. Walcher said, that "some people want to slow tourism down, then shut it down."
"It would be a horrible mistake not to take them seriously," he said.

HEADLINE: Requests Are to Include More Aid for Russia

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
In his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night, President Clinton will insist that the United States substantially increase its financial assistance to Russia to minimize the threat posed by the Russian nuclear arsenal, Administration officials say.
"The President believes it's in the national security interest of the American people that we work with Russia and other former Soviet countries to reduce the risk that materials, technology and expertise for weapons of mass destruction fall into the hands of rogue nations or terrorists," David Leavy, a National Security Council spokesman, said today. 
 Another senior official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Clinton was concerned about "people trying to sell what has value."
"As Russia is in a period of greater economic distress, it is even more in our interest to accelerate these programs," the official said.
The Administration officials said the President would propose spending $4.2 billion over the next five years, a 68 percent increase over the $2.5 billion already budgeted.
The new money would be used in these areas:
*To dismantle warheads and other weapons.
*To redirect Russian scientists and scientific institutes into civilian pursuits.
*To tighten controls over non-nuclear weapons and materials like chemical and biological weapons and missile parts and help the Russians beef up their export controls.
*To assist in the relocation of Russian troops now stationed outside the country.
The President will emphasize that the money will not be available to institutions that offer nuclear assistance to Iran. Last week, the White House announced economic sanctions against three Russian institutions that the Administration said were helping Iran and possibly other nations develop nuclear weapons and missiles.
In an interview, Michael Krepon, president of the Henry L. Stimson Center, a military research organization here, and an expert on Russian nuclear weapons, said the increased spending to be proposed would be "a good down payment to solve an important problem."
Asked how much it would cost to solve the problem once and for all, Mr. Krepon replied, "There isn't a soul who knows the answer."
The request for additional financial assistance to Russia will be the centerpiece of the quarter of the speech devoted to foreign and military policy, the officials said. They said the President would also talk about efforts to contain the threat from Iraq and to achieve peace in the Middle East, Northern Ireland and the Balkans.
Mr. Clinton will also press for a five-year increase in the Defense Department budget, with an emphasis on improving the ability of troops to respond quickly to emergencies, and will call on the Senate to approve the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. As long as the United States does not join the 151 other nations who have signed the treaty, the President plans to say, this country will lack the moral authority to persuade India and Pakistan to stop testing nuclear weapons.
Other passages will involve United States policy in Asia and Africa, and there will be a sizable section on trade and international economics. The President will urge Congress to reinstate his authority to negotiate trade agreements under a process that would allow Congress to approve or reject the pacts but not amend them.
In 1991, in the aftermath of the fall of the Soviet Union, Congress approved legislation that provided money to Russia and other former Soviet states to help them dismantle their nuclear arsenals and create safe storage for weapons-grade nuclear material.
This is called the Nunn-Lugar program after its chief sponsors, former Senator Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat who headed the Armed Services Committee, and Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, a former chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.
An Administration official said that somewhat more than $1 billion had been spent since the program's inception.
A spokesman for Mr. Lugar, now the second-ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee, said that the Senator had been briefed on President Clinton's proposed expansion of the program and supported the initiative.
But the President's plan could still run into difficulty in Congress, because many Republicans do not trust the Russians and are wary about giving them assistance.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Propose Tax Break For Parents Who Stay at Home

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
President Clinton will embrace an idea long favored by conservatives and propose a tax break for parents who stay home to care for their children, White House officials said today.
The proposed tax credit, up to $250 a year for each child under age 1, is smaller than the tax breaks proposed by Republicans for the same purpose. But the Administration now accepts the Republican argument that the Government should recognize the value of services provided by a parent, generally the mother, who forgoes paid employment to stay home and care for the children. 
 "The President believes we should respect and support parents in whatever choices they make, whether to work or to stay at home," said Bruce N. Reed, Mr. Clinton's chief domestic policy adviser. "Mothers or fathers who stay home to raise a child need help too."
In the past, Mr. Clinton has offered several proposals to make child care more affordable to working parents.
Administration officials said Mr. Clinton would probably highlight his child care proposals, including the tax credit, in his State of the Union Message to Congress on Tuesday. Republicans led by Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island proposed a similar tax credit last year, and they intend to try again this year.
In addition, White House officials said, Mr. Clinton will propose a tax credit to encourage small businesses to provide health insurance to employees. Under the proposal, employers with fewer than 50 workers could get the tax credits for two years if they established or joined a purchasing coalition to obtain health insurance.
Employers would receive a tax credit of $500 a year for each family insured through a coalition, and $200 for each person covered as an individual.
Small businesses are much less likely than big companies to provide health insurance to their employees, in part because the premiums are higher and the costs less predictable. Small businesses have generated most of the nation's new jobs, and this helps explain why the ranks of the uninsured are growing even as the nation's economy expands and employment rises to record levels.
About 11 million people are uninsured and work for companies with fewer than 25 employees. They account for nearly half of all uninsured workers and nearly one-fourth of people without insurance.
Administration officials said tonight that Mr. Clinton would also ask Congress for $1 billion to help poor people move from welfare to work next year. Labor Department officials said the money could help 200,000 people, by subsidizing jobs for school dropouts, long-term welfare recipients and other people with few skills. The plan was reported tonight by The Washington Post.
In the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, Congress provided $1.5 billion a year in "welfare-to-work grants" for 1998 and 1999. The President wants to extend the program for one more year, on the assumption that people who remain on welfare need extra help getting jobs.
White House officials said the tax break for small businesses would cost $44 million over five years. It would be available only to companies that did not provide health benefits to employees in 1997 or 1998.
The proposed tax credit for stay-at-home parents is part of a package of measures to subsidize child care that would cost more than $18 billion over five years. The tax credit would cost $1.3 billion over five years and would benefit 1.7 million families, the White House said.
Other items in the package would give additional tax relief based on income and child care expenses to working parents, to help offset child care costs, and would expand the main Federal program that subsidizes child care for families so poor that they pay no taxes.
Most of the child care proposals, aside from the assistance for parents who stay home, were included in Mr. Clinton's budget last year. He announced the proposals with fanfare at the White House in January 1998, but he did not fight hard for them on Capitol Hill. The proposals died in Congress, in part because their financing was linked directly to a big tobacco bill, strenuously opposed by the tobacco industry. There will be no such link this year.
Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee, said the President's proposals on child care and health insurance were intriguing.
But he said: "We have two questions. Is the White House inviting the Internal Revenue Service deeper into people's lives by complicating the tax code? Is the Clinton Administration paying for its initiatives by raising taxes on the American people?"
Republicans last year faulted Mr. Clinton for not proposing assistance to parents who stay home to care for children. The criticism came from moderates like Senator Chafee and conservatives like Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho. "The Government should not discriminate against parents who decide to stay home and take care of their kids," Mr. Craig said.
On another issue, the Administration has decided to seek a substantial increase in Federal grants to the states for services to people with severe mental illnesses. The grants would total $358 million, an increase of $70 million, or 24 percent, over this year's level.
