HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN BRAZIL: THE OVERVIEW;
BRAZILIANS PLEDGE MARKET CURRENCY

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Brazil said today that it would continue to allow market forces to set the value of its currency, the real, all but abandoning a policy to support the currency that was draining billions from its reserves of dollars.
With the Government still seeking some control over the currency, the nation's central bank raised interest rates on overnight loans today to keep the real from weakening further. Finance Minister Pedro Malan traveled to Washington and told American officials that President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's administration was determined to take whatever steps necessary to avert crippling new inflation. Page C8. 
 The Government's move on Friday to allow the real to trade freely against the dollar had lifted the benchmark stock market index here by 33.4 percent, and its announcement today kindled a further upswing, with the index rising 5.4 percent. Though New York exchanges were closed for a holiday, European markets rose. The real, however, fell an additional 10 percent, to a rate of 1.58 to the dollar. It has plunged 24 percent since the Government first moved to devalue the currency.
The decision by Brazil ends a policy that had been geared toward suppressing once-crippling inflation by pegging the currency to the dollar, which helps keep a tight rein on the money supply. That was a key feature of the so-called Real Plan, which was introduced in 1994. But the country could no longer afford to prop up the value of the currency by buying reais with its diminishing reserves, which must also be used to pay foreign debt. Brazil's economy has been stagnating; unemployment is at near-record levels; exports are falling and the trade deficit is way up, and the the nation's troubles have aroused fears of an Asian-style collapse that could weaken economies throughout the region, including in the United States.
The central bank said that "as of today," it would let market forces "define the exchange rate." It added that it might intervene in currency trading in the future, "occasionally and in a limited way, with the goal of countering disordered movement in exchange rates."
With the currency disconnected from the dollar, editorial cartoons in one newspaper pictured Mr. Malan and the new central bank president, Francisco Lopes, flying in a red purse in search of solutions to Brazil's difficulties. On Saturday, the handbag was shown taking them to Washington for talks with the International Monetary Fund, which has promised to lend $41.5 billion to help Brazil weather its crisis. Brazil has already received $9 billion from the package, and another $9 billion is to be released at the end of February. Brazilian and American officials said today that there were no discussions about granting the loans ahead of schedule.
Communications Minister Pimenta da Veiga said the President was "extremely impressed with the reaction of the markets" to Friday's devaluation, during which the real did not lose the 30 percent in value that economists had predicted. He said there would be "a period with moments of tension, certainly" but added, "The floating of the currency has had a very positive result."
A weak currency can help stimulate exports by making them cheaper abroad. But it also reduces the purchasing power of consumers, particularly when buying imports, and puts downward pressure on the currencies of neighboring nations.
President Cardoso told reporters in Brasilia today that devaluation would not make the real more vulnerable and that the currency could grow stronger. Now, he said, "we are more dependent on ourselves."
The attention of investors is turning to Brasilia, where Congress is expected to take the second of a series of votes needed to extend and increase a tax on financial transactions. The tax is part of an austerity plan, estimated at $23.5 billion in tax increases and spending cuts before the devaluation, that was a condition for Brazil to win I.M.F. backing for a standby loan last fall. The austerity plan is intended to reduce a huge budget deficit and restore confidence in the economy.
The Government is also sending a bill to Congress this week that would make civil servants contribute to the public pension system, which Congress has already rejected four times. Public workers enjoy generous lifetime pensions equal to, or higher than their salaries when working, and benefits for an estimated 1.8 million of them are expected to produce a $30 billion deficit this year.
If Congress acts decisively, said William Cline, chief economist at the Institute for International Finance in Washington, "chances are relatively good that confidence will rebuild, and that will allow the central bank to reduce interest rates and take a lot of the severe recessionary pressure off the economy."
After talks with officials at the fund this weekend, Mr. Malan said Brazil did not ask the I.M.F. to speed up the second installment of its loan. Mr. Malan said that "additional measures will be adopted, as appropriate, to deal with the fiscal impact of the exchange rate devaluation."
As investment specialists here braced for a possible new round of austerity moves from the Government, short-term interest rates rose. Martin Arranz, who tracks international markets at Banco Patente here, said he expected the Government to announce another series of measures in the next few weeks to help it pay debts due in 1999 that must be paid in dollars. He estimated such debt rose $13 billion with last week's devaluation.
"The worst has not happened yet," Mr. Arranz said. "With the money devalued, economic activity will shrink even more. Companies that began to invest are going to put on the brakes."
The President is insisting that Brazil has not abandoned the control of inflation, which sank below 1 percent last year and ran in three digits only a few years ago. Today, he called on businesses not to ignite instant inflation, which Mr. Malan estimated would reach 8 percent this year by raising prices in response to the devaluation.
Banking experts say that despite the devaluation, Brazil is in stronger condition to meet its foreign obligations than was Mexico in 1994-95 or South Korea in 1997, both of which devalued their currencies in response to financial crisis.
Across Latin America, major markets rose modestly on word that Brazil had abandoned its policy of spending dollar reserves to defend its currency. Only Argentina's benchmark index closed down, at 2.4 percent, with business leaders there calling for trade barriers to keep out a flood of suddenly cheaper Brazilian imports. The two countries are among the partners in Mercosur, a regional customs union and have extensive trade relations.

Graphs: "Turbulent Ride for Brazil"
A strong reaction to last Wednesday's loosening of central bank intervention in the Brazilian currency market led to a swift decision to let the real trade freely, which investors immediately rewarded. The news that Brazil would not defend the value of the real brought interest rates down from their peak, lessened the loss of U.S. dollars, and the stock market enjoyed robust gains. COUNTRY: BRAZIL (99%); UNITED STATES (95%); EUROPE (79%);

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1523 words

HEADLINE: Rikers Island Learns to Recycle;
Behind Razor Wire, Gardens and a Composting Plant

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
As weekly pickups of recyclable trash spread to all the neighborhoods of New York City, there is one eco-friendly urban corner that is way ahead of them, already providing pickups twice a week.
In the rest of the city, composting is confined to the odd backyard, but gardeners in this place compost six tons of food scraps and packaging a day. The $5 million plant where they do it, said to be the world's largest devoted to composting only food, has a roof made of photovoltaic cells, making it one of the city's most ambitious efforts to turn sunlight into electricity. 
 Last year, 30,000 pounds of vegetables were harvested here in the city's largest community garden. There are daily classes on garden design, plant care and other horticultural topics. There is a Zen meditation pond, an ornamental grass garden and a native woodlands area. Birds peck at suet in feeders as observers keep lists of species.
Environmentalists visiting this spot might think they had died and gone to eco-heaven, but this New York City address is nobody's idea of paradise. It is Rikers Island, home to 10 jails and 16,000 inmates, to tall fences, miles of menacing razor ribbon and ominous guard towers.
But the experimental jail farm is also a strikingly unexpected laboratory for solving one of the city's most intractable problems: getting rid of garbage. As Staten Island's Fresh Kills landfill prepares to close in 2001 and the city scrambles against mounting opposition to sending its trash out of state, environmentalists say the jail complex is demonstrating how to deal with more waste at home.
The Rikers experiment is explicitly part of a waste-management plan the city drafted in 1992 and updated last year. Ultimately, experts say, if the city meets its recycling goals, all of its food waste -- which at that point would be one-fourth of the city's total garbage -- could be composted within the five boroughs.
"The whole purpose here is to remove the word waste from the dictionary," said Thomas C. McCarthy, a spokesman with the City Department of Correction. "To take what used to be called waste and find a use for it."
Greater self-sufficiency is also the main benefit of the other environmental programs at Rikers. The farm last year raised 30,000 pounds of fresh vegetables for use in prison meals, an amount that would have cost $8,111 to buy.
Even more important, officials here say, are the practical and psychological benefits inmates gain from learning new, possibly money-making skills as well as from the simple pleasures of gardening.
"It's like serenity," said Frederick Lewis, 45, an inmate who finds that the rewards in his job in the landscaping program go far beyond the 15 cents an hour he is paid. "There's a sense of freedom."
From the prison authorities' perspective, the benefit is greater control of potentially unruly inmates. "You hardly have any violence at all," said Gary Pereira, a correction officer for 12 years.
Only inmates convicted of nonviolent offenses are allowed to participate in the program at Rikers, a maximum-security prison complex. But given that inmates work with pitchforks, shovels and shears, security concerns are paramount and gardeners are pat-searched coming and going. "No one's going nowhere until all the tools are counted," said Manuel Monserrat, a correction officer.
Terrariums are made with unbreakable plastic rather than with glass, and garbage compactors must be searched to make sure inmates are not trying to escape by hiding among recyclable material.
Besides the hands-on work, the program involves daily classroom instruction: a blackboard has two dozen words, like "chloroplast," "anther" and "mulch." Inmates learn how to cultivate house plants and design outdoor gardens. In the native plants area, they have planted dogwood, juniper and plum trees. They make their own decisions on garden design. Women in prison made the biological symbol for female the centerpiece of one garden.
Last summer, inmates collected worms for a nestful of baby mockingbirds. They scattered ladybugs about as a weapon against aphids that were attacking the plants. They were amazed to learn that tulips grow from bulbs, not seeds. In the farm program, which runs from April through September, they grew zucchini, tomatoes, peppers and other vegetables.
"It's nurturing," said Mr. Lewis, a former construction worker from East Harlem who would not specify his offense. "Planting a seed and seeing it grow is more satisfying than just eating the stuff."
David Brown, 41, of the Bronx, who was convicted of stripping automobiles, said: "I knew my cars. Now I know my plants."
On a day-to-day basis, the Rikers program, operated by the Horticulture Society of New York, is run by James Jiler, 39, who quit his job as a Wall Street commodities analyst and joined the Peace Corps. He advised the Government of Nepal on organic farming. He picked up a master's in urban forestry from Yale University. He works with prisoners five days a week.
More than 200 inmates have participated. For the women, Mr. Jiler teaches a course on house plant care, encouraging them to think of themselves as doctors nurturing patients. For the men, he is beginning a program to raise plants for use in landscaping grounds next to city bus garages. Other plants have gone to the median islands on upper Broadway.
"We want to encourage a sense of creativity," Mr. Jiler said.
In helping to make things grow, Rikers Island is returning to its roots. It began as a 90-acre farm owned by the Riker family, and through the dumping of waste was expanded to 450 acres. It became a prison in the 1930's.
In 1986, the Horticulture Society started a greenhouse and landscaping program, but the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ended it for budgetary reasons in 1994.
The society returned in September 1997 partly because the gardening program fit into other programs. For instance, the society uses plants from Rikers Island to beautify the lawns of landmark Carnegie libraries. And the new society president, Anthony Smith, is also a director of South 40 Corporation, which helps former inmates find jobs. The society has promised to pay all of the program's bills.
Mr. Smith contends that the program is more than worth the cost. "Inmates may be seeing something for the first time that is going to live or die based on what they do or don't do," he said. He added that in the program's first incarnation, 25 percent of participants returned to prison after they were released, compared with more than 60 percent of the general inmate population.
The recycling and composting operations would seem to involve inmates the least, but their participation is actually crucial. It is the job of one correction officer, Sandra Simmons, to get the prisoners' attention; they must sort food waste into the right bins for the program to have any chance of working.
"You have to be very demanding to be taken seriously," said Ms. Simmons, whom inmates have dubbed the Garbage Queen. "If you ask for 100 percent, you get 50 percent. It works."
Ms. Simmons got her appreciation for recycling from her mother, who took her to a recycling and redemption center near their Queens home when she was a little girl. She found that few inmates had the same background. Most thought the waste was being taken to hog farms to be used as swill. "Some couldn't care less and some were confused," she said. "But for some, it was like the circle of life."
The goal of the composting operation is to take the process from backyards to a much larger part of the population. If composting can be shown to be economical in the large Rikers Island project, other composting centers might be constructed around the city. The compost could be used in parks, golf courses and botanical gardens and for other uses, both within and outside the city.
"How to do anything beyond backyard composting in New York City becomes very, very complex," said Thomas Outerbridge, who originally planned the project as a Sanitation Department official and now works as an environmental consultant.
"Our first idea was that the project must be big enough to catch the attention of the people at sanitation," he said.
The composting center cost $5 million, mostly in state money, and is on an isolated corner of the island unlikely to be used for a new jail. It enables the Correction Department to avoid using hundreds of garbage trucks that otherwise might pose a security risk, and the department pays nothing to the Sanitation Department for running the program.
Each day, the residue of 60,000 meals is mixed with recycled cardboard into a yeasty substance that smells like manure. The final result is high-grade fertilizer for use in the gardening and farm programs.
"It's the largest composting facility in America used strictly for food waste," said Robert LaValva, the Sanitation Department's chief of composting. "This is the point of reference for the rest of the city."
Well, maybe. Neighbors have been known to complain about the odor from composting. Nobody had to ask the inmates for their view.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Investors Sour on Belo as Ad Sales Fall at Flagship Paper

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON and FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
It's as if, as 1998 ended, some prankster turned the A. H. Belo Corporation's stock chart upside down. Falling from $28 and change to less than $20 last year, a stock that had long paced the newspaper industry fell far behind, with its worst performance since Belo went public in 1981.
The cause everyone points to is weak advertising at the company's flagship, The Dallas Morning News, which regularly prints more column inches of advertising than any other newspaper in the nation. But total advertising volume dropped by 2.3 percent in 1998, and classified advertising -- the most profitable advertising newspapers sell -- led the decline. Some company executives and analysts speculate that the drop was fueled by the migration of high-technology help-wanted advertising to the Internet. 
 A quarterly earnings report due on Thursday will show whether Belo's efforts to control expenses in the last six months have had results. Analysts, absorbing the company's cautions, have trimmed their outlook to 20 cents a share, from 28 cents three months ago.
Publishing represents about 45 percent of Belo's profits, and The Morning News perhaps three-quarters of that. But those numbers alone cannot convey the true heft of the newspaper as the symbol of the financial and journalistic success of a media company that with $1.2 billion in 1997 revenue is one of the nation's largest. When The Morning News does well, Belo smiles and Wall Street smiles with it. And when The Morning News suffers, Wall Street feels Belo's pain.
Elsewhere, Belo's situation is stable, or even promising. At its 17 television stations, which now reach one of seven households around the nation, advertising gains remain healthy. Its other newspapers, including The Providence Journal-Bulletin and The Press-Enterprise of Riverside, Calif., had good results in 1998.
But the company and its many acquisitions have been built on the growth and profitability of The Morning News. Given the strength of the Dallas economy, investors want to know what's wrong.
Robert W. Decherd, Belo's chairman, president and chief executive, has confronted the reversals with the same bravado that has helped him turn a business run by his family for more than seven decades into a media giant. He contends that the current doldrums are simply part of the normal cycle that every business goes through, especially when digesting major acquisitions.
In fact, the company's stock, which had outperformed the newspaper industry for two years, beginning in the fall of 1994, had already begun to slip behind the group just before Belo's $1.7 billion acquisition of the Journal-Bulletin Company in 1997. And the gap between Belo and the industry increased, so that by the end of 1998, its stock was the worst performer in the group.
But Mr. Decherd argues that the stock's downturn should not detract from the underlying strength that he sees resulting from Belo's heavy investments in its newspapers and broadcast stations.
"It's clearly a patient-money strategy," he said in an interview. "Crepe-hanging over the performance of The Dallas Morning News in 1998 is the most ridiculous idea I can imagine."
Yet underlying the advantages are some of the broadest uncertainties Belo and Mr. Decherd have faced since they won a fight to the death with The Dallas Times Herald, which Belo bought and closed in 1991. Mr. Decherd, who became the company's president six years before that, at age 33, must now find among his contemporaries successors for the two top executives who -- besides him -- are most responsible for Belo's growth and success: Ward L. Huey Jr., the vice chairman and broadcast division chairman, who is 60, and Burl Osborne, the publisher of The Dallas Morning News and president of the newspaper division, who is 61. Two other top executives quit the company last year.
Although Mr. Huey and Mr. Osborne do not plan to leave before reaching the usual retirement age of 65, preparing for their departures is already a Decherd priority. "The question you pose is one I take very seriously and about which I have a lot of personal angst," he said, finishing with a word that repeatedly creeps into his speech these days.
The naming of Robert W. Mong Jr., 49, who had come up through the Dallas newsroom, as the newspaper's president last September appears to put him in a position to eventually become its publisher and the chief of the entire newspaper division. Mr. Mong is striving to establish his cost-cutting credentials. His first memo in his new job began, "I want to let you know that we will not be having a company picnic this fall," and went on to cite the newspaper's lagging performance.
Reporter's travel has been curtailed, and new parking decks, for the newspaper and an adjacent television station, have been delayed. So has construction of a new building for the Riverside newspaper. And the planned pace for adding high-definition capability to the television stations has been slowed. All told, Belo intends to cut capital spending this year from a planned $125 million to $98 million.
Early retirement incentives offered to 300 employees of The Morning News and the Dallas television station were accepted by about 180, averting the need to begin the year with layoffs.
Mr. Mong succeeded Jeremy L. Halbreich, who had been president since 1991. Mr. Halbreich had worked for Mr. Decherd since graduating from Harvard, which Mr. Decherd attended at the same time, in 1974. Although Mr. Halbreich's associates say he was offered other positions with Belo, he decided to leave.
In June, Belo also lost Michael D. Perry, its chief financial officer. Mr. Decherd described the resignation as voluntary. But two people who know both men well said that their relationship had grown rancorous. The separation agreement, which included job-hunting services for Mr. Perry, reads almost like the terms of a cease-fire in an armed conflict. One provision, for example, commits Mr. Perry and the company to saying nothing negative about the other.
Many of Mr. Perry's duties went to James M. Moroney, a 42-year-old, Stanford-educated cousin of Mr. Decherd's and the son of a former Belo chairman. Mr. Moroney had risen to second-in-command at the broadcast division. As executive vice president for finance, with the new chief financial officer reporting to him, he gave the company's presentation last week at a Salomon Smith Barney investment conference.
Despite the turnover and pending retirements, Mr. Decherd says that investors should draw assurance from his own continuing tenure and his status as Belo's largest shareholder. "I'll be 48 in April and have no plans to go anywhere," he said. Lest anyone doubt his robust good health, he suggested with a laugh that an interviewer meet him at the pool where his coach, a champion swimmer himself, pushes him through hourlong workouts.
At a newspaper generally considered one of the nation's best regional dailies, Mr. Mong and Mr. Decherd pledge to continue the necessary spending and investments. They cite the addition of another weekly zoned section for the fringe suburbs and a personal-technology section, as well as the purchase of new $36 million presses scheduled for installation in 2000. The newspaper's reporters are also appearing on the Texas Cable Channel, which Belo introduced on Jan. 4 -- itself a $15 million investment in plant and equipment.
Even the newspaper's critics have noticed improvements in The Morning News, which has won six Pulitzer Prizes since 1986. "The News is getting better, though we hate to admit it" said Molly Ivins, the popular columnist for the rival Fort Worth Star-Telegram.
The cash-flow margins for the newspaper -- perhaps the best measure of profitability -- peaked at 34 percent in 1997 before dropping to 32.6 percent in 1998. Newspaper margins in the 20's are more common.
Although Morning News circulation, like that of other major newspapers, has been sliding, it was the loss of advertising that prompted analysts to turn negative. Double-digit growth in advertising revenue in 1995 and 1996 had tailed off to 7.2 percent in 1997. And beginning last August, these sales went into a steep decline. The greatest losses came in what had been the newspaper's most profitable category, help-wanted, which was off by 6 percent in September and 3 percent in October, the company told analysts.
Some analysts blame rate increases of 32 percent from 1995 to 1998 for retail advertising, 47 percent for general advertising and 75 percent for classified employment ads. But Belo executives say that advertisers' cost per thousand readers remains below the average for the largest newspapers. They say that high-technology employment advertisements may have migrated to the Internet, or may have dried up with the loss of Asian demand for high-technology products. Similar weakness in classified advertising dented profits for newspapers in San Jose, Calif., Los Angeles and Boston.
Mr. Decherd sees no broader Internet invasion. "These are computer-facile people," he said, working his fingers as if his conference table were a keyboard. "I don't think it means there is some sort of broader secular change in terms of newspaper advertising generally."
But Mr. Decherd sees an even broader challenge -- demonstrating that in journalism, high quality can still bring high and growing profits. "If it doesn't work for Belo, my opinion is it won't work for anybody," he said, his voice falling to a distant murmur.

SECTION: Section F; Page 7; Column 1; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk

HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
A Sure Cure for Bordeaux Sticker Shock

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
THE best 1996 Bordeaux wines are being bottled right now, the 1997's are still maturing in barrels and the 1998's are almost ready for blending. In a few months, the most famous first-growth chateaus will announce their prices for the 1998 vintage, to be delivered in 2001.
No one is expecting any surprises: even if prices stay at current levels, they will be exceptionally high. And annual price increases have become the norm in Bordeaux in recent years, regardless of the quality of the vintage. 
 For investors and collectors, these increases are no more than a minor annoyance, since their wines will probably be worth even more 10 years from now. But for the average wine drinker, it would seem that these high prices would put good Bordeaux totally out of reach. Actually, they merely pose a challenge -- to find good Bordeaux for a reasonable cost. Happily, that is not so difficult to do.
To some extent, the staggering prices of the most famous Bordeaux do reflect production costs and the intrinsic quality of the wines. But mostly they reflect the laws of supply and demand. Most of the top-name chateaus make fewer than 30,000 cases a year -- a huge amount compared with production at Burgundy estates and the cult California wineries, but still hardly enough to meet demand.
Yet, there are hundreds of chateaus in Bordeaux not part of this special market. Their prices are far more reasonable and more closely reflect their costs. What is more, many of these non-first-growth wines are from the fine 1995 vintage -- the one that Chateau Margaux sells for more than $300 a bottle and that Latour, Lafite-Rothschild, Mouton-Rothschild and Haut-Brion sell for $200 to $300.
I WOULD be much more tempted by the exceptional 1995 Lynch-Bages for about $55. Jean-Michel Cazes, the owner, regularly produces wines of first-growth quality at prices that people who actually drink wine can afford; a 1995 bottle of Haut-Bages-Averous, his second label at Lynch-Bages, can be found for less than $25. Lynch-Bages is in prestigious Pauillac. The Cazes family also owns Les Ormes de Pez, in St.-Estephe, and its 1995 is also under $25.
There have always been so-called second wines from the top Bordeaux chateaus, usually from younger vines or from lots that just don't qualify for the principal wine. And a few of these second wines are considered about on par with the principal wines from lesser properties. Among these second labels are Les Forts de Latour and Les Fiefs de Lagrange.
Les Forts de Latour is the second wine of Chateau Latour. Tradition has it that in less memorable vintages Les Forts can be more appealing than Latour itself. That has not been my experience, although I remember when a bottle of the 1973 was opened for lunch at the chateau in the early 1980's and the magnificent bouquet filled the house. The 1995 Forts de Latour is going to set you back $50, but if you happened to have an urge to spend $50 on a bottle of Bordeaux, you needn't look any further.
Almost in the same class and much less expensive, at about $20, is Les Fiefs de Lagrange, the second wine of Chateau Lagrange, in St.-Julien. This is an underrated chateau that has been making superb wines since it was purchased by Suntory, the Japanese wine and spirits conglomerate, in 1983. St.-Julien wines are usually softer and more approachable than those of adjoining Pauillac, and that is true of the 1995 vintage. The first wine probably needs several more years to reach maturity, but Les Fiefs is ready now.
ONE of St.-Julien's best-known properties, at least in this country, is Chateau Gloria, which was made famous by its owner, the late Henri Martin, a legendary figure in the Bordeaux wine trade. Gloria was not included in the 1855 classification, so it cannot command the prices of the chateaus around it. But most of its vineyards were bought by Mr. Martin from those classified properties. Over the years, Gloria's wines have matched or bettered those of many of its neighbors in quality and beaten them in price. The 1995 is about $30.
I have always wondered why, even with the unconscionable inflation of Bordeaux prices in recent years, some chateaus that could have raised prices did not. One of them is Chateau Meyney, another property in St.-Estephe, in the northern Medoc. The wines are big and rich and, like most St.-Estephes, a bit hard when they are young. In the 1995 Meyney, that hardness has dissipated, leaving a full, rounded wine, ready to drink now, for about $22 a bottle.
I've concentrated on the Medoc here, but there are well-priced 1995's to be found all over the Bordeaux region. In St.-Emilion, there is Clos des Jacobins at about $27, and La Commanderie, a light, easy-drinking wine at about $15. In adjoining Pomerol, there is an elegant Clos l'Eglise at about $30.
Clos de Jacobins is owned by Domaines Cordier, a well-known Bordeaux negociant that also owns Meyney. Offering good chateau-bottled wine at reasonable prices would seem to be a Cordier principle. Clos l'Eglise is an austere wine for a Pomerol, whose wines are often compared to Burgundies. This 1995 has a beautiful bouquet, plenty of ripe fruit in the taste and a most appealing silky finish.
Anyone can buy superexpensive Bordeaux wines and show that they have lots of money. A shrewd few can buy Bordeaux like these and show that they have lots of smarts.
 
Tastings
Pure Pleasure In Pinot Noir
 
Buena Vista Pinot Noir 1996, Carneros, Calif. About $16.
SOME California pinot noirs are selling for $60 and more; a few are worth it. For the rest, it would be tough to defend their costs on the basis of quality when compared with this modestly priced offering from Buena Vista.
The Carneros region, which stretches across the south end of both Napa and Sonoma, is incontestably one of the best places in California to grow pinot noir. Buena Vista, with more than 900 acres, is the largest estate winery there, and has more than 160 acres planted in pinot noir.
Spring rains reduced the size of the 1996 crop, but what survived was mostly high-quality fruit. Two weeks of lower-than-normal temperatures in August made it possible to keep the grapes on the vines longer than usual, adding to both flavor and color.
The wine has good color and a delectable bouquet, although I didn't get the touch of menthol found by Judy Matulich-Weitz, the wine maker.
With or without menthol, it is a most attractive pinot noir, ready to drink now.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Jamaica prepares to put troops on patrol at resorts to help ease tourists' fears of crime.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:
WITH its tourist industry battered by fear of crime and by visitor complaints of harassment, Jamaica is trying to decide when to deploy troops to its tourist resorts and whether they will be in uniform or plainclothes. The move is backed by the Jamaica Hotel and Motel Association, which was previously lukewarm toward the idea. The change comes as occupancy rates have fallen after several well-publicized crimes against tourists.
While Jamaican officials say that crime against visitors has fallen in the last couple of years, harassment is so widespread, especially in cruise ports, that Prime Minister Percival J. Patterson described the situation last year as the single biggest problem facing the tourist industry. 
 Four cruise lines threatened to pull out of Montego Bay two years ago, and one line, Celebrity, did pull out its Mercury ship. Still, merchants say that this year fewer than half the passengers on cruise ships in Ocho Rios are staying aboard rather than coming ashore.
At stake is an industry that is Jamaica's biggest money maker by far. In 1997, the island drew 1.9 million visitors, whose spending accounted for 45 percent of Jamaica's foreign exchange, almost 14 percent of its gross domestic product and one in every four jobs.
To protect the industry, Jamaica raised fines last year for harassing tourists: the penalty for a first-time offense is about $2,700, up from $27, and repeat offenses draw fines of about $4,100, also up from $27. But, judging from last week's decision to deploy troops, the harsher penalties have apparently had little effect.
The date of the deployment has not been determined, a spokeswoman for the Jamaica Tourist Board said yesterday, largely because the tourism and security ministries have not yet resolved whether the soldiers will patrol in uniform or plainclothes, or whether they will patrol at all resorts simultaneously. The United States State Department, meantime, recently updated a year-old advisory warning visitors to Jamaica to exercise caution.
 
1998: A So-So Year
Final statistics for 1998 travel and tourism will not be compiled for months, but the numbers are expected to surpass those for 1997, if just barely. While the number of cruise passengers is likely to top the 5.05 million who sailed in 1997, several other major tourist industries slumped last year.
Attendance at theme parks, for example, fell almost two million in 1998 principally because of bad weather, while visits to such popular national parks as Grand Canyon in Arizona and Yosemite in California were also down significantly. Unusually warm weather toward the end of the year ruined the plans of tens of thousands of skiers, and lowered hotel occupancy rates in Orlando and elsewhere in central Florida.
The bad economic news from Asia, especially Japan, also hurt attendance at theme parks in California and Florida, while dealing a hammer blow to Hawaiian tourism.
The number of Japanese visitors to Las Vegas probably reached a record in 1998, but would perhaps have been even higher if the yen had remained strong.
 
A Few Worries in Utah
The scandal over reports of bribery involving the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City is creating concern that the expected 50,000 additional visitors a day might not show up, either out of disgust with the process used to land the Olympics or because diminished sponsorship might result in fewer events surrounding the Games.
Any significant drop in visitors would affect hotels, restaurants and much else, including the State of Utah, which had projected an extra $19 million in tax revenues. And a decline in foreign visitors would be especially painful, since Utah has been expecting them to spend generously as well as spread the word back home about the state's many scenic charms.
For now, though, the Utah Travel Council has said that calls to its information line have more than doubled since the scandal emerged. More worrisome, for the time being at least, is the below-average snowfall over much of the state, which has led to a disappointing ski season so far.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Archive Tells How Church And City Grew

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
THE moving van has yet to roll up to John Cardinal O'Connor's residence on Madison Avenue. Although at 79 he has passed the church's mandatory retirement age of 75, he continues to serve at the discretion of his friend and superior, Pope John Paul II. So, what gives with all the boxes he has been sending to the archdiocese's seminary in Yonkers?
The Cardinal is not cleaning house; he has history on his mind. The boxes, several dozen so far, contain speeches, letters and assorted awards from his tenure as Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York. They have joined hundreds of other boxes, albums and books from his predecessors that now spill out of three rooms at the seminary's library. Come September, the documents will have a new home at the seminary's Archbishop John Hughes Heritage Center, a climate-controlled archive and exhibition space for scholarly research on the church in New York. 
 But the archive's value, Cardinal O'Connor said, goes beyond church matters. He said it offered an often-overlooked perspective on the city's growth, as seen through the church's network of schools, charities and societies that turned immigrants into Americans. While some social critics have recently embraced the notion that churches can save the inner city, the archives show that such work was being done since the diocese's founding in 1808.
"The history of the church here parallels the history of New York and in many ways is one with it," the Cardinal said. "We are an immigrant church today. We were an immigrant church 200 years ago. Right now, I'm meeting with a group of concerned individuals about how do we support the Mexican community. In trying to come to grips with this, I have been going back and seeing what was recorded in how we dealt with immigrant populations through the past 200 years."
A striking example is found in the legacy of the center's namesake, Archbishop Hughes of the mid-1800's. Dagger John, as he was known, defended the Irish immigrants, who were scorned as criminals and louts. His battles with Protestants whom he accused of anti-Catholic bias in the education of poor children led him to start a system of parochial schools. When nativist riots were threatened, he rounded up 1,000 militiamen to protect the cathedral.
"He had an enormous impact on the city," the Cardinal said. "He was almost alone in recognizing the needs of the immigrants and the contemptuous treatment of them. He helped them integrate into society."
Sister Marguerita Smith, the seminary's archivist, said such efforts eased the way for other immigrants who arrived facing even more hurdles than the Irish. The Italians who settled in New York in the late 1800's, she said, did not speak English and were often beholden to padrones who treated them like indentured servants. Archbishop Michael Corrigan established the St. Raphael Society to break those ties and encourage assimilation.
"The priests would try to meet them at Ellis Island so they wouldn't fall into the hands of the padrones," she said. "The priests would find them jobs, tide them over with money or help them if somebody died in the family."
OTHER groups followed a similar path and the church responded in kind. When paperboys and ragamuffins slept in hallways, Father John Christopher Drumgoole started an orphanage on Staten Island. The archives hold copies of a newsletter he published about the hard-knock lives of homeless waifs.
There are volumes about the hospitals founded by nuns to treat the poor, demands for economic and racial equality in Harlem and calls for increased attention to the social ills that plagued the newcomers in old neighborhoods. You could tell the newest arrivals easily enough: they were the ones who held services in church basements.
To bring the archives up to date, 100 priests, nuns and lay people are being interviewed for oral histories that will reflect the moods of various neighborhoods in this century. A photographer has been visiting several landmark churches, documenting the handiwork of generations of artisans.
Msgr. Jeremiah Monahan, the chancellor of the archdiocese, said the archives would ultimately affirm the heritage and contributions of the city's people and parishes. After nearly 200 years, they've finally arrived. "We always thought the archives would be a grand place to match the grandeur of New York," Monsignor Monahan said. "It's not just a place where we put our things."

HEADLINE: King Hussein Back Home; Despite Joy, Jordan Frets

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Piloting his own plane, King Hussein of Jordan returned to his kingdom today after six months of cancer treatment. His arrival prompted scenes of widespread jubilation, but also speculation about who might next take the reins of the country he has governed for nearly half a century.
The 63-year-old King has promised only "a comprehensive review" of Jordan's course. But senior officials said today that he was contemplating succession by one of his five sons rather than by his long-designated successor, his brother, Crown Prince Hassan, who has ruled the country during his long absence. 
 Never before during his reign has King Hussein been away from Jordan for so long. He was welcomed home by hundreds of thousands of Jordanians, who braved unseasonably chilly and rainy weather to pay tribute to a King who has been the only leader a vast majority of them have ever known.
After landing his jet at a military airport today, during the Id al-Fitr holiday marking the end of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, the King, gaunt and hairless from his cancer therapy, knelt on a prayer rug to give thanks.
Before his return, the King had fueled much talk here that he might be reconsidering a succession plan that for more than 30 years had put his brother next in line for the throne. He has kept people guessing with comments like, "No one knows what is in the mind of al-Hussein until it crystallizes into a reality."
Today the King praised Prince Hassan for serving as his "deputy," but gave no clue about his intentions. A senior palace official said, though, that the King's "difficult days of life and death" during his treatment had "naturally rekindled a wish to seek posterity through passing the succession to one of his sons."
Only once before, in 1992, after treatment for an earlier bout with cancer, had the King's return from abroad prompted the kind of rejoicing that burst forth today.
Fireworks exploded over Amman, and streets were decorated with pennants and banners and crowded with hundreds of thousands of people. Dancers from around the kingdom joined in what by any measure was a most extraordinary pageant.
King Hussein has ruled Jordan since 1952 -- when Harry S. Truman was President -- and there is no doubt that he has been sorely missed.
"Thank God he has returned," Amira al-Awahdi, a 42-year-old homemaker, said this afternoon as she took part in the celebration. "I can't imagine what we will ever do without him."
Jordan, with its 4 million people, has a strategic location, sandwiched between Syria, Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Israel.
In the last five years Jordan has reached out to Israel, joining Egypt as the only two Arab countries to make peace with Israel. But it has never fully forsworn its ties with Iraq -- on which it still depends for oil -- and that prompts distrust in Egypt, Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries that joined the United States in waging war against Iraq in 1991 after it invaded Kuwait.
This has left Jordan a bit lonely, despite King Hussein's efforts to bridge gaps through his charm and diplomacy. The King took time out from his treatment at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., to join President Clinton last October for Middle East peace talks at the Wye Plantation in Maryland. Then, as happened several times in the past, he was credited with helping to bridge the gap between Israeli and Palestinian leaders.
In his absence the country was led by Crown Prince Hassan, the King's understudy for more than 33 years, who is seen both at home and abroad as a competent and effective leader.
But still, at 52, Hassan seems to lack the common touch that might be necessary to guide Jordan though what many expect will be tumultuous years ahead.
For years Jordan had depended for much of its revenue on trade with Iraq, most of which was halted under the United Nations sanctions that stemmed from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
More than half of Jordan's people are Palestinians whose homeland is the West Bank, but for whom returning there has become an increasingly distant prospect.
Jordan has yet to reap clear dividends from its accord with Israel in 1994, which remains deeply unpopular among many Jordanians. In the years since, the economy has suffered and unemployment has soared.
In the days preceding his return, King Hussein had seemed intent on pre-empting his critics. In a televised address from London over the weekend, he declared that there was "no choice but to engage soon in a comprehensive review of our national course and dealing with all the issues and challenges that occupy our minds or obstruct our blessed path."
Jordanian officials have interpreted that statement as a signal that the King may be reconsidering the succession. For many Jordanians, that kind of speculation was fueled again today when the King, in a statement on his arrival, made no more than passing reference to his brother.
Many people in Jordan believe that he would prefer to be succeeded by one of his five sons from his four marriages. The one most often mentioned is Prince Hamzeh, 18, the King's eldest son by his current wife, the American-born Queen Noor.
As his father was, Prince Hamzeh is being educated at the British military academy at Sandhurst. His eloquence in Arabic and English has been widely admired in Jordan, and he has been at the King's side through most of his illness.
The speculation was fed today by the very public presence of Queen Noor at the King's side as the royal party rolled through the streets of Amman in a 1960's Mercedes-Benz limousine.
Even in Jordan, which has a more relaxed attitude toward public roles for women than most Arab countries, it is unusual that the wife of a leader would be presented so prominently.
The King has pronounced himself "fully recovered" from his lymphoma. Since July he has undergone six courses of chemotherapy, which he has acknowledged left him physically and emotionally weakened, and today he appeared a bit frail.
But throughout his illness, the King has appeared determined to display his physical vigor, most often by taking control of his aircraft, as he did today by flying his Gulfstream jet here from London, where he had been recovering in a holiday home.

HEADLINE: Browsers and Borders Are Argued at the Microsoft Trial

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
In the Microsoft antitrust trial, the Government spent most of today attacking the company's central defense -- that its Internet browsing software is a seamless feature of its Windows operating system and not a stand-alone product. The Government is trying to prove that the browser and operating system are two products, illegally bundled together mainly to stifle competition.
But the Justice Department and 19 states suing the Microsoft Corporation face an uphill struggle to confirm that allegation. In a related case, a Federal appeals court ruled last June that Microsoft had virtually unlimited freedom to include anything it wanted in its products. The decision pointedly noted the "undesirability of having courts oversee product design." 
 In the current trial, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of United States District Court is not necessarily bound by the appeals court ruling. But it does suggest that the Government must make some very convincing arguments to prevail.
David Boies, the lead trial lawyer for the Justice Department, spent hours today trying to show that Microsoft's position on the issue was contradicted by the company's own internal documents and by common sense. Using other products as examples to illustrate his point, Mr. Boies insisted that it was possible to do what Microsoft says is nearly impossible -- draw a boundary line in software code, separating one product from another.
Microsoft, Mr. Boies said, could do the same thing with its popular word-processing program, Word, as it did with its Internet Explorer browser. "But the mere fact that two programs share some software code -- and a company can make it difficult to disentangle that code" -- by no means proved that they were a single product, Mr. Boies said.
Mr. Boies directed question after question at Microsoft's first witness, Richard L. Schmalensee, an economist who is the dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The Justice Department lawyer noted that even Michael Dertouzos, the director of M.I.T.'s Computer Science Laboratory -- who was initially on Microsoft's witness list but was later dropped -- had testified in a deposition that he considered the browser an application program, separate from the operating system.
Mr. Schmalensee held his ground, however, cautioning the court against immersing itself too deeply in software code. "One thing this industry teaches is that the borders between products vary over time as technology advances," he said.
At another point, he explained that he did not give "any particular weight" to the testimony from expert witnesses that the browser and operating system were separate products. "Testimony as to the way things are," Mr. Schmalensee said, should not be binding in determining "guidelines that are going to affect the evolution of this industry" -- a nod to the expectation that whatever the verdict for Microsoft, the case will have a far-reaching effect on the nation's high-technology economy.
The Government argues that Microsoft's decisions to bundle its browser with Windows and to place contract restrictions on personal computer makers add up to anticompetitive behavior.
Pursuing that line, Mr. Boies asked Mr. Schmalensee if Microsoft had bundled its browser with Windows in part to increase the distribution of its browser. "It certainly had that effect," the witness replied.
Next, Mr. Boies asked if one purpose for the bundling was to make it more difficult for a Microsoft rival, the Netscape Communications Corporation, to distribute its browser.
"Yes," Mr. Schmalensee replied, "but that would have happened anyway. Competition would have plausibly raised Netscape's distribution costs."
"Competition on the merits can raise rivals' costs," he added, "but that says nothing about anticompetitive effects."
The M.I.T. business school dean insisted that the Government had not shown any current harm to consumers from Microsoft's decision to fold browsing software into its operating system and to give the browser away. And in determining whether business practices are legitimate competition or anticompetitive predation, Mr. Schmalensee emphasized that "the touchstone has to be ultimate impact on consumers."
The Government contends that Microsoft's practices effectively limited Netscape's access to mainstream channels of distribution where most people obtain their browsing software -- from computer makers who load it onto new PC's and from Internet service providers.
"And that harms consumers because it deprives them of choice," Mr. Boies said today on the courthouse steps.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Christopher S. Wren

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
BRITAIN: THE CASE AGAINST PINOCHET -- The Law Lords rehearing Gen. Augusto Pinochet's claim to immunity from arrest were told that the acts leading to charges of crimes against humanity should not be thought of as functions of a head of state. "It must be that no matter who you are, whether you are a head of state, a government official, a public official, you have individual, personal responsibility in respect of a category of crimes recognized internationally as particularly odious, such as genocide, torture and taking hostages," said Alun Jones, the lawyer arguing the case against the former Chilean dictator. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: YELTSIN DELAYS TRIP TO FRANCE -- President Boris N. Yeltsin's state visit to France, initially planned for next week, has been postponed until mid-March. The 67-year-old Mr. Yeltsin was hospitalized on Sunday with a stomach ulcer and is expected to stay at least two weeks. (Reuters) 

RUSSIA: NEW ENVOY TO U.S. TAKES OVER -- Russia's new Ambassador to the United States, Yuri Ushakov, formally took up his post and will present his credentials to President Clinton on Friday. Mr. Ushakov, 51, who is a career diplomat, replaces Yuli Vorontsov, who is retiring at 69. (Reuters)
 
FRANCE: WARNING ON WEB PORNOGRAPHY -- Police and other experts discussed how to stop the spread of child pornography on the Internet in a conference at the Paris headquarters of the United Nations Economic, Social and Cultural Organization. Unesco warned that children are falling victim to the boom in information technology, with hundreds of Web sites used to promote sex tourism and to exploit children. (Agence France-Presse)
 
VATICAN: POPE'S PLEA FOR THE POOR -- Pope John Paul II urged the world to open its arms to the poor, the lonely and "those excluded from the banquet of everyday consumerism." In his traditional message for the Christian season of Lent, which begins on Feb. 17, the Pope returned to a theme that has often troubled him in the past year: the marginalization of the world's poor in the face of free marketeering and economic globalization. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
JAPAN: A PLEDGE TO RECOVERY -- Opening this year's session of Parliament, Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi promised to put his recession-plagued country on the path to recovery and told lawmakers to make decisions quickly to combat Japan's problems. But he apologized for not being able to mention concrete measures. Less than a week ago Mr. Obuchi shuffled his Cabinet to form a conservative coalition. (AP)
 
CHINA: AN ECONOMIC WARNING -- China's financial system has weathered the Asian financial crisis but is threatened by a combination of internal and external factors, including bad debts and poor management, the official China Daily newspaper said. It said some Chinese financial institutions had skirted regulations and taken on too much risk in their investments. (Agence France-Presse)
 
KASHMIR: INDIA AND PAKISTAN CLASH -- Indian troops fought with Pakistani soldiers who tried to seize a military post high on a glacier in disputed Kashmir, killing four Pakistani soldiers, the Press Trust of India reported. The clash took place after nearly 20 Pakistani soldiers advanced toward Indian-held territory on the Siachen glacier, the news agency said, quoting an Indian military statement. (AP)
 
NORTH KOREA: ENVOY SAID TO SEEK ASYLUM -- A North Korean diplomat and his wife who disappeared in Berlin are seeking political asylum in the United States, The Korea Herald in South Korea reported. The envoy, Kim Kyong Pil, 54, was the second secretary in North Korea's representative office in Berlin. (Reuters)
 
PHILIPPINES: DEATH SENTENCE STANDS -- The Supreme Court ruled that the death sentence for a house painter convicted of raping his 10-year-old stepdaughter should be carried out in what will be the country's first execution since 1976. The ruling followed an overwhelming vote in the lower house of Parliament to retain capital punishment, which was abolished in 1987 but reinstated in 1994. (Reuters)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
YEMEN: KIDNAPPERS' DEMANDS -- Tribesmen in Yemen who have kidnapped two Britons and four Dutch nationals are demanding the release of a detained clansman, security officials said. They said the kidnappers are members of the Bakeel tribe and not Islamic militants, whose abduction last month of 16 Westerners ended in a shootout with soldiers that killed four hostages. (AP)
 
AFRICA
 
SIERRA LEONE: FAMINE WARNING BY U.N. -- West African troops fighting rebels in Sierra Leone said they now controlled the port area of Freetown, which could make it easier for ships to deliver desperately needed food. Dozens of bodies, mostly of rebels, have been found in the capital. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization warned that the depletion of food stocks could lead to famine in the devastated capital, where refugees have swollen the population to an estimated one million people. (Reuters)
 
CONGO: REBELS IGNORE WORD OF TRUCE -- Congolese rebels trying to topple President Laurent Kabila said they would not lay down their arms until Mr. Kabila meets them at the negotiating table. The rebels said they would pay little heed to a cease-fire commitment reached by five African nations that have sent troops into Congo to fight for either side. (AP)
 
LESOTHO: POLITICAL PACT BROKEN -- The fragile truce between Lesotho's Government and the opposition fractured when seven political parties walked out of a meeting of the interim political authority to protest worsening security in the kingdom. The walkout, by 14 members of the 24-member body set up to guide the volatile kingdom to elections, came after 50 soldiers facing charges of mutiny took control of the Maseru prison for several hours late Monday. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ZIMBABWE: REPORTER ARRESTED -- The police arrested a journalist who wrote about an alleged coup plot, a week after the army detained his editor over the report, a colleague at their weekly newspaper said. The colleague said Ray Choto, a reporter for the independent Standard, was taken to the central police station in Harare, the capital. (Reuters)
 
RWANDA: GENOCIDE PROSECUTIONS -- Rwandan courts last year tried 864 people accused of taking part in genocide in the central African country in 1994, said the supreme court's public prosecutor, Simeon Rwagasore. He gave no details of convictions or sentences handed down in the trials. (Agence France-Presse)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
CUBA: RUSSIA SEEKS CLOSER TIES -- Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia told the visiting Cuban Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina, that Moscow wanted to increase ties with Havana, its cold-war ally. The Interfax news agency quoted Mr. Primakov as saying during the talks, "We have to draw closer." Cuba's special relationship, including a steady flow of financial aid from the Kremlin, ended with the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, but Russia remains a major trading partner. (Reuters)
 
GRENADA: GOVERNING PARTY WINS VOTE -- Supporters of the governing New National Party staged street parties to celebrate a clean sweep of Grenada's 15 parliamentary seats in general elections on Monday. Prime Minister Keith Mitchell called the vote ahead of schedule after his party lost its parliamentary majority when two members defected to the opposition. (Agence France-Presse)
 
MEXICO: 500 IN KIDNAPPING RING -- The most dangerous kidnapping ring in Mexico, according to federal law enforcement officials, has an estimated 500 members and has abducted at least 50 people in six years, the newspaper Reforma reported. The gang, said to be led by Jose Alonso Avila Palafox, has taken in more than $10 million in ransom in the last two years alone, officials said. Julia Preston (NYT)

HEADLINE: Chief Regulator Of Futures To Step Down

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

 BODY:
Brooksley E. Born, the chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, said yesterday that she would step down from that post, ending a year of sharp public disagreements with other regulators and Clinton Administration officials over regulation of the financial derivatives markets.
The announcement came just a few months before President Clinton would have decided on whether to reappoint Ms. Born to a second five-year term. Administration officials say there was little expectation that she would have been reappointed because Ms. Born openly broke ranks with some of the Administration's top economic advisers -- including Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. The issue was her edging toward tighter regulation of the market in over-the-counter derivatives. 
 But Ms. Born, who was appointed by President Clinton in 1996 to oversee the commodity futures and options market, said yesterday that the debate over regulating the derivatives market did not play a role in her decision against seeking a second term. After careful consideration over the holidays, Ms. Born said, she had decided to return to her "true calling," the private practice of law.
"I don't think the controversy played any role," she said in a telephone interview. "The fact that Congress and the other financial regulators and a number of international organizations are now addressing the major issues posed by the over-the-counter derivatives market is very gratifying to me. It makes me feel as though these issues are being left in good hands."
The debate over whether the complex financial instruments known as derivatives ought to be more heavily regulated, though, clearly contributed to the criticism of Ms. Born. The global marketplace seems increasingly bent on deregulation, despite several high-profile disasters in the derivatives market, most recently the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, the giant hedge fund rescued in a federally orchestrated bailout by a consortium of Wall Street firms.
Last May, when Ms. Born issued a "concept release" seeking comment on the regulation of the over-the-counter derivatives market, the commission came under a barrage of criticism, from Wall Street officials who saw the attempt at tighter regulation as costly and cumbersome and from Washington officials who believed that the commission was overstepping its jurisdiction and creating legal uncertainties that could drive business offshore.
On the day the "concept release" was issued in May, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan; Treasury Secretary Rubin and Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, issued a joint statement saying that they had grave concerns about the commission's action.
Mark C. Brickell, a board member of the International Swaps and Derivatives Assocation, said that even though the commission action had educated Congress about the importance of derivatives activity, Wall Street officials were troubled by the move. "Regulations that make it harder to manage risk raise widespread concern," he said.
Ms. Born later said that she was not intent on creating regulatory burdens, but had simply been raising important questions, particularly about the need for more information for hedge funds and others that trade in the derivatives. Still, Congress and Treasury officials evidently thought otherwise.
Treasury officials lobbied Congress to pass legislation that would prevent the commission from regulating the over-the-counter derivatives market, which is now only loosely regulated through banks and brokerage firms. It is a huge multitrillion-dollar market that allows investors to manage a great deal of risk, and Administration officials said any move to increase regulation would weaken the market.
After public hearings, Congress blocked for six months any move by the commission to enact regulation of the over-the-counter market, where financial instruments like interest rate swaps are traded.
The last 12 months have been a volatile time for Ms. Born, 58, who was on the short list of those under consideration for Attorney General in late 1992, shortly after Bill Clinton was elected President.
But Ms. Born -- who sent a letter to the President yesterday stating that she would not seek a second term -- said that she did not feel any bitterness over the derivatives debate and that she had confidence the regulators would improve the market and protect the public interest.
Indeed, she said the "concept release" issued last May made more sense in light of Long-Term Capital's near-demise, which unnerved markets around the world.
"I think that Long-Term Capital Management vividly demonstrated to many people that the issues that had been raised in the concept release were important," she said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Index Hits a High, Eclipsing the Other Indicators

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A further advance in Internet and telecommunications shares helped push stock markets higher yesterday, even as analysts expressed fear about hefty valuations.
The rally in Internet and telecommunications stocks, fueled by the At Home Corporation's agreement to buy Excite Inc. in a deal valued at $6.7 billion and Vodafone Group P.L.C.'s $59.7 billion planned acquisition of Airtouch Communications Inc., helped to push the Nasdaq composite index to a new high. It closed above 2,400 for the first time. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was moderate, at 787 million shares. But 1.1 billion shares changed hands on the Nasdaq.
Other market averages, which bobbed for much of the session, rallied late and closed higher.
Helped by big gains in AT&T and I.B.M., the Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.67, or two-tenths of a percent, to 9,355.22. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 8.74, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 1,252. The Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization companies did even better, rising 3.84, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 430.89.
But those gains were eclipsed by the Nasdaq composite, which jumped 59.97, or 2.5 percent, to 2,408.17. And Thestreet.com's index of 20 Internet companies rose 43.92, or 8.7 percent, to 548.29.
"The merger and acquisition news in the technology sector led the day," said Michael Clark, head of United States stock trading at Credit Suisse First Boston. "And the news provided a tremendous amount of support for the market."
Still, many analysts and traders said stocks were very richly priced, and due for a correction. Bad news from important foreign markets like Brazil or China could pound stocks, they said. And they said they are wary about what the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, may say about the stock market when he testifies before the House Ways and Means Committee today.
"The market has become such an economic driver that he has to say something," said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason in Baltimore.
Worries about Brazil eased a bit yesterday, as the Brazilian Senate approved an important part of the Government's austerity package. For the day, Brazil's Bovespa stock index gained 3.8 percent.
Besides the merger announcements, expectations that Microsoft's profits for the quarter ended Dec. 31 would meet or exceed expectations were also an important part of yesterday's overall advance.
Microsoft rose 5 7/8, to 155 5/8. After the close of trading, the world's leading software company reported that it earned 73 cents a share during the period, 20 percent more than the highest estimate.
Three of the most venerable names in American capitalism -- AT&T, I.B.M. and General Motors -- were the Dow's biggest gainers. Gains in those stocks offset weakness among bank shares.
AT&T jumped 7 1/8, to 91 3/8. It will take control of At Home when its acquisition of Tele-Communications Inc. is completed. TCI is At Home's largest shareholder.
I.B.M. gained 7 5/16, to 192 1/4, a record. General Motors rose 4 11/6, to 88.
Dow losers included American Express, which dropped 3 7/8, to 100 1/2, J. P. Morgan, which shed 2 13/16, to 105 15/16, and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which lost 1 13/16, to 72 3/4.
At Home's announcement that it would pay 1.04 shares for each share of Excite, the second-biggest Internet directory company, caused a surge in the price of Excite and other Internet stocks. Excite leaped 42 1/2, to 110, a 57 percent increase.
Lycos Inc., the third-biggest directory, gained 25 1/16, to 112 15/16.

Bond Prices End Lower
By Bloomberg News
Bonds fell yesterday, reflecting expectations among investors that the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, will quash hopes for an interest rate cut when he testifies before Congress today. Lower rates tend to improve bond prices.
The 30-year Treasury bond fell 13/32, to a price of 101 19/32. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, advanced to 5.14 percent from 5.12.

HEADLINE: Excite and At Home Confirm $6.7 Billion Merger

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON

 BODY:
One company was started in the proverbial Silicon Valley garage. The other began as a play by some of the nation's biggest cable television interests. Yesterday, they joined forces in the race to capture Internet users and the dollars they are increasingly spending on line, and investors appeared to endorse the strategy.
The deal brought together Excite Inc., which has evolved from a simple search engine into the Internet's sixth most heavily trafficked site, and the At Home Corporation, a high-speed Internet service aimed at cable television subscribers, in what the two companies described as a merger. 
 The transaction, which involved issuing 1.04 shares in At Home for each share of Excite, was valued at $6.7 billion, making it the largest in the recent spate of consolidations among Internet companies.
The deal valued Excite at $106.27 a share, or a 57 percent premium over its closing price on Friday. In raising the stakes that high, At Home is hoping that it will be able to exploit Excite's position as one of the leading Internet destinations to attract subscribers to its own service.
And yesterday Wall Street seemed to share that vision. At Home ended trading at $115.375, up $13.375, while Excite closed at $110, up $42.50.
Analysts said the deal heralded another round of consolidation that would leave just a few major companies controlling both access to the Internet and the most heavily used content.
"At the end of the day we're going to have an oligopoly structure in terms of Internet media and access," said Alan Braverman, an analyst at Deutsche Bank Securities. "In my mind one of the survivors will be the At Home camp, and this makes it all the more likely."
At Home's major shareholder, the cable giant Tele-Communications Inc., is being acquired by the AT&T Corporation, which also markets Internet access through AT&T Worldnet. If the Excite deal goes through, the combined company's main competitor on the Internet front will be America Online, which in turn has announced plans to acquire the Netscape Communications Corporation.
The At Home-Excite deal also sets the stage for the battle shaping up around high-speed Internet access. About two million households will have high-speed connections by 2000, through either telephone lines or television cables, according to Forrester Research Inc.
America Online, the largest Internet service provider, with 15 million subscribers, last week announced a deal with the Bell Atlantic Corporation to provide high-speed access to some of its subscribers starting this summer. And this week, Snap, an Internet company part-owned by NBC, said it would offer a new service that takes advantage of the ability to provide higher-quality video and audio programming over high-speed connections to the Internet.
At Home has forged partnerships with cable providers that it says will eventually enable it to provide high-speed Internet access to 60 million homes. But largely because cable providers have been slow to make necessary upgrades to their systems, the At Home service is available to only 10 million homes, and only 330,000 have signed up for it. Cable modems attached to home computers operate at speeds 10 to 30 times faster than the telephone modems that most of the nation's 28 million Internet households rely on.
A key piece of the merger plan is to use Excite's current Internet presence to promote At Home's service. In November, according to the Internet measuring service Media Metrix, Excite had 14.2 million visitors to its site. About 20 million people have used Excite's My Excite feature to create a service that provides them with individualized information on favorite sports teams, stocks and news. Many of them have given the company permission to E-mail them material that might be of interest.
"We can take what we know about these people and intuit their income levels and imputed demographic profile and whether they are likely to want to sign up for broadband," George Bell, the chief executive of Excite, said. "That's a powerful method of cross-promotion."
At Home plans to use Excite's customer data base to recruit advertisers as well. Last year, Excite acquired Matchlogic, an advertising tracking firm, and it has been developing a plan to adapt its services to cable television, where a service provider like At Home knows far more about its customers -- including their addresses -- than most Web sites do.
"Probably the hidden gem of the whole deal is how we'll be able to implement their targeting and database technology to deliver advertising to the individual user," said At Home's chief executive, Tom Jermoluk.
In many ways the story of the deal reflects the struggle for control over the Internet by unknown start-ups and established media companies and the dizzying pace of the industry's evolution.
Excite, started in 1994 by a group of Stanford graduates in a garage and originally called Architext, was financed by the high-profile venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. In April 1996, the company went public, marketing itself as a search engine. Mutating with the market, it then turned itself into a so-called portal site, offering not only search capabilities but news, weather, stock quotes, free E-mail accounts and, of course, advertising. Although Excite's stock price has appreciated by almost 600 percent since its initial public offering, the company lost $39.6 million on income of $100 million in the September 1998 quarter.
At Home, though also backed by Kleiner Perkins, has very different origins. It was an effort by major cable companies -- Tele-Communications, Cox and Comcast -- to devise a high-bandwidth Web service and programming intended to be a selling point for cable modems.
Now they are next door to each other in Redwood City, Calif., with roughly the same number of employees and the same interior designer. Each company has a curvy red slide that employees may use to go from the third to the second floor.
"The only thing that separates us is a fountain," Mr. Jermoluk said. "And we're having a party there today."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Microsoft's Profit Up 75% In Quarter

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
Strong shipments of personal computers strengthened the second-quarter financial results of the Microsoft Corporation, which reported a 75 percent gain in earnings yesterday, far exceeding the most optimistic projections of Wall Street analysts.
But officials at Microsoft, the world's leading maker of personal computer software, remained cautious in their outlook, citing concerns about the uncertainty of corporate spending on solutions to the Year 2000 computer clock problem as well as continued financial crises in many foreign markets. 
 Microsoft reported its results after the stock market closed. In anticipation of a strong quarter, its shares rose $5.875, to close at $155.625, in Nasdaq trading. The good news sent Microsoft shares up further in after-hours trading, where they sold as high as $163.25.
Once again, Microsoft's financial performance eclipsed worries about the effects of the Justice Department's antitrust suit.
"It was classic Microsoft: Blow the numbers out and then tell everybody why you won't do it again this quarter," said Rick Sherlund of Goldman, Sachs. "The second half of calendar 1999 they didn't say anything about because they really don't know. That's the tougher call."
Analysts have grown accustomed to Microsoft's pattern of greatly exceeding its quarterly estimates, only to have the company's executives offer a sobering outlook based on perceived threats to its continued prosperity. Those executives attributed the second quarter's strong performance to what was for some people an unexpected surge in personal computer sales, which in turn drove sales of the Windows 98 and Windows NT operating systems.
"Reports of the death of the PC turned out to be greatly exaggerated," Greg Maffei, Microsoft's chief financial officer, said in a conference call with securities analysts from headquarters in Redmond, Wash. He noted that in October, when many predicted a slowdown, Microsoft, rather than offering its usual gloom, forecast strong growth. "However, results also spiked due in part to demand caused by Year 2000 concerns," he said.
"We remain guarded about growth in 1999," Mr. Maffei said. In the current quarter, he said, it seems likely that revenue will decline by at least $300 million from the one being reported yesterday. Although Microsoft's operating earnings will be up 25 percent year over year, and analysts' current estimates are 2 or 3 cents short, Mr. Maffei said earnings will be down compared with the second quarter.
"That's his guidance," Mr. Sherlund remarked. "Whether we want to follow it is another question. They certainly are steering the Street toward slower growth."
For the quarter ending on Dec. 31, Microsoft reported earnings of $1.98 billion, or 73 cents a diluted share, up 75 percent from $1.13 billion, or 42 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenue rose nearly 38 percent, to $4.94 billion, over the $3.585 billion reported in the second quarter of fiscal year 1998.
Analysts had expected Microsoft to earn 59 cents a share, according to First Call.
Unearned revenue, the portion of sales Microsoft sets aside to reflect the long-term use of many of its products, grew to $3.37 billion, from $3.13 billion in the first fiscal quarter.
On a cautionary note, Mr. Maffei said that conditions in Asia, Latin America and Russia remained tough, and that the company did not see a timely end to the difficulty in those markets. "We're talking about a whole segment of the globe," he said. "It's a strange situation. The developing countries are growing slowest while the mature markets, like the U.S., are growing fastest," he said. "Obviously it can't continue, but we don't see how it will end."
