HEADLINE: U.S. Audit Is Said to Criticize Giuliani's Strict Welfare Plan

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS

 BODY:
A two-month Federal inquiry into New York City's welfare program has found that city officials routinely violate the law by denying poor people the right to apply promptly for food stamps, according to two officials who have read a draft report prepared by the United States Department of Agriculture.
The officials said Federal auditors, who reviewed 600 cases at two welfare offices in Queens, had found that city workers failed to make applications immediately available as required by law. The workers also failed to screen families for emergency food needs, required the poor to search for jobs before receiving help and cut off food stamps to needy families who were still eligible for those benefits, the officials said, speaking on the condition that neither they nor their agencies be identified. 
 The Federal investigators, the officials said, also sharply criticized the state for failing to properly monitor the city's welfare program, which the Giuliani administration has said was intended to discourage people from applying for public benefits, including food stamps. Advocates for the poor -- not state officials -- alerted the Federal Government to the problems at city welfare offices.
"Substantial noncompliance with the food stamp act and regulations has gone undetected and unaddressed at the local level," the report said, according to the two officials who described its findings to The New York Times.
The Federal report offered the sharpest criticism yet of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's tough welfare policies, which Mr. Giuliani has repeatedly described as one of his biggest accomplishments. Federal officials are also reviewing the city's Medicaid policies to determine whether the city is improperly preventing the poor from applying for medical assistance.
Officials from the Department of Agriculture, who presented the draft report to the city and state last week, told the local officials that they must act immediately to correct the deficiencies and gave them until yesterday evening to respond.
City officials declined to discuss the report or to describe the changes they were making in response to it. Instead, they accused the investigators of trying to sabotage their efforts to push people to rely more on themselves and less on government.
"The review being conducted by U.S.D.A. is a misguided effort intended to derail the state and city's progress in transforming welfare, which includes food stamps, into one where work and self-sufficiency are the foremost objectives of the program," said Debra Sproles, a spokeswoman for the city's Human Resources Administration, which runs the city's welfare programs.
State officials said they had responded in writing, telling the Federal auditors that the city had agreed to develop a new application form, to improve the screening process for emergency food needs and to allow food stamp applicants with children under 6 to forgo the work requirement. But the state officials vigorously defended their oversight of the city, saying the problems were minor and already being addressed.
"We have spent unprecedented amounts of time working on various food stamp issues," said Daniel D. Hogan, a Deputy Commissioner of the state's Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, which oversees welfare programs in New York City.
"We have asked the Federal Government to withdraw this review," Mr. Hogan said. "There's no basis for it. A conference call could have taken care of these issues. The city's only intention here is to run a fair, efficient operation that works."
Federal officials, who have the power to withhold financing from states that fail to address legal violations, plan to issue a final report in several weeks once they review New York's comments on their findings. But the inquiry has already spawned a Federal class-action lawsuit, filed by lawyers for the poor last month, as well as some soul searching in welfare offices and state capitals across the country.
The situation in New York highlights the conundrum confronted by welfare officials across the country, who find themselves struggling to juggle two very different Federal mandates. On one hand, the Federal welfare law allows states and municipalities to discourage people from applying for cash benefits, and offers financial incentives for those with declines in their caseloads.
On the other, the law requires states to encourage the needy to apply for food stamps and Medicaid, two benefits described as critical by Federal officials hoping to keep the working poor off welfare and the newly employed from returning.
While the law allows food stamp applicants who are denied benefits to appeal those decisions, it was unclear last night whether people who have been improperly discouraged from applying for food stamps have any recourse, beyond reapplying. An official familiar with the Federal report said it did not address that issue.
New York City began its new application process in April when it started converting welfare offices into "job centers," where caseworkers encourage people to seek child support payments, unemployment benefits or help from food pantries instead of cash benefits. The workers offer applications only if a person returns for a second appointment.
About a third of the city's welfare offices currently operate under those rules. When the Federal investigators examined the two Queens offices, they were among only 9 of the roughly 30 offices citywide that had been converted.
The welfare issue is important to Mayor Giuliani, who may be contemplating national office and often mentions his tougher approach to welfare when he travels across the country testing the political waters. And when the Federal inquiry became public in November, Mr. Giuliani began a vigorous attack on the Federal investigators and advocates for the poor.
At first, Jason Turner, the city's welfare Commissioner, told The Times that he would speed up the distribution of applications to the poor as a precaution while the Government conducted its inquiry.
But the next day, city officials said they would not speed up the distribution. They said agriculture officials had determined that their policies complied with Federal law, an assertion the officials promptly denied.
Later that week, Mr. Giuliani said that The Times had not reported Mr. Turner's remarks accurately, adding, "Sometimes, things aren't reported exactly the way somebody says something because there is an emotional or ideological bias." Mr. Turner did not complain of being misquoted, but he was no longer available to comment.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION;
Clinton Outlines His Vision for Nation's Transition to the 21st Century

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the presentations yesterday by Representatives Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, and Steve Largent, Republican of Oklahoma, in response to President Clinton's State of the Union Message, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
MS. DUNN
As you might imagine, if you'd been sitting with us in the House chamber tonight as the President was giving his speech, you could have felt the swirl of history. These are disturbing and controversial times in our nation's capital. 
 A couple of weeks ago, I even heard a network anchor say, "The capital is in chaos." Another proclaimed we were in the midst of a constitutional crisis.
Ladies and gentlemen, our country is not in crisis. There are no tanks in the streets. Our system of government is as solid as the Capitol dome you see behind me.
Our democracy is sound. Our economy is prosperous. The state of our union is strong. And no matter what the outcome of the President's situation, life in America will go on. Our lives will continue to be filled with practical matters, not constitutional ones.
I've been a single mother since my boys were little, 6 and 8. My life in those days was taken up with meeting -- trying to make -- make ends meet, trying to get to two soccer games at the same time on two different fields, worrying about dropping the boys off early at school in order for me to get to work on time. I know how that knot in the pit of your stomach feels. I've been there.
I'm still a practical person. You heard the President make a lot of promises to a lot of people tonight. But I'd like to talk to you about two very practical Republican priorities, tax relief and Social Security reform.
Our current tax system is a burden on the economy and on the American people. Let me tell you a story about a fellow I represent from North Bend, Wash. His name is Robert Allan.
A few years ago, the I.R.S. denied his right to file a joint return with his wife because they said his wife, Shirley, was deceased. Well, I've seen Shirley -- she looks pretty good for a dead person.
Robert took Shirley to the I.R.S. office in Seattle. The I.R.S. was not convinced. So the Allans brought in their family doctor, and in his medical opinion he pronounced Shirley alive. The I.R.S. was still not convinced.
It took intervention by a member of Congress, me, to resolve this comedy, which in truth is a tragedy because it's symbolic of how removed our entire tax system has become from reality and from common sense.
Last year, we passed legislation reining in the I.R.S., so that taxpayers are now considered innocent until proven guilty. But so much more needs to be done.
Next year there will be a $63 billion budget surplus. Mr. President, give it back. Last year, a typical mother and father who both work paid nearly 40 percent of their income in taxes. That means 40 cents out of every dollar they earned went to the government in Federal, state or local taxes.
That's the highest percentage of income ever paid in taxes by American families.
I don't know about you but that really bothers me; no wonder so many American families are struggling:
Get married, and your taxes go up.
Save for your children's education, and your taxes go up.
And when you die -- that's right, your taxes go up. The Government gets a bigger piece of your life's work than all your children put together. So what can you expect from Republicans? Expect action.
First, tonight we're proposing a 10 percent, across-the-board cut in tax rates for every working American. That's the down payment on a simpler, fairer, flatter tax system.
Second, we must end the marriage penalty. We should honor commitment, not tax it.
And third, we must cut death taxes so that families don't have to sell their businesses and farms when mom and dad die.
In all of our tax policies, we start from this premise: the people's money belongs to the people, not to the Government.
The second thing I want to talk about is Social Security. A year ago in his State of the Union speech, the President said he was committed to saving Social Security. I'm glad to hear him discuss it again this evening. Unfortunately, spending the surplus, as he proposes, will not save Social Security. It just temporarily props it up with some extra cash.
Mr. President, we're still waiting for real legislation.
We've reserved H.R.1, the very first bill of this Congress, for the President's Social Security plan.
There's one thing we can all agree on, one nonnegotiable principle: we must keep our contract with our senior citizens who depend on Social Security for part or all of their retirement income. This nation made that promise long ago and we will keep that promise.
But Social Security needs not just to be patched up; it needs to be updated for the 21st century. People today want and expect to have more control over their lives and over their money. But President Clinton's approach, as you've just heard, gives the Government more control of your retirement income.
The Social Security dollars deducted from your paycheck currently earn less than 3 percent a year. That's not enough of a return; that's not going to keep Social Security solvent, and it's especially not fair to young people and to women.
For example, the current system works against mothers who choose to step out of their job for a while, away from their career, to raise children or to care for parents.
It works against wives, who more often than not, survive their husbands and they end up living for more years on fewer dollars. And it works against young people who believe they'll never see a Social Security check.
Here's a better way: give working Americans the choice to invest some of their Social Security dollars in personal retirement accounts. We can do this without touching a dime in Social Security funds, without raising one nickel in taxes and without touching one penny of current benefits.
A new century requires a new beginning, in approaches, in ideas, and, yes, in civility and cooperation between political parties.
I'd like to close on a personal note. I'm a mother, a gardener, a Republican and a member of Congress. Believe me, all four take patience. My boys, thankfully, turned out to be wonderful young men. My plants at home, unfortunately, need a lot of work. And as for my efforts in the Congress, I am constantly planting and watering.
As one citizen to another, in spite of all the troubling things you hear about our nation's capital, I believe that good ideas can take root here, good things can grow here and good things can blossom here.
 
MR. LARGENT
Tonight, I want to share some brief but important thoughts with you.
First, let me say what a special privilege it is to speak to you and give my response and the Republicans' response to the President's remarks.
Let me tell you a bit about myself. I grew up in Oklahoma and was born in the very district I'm now proud to represent.
I was raised in a broken home and thanks to my mom, I stayed in school, stayed out of most trouble, and went to college. I married my high school sweetheart, Terry, a cheerleader. And, for the next 14 years, I got to live every boy's dream -- playing in the National Football League for the Seattle Seahawks.
After I concluded my career in the N.F.L., I started my own marketing and advertising business back in Tulsa. But in 1994 I campaigned for the first elective office in my life and won. I came to Washington with a group of Republicans committed to balancing the budget, slowing the growth of government, cutting taxes, reforming welfare and saving Medicare. And that's exactly what we did. . . .
Prior to 1994, my wife and I, we weren't political. We were like most families --raising four kids, hustling from one school or sports event to another, our car littered by fast-food wrappers and french fries. In fact, it wasn't until after I was elected that I attended a Republican function where a banner hung that read "G.O.P." I had to ask someone what those letters stood for. They said, "Grand Old Party, of course."
I believe tonight is an appropriate time to ask once again, what does the G.O.P. stand for? What does the party of Lincoln and Reagan stand for today? What are the lasting bedrock principles that personify and distinguish the Republican Party? It's these questions I want to answer tonight because the answer is why I ran for office in the first place.
Here's the 15-second sound bite answer: the Republican Party's mission is to promote, preserve, and protect individual liberty, free enterprise and limited government. But what does that mean to my family and your family?
First, we must preserve the notion that true liberty and freedom come from God and are His blessing on this land and that freedom reigns only as we act responsibly toward God, each other, and His creation.
Our freedom was bought at a great price, and our most important responsibility is to defend this sacred gift and keep our country secure. Tonight we support our troops that are stationed in Bosnia, the Middle East and around the world. And the good news is that after six years of cutting spending for our armed forces, the President has signaled that he is ready to join us in strengthening our national defense.
We must never be complacent in what is still a dangerous world. Terrorists and rogue nations are rapidly acquiring technology to deliver weapons of mass destruction to our very doorstep.
Most Americans are shocked to discover that our country is unshielded from the accidental or ruthless launch of even a single missile over our skies. Mr. President, we urge you to join Congress in establishing a viable missile defense system to protect the United States.
Protecting individual liberty also means protecting the unborn. Again this year, overwhelming majorities in both Houses will urge the President to end the dreadful and unwarranted practice of partial-birth abortion. We must uphold the sanctity of life amidst the tragedies of abortion, euthanasia, and assisted suicide.
Republicans also promote free enterprise. We believe market principles like competition really work. At the heart of free enterprise is good education. For far too long we've allowed Washington to dictate how our children are taught. One of our priorities is to give control of our schools to local communities.
We want the most important election affecting your children's education to be the one that decides who sits on the school board, not who you send to Washington. Parents deserve the opportunity to choose the best school, with the best curriculum, the best teachers and the safest environment for their children.
I recently met with a room full of teachers in Jenks, Okla. I came out of that meeting convinced more than ever that teachers like these know best how Federal education dollars should be spent.
That's why Republicans are leading the effort that will insure 90 cents of every Federal education dollar goes directly to the classroom, empowering parents and teachers, not bureaucrats.
And if we really want to "free" enterprise and the economy, lets scrap the Internal Revenue tax code. The 8,000 plus pages of confusion, contradiction and confiscation are choking small business and driving the average taxpayer mad.
Republicans want to establish a date by which the tax code will be abolished and replaced by something that's simple, fair and takes a smaller bite from the family's pocket book.
 Finally, Republicans stand for limited government. Ronald Reagan reminded us that "a government that is big enough to give you everything you want is also big enough to take everything you have." And tonight the Federal Government is still too big and taking more than it should. We will continue our efforts to control Washington's wasteful spending and its insatiable appetite for your money.
Well, this is what the Grand Old Party stands for and if this represents your hopes and dreams, we ask not that you pull for us, but that you push with us. . . .
Yesterday marked the 70th year since the birth of a great American leader and hero, Dr. Martin Luther King. In one of his last sermons in 1968, Dr. King warned that, while the world is a closer neighborhood, we are experiencing less brotherhood. That's equally true today.
It is no longer the aggression from without that is America's greatest threat, but alienation from within; alienation at every level -- husband from wife, mother from father, parent from child, black from white, Republican from Democrat, liberal from conservative.
And there's only one solution -- reconciliation. Ironically, the word Congress itself is made of two Latin words that mean "to walk together."
Reconciliation requires the humility and courage to say, "I'm sorry, I was wrong, will you forgive me." Therein lies the healing salve for the wounded soul of our nation. You see, the body of our country is strong. It's the heart that needs attention.
On Christmas Eve my family and I packed up our kids and gifts and headed to grandma's house. In the car, we sang along with Vince Gill's Christmas tape. As we sang one particular song, I was struck by the words and by their poignancy for our country tonight. The chorus went, "Let there be peace on earth, and let it begin with me."
So, let there be peace on earth, and let it begin with me. And let it begin with Republicans and Democrats and blacks and whites, and moms and, yes, especially dads. Let there be peace on earth and let it begin with all of us who comprise one nation, under God, indivisible.
And if we work together and walk together, and if we have a Congress motivated not by the maintenance of power, but by principle, then I believe historians will tell our children's children: There walked a great people, a nation that preserved the wonderful promise that we call America.
May God bless you and your family, and may God continue to bless this great nation.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: THE RESPONSE;
In New Unity, G.O.P. Seeks 10% U.S. Tax Cut

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL and KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Republicans sought today to dispel the image of a Congress consumed by impeachment, putting forward an agenda that calls for a 10 percent across-the-board cut in income tax rates and pledging to engage President Clinton on assuring the long-term solvency of Social Security.
The proposal for a sweeping income tax reduction was made by Senate Republicans in a morning news conference, and then highlighted tonight by Representative Jennifer Dunn of Washington, who shared with Representative Steve Largent of Oklahoma the televised Republican response to the State of the Union Message. 
 The House and Senate coordination on tax cuts showed a new unity on the part of Republicans in the two chambers who fought bitterly over tax reduction last year. The proposal sets up a sharp ideological collision between the Republicans' tax-cutting ambitions and Mr. Clinton's call to allocate budget surpluses over the next 15 years to Social Security, Medicare and increased domestic and military spending.
"Americans should not have to wait 15 years for a tax cut," said Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, after Senate Republicans introduced the tax cut plan as one of the first five bills of the year.
Leading Republicans in the House and Senate today also immediately criticized Mr. Clinton's call for the Federal Government to invest some of the retirement benefits in the stock market. They prefer giving Americans private investment accounts to manage themselves.
"If you thought a Government takeover of health care was bad," said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, "just wait until the Government becomes an owner of America's private sector companies."
And Representative Dennis Hastert of Illinois, the new Speaker, said, "Having the Government invest in the stock market for the American people will not strengthen our economic security. The President's suggestion that Social Security reform starts with Government intervention in the stock market is plain wrong."
On a day that saw lawmakers ricochet from the impeachment trial in the Senate to the President's State of the Union Message before a joint session of Congress in the House chamber, most Republicans were studiously polite, although two House leaders, Dick Armey of Texas and Tom DeLay of Texas, noticeably did not applaud.
Mr. DeLay said of the President's speech, "It was a political speech. He used all of his weapons of mass distraction."
Mostly, Republicans as much as Mr. Clinton sought to play down the impeachment struggle. And by putting forward Ms. Dunn and Mr. Largent for the party's response, the Republicans tried to give a fresh and more diverse look to the Congressional majority that for four years had seemed to be defined by just one person, Newt Gingrich. The two -- both told a bit of their personal story tonight -- had emphasized their newer faces as selling points in House leadership races last year that they both lost.
Standing with the Capitol dome as a backdrop, neither House member outright mentioned impeachment, but Ms. Dunn tried to defuse the issue immediately and remove it from center stage.
"A couple of weeks ago, I heard a network anchor say, 'The capital is in chaos,' " she said. "Another proclaimed we were in the midst of a constitutional crisis. Ladies and gentlemen, our country is not in crisis."
Ms. Dunn noted, "There are no tanks in the streets."
Then picking her words carefully, she said, "No matter what the outcome of the President's situation, life in America will go on. Our lives will continue to be filled with practical matters, not constitutional ones."
She called for an array of tax cuts to satisfy every Republican constituency, beginning with the 10 percent reduction in income tax rates, saying "That is the down payment on a simpler, fairer, flatter tax system." Ms. Dunn also advocated an end to the so-called marriage penalty, which charges some couples more in taxes than they would pay if they were single, and a reduction in the inheritance tax.
The Republicans did not spell out how much revenue the Government would lose under their plan. By some estimates, the cut in the income tax rates alone would amount to $700 billion over a decade. Under their plan, each marginal income tax rate would fall. The 15 percent rate would drop to 13.5 percent, for example, while the highest rate of 39.6 percent would fall to 35.64 percent.
The proposal means that a married couple with two children earning $75,000 a year, for example, would see its tax payment fall to $9,277 from $10,308, for a net tax savings of $1,031, according to the Senate Finance Committee. Those savings assume the couple does not itemize its taxes.
Republican leaders sought to counterpose such a sweeping tax rate reduction against Mr. Clinton's own call for specific tax credits for needs like child care and displaced workers. Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, called such selective tax relief "the old Washington solution:Take it from the worker, bring it to Washington, Washington takes the parts it wants. And then return it back to the people in a way that we tell them that they can have a tax credit."
On Social Security, Ms. Dunn challenged Mr. Clinton to send forward legislation immediately. But she also criticized his proposal as "giving Government more control of your retirement income." She promoted instead a Republican proposal for Americans to have individual accounts that they choose how to invest.
Mr. Largent's response emphasized issues of concern to the Republicans' conservative base, while at the same time trying to strike a theme of reconciliation for the Congress left so divided by impeachment.
"First, we must preserve the notion that true liberty and freedom come from God and are His blessing on this land," Mr. Largent said, "and that freedom reigns only as we act responsibly toward God, each other and His creation."
Mr. Largent praised Mr. Clinton for proposing an increase in military spending and asked him to embrace a Republican proposal for a national missile defense system.
Mr. Largent also turned to an issue paramount for social conservatives, saying "protecting individual liberty also means protecting the unborn." He called for an end to a form of abortion that opponents call partial-birth abortion. Mr. Clinton has vetoed legislation that would ban the practice, in which a fetus is partially extracted and its skull collapsed in the birth canal. The House overrode his veto but the Senate failed to do so by three votes last year.
Another major policy battle was shaping up on education, an issue both parties said would be a priority in this session. Republicans criticized Mr. Clinton's newest proposals, which would hold states and schools accountable for their progress and use Federal aid as a lever to improve performance, as an encroachment on local control of schools.
"We will focus on local school districts," said Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee.
Some Republicans were also dubious of Mr. Clinton's announcement that the Justice Department will sue the tobacco companies. "Some may view it as relieving the Congress of having to move on any legislation," said Senator John McCain of Arizona, who tried and failed to push through the Senate anti-tobacco legislation last year.
By night's end some members of Congress were left reeling by the convergence of impeachment and the State of the Union address. "This is schizophrenia at its highest," Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania said. "The President excels at appearing oblivious."

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: THE OVERVIEW;
Unbowed, Clinton Presses Social Security Plan

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
President Clinton proposed tonight that the Federal Government invest for the first time in the stock market to strengthen Social Security, as he delivered a confident report on the State of the Union to a divided Congress considering cutting short his Presidency.
Appearing in the grand House chamber a month to the day after he was impeached there, Mr. Clinton also urged Congress to begin contributing $33 billion a year to a new system of retirement accounts for American workers. 
 The President smiled and even joked with his audience of antagonists and allies as he ignored the trial steps away in the Senate -- where lawyers began defending him just a few hours earlier -- and envisioned using the rest of his term to strengthen the nation's schools, military forces and programs for the elderly.
In a sure-footed, 77-minute address, Mr. Clinton coupled a rosy appraisal of the nation's state with an urgent appeal for action, flaunting his laurels but insisting he would not rest on them.
"America is working again," the President said. "The promise of our future is limitless. But we cannot realize that promise if we allow the hum of our prosperity to lull us into complacency." Transcript, pages A22-23.
Mr. Clinton announced tonight that the Justice Department was preparing to sue tobacco companies, opening a new front in a war that has repeatedly gained him political ground. He argued that Federal programs like Medicare were due hundreds of billions of dollars for the costs of treating lung cancer and other diseases.
Mr. Clinton left it to his lawyers to attack the charges that he broke the law to cover up his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, the former intern.
But he seized on his State of the Union Message as his most potent defense, just as for the last turbulent year he has counted on his dogged advocacy of popular programs to sustain him.
Mr. Clinton exuded ease and a sense of political control, reacting with unmistakable delight when both sides of the chamber erupted in applause for his call for equal pay for equal work by women or men.
"That was more encouraging, you know," he said, grinning and spreading his arms wide as he bent slightly from side to side. "There was more balance on the seesaw. I like that!"
After the traditional, bipartisan ovation welcoming the President, Democrats applauded far longer and louder, and some of Mr. Clinton's accusers sat with lips compressed and hands folded.
But Mr. Clinton tried to draw his opponents in. Early on, he recalled the acceptance speech of the new Speaker, Dennis Hastert, who urged members to work together in a spirit of civility and bipartisanship.
"Mr. Speaker, let's do exactly that," the President said, turning and extending his hand to the Republican. A surprised Mr. Hastert stood and accepted the handshake.
The President presented his legislative shopping list -- from an initiative to ease traffic congestion to a $1 billion program to help people switch from welfare to work -- to a Republican Congress with far different plans for spending the surpluses accumulating after decades of deficits. He did not explain how he would pay for most of his programs.
Yet even if some of his plans stand little chance of passage, Mr. Clinton was able to command a television audience for a recitation of the economic benefits of his leadership -- and an implicit argument that the trial is an unwarranted distraction from important business.
"With our budget surplus growing, our economy expanding, our confidence rising, now is the moment for this generation to meet our historic responsibility to the 21st Century," Mr. Clinton said. Calling this time "a new dawn for America," he urged his listeners to "put aside our divisions" and find "a new hour of healing and hopefulness."
Mr. Clinton recognized several people in the galleries to underscore his points. Among them, Sammy Sosa, the home run hitter, and Rosa Parks, the civil rights demonstrator, brought thunderous applause that created an image of bipartisan bonhomie, at least on television.
The President also singled out his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, whose loyalty and advice have been important to his political stamina. "I'd like to take just a minute to honor her," he said. Mrs. Clinton beamed as the President gazed up at her through squinting eyes. She rose, sat, then rose again to wave and acknowledge applause.
In all, Mr. Clinton was interrupted about 98 times by the usually partisan applause.
Illustrating the peculiar political dynamic unfolding here, Republican leaders also seemed eager today to play down the trial. They laid out their own legislative agenda this morning, insisting that mulling the first removal of a sitting President would not divert them from what Trent Lott, the majority leader, called "the people's business."
In giving the Republican response tonight, Rep. Jennifer Dunn of Washington assured her viewers that "our country is not in crisis," and that "no matter what the outcome of the President's situation, life in America will go on."
Mr. Clinton devoted only a fraction of his speech to foreign policy, joining in one paragraph a statement of pride in Northern Ireland's peace with a condemnation of the violence in Kosovo.
Though the President called for sure-fire political initiatives like putting 50,000 more police officers on the street, he also used his speech to push beyond his short-term predicament. He urged a long-term fix to the Social Security system his associates said he hopes will shine through the historic blot of impeachment.
Anticipating a political free fall over the coming budget, Mr. Clinton urged Congress in his State of the Union Message last year to "Save Social Security first." That proved a deft political move, stifling Republican appeals for tax cuts.
But with the surpluses growing and a new politics of prosperity firing legislators' imaginations, Senate Republicans declared this morning that they would seek a 10 percent cut in personal income tax rates.
Tonight, Mr. Clinton again moved to box them in.
"I reach out my hand to all of you in both houses and both parties and ask that we join together in saying to the American people: We will save Social Security now," he said. "Now, last year we wisely reserved all of the surplus until we knew what it would take to save Social Security. Again, I say we shouldn't spend any of it, not any of it, until after Social Security is truly saved. First things first."
For a month, the White House has deliberately leaked proposals from Mr. Clinton's State of the Union speech to capture headlines showing the President at work. But it held back its plans for Social Security as well as for tobacco, to try to insure that Mr. Clinton's substantive proposals, rather than the spectacle of his appearance before Congress, would drive tonight's news coverage.
Mr. Clinton argued that the greater share -- 62 percent -- of forthcoming Federal surpluses should be earmarked to preserve Social Security, a program that was at the heart of the Democratic New Deal but that has since developed overwhelming popular support.
Another 15 percent of the surpluses, Mr. Clinton said, should go to protect the Medicare program, which assists the elderly with health care. The President would spend about 11 percent of the surpluses to create retirement savings accounts, called Universal Savings Accounts.
The remainder of the surpluses -- roughly another 11 percent, according to the Administration -- would go to defense and domestic initiatives.
In all, Mr. Clinton proposed that $2.7 trillion of a projected $4.4 trillion in surpluses over the next 15 years be directed to help preserve Social Security. The changes Mr. Clinton seeks in the system, the Administration contends, will keep it solvent until 2055. It is now projected to run out of money to pay the claims of retirees -- who are expected not only to grow in number but also to live longer -- by 2032.
But the Administration's goal is to secure Social Security until 2075, which means today's plan even by Mr. Clinton's standards is only a partial solution. Mr. Clinton made clear tonight that he had no interest in pursuing politically unattractive options, like tax increases or what he called "drastic cuts in benefits."
Mr. Clinton argued that Social Security would be stronger if it could invest some of its trust fund in the stock market, where it could earn higher returns than from the Treasury bonds it invests in now. Although state governments invest their pension plans in stocks, this would be the first venture by the Federal Government into the market.
In all, the Administration proposed investing up to 25 percent of the new money for Social Security, or $700 billion, in stocks over the next 15 years. Gene Sperling, the director of the National Economic Council, said that under this plan, Social Security would never have more than 15 percent of its assets in the market, a level he called "far, far more conservative than any pension plan in the country does."
The Administration proposes to work with Congress to create a privately managed system to invest the money without political interference.
But Republicans signaled they had no interest in the President's suggestion. "Government-controlled investment in markets is contrary to free enterprise," said Bill Archer, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Archer said that such investment "will open the doors to all kinds of mischief involving Government dictates, favoritism, and cronyism."
The remainder of the surplus money Mr. Clinton hopes to reserve for Social Security -- about $2 trillion -- would, like the money he would set aside for Medicare, go to pay off the Federal debt. They propose using the money to shore up the Social Security system by reducing the national debt.
That would simultaneously reduce the amount of Government debt and increase Social Security's financial reserves. The Administration says it would help bring down interest rates, stimulate new investment and create conditions for faster economic growth to guard against the strains caused by the retirement of the baby boom generation.
Mr. Sperling said that under this plan, the Federal debt would fall as a percentage of the domestic product from 44 percent today to less than 10 percent by 2014. When Mr. Clinton took office, he said, that number was 50.1 percent.
In proposing his fix for Social Security, Mr. Clinton heeded the demands of his core Democratic constituencies, rejecting a Republican call that individuals be permitted make some of their investment decisions about the money the Government deducts from their pay.
Instead, he called for maintaining Social Security as a "defined benefit" plan, that is, one with a guaranteed payout. But tonight he also proposed the system of personal savings accounts, which are similar to what Republicans are seeking as at least a partial replacement for Social Security. For the President, the new accounts would supplement Social Security, not replace it.
Each worker would receive some flat payment, say $100, to open an account. If a worker then chose to deposit more money, Administration officials said, the Government would match part of it, perhaps in the form of a tax credit. Mr. Sperling said that the Administration favored weighting the matching system so that it provided a greater benefit to lower-income workers.
Mr. Clinton's aides repeatedly referred to the agenda he presented tonight as the most aggressive he has offered since 1993, and far different than the kind of agenda one might expect from a President contemplating his seventh year.
They were emphasizing that Mr. Clinton intended to stick around, and they were trying to draw a sharp contrast with the Republicans.
Mr. Clinton proposed a raft of domestic initiatives tonight, including several to bolster education. This year, Congress must reauthorize the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, as it does every five years.
The Administration hopes to amend the law, which governs aid to public schools, to demand that states and school systems begin testing new teachers for competence, identify failing schools and shut them if necessary, and end practices like social promotion, or moving children into the next grade even if they have not gained the necessary skills.
"Each year the national Government invests more than $15 billion in our public schools," Mr. Clinton said. "I believe we must change the way we invest that money, to support what works and to stop supporting what does not work."

HEADLINE: Chase, Among Other Banks, Posts Gains for 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Some of the biggest United States banks reported gains in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday as a strong economy lifted income from loans and fees.
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's third-largest bank, and the Bank One Corporation, the fifth largest, both benefited from growth in credit card fees. 
 "Strong fee growth and fairly strong mortgage and loan origination are functions of a strong economy," said Scott Edgar, director of research at Sife Trust Fund in Walnut Creek, Calif., which owns $1.1 billion in financial stocks.
Concern among investors about whether that growth can be sustained should the economy slow led some bank stocks to fall yesterday, Mr. Edgar said.
BankAmerica, the nation's second-largest bank after Citigroup Inc., also benefited from growth in credit card loans. One-time merger charges, losses from a loan to D. E. Shaw & Company, a hedge fund and securities firm, and lower income from capital markets offset those gains.
J. P. Morgan & Company, the financial services giant, said that its earnings fell because of weak results from equity investments.
Shares of Chase rose $3.50, to $74.375; those of BankAmerica declined 56.25 cents, to $64, and those of J. P. Morgan fell $2.8125, to $105.9375.
Bank One slipped $1 a share, to $54.125; PNC dropped 81.25 cents, to $49.125; Bank of New York fell $1.9375, to $35.125, and Wells Fargo & Company fell 68.75 cents, to $36.8125.
Chase's fourth-quarter earnings rose 31 percent, to a record $1.15 billion, or $1.31 a diluted share, compared with $850 million, or 94 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. That surpassed analyst expectations of $1.19 a share.
For the full year, earnings for the bank, which is based in New York, were $4.02 billion, or $4.51 a share, compared with $3.85 billion, or $4.17 a share, in 1997.
BankAmerica reported a quarterly profit of $1.60 billion, or 91 cents a diluted share, excluding the cost of the company's merger with Nationsbank last fall, a performance in line with Wall Street's expectations.
After $441 million in merger-related charges, net income was $1.16 billion, or 66 cents a diluted share. For the period a year earlier, net income was $1.46 billion, or 81 cents a share, including a $220 million charge related to Nationsbank's earlier merger with Barnett Banks.
BankAmerica lost $201 million, or 7 cents a diluted share, before taxes on its business with Shaw, the securities firm and hedge fund. BankAmerica took over a $20 billion bond portfolio from Shaw. The bank sold more than $13 billion of that portfolio, incurring trading losses of $43 million. BankAmerica wrote down the value of a loan to Shaw by $158 million.
For all of 1998, BankAmerica, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., posted net earnings of $5.17 billion, or $2.90 a diluted share, compared with $6.54 billion, or $3.61 a share, in 1997.
Morgan's earnings fell 35 percent, to $175 million, or 86 cents a diluted share, compared with $271 million, or $1.33 a share, in the quarter a year earlier -- more than double analyst expectations of 38 cents a share.
Including an after-tax charge of $86 million for severance pay and consolidating the bank's real estate in Europe, profit fell 67 percent, to $89 million, or 42 cents a share.
For all of 1998, Morgan, which is based in New York, had net earnings of $963 million, or $4.71 a share, compared with $1.47 billion, or $7.17 a share, in 1997.
Fourth-quarter earnings for Bank One, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, rose 17 percent as profit from operations rose to $1.04 billion, or 88 cents a share, from $890 million, or 75 cents in the period a year ago, matching analyst estimates.
Net income fell 75 percent, to $226 million, or 19 cents a share, including one-time charges for the merger in October with the First Chicago NBD Corporation, a write-down of the value of its auto-leasing portfolio and the closing of some automated-teller machines.
Net earnings for all of 1998 were $3.12 billion, or $2.61 a share, compared with $2.96 billion, or $2.43 a share, in 1997.
Wells Fargo's profit from operations rose 18 percent, to $768 million, or 46 cents a diluted share, compared with $650 million, or 39 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier, in line with analyst estimates.
The bank, based in San Francisco, reported a net loss of $194 million, or 12 cents a share, for the fourth quarter because of charges from its merger with the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis in November.
Including unusual charges, Wells Fargo earned $1.95 billion, or $1.17 a share, in 1998, down from $2.50 billion, or $1.48 a share, in 1997.
Bank of New York said fourth-quarter earnings rose 5 percent, to $313 million, or 40 cents a share, compared with $298 million, or 37 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier, led by growth in its securities-processing businesses. The results met analyst forecasts.
For the year, Bank of New York's profit grew 8 percent, to $1.19 billion, or $1.53 a share, compared with $1.10 billion, or $1.36 a share, for 1997.

HEADLINE: Fleet Says Profit Rose in Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The Fleet Financial Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter profits rose 25 percent, to $416 million, assisted by growth in fee income and solid credit quality.
The Boston-based bank earned 69 cents a diluted share in the quarter, a penny better than forecast by analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation and higher than the 57 cents a share Fleet earned in the corresponding quarter a year earlier, after merger-related charges, it said. 
 "Fleet continues to benefit from strong asset generation, particularly in commercial banking, where loans were up 15 percent for the year," said Fleet's president, Robert Higgins. "Fleet's national businesses, including credit card and asset management, contributed to significant growth in fee income."
Fleet, which has about $104.4 billion in total assets, said noninterest income jumped 43 percent in the fourth quarter, to $890 million, with particularly robust growth in credit cards and capital markets revenues.
Strength in corporate finance fees, venture capital revenue, market-making activities at its Quick & Reilly unit and foreign exchange and interest rate products trading revenue drove capital markets revenue up to $161 million from $88 million, Fleet said.
Its net interest income rose to $1 billion in the fourth quarter from $944 million amid commercial loan growth.

HEADLINE: G.E. Reports 14% Profit Gain As It Does More Service Work

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 20

 BODY:
The General Electric Company, which makes everything from light bulbs to locomotives, said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 14 percent as the company sold more industrial service contracts.
Net income climbed to $2.67 billion, or 80 cents a diluted share, compared with $2.35 billion, or 70 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The results matched analysts' expectations. Revenue rose 7 percent, to $28.6 billion from $26.7 billion. 
 For the year, G.E. said its profit climbed 13 percent, to $9.3 billion, or $2.80 a share, compared with $8.2 billion, or $2.46 a share. Revenue rose 11 percent, to a record $100.5 billion from $90.8 billion.
G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., increasingly generates profit and revenue by selling long-term service contracts with its industrial products, a strategy that insures steady revenue. Profit from service contracts tends to be more reliable than that from product sales, which can rise or fall with the economy. The contracts let G.E. lock in revenue over time. G.E. has a large base of installed equipment to service and provides service for other manufacturers' products.
About 70 percent of G.E.'s revenue comes from services, including those provided by its GE Capital finance unit, according to estimates by some analysts.
G.E. said services in 1998 at its industrial units rose more than 20 percent, though it did not break out a percentage of revenue that services now make up. Some analysts estimated it to be as much as one-third of sales.
Results were led in part by G.E.'s aircraft engine unit, the No. 1 maker of jet engines; its power systems unit, the No. 1 provider of power generation equipment and services; its medical systems unit, the No. 1 maker of MRI and CAT scan machines, and GE Capital.
That offset slower profit gains at the company's lighting, appliances, plastics and broadcasting units, including the NBC television network.
G.E. has also taken advantage of recessions in Asia, particularly at GE Capital, by snapping up companies at reduced prices or creating joint ventures, such as one it entered in February with Toho Mutual Life.
Last year, G.E. made 108 acquisitions -- including more than 70 outside the United States -- totaling more than $18 billion.
Shares of G.E., whose $328 billion market value is exceeded only by that of Microsoft, fell $1.0625, to $100.375. G.E.'s stock has climbed more than 33 percent in the last 12 months and has almost quadrupled in the five years ended Dec. 31.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Output Is Off at Car Makers in Japan

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Domestic production at the major Japanese auto makers fell in 1998 because of a prolonged domestic recession and economic turmoil in the rest of Asia, the manufacturers said today.
Toyota Motor, the nation's largest car maker, said its domestic production fell 9.6 percent, to 3.17 million vehicles last year. Nissan Motor, Japan's second largest, reported a 10.1 percent decline, to 1.55 million, while Mitsubishi Motors recorded a 12.8 percent drop, to 1.08 million. 
 Honda Motor and Mazda Motor, which is controlled by Ford Motor of the United States, recorded their first declines in three years. Honda's domestic production fell 4.8 percent, to 1.24 million vehicles, while Mazda's declined 3.5 percent, to 838,179.
Toyota's exports in 1998 declined 2.1 percent, to 1.46 million vehicles; Mitsubishi's dropped 5.2 percent, to 522,988, and those at Honda slipped 2.5 percent, to 530,717 vehicles.
Bucking the trend was Nissan, whose exports rose 2 percent, to 705,730, and Mazda, which exported 555,717 vehicles, 2.7 percent more than in 1997.

HEADLINE: Unprecedented Good Times

 BODY:
The current economic expansion will soon enter its ninth year, making it the longest peacetime expansion in American history. But it is unusual in more ways than length, as Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, emphasized in Congressional testimony yesterday.
Mr. Greenspan pointed to the unprecedented rise in stock prices. That has made it far cheaper and easier for American industry to raise capital, and it has contributed to a sense of well-being in this country. It also has led to President Clinton's proposal to have some Social Security money go into stocks, an idea Mr. Greenspan opposed out of fear of political influence in investment decisions. 
 As Mr. Greenspan pointed out, Government statistics show that Americans are saving far less than they were in 1992, when Mr. Clinton was running for President and complaining about poor economic performance, but are much richer as household net worth has risen about 50 percent. That has stimulated consumption, which remained strong even when economists were most alarmed about the threats from Asia's recession.
Mr. Greenspan insisted that, when the Fed cut interest rates last fall, "we were not attempting to prop up equity prices," but he knows that was one result, and he appears to be bothered by it. He warned that prices had risen further than profit growth would seem to justify. He voiced concern about the impact a falling stock market could have on consumer behavior and on the economy, and warned that protectionist trade measures could severely damage investor confidence.
Mr. Greenspan, along with most economists, expects the American economy to slow this year, but he conceded that there is as yet little evidence that is happening. Indeed, most sectors are booming. The country's huge trade deficit has so far had little impact because foreigners have been willing to finance it. In a time of international financial turmoil, American investments have seemed attractive to many, even with interest rates low.
There are sectors of the economy that are suffering -- largely the parts most sensitive to international weakness. Food prices are down substantially, hurting farmers. Producers of industrial materials such as steel are suffering from the reduced demand abroad, and many other manufacturers have seen orders and profits decline. But together, notes Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, those sectors employ about 20 percent of the work force. The rest are doing well.
This economic recovery began slowly in 1991, and now is going very strongly. That is the reverse of the normal process, and has surprised economists. But that very lack of predictability should make politicians hesitate as they decide what to do with the budget surpluses that have resulted. Assuming that the good times will continue indefinitely may be tempting, but it would also be foolish. 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 297 words

HEADLINE: Reducing Russian Dangers

 BODY:
No investment in American national security has paid higher dividends than the $2 billion Washington has spent over the last eight years to help Russia and other former Soviet republics dismantle nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. President Clinton was right, in his State of the Union address Tuesday night, to call for significantly increased spending on such programs. Congress, including members who oppose other foreign aid to Russia, should approve this White House request in full.
There is no longer any threat of Russia's deliberately attacking the United States. But Moscow's still-formidable stocks of nuclear bombs, nuclear ingredients and biological and chemical warfare agents pose a different kind of danger. Much of this material is inadequately secured, and the workers guarding it are paid poorly or not at all. That creates an unacceptably high risk that some material could be sold to potential aggressors like Iraq, Libya, North Korea or Serbia. Many Russian weapons scientists are also unemployed or unpaid and vulnerable to foreign recruitment. 
 Some of the $4.5 billion the Administration is requesting for the next five years would be used to speed the safe disposal of bomb plutonium and chemical and biological weapons stocks, and further improve security at storage sites. Washington would add new defenses against smuggling by helping Russia to establish better border controls and export monitoring. There would also be an expansion of efforts to re-employ scientists in civilian work.
During the cold war, the United States spent trillions of dollars to deter Russia from using its nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. It would not take much more than $10 billion to eliminate most of the risks from those weapons today. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: U.N. Frees $81 Million for Iraq to Increase Its Electricity Supply

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The United Nations is releasing more than $81 million to Iraq to buy equipment to increase its supply of electricity, the director of the Iraqi relief program said today.
Iraq, which suffers frequent power shortages as power plants fail and electrical demand rises, applied to buy the necessary generating equipment last year, when the "oil for food" program was expanded to allow Iraq to begin rebuilding its crumbling public services. Sanctions and a more limited oil sales program had earlier prevented the Iraqis from replacing old equipment. 
 The bulk of the purchases, $74.9 million in gas turbines, will come from China, said Benon V. Sevan, director of all nonweapons projects for Iraq. Last year Iraq bought $70 million in power-generating equipment from a Russian company.
Under a separate program, the Security Council sanctions committee approved $6.5 million worth of contracts for oil industry spare parts to upgrade pumping equipment, officials said.
Washington opposes calls for a lifting of the embargo on Iraqi oil sales so that Baghdad can buy what it needs, although with international supervision.
Iraq has had difficulties in recent months raising enough money through permitted oil sales, since the international price of oil has plummeted. Money earned on oil sales goes into a United Nations-supervised escrow account.
Under the expanded oil sales program, even with prices low, Iraq has been able to buy equipment to repair its telephone system and place computers in schools.
But Iraq has not used $17 million set aside last year for fortified biscuits and milk for malnourished children and mothers, Mr. Sevan said today. And millions of dollars worth of medicine remains in warehouses.
In Washington today, the Clinton Administration took another step toward giving more support to Iraqi opposition groups. In a report to Congress, the White House designated seven organizations as permitted recipients of American financial support.
Among the groups is the Iranian-based Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution, led by Mohammed Bakr al-Hakim, a Shiite Muslim clergyman. The organization is considered most influential in the largely Shiite Iraqi south, where opposition to President Saddam Hussein is widespread.
In the past, United States administrations have been wary of backing Shiite groups because of their links to Iran. But relations with Iran are beginning to thaw slightly, making a gamble possible. Shiite Muslims account for about two-thirds of the Iraqi population, although Mr. Hussein's Government is dominated by Sunni Muslims.
Other groups eligible for American aid under a $97 million program created last year by Congress are the Iraqi National Congress, a coalition of opposition organizations; the Kurdistan Democratic Party and the Popular Union of Kurdistan, both based in the autonomous Kurdish north of Iraq; the Movement for Constitutional Monarchy, led by the pretender to the Iraqi throne; the Iraqi National Accord, and the Islamic Movement of Iraqi Kurdistan.
The Iraqi Communist Party, long a foe of Mr. Hussein, was not on the list.
Today 47 exiled Iraqi opposition leaders -- but not the major Kurdish parties in northern Iraq -- asked Arab foreign ministers who are planning to meet on Sunday in Cairo to lend their support to a campaign to overthrow the Hussein Government.

HEADLINE: Chancellor May Sell or Spin Off Some Units to Raise Share Value

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The Chancellor Media Corporation, soon to be the No. 1 owner of radio stations in the United States, said today that it might sell or spin off all or part of its businesses to raise its share value to that of its biggest rivals.
Company officials say they are frustrated by Chancellor's stock price, now about 16.7 times 1998 broadcast cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization and corporate overhead. That compares with 24.9 for the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation and 27.2 for Clear Channel Communications Inc. 
 Chancellor was formed by the Dallas buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., which will own a 25 percent stake after planned purchases are completed. Chancellor stock traded as high as $57.375 last July and as low as $18.625 in October as investors worried that a slowing economy might hurt revenue. The stock has rebounded recently, though it still does not carry the same valuation as its competitors. Shares of Chancellor soared $9.1875, to $54.75.
"We can't help but compare ourselves to Infinity and Clear Channel," said Jeffrey Marcus, the company's president and chief executive. "We sell at multiples consistently less than they do. These are great companies, but so is ours."
Mr. Marcus said Chancellor might "end up selling a division or merging the entire company or selling the entire company." The company intends to proceed with all pending acquisitions, including the Capstar Broadcasting Corporation and the LIN Television Corporation, he said.
Chancellor said that it had asked the investment bank BT Alex. Brown Inc. to help it consider strategic options, including a possible sale.
Potential buyers might include Clear Channel, the Walt Disney Company or the General Electric Company, analysts said. Chancellor also might spin off one or more of its media businesses, similar to the CBS Corporation's public stock sale of Infinity for $2.87 billion.
Hicks, Muse formed Chancellor last year by combining the Evergreen Media Company and the Chancellor Broadcasting Company, both owned by Hicks, Muse. Thomas Hicks, the chief executive of Hicks, Muse, is also the chairman of Chancellor.
A sale of all of Chancellor could bring $65 to $70 a share, or $23 billion, based on analyst estimates, said Frank Bodenchak, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company.

HEADLINE: E-Mail to U.S. Lands Chinese Internet Entrepreneur in Jail

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Jan. 20

 BODY:
A court here sentenced a computer engineer to two years in jail today in a case watched closely by people monitoring official efforts to control China's growing use of the Internet.
The Shanghai No. 1 Intermediate Court ruled that Lin Hai, 30, committed a subversive act last year when he sent 30,000 Chinese E-mail addresses to VIP Reference, an electronic publication based in the United States that the Chinese authorities consider hostile to Beijing. 
 Mr. Lin, who was arrested last March, ran a software company that set up Web sites and offered other Internet-related services. Mr. Lin's wife, Xu Hong, said her husband was not interested in politics and had simply been exchanging E-mail addresses to build a database for his on-line business.
But prosecutors argued that the names provided by Mr. Lin had been used to distribute "large numbers of articles aimed at inciting subversion of state power and the socialist system."
VIP Reference, one of many electronic publications that distribute news about China, is compiled by Chinese democracy advocates in Washington. Editors of the newsletter say they send information to 250,000 E-mail accounts in China.
Efforts to restrict the exchange of political information on the Internet, these editors contend, are fruitless because of the volume and variety of electronic commerce.
Chinese officials formally embrace use of the Internet as a necessary part of efforts to modernize their economy and society. At the same time, special task forces monitor political content on the Internet and block some Web sites carrying information that Beijing deems unfriendly.
Although no one knows the true size of Internet use in China because many users share accounts, one recent official estimate said 2.1 million people in China were on the Internet by the end of 1998, up from 670,000 a year earlier.
In such a fast-growing environment, the case against Mr. Lin looks like a throwback to an earlier era, when Beijing had tighter control of the spread of information. It may also reflect a decision by the authorities to make an example of someone seen to be helping a publication like VIP Reference, if only indirectly.
Mr. Lin's two-year sentence, harsh by any international standard, is relatively light for a charge of political subversion in China. In a recent crackdown on efforts to set up a democratic political party, three leading dissidents were given sentences ranging from 11 to 13 years in prison.
In a country where the official media offer dull versions of the news, some Chinese on-line services feel freer to provide flashy news accounts that do not go through the same official censors as newspapers, television and radio.
Although the Communist authorities would clearly like to maintain their once-firm control over access to information, they are steadily becoming overwhelmed by the growth in more open communication -- by telephone, fax and now by Internet -- that has come with efforts to modernize China's economy.
The official New China News Agency reported today that a recent survey of young people, ages 14 to 28, found an overwhelming hunger for access to the Intenet. But 69 percent of those surveyed said they had no way to get on line.
Only 3.4 percent of the young people said they surfed the Internet regularly. At the same time, only 7 percent said they had no interest in the Internet, and 6 percent said they had not heard of it.
"There is still a long way to go before the Internet becomes truly popular among Chinese youth," the news agency concluded.

HEADLINE: The Name Behind Those Ping-Pong Balls

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
FIRST, to answer the most obvious question: Yolanda Vega does always say her name that way. "Hi," she said yesterday, and then without a trace of show biz: "I'm Yo-LAHNNN-da Vega!"
The woman who has become the smiling personification of fate for any New Yorker with a lottery ticket shook a reporter's hand in both of hers at the lottery's offices on Beaver Street in lower Manhattan, in the small room where the big cardboard checks are handed out. 
 She beamed exactly the way she does on television when she reveals the numbers on the airblown Ping-Pong balls. Then she sat down to explain, as she has in countless interviews since she began announcing the lottery results nine years ago, that she has absolutely no idea why she has become famous for the way she says her name.
"Many women have told me that the first word their little girls say is "LAAAHNNDAVEGA," she said. "It's melodic, I guess. It's got a rhythm. And I guess grown people like it because, by the way I say my name, I show I'm proud of who I am and happy doing what I do. But who knows? It's a crazy thing."
She is only one of five regular lottery number announcers, sharing air time at the lottery's Schenectady studios most nights of the week with Annette Collins, Judith Ortiz, Stephanie Moore and Kimberly Chapman. In New York City, they are watched by millions of viewers around 7:40 P.M. and around 11 P.M. on WABC, Channel 7.
But it is Ms. Vega, 43, who has become the Vanna White of the lottery drawings, invited to more charity events and panel discussions and onto the Oprah Winfrey show for a makeover. To capitalize on her following, lottery officials have even begun a contest -- the "I Want to Be Yolanda Vega" Sweepstakes -- in which applicants are invited to send, before Feb. 4, a videotape of themselves announcing lottery numbers.
The winner will get to announce winning numbers alongside Ms. Vega later this year.
"In the beginning it was a little weird with the other girls," she said yesterday. "I felt like: 'Oh, they should be here getting interviewed with me. They should be here on Oprah with me.' But they weren't and I was. And if it had been them, I would have been happy for them."
Now, she says, she feels a little like "Diana Ross leading the Supremes," and she has decided to be comfortable with it.
"I've been told -- and this is just what I've been told -- that out of all the drawing assistants, when I get out there, my eyes really shine. And the other girls, 'We don't see that shine in their eyes.' "
Ms. Vega, who grew up very poor in Red Hook, Brooklyn, the third of six daughters of Cruz and Marta I. Antequera, said her success has been all the more bewildering because she never had any desire to be on television. When she auditioned in 1990, she trembled as she read the numbers. ("I didn't even know how to put on makeup nine years ago -- I think I had blue eyeliner on.")
In fact, her only preparation for the lottery was that she was always great with numbers. She excelled in math at John Jay High School in Park Slope and earned a bachelor's degree in economics at Hunter College in 1977, becoming the first member of her family to graduate from college.
AFTER school, she took a series of bookkeeping jobs, and then met Miguel A. Vega, a security guard in Albany, while she was on a trip upstate to see her best friend.
Four years later, Mr. Vega had become a state trooper and they were married. She was working full time doing accounting jobs for a bagel maker in Albany, and she auditioned to become a lottery announcer simply to make some extra money for herself at a night job.
But when she became pregnant with her first child -- she now has two daughters, Gabriella Frances, 7, and Rebecca Isabel, 6 -- she quit her day job and, basically, became a full-time television announcer so she could spend more time with her children.
She is quick to point out that she is not paid what most people think of as television wages. As a state employee, she started out making $15 an hour and working 20 hours a week. She added, smiling at a lottery spokesman who sat across from her, "I don't make a whole lot more now."
"Everybody tells me, 'Wow, I'd like your job: what do you work, maybe two, three minutes a day?' " she said, rolling her eyes. "Let me tell you: first we have to set up the equipment and test it. There are lots of procedures to make sure it's working right. There's an auditor there every night. We do test runs to make sure it works. Then we do the drawing. Then we break the whole set down, go put it all away in the safe, and get out the next game. It's more involved than people care to believe."
But the job has unexpected perks. Her father-in-law, who lives in southern Puerto Rico, gets to see her several nights a week when he tunes in. "He watched me carry both of his granddaughters almost to full term -- on television," she said.
Her husband is sometimes not crazy about all the attention. "At work, they say: 'Trooper Vega? No, it's Mr. Yo-LAHNNN-da Vega.' " But she admits she kind of likes it.
"We were coming up the steps just now at Penn Station," she said, beaming, "and this little old Italian man sees me and goes, 'Yo-LAHNNN-da Vega! You gonna make me rich?"

HEADLINE: THE TRIAL OF THE PRESIDENT: THE SURPLUS;
$4.4 Trillion Windfall And Parties Square Off

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
After a yearlong transition in which both parties struggled to shift from an era of crippling Federal budget deficits to an anticipated age of fiscal plenty, the battle has at last been joined over how the country should allocate the flood of excess money streaming into Washington.
In an immediate sense, the debate is whether nearly all the surplus will be needed for the twin pillars of the social welfare system, Social Security and Medicare, as Democrats assert, or whether there is enough to take care of those looming problems and still return much of the surplus to the people in the form of tax cuts, as Republicans say. 
 In a broader sense, though, it is about the size and role of the Federal Government, a familiar ideological issue but one that has been seen for most of the last two decades through the prism of deficit reduction.
President Clinton changed that on Tuesday night in his State of the Union address. The headlines were about his proposal for shoring up Social Security, but Mr. Clinton was setting out to do something more than deal with the retirement system's future.
Mr. Clinton said the Government was going to take in $4.4 trillion more than needed to pay for current programs over the next 15 years, a previously undisclosed and staggeringly big windfall that, if it materializes, would be unlike anything the country has ever experienced. Roughly 60 percent of the money would come from excess payroll tax revenues that are earmarked for Social Security. The rest would be a true surplus, the difference between general tax revenues and what the Government would spend to maintain current programs at their existing levels.
Rather than just repeating his demand from a year ago that the projected surpluses be left untouched until Social Security's future is assured, Mr. Clinton laid out exactly how he would spend the money. Social Security was at the top of the list. But he also proposed using hundreds of billions of dollars for Medicare, unveiled a plan under which the Government would subsidize retirement savings accounts for low- and middle-income workers, and said he would set aside big sums for the Pentagon, education and other domestic programs.
In setting out his priorities, Mr. Clinton was moving into a policy vacuum that he had created last year with his "save Social Security first" strategy. But Republicans, who last year had been shy about advancing any big ideas because of their well-founded fears that they would be accused by Democrats of endangering Social Security, immediately made clear that they would be far less inhibited this year.
Seeking an issue as potent as Social Security to claim as their own, Republicans turned to the one idea that unites their fractious party, tax cuts, and proposed a plan that they say combines good economic policy with strong political appeal: reducing income tax rates by 10 percent across the board.
The result is that -- to the degree it is not consumed with Mr. Clinton's impeachment trial -- Washington will see a wide-ranging ideological debate this year over fundamentally different views of how the country should capitalize on its good fortune.
"The President essentially made the case that we should use this period of extra resources and prosperity to invest in the future and save to solve future retirement challenges," said Gene Sperling, the White House economic policy director. "The Republicans seemed to respond by suggesting we should go to across-the-board consumption. That's a good solid policy debate for the nation to have."
Mr. Clinton's view of an activist Government shoring up the social safety net programs played to the liberal wing of his party, but with a twist: He portrayed himself as the champion of austerity, dedicated to paying down the national debt to levels not seen since World War I.
Republicans said they were energized to make the case for a smaller Federal Government once again, a task that they admitted would be more difficult now that the discipline of reducing the deficit can no longer be the backbone of their argument. They said tax cuts would not only put more money back in the hands of the people out of whose paychecks it is coming but would help strangle the Federal bureaucracy and push power back closer to the people.
"After Ronald Reagan extended spending and borrowing a great deal in the 1980's, the deficit was a forced limit on the growth of Government," said Representative Nick Smith, Republican of Michigan. "Now that damper is sort of off, and we're going to have to make an upfront philosophical decision whether we want to reduce taxes and slow the growth of the Federal Government."
"We're faced with a situation where there's still a political advantage to coming up with programs that do new things for more people and spend more money," Mr. Smith said. "It's going to be a huge challenge even in the Republican ranks not to take advantage of spending some of that money on programs they think are important."
What remains unclear is whether the debate will lead to bipartisan deals on issues like Social Security, or simply allow the two parties to define what they stand for heading into the 2000 elections.
Having the debate serve as an electoral platform "is the more probable outcome, but that's not inconsequential by itself," said Representative Lloyd Doggett, Democrat of Texas, adding, "To frame the issue for debate and consideration in the election is worthwhile, and maybe some progress can be made toward resolving the issue in some way this year."
The optimistic scenario is that the surplus is so big, and the options for dealing with issues like Social Security so fluid, that there is plenty of room for a legacy-minded President and a Republican leadership eager to prove it can pass legislation to come to some accommodation this year.
The pessimistic scenario is that the battle over Mr. Clinton's removal from office has so poisoned the atmosphere in Washington that the two parties will never trust each other enough to join together in addressing politically sensitive issues. And without any consensus on how to use the surplus, it could gradually be eaten away by politically popular tax-and-spending programs from both sides.
"We have paid the price for running up huge deficits, and we have finally, with the help of good economic times as well as hard work by politicians, gotten past that," said Martha Phillips, the executive director of the Concord Coalition, a fiscal watchdog group. "Now we have to find a way for politicians to do their thing without going too far."
