HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Falls 19.31 as Earnings News Prompts Profit Taking

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Shrugging off the latest caution by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, stock prices marched higher during the morning yesterday but then faded in the final hour or so and ended mixed.
Once again, technology stocks supplied much of the lift, spurred by the surprisingly strong profits reported by Microsoft after the markets closed on Tuesday. 
 But with the quarterly earnings season in full stride, investors seemed inclined to take profits on upbeat reports, with General Motors a prominent example. The auto giant's shares jumped as much as 4 points, to 92 -- practically double their low on Oct. 8 -- after announcing a big jump in earnings, only to slip back to 88 15/16.
And several Internet stocks, which have dazzled for so long, fell sharply.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.31 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 9,335.91, after rising nearly 125 points during the day. Nineteen of its 30 blue-chip components posted losses. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index followed a similar pattern but hung on to small gains. Nasdaq edged up 7.32 points, to 2,415.49, its second straight record, and the S.& P. 500 rose 4.62 points, to 1,256.62.
"The market valuation level scares a lot of people," said James W. Paulsen, chief strategist at Norwest Investment Management in Minneapolis. Nonetheless, he added, the economy is strong and stock prices relative to bond prices are still lower than they were last summer.
Mr. Greenspan was less blunt in his appraisal of the stock market, the subject of close scrutiny by policy makers these days. He told the House Ways and Means Committee yesterday that current valuation levels "would appear to envision substantially greater growth of profits than has been experienced of late."
But Mr. Greenspan, confirming widespread belief, also seemed to rule out raising interest rates despite an economy still growing rapidly.
"If you didn't have a global crisis, you'd be worried that the guy is setting himself for a tightening stance," said Mark C. Lapman, executive vice president of Independence Investment Associates in Boston. "But he can't do that at this point."
Analysts said that President Clinton's State of the Union Message, which included a proposal to invest Social Security money in stocks, was a modest plus yesterday. Tobacco stocks, however, tumbled because of the President's surprise announcement of a Federal lawsuit. Philip Morris fell 2 3/8, to 48 7/16.
Microsoft surged 7, to 162 5/8, while Dell Computer rose 3 3/16, to 85 5/16. Texas Instruments rose 6 5/8, to 99 5/8, after reporting improved profits.
"Strong earnings seem to be carrying the market," Michael Pendergast, managing director of HGK Asset Management in Jersey City, said before the late swoon.
But Internet stocks were weak throughout. Amazon.com skidded 26 13/16, to 113, its biggest decline since Aug. 31. Ebay fell 16 1/8, to 213 3/4; Yahoo was down 35 13/16, to 287 3/16; Broadcast.com dropped 17 3/8, to 120, and Excite slid 13 3/8, to 96 5/8.
Airline stocks were also pounded, with U S Airways falling 6 5/16, to 51 1/8, and AMR, the parent of American Airlines, down 4 7/16, to 59 13/16, after both companies reported disappointing profits.
"You've got a bit of profit taking coming in here," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief strategist at Gruntal.
As these groups faltered, some stocks that had been under pressure of late rebounded. Among them were shares of drug companies, with Pfizer up 31 3/16, to 119 11/16, Lilly and Schering-Plough up more than 2 each and Bristol-Myers Squibb and Merck each up more than a point.
New York Stock Exchange volume picked up to 906 million from 787 million Tuesday.
Stocks ending lower yesterday held a slim margin over those advancing, 1,587 to 1,478.
Overseas, stocks gained in nearly every major foreign market. Brazil's Bovespa surged 3.98 percent; Mexico's Bolsa was up 4.77 percent, and Germany's DAX index rose 3.15 percent. Lesser gains were 1.87 percent in Japan, 1.8 percent in France, 1.29 percent in Britain and two-tenths of a percent in Hong Kong.

Treasury Prices Fall
 By Bloomberg News
 Bond prices fell for a third session as Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said there was little evidence the economy was losing steam, snuffing expectations for another interest rate reduction.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 12/32, to 101 7/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.17 percent, from 5.14 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Finance Commissioner to Head Grand Central Business Group

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
The Grand Central Partnership is expected to name Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, the city's Finance Commissioner, as its president today, further consolidating Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's influence over the business group, which oversees sanitation, security and other services in the area around Grand Central Terminal.
Mr. Cerullo, 37, will replace Daniel A. Biederman, who resigned in September as president of the group, under pressure from the Mayor. Mr. Giuliani had complained that Mr. Biederman amassed an unhealthy degree of power by managing two of the city's other private-public partnerships, which are known as business improvement districts or BID's, while heading the Grand Central group. 
 Last July, the city refused to renew its contract with the Grand Central Partnership, blocking the group's access to about $6 million collected from businesses within its boundaries. One month ago, Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington said that the city was within days of signing a new contract with the business group, but the organization continues to operate without one.
Last month, Bernard H. Mendik, who had been chosen by the Mayor as the interim chairman of the group, announced plans to reorganize it under a new name in order to purge it of board members loyal to Mr. Biederman. But those plans were rescinded after three board members resigned.
Mr. Cerullo, a former Republican leader of the City Council and a close ally of Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President, was appointed Finance Commissioner in 1995 after serving as Commissioner of Consumer Affairs from 1994 to 1995.
Last year, the Mayor tried to put Mr. Cerullo in charge of the Times Square Business Improvement District, but ran into opposition. Brendan J. Sexton, the group's new president, praises his former rival as highly qualified. "He's friendly, funny and easy to deal with," Mr. Sexton said. "He's a BID type of guy, by virtue of his personality."
Mr. Cerullo, one of several candidates interviewed for the Grand Central job, was selected by the group's seven-member executive committee, which includes Mr. Mendik. Mr. Cerullo did not respond yesterday to a request for an interview. He is expected to assume his new post next month.
Victor A. Kovner, a former counsel to the Grand Central Partnership who subsequently represented several of the Biederman loyalists, said the appointment of Mr. Cerullo had ominous implications.
"I have nothing negative to say about Mr. Cerullo," Mr. Kovner said. "I gather that he's done a credible job. But for a BID to turn over to the Mayor's office in effect the picking of the president, the picking of the interim chair and the cleansing of certain disfavored directors, threatens BID's everywhere."
William G. Cohen, the executive vice president of Newmark & Company Real Estate, and a board member, said he was glad that the partnership was no longer a "headless horseman." But he said he hoped that Mr. Cerullo's government background would not make him ill-suited for a group that prides itself on efficiency.
"One of the reasons we've been able to make a difference," Mr. Cohen said, "is that we've operated from the mentality and mind-set of a private company. It's important to maintain that mind-set."

HEADLINE: U.S. Presents Documents in Case Against Microsoft

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The Government presented documents and E-mail in the Microsoft trial today as evidence for its allegation that the big software maker had imposed contract restrictions on personal computer makers to thwart competition.
The contracts imposed strict limits on Windows' opening "desktop," the screen that computer users see when they turn on their computers. These limits clearly upset some manufacturers who wanted to use the desktop to display their own brands or to feature factory-installed software -- often made by Microsoft's competitors. 
 In a memo to the Microsoft Corporation, an executive at the Hewlett-Packard Company complained about the restraints and concluded that if his company had any alternative to loading Microsoft's Windows operating system, "you would not be our supplier of choice."
Microsoft began imposing the restrictions in 1996, saying it had the legal right to do so and adding that the curbs helped consumers by insuring a "uniform Windows experience." But 1996 was also when Microsoft was struggling to catch up to the early leader in the Internet software market, the Netscape Communications Corporation, which pioneered the browser software used to navigate the World Wide Web.
At one point in court today, the Government also addressed the fact that on Tuesday, Microsoft reported a 75 percent jump in quarterly earnings, well ahead of expectations on Wall Street. David Boies, the lead trial lawyer for the Justice Department, mentioned the earnings report in his cross-examination of the company's leadoff witness and asked if consistently high profits were an indicator of monopoly power.
The witness, Richard L. Schmalensee, an economist and dean of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management, conceded that persistently high profits suggest "some impediment to competitive alternatives." But such a barrier, he added quickly, could well be a very valuable asset, protected by intellectual property rights, like Microsoft's industry-standard Windows operating system.
"You simply cannot infer monopoly power from profits," Mr. Schmalensee said.
The Government contends that Microsoft's contracts were mainly intended to unfairly damage Netscape, not to benefit consumers. Microsoft used its monopoly power in the operating system market, the Government charges, to force computer makers to restrict how they could promote Netscape's browser.
To make that point, the Government cited a number of documents, including a Jan. 5, 1996, E-mail memo in which William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman, stressed that increasing the company's browser share was a "very, very important goal." He also complained that some PC makers were displaying competing browsers on their machines "in a FAR more prominent way" than Microsoft's Internet Explorer.
Later that month, an executive review of Microsoft's sales to PC makers during the previous six months noted that one of its missed opportunities was failing to impose "control over start-up screens."
Yet by May 1998, Microsoft was weighing dropping the contract curbs on some major PC makers in response to their complaints, and it later did. An internal E-mail written by Brad Chase, a Microsoft executive, however, noted that the reaction from the company's "antitrust team was negative." He continued, "Changes like this undermine our whole defense of Windows Experience."
Microsoft says that the Justice Department is selectively plucking comments from the more than three million pages of E-mail and documents the company has produced during the Government's investigation. The documents, taken out of context, may seem damaging but are not, according to Microsoft.
Throughout his cross-examination, which began last week, Mr. Schmalensee has held to his main themes -- that Microsoft's contracts are mostly garden-variety business deals, that friction and fights among business partners are to be expected, that Netscape has been able to distribute many millions of copies of its browser, and that consumers have benefited from Microsoft's practices.
Late this afternoon, Mr. Boies concluded his cross-examination with the kind of diverting exchange that occasionally brings some levity to the trial. Asked about Microsoft's profit margins on its operating system sales, Mr. Schmalensee replied that was difficult to determine precisely and that the company's internal accounting systems were not all that sophisticated.
Microsoft, he said, records "operating system sales by hand on sheets of paper." Since that struck many in the courtroom as odd for a leading producer of data-base and financial-spreadsheet software, people laughed aloud in the courtroom. Later, Microsoft executives said Mr. Schmalensee probably misspoke.
"What you saw in there," said William Neukom, Microsoft's senior vice president for law and corporate affairs, "was a trial lawyer looking for an exit line."

HEADLINE: THE TRIAL OF THE PRESIDENT;
The Rule of Law Protects the President, Too, a Counsel Tells the Senate

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Cheryl D. Mills, White House deputy counsel, on accusations of obstruction of justice in Article II in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton:
 Over the course of the House managers' presentation last week, I confess I was struck by how often they referred the significance of the "rule of law." House Manager Sensenbrenner, for example, quoted President Theodore Roosevelt stating, "No man is above the law, and no man is below it." 
 As a lawyer, as an American and as an African-American, it is a principle in which I believe to the very core of my being. It is what many have struggled and died for, the right to be equal before the law, without regard to race or gender or ethnicity, disability, privilege or station in life. The rule of law applies to the weak and the strong, the rich and the poor, the powerful and the powerless.
If you love the rule of law, you must love it in all of its applications. You cannot only love it when it provides the verdict you seek; you must love it when the verdict goes against you, as well. We cannot uphold the rule of law only when it is consistent with our beliefs; we must uphold it even when it protects behavior that we don't like or is unattractive, or is not admirable, or that might even be hurtful. And we cannot say we love the rule of law but dismiss arguments that appeal to the rule of law, as "legalisms" or "legal hair-splitting."
I say all this because, not only the facts, but the law of obstruction of justice protects the President. It does not condemn him. And the managers cannot deny the President the protection that is provided by the law, and still insist they are acting to uphold the law.
His conduct, while clearly not attractive or admirable, is not criminal.
That is the rule of law in this case. . . .
So let's talk about the allegation of obstruction of justice, about the box of gifts that Ms. Currie received from Ms. Lewinsky. I want to begin by telling you another true story, the real story of the now-famous gifts.
It takes place on Dec. 28, 1997. On that day the President gave Ms. Lewinsky holiday gifts. During her visit with the President, Ms. Lewinsky has said that she raised the subpoena that she had received from the Jones lawyers on the 19th and asked him what should she do about the gifts.
The President has said he told her, whenever it was that they discussed it, that she would have to give over whatever she had. He was not concerned about the gifts, because he gives so many gifts to so many people. Unbeknownst to the President, however, Ms. Lewinsky had been worrying about what to do with the gifts ever since she got the subpoena. She was concerned that the Jones lawyers might even search her apartment, so she wanted to get the gifts out of her home.
After Ms. Lewinsky's visit with the President, Ms. Currie walked her from the building. Then or later, either in person or on the phone, Ms. Lewinsky told Ms. Currie that she had a box of gifts that the President had given her that she wanted Ms. Currie to hold because people were asking questions. In the course of that conversation, they discussed other things as well, and Ms. Currie agreed to hold the box of gifts. After their discussion, Ms. Lewinsky packed up some, but not all, of the gifts that the President had given her over time. She kept out presents of particular sentimental value, as well as virtually all of the gifts he had given her that very day, on the 28th.
Ms. Currie went by Ms. Lewinsky's home after leaving work, picked up the box, which had a note on it that said, "Do not throw away," and she took it home. Ms. Currie did not raise Ms. Lewinsky's request with the President because she saw herself as doing a favor for her friend. Ms. Currie had no idea the gifts were under subpoena. And so Mrs. Lewinsky's request hardly struck her as criminal.
 
'A Selective Reading'
This story that I just told you is obviously very different from the story presented by the House managers. How can I tell such a story that is so at odds with that which has been presented by the House managers? The answer lies in a selective reading of the record by the House managers. But theirs is not the only version of the facts that can be told. . . .
Now, let's go through their story piece by piece. On Dec. 19, Monica Lewinsky was served with a subpoena in the Jones case. The subpoena required her to testify at a deposition in January 1998, and also to produce each and every gift given to her by the President. This statement is factually accurate. It does not, however, convey the entire state of affairs.
Ms. Lewinsky told the F.B.I. that when she got the subpoena, she wanted the gifts out of her apartment. Why? Because she suspected that lawyers for Jones would break into her apartment looking for gifts. She was also concerned that the Jones people might tap her phone. Therefore, she wanted to put the gifts out of reach of the Jones lawyers, out of harm's way.
The managers entirely disregarded Ms. Lewinsky's own independent motivations for wanting to move the gifts.
Let's continue. On Dec. 28, 1997, Ms. Lewinsky and the President met in the Oval Office to exchange Christmas gifts, at which time they discussed the fact that the lawyers in the Jones case had subpoenaed all the gifts from the President to Ms. Lewinsky. During the conversation on Dec. 28, Ms. Lewinsky asked the President whether she should "put away the gifts outside her house some place or give them to someone, maybe Betty." At that time, according to Ms. Lewinsky, the President said, "Let me think about it."
The House managers have consistently described the Dec. 28 meeting exactly this way, as did the majority counsel for the House Judiciary, as did the Office of Independent Counsel.
It's been said so often that it's become conventional wisdom, but it is not -- it is not the whole truth. It is not the full record. Ms. Lewinsky actually gave 10 renditions of her conversation with the President. All of them have been outlined in our trial brief. Invariably, the one most cited is the one least favorable to the President. But even in that version, the one that is least favorable to the President, no one claims he ordered, suggested, or even hinted that anyone obstruct justice. At most, the President says, "Let me think about it." That is not obstruction of justice. . . .
You also may not have heard this version, and this is a juror speaking -- a grand juror speaking to Ms. Lewinsky:
The juror: "Now did you bring up Betty's name, or did the President bring up Betty's name?" And this is at their meeting on the 28th.
Ms. Lewinsky: "I think I brought it up. The President wouldn't have brought up Betty's name, because he didn't -- he really didn't discuss it." . . .
Why haven't we heard these versions? Because they weaken an already fragile circumstantial case. If Ms. Lewinsky says that the President didn't respond at all, then there's absolutely no evidence for the House managers' obstruction of justice theory, even under their version of events.
So these versions get discarded to insure that the House managers' big picture doesn't get cluttered by all those details. It's those facts, those stubborn facts that just don't fit.
But the most significant detail the managers discard because it doesn't fit is the President's testimony. The President testified that he told Ms. Lewinsky that she had to give the Jones lawyers whatever gifts she had. Why -- as the House managers predicted we would ask, because it is a question that begs to be asked -- why would the President give Ms. Lewinsky gifts if he wanted her to give them right back? The only real explanation is he truly was, as he testified, unconcerned about the gifts.
The House managers want you to believe that this gift-giving was a show of confidence, that he knew Ms. Lewinsky would conceal them. But then why, under their theory, ask Ms. Currie to go pick them up? Why not know that Ms. Lewinsky is just going to conceal them? Better still, why not just show her the gifts and tell her to come by after the subpoena date has passed? It simply doesn't make sense. The President's actions entirely undermine the House managers' theory of obstruction of justice.
But let's continue with their version of events: "That answer, the let-me-think-about-it answer, that answer led to action. Later that day, Ms. Lewinsky got a call at 3:32 P.M. from Ms. Currie who said, 'I understand you have something to give me' or 'The President said you have something to give me.' It was the President who initiated the retrieval of the gifts and the concealment of the evidence."
Here is where the House managers have dramatically shortchanged the truth, because the whole truth demands that Ms. Currie's testimony be presented fairly. In telling their story, the House managers do concede that there is a conflict in the testimony between Ms. Lewinsky and Ms. Currie.
But they strive mightily -- they strive mightily -- to get you to disregard Ms. Currie's testimony by telling you that her memory on the issue of how she came to pick up the gifts was fuzzy. Fuzzy. In particular, Manager Hutchinson told you:
"I will concede there is a conflict in the testimony on this point with Ms. Currie. Ms. Currie in her grand jury testimony had a fuzzy memory, a little different recollection. She testified that the best she could remember, Ms. Lewinsky called her, but when she was asked further, she said that maybe Ms. Lewinsky's memory is better than hers on that issue." That's what the House managers want you to believe about Ms. Currie.
That's not playing fair by Ms. Currie. It's not playing fair by the facts. Why? Because Ms. Currie was asked about who initiated the gift pick-up five times. Her answer each time was unequivocal -- five times. From the first F.B.I. interview just days after the story broke in the media to her last grand jury appearance, Ms. Currie repeatedly and unwaveringly testified that it was Ms. Lewinsky who contacted her about the gifts. Her memory on this issue is clear. . . .
But what about that supposedly corroborating cell-phone call from Betty Currie to Monica Lewinsky on Dec. 28? The managers highlighted this call, which they claim is the call in which Ms. Currie told Ms. Lewinsky that she understood she had something for her, the gifts.
This, they say, is the linchpin that closes the deal on their version of the facts.
What the managers downplay, as Mr. Ruff discussed yesterday, is the fact that this call to arrange the pickup of the gifts, comes after the time Ms. Lewinsky repeatedly testified that the gifts were picked up by Ms. Currie.
In citing the cell-phone record as corroboration, they also disregard Ms. Currie's testimony that she picked up the gifts, leaving from work, on her way home. That would have been from Washington to Arlington. That is inconsistent with a call from Arlington.
Most significantly, the managers purposely avoided telling you about the length of the call. As Mr. Ruff pointed out yesterday, the call is for one minute or less.
According to Ms. Lewinsky's own testimony, when she spoke to Ms. Currie to arrange the gift pickup, they talked about other matters, as well as the box. They had a conversation. That's a lot of talk: "I have a box. When can you come pick it up? Where do you want me to meet you?" -- other chitchat. That's a lot of talk for a call that lasts one minute or less. . . .
 
No Evidence of a Threat
On Jan. 17, 1998, the President called Ms. Currie after his deposition and asked her to meet with him the following day. On Jan. 18, the President and Ms. Currie met, and the President told her about some of those surprising questions he had been asked in his deposition about Ms. Lewinsky. In the course of their conversation, according to Ms. Currie, the President posed a series of questions and made statements, including, "You were always there when she was there, right?""We were never really alone." "You could see and hear everything." "Monica came on to me, and I never touched her -- right?" And "She wanted to have sex with me, and I can't do that."
Our analysis of this issue could stop here. There is no case for obstruction of justice. Why? There is no evidence whatsoever of any kind of threat or intimidation. And, as we discussed, the U.S. Attorney's manual indicates that without a threat or intimidation there is no corrupt influence. Without corrupt influence there is no obstruction of justice.
But the evidence reveals much more. Not only does the record lack any evidence of threat or intimidation, the record specifically contains Ms. Currie's undisputed testimony, which exonerates the President of this charge. This is Ms. Currie's testimony, and is the fourth exhibit in your materials:
Q. Now, back again to the four statements that you testified the President made to you that were presented as statements, did you feel you were pressured when he told you those statements?
A. None whatsoever.
Q. Well, what did you think, or what was going through your mind about what he was doing?
A. At the time, I felt he was -- I want to use the word 'shocked' or surprised that this was an issue and he was just talking.
Q. That was your impression, that he wanted you to say, because he would end each of the statements with 'right,' with a question?
A. I do not remember that he wanted me to say, 'right.' He would say 'right?' and I would have said 'wrong.'
Q. But he would put each of these questions to you with a 'right,' and you could either say it was true or not true?
A. Correct.
Q. Did you feel any pressure to agree with your boss?
A. None.
The evidence on this issue is clear. There was no effort to intimidate or pressure Ms. Currie, and she testified that she did not feel pressured. Betty Currie's testimony unequivocally establishes that the managers' case lacks any element of threat or intimidation. There is no evidence, direct or circumstantial, that refutes this testimony. This is not obstruction of justice.
But let's not stop there. Let's look at the intent element of the obstruction of justice laws; in other words, whether the President had the intent to influence Ms. Currie's supposed testimony or potential testimony. In an attempt to satisfy this element of the law the managers overreached in their presentation to create the appearance that the President has the necessary specific intent. They argue that based upon the way he answered the questions in the Jones deposition he purposely referred to Ms. Currie in the hopes that the Jones lawyers would call her as a corroborating witness. Therefore, according to their theory he had the specific intent. The facts belie they are overreaching.
The House managers suggested to you that the President increased the likelihood that Ms. Currie would be called as a witness by challenging the plaintiff's attorney to question Ms. Currie. Her review of the transcript, however, shows that the President's few references to Ms. Currie were neither forced nor needlessly interposed. They were natural, appropriate. They were responsive.
Indeed the only occasion where he suggested that the Jones lawyers speak to Ms. Currie is when they asked him if it was typical for Ms. Currie to be in the White House after midnight. He understandably said, "You have to ask her" -- hardly a challenge. It's a reasonable response to an inquiry about someone else's activities.
The managers' conjecture about the President's state of mind, however, fails on an even more basic level. If you believe the managers' theory, if you believe that the President went to great lengths to hide his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, then why on earth would he want Ms. Currie to be a witness in the Jones case? If there was one person who knew the extent of his contacts with Ms. Lewinsky it was Ms. Currie. . . .
And even if the Jones lawyers had wanted to question Ms. Currie, it's highly unlikely they would have been allowed to do so given the posture of the case at that time.
Judge Wright ordered the parties in August of 1997 to exchange names and addresses of all witnesses no later than Dec. 5, 1997. Ms. Currie was not on their final witness list. Moreover, the cut-off date for all discovery was Jan. 30. By the time the President's deposition was over it was really too late to call Ms. Currie as a witness. . . .
The President was understandably concerned about media inquiries, a concern everyone who lives and serves in public eye likely can understand. In trying to prepare for what he saw as the inevitable media attention, he talked to Ms. Currie to see what her perceptions were and what she recalled. He talked to her to see what she knew.
Remember some of the questions that the Jones lawyers asked the President were so off-base -- for example, they asked him about visits from Ms. Lewinsky between midnight and 6 A.M., when Ms. Currie supposedly cleared her in. The President wanted to know whether or not Ms. Currie agreed with this perception or whether she had a different one; whether she agreed that Ms. Lewinsky was cleared in when he was present, or whether there may have been other occasions that he didn't know about.
He also wanted to assess Ms. Currie's perception of the relationship. She knew the first person who would be questioned about media accounts, particularly given that she was in the Internet report, was going to be Ms. Currie.
The House managers did the President a disservice in suggesting in the end that his five pages of testimony about why he spoke to Ms. Currie ultimately amounts to a forward sound bite of "to refresh his recollection." He obviously said a lot more. Why did they say that? Because they needed to establish intent. And the testimony and the facts do not show intent. That is the truth. That is all of the facts.
The President's intent was never to obstruct justice in the Jones case. It was to manage a looming media firestorm, which he correctly foresaw. As the President told the grand jury, "I was trying to get the facts and trying to think of the best defense we could construct in the face of what I thought was going to be a media onslaught." He was thinking about the media. That is the big picture. That is not obstruction of justice. . . .
Before I close, I do want to take a moment to address a theme that the House managers sounded throughout their presentation last week: civil rights. They suggested that by not removing the President from office, the entire house of civil rights might well fall. While acknowledging that the President is a good advocate for civil rights, they suggested that they had grave concerns because of the President's conduct in the Paula Jones case. And some managers suggested that we all should be concerned should the Senate fail to convict the President, because it will send a message that our civil rights laws and our sexual harassment laws are unimportant.
 
A Record of Civil Rights
I can't let their comments go unchallenged. I speak as but one woman, but I know I speak for others as well. I know I speak for the President. Bill Clinton's grandfather owned a store. His store catered primarily to African-Americans. Apparently his grandfather was one of only four white people in town who would do business with African-Americans, and he taught his grandson that the African Americans who came into his store were good people, and they worked hard, and they deserved a better deal in life.
The President has taken his grandfather's teachings to heart and he has worked every day to give all of us a better deal, an equal deal.
I'm not worried about the future of civil rights. I'm not worried because Ms. Jones had her day in court, and Judge Wright determined that all of the matters we are discussing here today were not material to her case and ultimately decided that Ms. Jones, based on the facts and the law in that case, did not have a case against the President.
I'm not worried because we've had imperfect leaders in the past and we'll have imperfect leaders in the future. But their imperfections did not roll back nor did they stop the march for civil rights and equal opportunity for all of our citizens. Thomas Jefferson, Frederick Douglass, Abraham Lincoln, John F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King Jr. -- we revere these men. We should. But they were not perfect men; they made human errors. But they struggled to do humanity good.
I'm not worried about civil rights, because this President's record on civil rights, on women's rights, on all of our rights is unimpeachable.
Ladies and gentleman of the Senate, you have an enormous decision to make, and in truth, there is little more I can do to lighten that burden. But I can do this, I can assure you that your decision to follow the facts and the law and the Constitution, and acquit this President will not shake the foundation of the house of civil rights. The house of civil rights is strong because its foundation is strong. And with all due respect, the foundation of the house of civil rights was never at the core of the Jones case, it was never at the heart of the Jones case.
The foundation of the house of civil rights is in the voices of all the great civil rights leaders and the soul of every person who heard them. It's in the hands of every person who folded a leaflet for change, and it's in the courage of every person who changed. It's here in the Senate, where men and women of courage and conviction stood for progress; where senators, some of them still in this chamber, some of them who lost their careers, looked to the Constitution, listened to their conscience, and then did the right thing. The foundation of the house of civil rights is in all of us who gathered up our will to raise it up and keep on building.
I stand here before you today because others before me decided to take a stand or, as one of my law professors so eloquently says, "because someone claimed my opportunities for me" by fighting for my right to have the education I have, by fighting for my right to seek the employment I choose, by fighting for my right to be a lawyer, by sitting-in and carrying signs, and walking long marches, riding freedom rides and putting their bodies on the line for civil rights. I stand here before you today because America decided that the way things were was not how they were going to be. We the people decided that we all deserved a better deal.
I stand here before you today because President Bill Clinton believed I could stand here for him.
Your decision whether to remove President Clinton from office, based on the Articles of Impeachment, I know will be based on the law and the facts and the Constitution. It would be wrong to convict him on this record. You should acquit him on this record. And you must not let imagined harms to the house of civil rights persuade you otherwise.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A Japanese Giant's Not-So-Subtle Courtship

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
FOR SALE: A piece of the world's sixth-largest car company. Excellent engineering and technical capabilities. Some $20 billion in debt, but a fixer-upper with promise. Interested parties may apply to Yoshikazu Hanawa, president of the Nissan Motor Company.
Mr. Hanawa has embarked on a sales campaign never before seen in Japan and perhaps in the world. Nearly every day for more than a week, Nissan's leonine president has been hawking his company, welcoming one and all to make a bid. 
 It's not exactly the subtle tap on the shoulder one would expect from a Japanese executive, but then, these are not subtle times for Nissan. The company's predicament -- carrying a staggering amount of debt at a time when it has lost ground in its two major markets, Japan and the United States -- is glaringly obvious, and the stronger yen and rising Japanese interest rates have only increased pressure on the company to act.
So far, Renault S.A., the rejuvenated French car company that is reaping the fruits of a corporate overhaul, is the only potential partner that has publicly acknowledged an interest in the company. After Nissan's operation in Britain leaked news of the overtures, Renault confirmed that it was indeed talking to Nissan -- and other car makers.
Last year, Renault embarked on an extended fact-finding mission on several Japanese vehicle manufacturers, according to bankers, including the Suzuki Motor Corporation and Fuji Heavy Industries, a Nissan affiliate. "Clearly, they're interested in Japan, but what in Japan, no one knows for sure," one banker said.
After subtracting debt, Renault has cash of about $1 billion, according to analysts, which would buy it a little more than 10 percent of Nissan at current market prices.
Shares of Nissan here have edged up 3.5 percent this week. In New York, its American depository receipts -- each representing two shares of the company -- closed today at $7.25, down 25 cents.
Under Japanese law, a shareholder must own at least 33.4 percent of a company to win board representation and veto power, and given Nissan's well-documented history of foot-dragging, a potential buyer would presumably want that kind of control at the minimum.
That does not mean a purchase is out of the question. Renault could, of course, use new shares as currency, but that would not help Nissan pay down debt and would dilute the holdings of Renault's shareholders.
DaimlerChrysler A.G. and the Ford Motor Company have also been rumored to have an interest in Nissan. Speculation that Jurgen E. Schrempp, a chairman of DaimlerChrysler, is taking an offer with him to Tokyo, where he is attending an exhibition of Daimler technology at the end of this week, is rampant.
Neither DaimlerChrysler nor Ford has sought to dispel such speculation, but Nissan has said it has yet to receive any offer. Indeed, the company has quite directly said it has as yet had no concrete discussions about any kind of equity purchase with anyone.
DaimlerChrysler clearly has designs on the global market, and Asia remains a huge gap in its plans. Mercedes-Benz cars continue to sell well in Japan despite the recession, and Chrysler has built test models of slimmed-down minivans that would be perfect for the Japanese market. Conceivably, some of Nissan's excess capacity, currently at about 35 percent, could be switched to production of Mercedes and Chrysler vehicles.
DaimlerChrysler has been negotiating with Nissan since May over the disposition of the Nissan Diesel Motor Company, a troubled truck maker in which Nissan owns a 39.8 percent stake. The negotiations have dragged on and on -- first, because DaimlerChrysler wanted more detailed financial information and, second, because the information it obtained made it wary.
DaimlerChrysler is now more comfortable with the numbers, but it has asked Nissan Diesel's bankers, led by the Industrial Bank of Japan and Fuji Bank, to forgive some of the truck maker's debt. Debt forgiveness is not unheard of in Japan, but it is unusual.
Nissan is expected to hold a news conference on Friday, but it has no plans at this point to announce a sale of Nissan Diesel to DaimlerChrysler.
Ford already has a relationship with Nissan. It produces some Nissan vehicles in the United States in an alliance that has been so-so for both partners, and it rents Nissan's shuttered Zama production plant southwest of here and uses it as an inspection site for its cars.
But it also owns 33.4 percent of the Mazda Motor Corporation, a company once caught in the same bind that now grips Nissan, but on a much smaller scale. Ford won the right to install its own executives and has managed to cut costs without layoffs, which are anathema in Japan. Mazda has cut procurement costs, frozen wages and paid down debt, making more gross profits a car now than it did a few years ago.
Having gone through such an exercise, does Ford now want to do it again on a much grander scale? Does it need to?
Mr. Hanawa has some goodies to sell that would be attractive to any buyer. For starters, Nissan presents a golden opportunity to establish a rather large beachhead in Asia.
And despite its problems, Nissan is still respected for its engineering prowess and technological skills. Nissan boasts some 150 alliances with car makers around the world that have sought its engineering expertise. Its strained budget has been most apparent in the design of its cars, which has been, in a word, boring, but their quality and performance is still among the best in the world.
What is more, the company owns big chunks of real estate that were acquired decades ago and are still carried on the books at more or less their original prices. It also has a hefty stock portfolio.
Jay N. Woodworth, an independent auto analyst, has scoured the company's Japanese financial statements. He believes the company values its total fixed assets and real estate at about $7.5 billion, which he regards as being well under their present value.
But it will take a lot of sales to put a dent in Nissan's debt, which ranges between $24 billion -- excluding potential leasing liabilities -- and $39 billion if those liabilities are included.
Christopher Redl, an analyst who follows auto parts makers at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo, has a novel suggestion for potential buyers. "If people are interested in Nissan's technology, they should consider buying one of its parts makers," he said. "That's where the technology resides anyway."

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: EDUCATION PROGRAMS;
In Chicago, the Story Behind the Rising Test Scores

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Not so long ago, Chicago's public schools were considered the worst in the nation. But in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, President Clinton held them up as a model.
Specifically, Mr. Clinton singled out the Chicago system's eliminating the practice of promoting students even if they did not meet their grade's academic standards, just so they could stay with their age, or social, group. He praised Chicago's decision three years ago to force students who do not have basic math and English skills to attend summer school, and to make them repeat a grade if they do no better by the end of the summer. 
 Mr. Clinton seemed to suggest that these policies accounted for the fact that student test scores in the Chicago school system have been rising for the last three years. But, as with most issues in education, the reality is more complex.
Chicago's ending of the schools' so-called social promotion is only one part of a major overhaul of the country's third-largest school system, something the city has been able to accomplish largely because the Illinois Legislature in 1995 gave Mayor Richard M. Daley extensive control over the schools. He appointed his budget director, Paul Vallas, as the school system's new chief executive officer, and Mr. Vallas has set about trying to make the public schools work with the efficacy of a business.
Among other things, Mr. Vallas and a school board, also appointed by the Mayor, have revamped the school system's budget, removed principals from some failing schools and put more resources into programs like early childhood education. More than 100 schools were put on academic probation and told to improve; now only 58 remain on the list.
Mr. Vallas, a former teacher, believes that the elimination of social promotion is another important part of the package.
"Social promotion kills an educational system," he said. "When we came in, 9,700 of the previous year's 27,000 graduates were reading at sixth-grade level or below. If you're a teacher, what are you to do? You have to lower your standards. You have to dummy down the curriculum. The children who are behind never get caught up. The children at grade level get taught to inferior standards."
Yet, as other cities follow Chicago's example, experts say it is still too early to rate the effectiveness of the policy against social promotion.
Begun with just eighth graders in 1996, it now applies to third, sixth and ninth graders as well. If students do not score above a cutoff on the Iowa Test of Basic Skills or, in ninth grade, if they fail subjects like math and reading, they are required to go to summer school. If they still do not pass, they must repeat the grade and receive at least an hour of extra instruction each day.
About a quarter of the students in these grades were required to attend summer school last year -- about the same percentage as in previous years. The results were not universally encouraging.
Of the 10,000 third graders who attended mandatory summer school, 5,500 are now repeating third grade, said Blondean Davis, the school system's Chief of Operations. Of those, 964 are repeating third grade for a second time.
In the sixth and eighth grades, the results were a little better, with just under 40 percent of the mandatory summer-school students held back a grade. Dr. Davis said the eighth-grade results were not quite as disappointing, however, because eighth-graders had a higher minimum test score this year.
Still, "the hopes have been that far larger numbers of kids going through the summer school would move from scores that weren't adequate up to the promotion level," said G. Alfred Hess, the director of Center for Urban School Policy at Northwestern University.
Professor Hess said that while the program seemed to have helped many students, "larger proportions than any of us had hoped have not made it to that level."
He said it was not yet clear whether the policy had yielded another hoped-for benefit: that the threat of going to summer classes and being held back would force students to take school more seriously.
The Chicago policy has its critics.
"It's a grossly unsuccessful policy," said Suzanne Davenport, the acting executive director of Designs for Change, a school reform, research and advocacy organization in Chicago. "Of all the things to quote about improvements in the Chicago school system, this is not what we would pick out."
Ms. Davenport said her organization did not advocate social promotion. But she said some studies showed that holding students back a grade did not help.
"Even if kids show any short-term gains, they don't last very long," she said. "And secondly, students are much more likely to drop out if they are held back."
The solution, she said, was significantly improving other aspects of the schools, like curriculum, teaching, class size. Struggling students should be promoted, she said, but given extra help in their new grade.
At one Chicago school today, teachers said they supported mandatory summer school and the end of social promotion.
"A lot of older kids see retention as a reality, all of a sudden, and it has lit a fire under a lot of them," said Julie Hines, a computer teacher at Louis J. Agassiz Elementary School on the North Side.
James Starzynski, a reading specialist and curriculum coordinator at the school, said: "I think it took a lot of courage to do such a thing, but the alternative is awful. You can't have 16-, 17-, 18-year-old social and economic liabilities walking around the streets of Chicago."

HEADLINE: Envoys Flock to Milosevic To Tackle Crisis He Created

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jan. 20

 BODY:
While NATO tried to convince the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, that the alliance is serious about using force against him, Western diplomats continued to flock here today to urge him to defuse a crisis he himself created.
Mr. Milosevic is back in the headlines after what the Clinton Administration is calling a mass killing of ethnic Albanian civilians on Friday in the Serbian province of Kosovo. 
 In some ways, it is a delicious moment for the Yugoslav leader, some senior Western diplomats here concede. He has thrown down the gauntlet to the West and is orchestrating anti-Western diatribes in the Serbian press, accusing Western officials of being unfair and too quick to believe propaganda from Kosovo's ethnic Albanians.
At the same time, the United States and its allies are sending him envoys, pressing him to make relatively easy concessions that will allow them to avoid using force, which Mr. Milosevic doubts they are willing to do in any event. Even American officials say they have real doubts, as was the case with Iraq, of what policy would follow any air strikes.
Mr. Milosevic sent away NATO's top military commanders with very little after a seven-hour meeting on Tuesday. After the generals, Wesley K. Clark, the NATO commander, and Klaus Naumann of Germany, left on Tuesday, more envoys followed.
Aleksandr Avdeyev, Russia's First Deputy Foreign Minister, has been here, as has a senior State Department official, James Pardew. The American negotiator, Christopher Hill, who is also the Ambassador to Macedonia, is about to arrive, and he will be followed by Knut Vollebaek, the Norwegian Foreign Minister who is the current chairman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, known as the O.S.C.E.
Mr. Milosevic is also leaving himself room to maneuver and back down, the diplomats noted. The case of William Walker, the American head of the O.S.C.E. monitoring mission in Kosovo, is one example.
He accused Serbian forces of the killing of at least 45 ethnic Albanians in the village of Racak, and in turn was accused by the Serbian propaganda machine of partiality. On Tuesday he was ordered to leave within 48 hours. That order was extended by another 24 hours after the organization, whose members include Russia, demanded that Mr. Milosevic allow Mr. Walker to remain.
It appeared tonight that Mr. Milosevic would let Mr. Walker stay, a senior Western diplomat said, at least as long as negotiations with the West continued. "As usual, if Milosevic concedes, it will be on an issue that he created," the diplomat said.
Mr. Vollebaek today ordered Mr. Walker, to keep working despite the deportation order, and Mr. Walker returned to Kosovo.
But Serbian officials here echoed accusations made in the Government-controlled press that the West had rushed to judgment on the killings in Racak, arguing that the 45 victims had been killed in fighting, not in cold blood, and that ethnic Albanians of the Kosovo Liberation Army later mutilated the bodies, changed their clothing and dumped them in one spot to be discovered.
While such charges have been dismissed out of hand by American officials, French officials say they are taking them more seriously, while urging the kind of international forensic investigation Washington also wants. The Serbs have agreed to allow some Finnish forensic scientists to see at least some of the bodies found in the village last week.
Washington and the West are also insisting that Mr. Milosevic resume full cooperation with international agencies in Kosovo, by living up to the cease-fire agreement he signed with the American envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, last October and by allowing the tribunal investigating war crimes in the former Yugoslavia access to Kosovo.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
G.M.'s Profit Rose 7.7% in Fourth Quarter

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation today announced an unexpectedly large increase in profits during the fourth quarter of last year, as the very strong American auto market and the company's continued recovery from last summer's strike more than offset losses in Latin America and East Asia.
G.M.'s profits rose 7.7 percent, to $1.77 billion, during the fourth quarter, but fell 53.2 percent, to $2.96 billion, for all of last year because of a 54-day strike in June and July at two auto parts factories in Flint, Mich. The strike forced the auto maker to close almost all of its assembly plants in North America. 
 The company's fully diluted earnings per share reached $2.61 in the fourth quarter, up 12 percent. Excluding a long list of one-time losses, G.M.'s earnings were $3.25 a share, easily beating the Wall Street analysts' average estimate of $2.65 a share, according to First Call.
Shares of G.M. rose to an all-time high after the earnings were announced. They closed at $88.9375, up 93.75 cents.
G.M.'s robust fourth-quarter results reflected exuberant sales of high-profit sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in the United States and continued profits in Europe. Because the Ford Motor Company also depends heavily on the American and European markets, G.M.'s results make it likely that Ford will also report healthy profits when it releases its earnings on Thursday.
"The regions of the world that are strongest happen to be where we are strongest," J. Michael Losh, G.M.'s chief financial officer, said in an interview today.
The North American auto market produced $1.58 billion in profits for G.M. in the fourth quarter, while European car operations generated another $146 million in profit, allowing the company to prosper despite economic troubles in emerging markets. By contrast, G.M.'s East Asian automotive division lost $213 million in the fourth quarter while operations in Latin America, Africa and the Middle East, previously very profitable, lost another $212 million.
Last summer's strike reduced G.M.'s full-year, after-tax profits by "at least $2 billion," Mr. Losh said. While G.M. had declared strike-related losses totaling $2.5 billion during the second and third quarters of last year, John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, had predicted in August that the company would be able to reduce that to $2 billion by the end of the year by building extra cars and trucks in the fourth quarter.
But Mr. Losh said that G.M. had not been able to catch up as much as expected during the fourth quarter because Americans bought cars and light trucks at a torrid pace. Indeed, last month had the highest seasonally adjusted annual rate of new auto sales in the United States since December 1986.
As a result, G.M. factories in North America will continue to produce cars and trucks at a brisk tempo in the first quarter, usually a slow season, Mr. Losh said. Whether the strike cost G.M. $2 billion or even more, it still remains easily the most expensive strike in American history, before adjusting for inflation.
Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst at ING Baring in the New York, said that G.M.'s strong fourth-quarter profits were likely to spill over into the first quarter because G.M. will be catching up on full-size pickup truck production, which is very profitable. Unlike past periods of prosperity, G.M. is also continuing to cut costs aggressively, Ms. Keller said, adding that she had raised her estimate of G.M.'s 1999 profits to $8.75 a share from $8.25 a share.
G.M. earned $4.18 a share in 1998 and $8.62 a share in 1997. G.M.'s sales also fell last year, to $161.32 billion from $171.18 billion.
G.M., which had cash reserves of $14.1 billion on Dec. 31, announced today that it would resume a $4 billion share buyback program soon and finish it this year. G.M. had suspended the program last summer because of the strike, after spending only a third of the $4 billion.
G.M.'s fourth-quarter earnings included $420 million in one-time, after-tax charges. These mostly reflected early retirement programs, but included a $97 million charge in G.M.'s East Asian automotive division that was caused partly by the need to replace equipment at a factory in Thailand.
Delphi Automotive Systems, G.M.'s wholly owned auto parts subsidiary, earned $88 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a $508 million loss in the period a year earlier, as smaller one-time charges more than offset a deterioration in operating results. Delphi plans an initial public offering of a 17.7 percent stake in itself this spring, and to become completely separate from G.M. by the end of this year through a distribution or exchange of shares.

HEADLINE: Limousine Company Signs Union Contract

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
In a breakthrough in one of New York City's largest unionization drives in decades, the machinists' union has signed a contract on behalf of nearly 700 drivers at one of the city's largest black-car companies, Elite Limousine Plus.
With the union seeking to organize the city's more than 12,000 black-car drivers, labor experts said the agreement with Elite could pave the way for most of the city's 41 other black-car companies to sign union contracts. 
 Elite had long led the battle against unionization attempts, taking the fight to the courts and the National Labor Relations Board, but now it has become the first large limousine company to sign a labor contract.
The International Association of Machinists reached the contract with Elite last weekend after a two-year battle in which most drivers voted to unionize. The company had refused to accept the union, asserting that the drivers were not employees, but independent contractors.
"It's a very important agreement in this industry, and it will get this whole industry off on the right track and help get other companies organized," said James Conigliaro, assistant director of the machinists' union for metropolitan New York.
Under the contract, the drivers will gain two coveted benefits: health insurance and free legal services, providing legal consultation and representation in their many disputes with the Taxi and Limousine Commission. In addition, Elite agreed to set up a grievance and arbitration system and to stop imposing fines on drivers -- they sometimes faced $100 fines for failing to wear a tie or a white shirt.
The contract covers a group of drivers, most of them immigrants, who say that they, notwithstanding their shiny limousines and suits, barely make enough to support their families. Even though many drivers work 70-hour weeks, they often net just $20,000 a year, after subtracting the cost of the car, insurance, gasoline, repairs and parking tickets. The drivers own their cars and set their own hours, while the companies provide a dispatching service and issue many rules on how they are to do business.
Shafquat Chaudhary, Elite's president, said in an interview that one of the main factors pressuring him to sign the contract was his desire to reduce turnover among the drivers working for him.
"We have been looking at ways to create some kind of benefits for the drivers," Mr. Chaudhary said. "It's a tough job, long hours. We would like to create an atmosphere where the drivers would like to stay."
Kevin Lynch, the machinists' organizing director in New York, said, "In the industry today, the most difficult thing is holding onto drivers. Doing a contract with the union will make it easier for Elite to hold onto its drivers."
Mr. Chaudhary acknowledged that he hoped the contract would help Elite grow faster by persuading drivers at other companies to move to Elite because they want health-care coverage.
Union officials predicted that other limousine companies would seek to avoid such an exodus of drivers to Elite by agreeing to sign similar labor contracts.
The contract also provides the drivers with $5,000 in life insurance and places a cap on the fees Elite receives from drivers. Elite now takes slightly more than one-fifth of each driver's daily gross.
Shaikh Nadeem, a Pakistani immigrant who drives for Elite, said: "I think it's a very good contract. It's very good benefits on some of the things drivers have been looking for for so long."
In 1997, Elite's drivers voted 218 to 117 to join the machinists, but the company refused to negotiate, asserting that the drivers were contractors, not employees. In November 1997, the National Labor Relations Board ruled against the company, saying that the drivers were employees.
But until recently, the company continued to refuse to bargain.
The new agreement skirts the issue of whether the drivers are employees or contractors, enabling the company to continue to insist they are independent contractors. If the workers are contractors, the company does not have to pay taxes for Social Security, unemployment insurance or workers' compensation.
A. Michael Weber, Elite's lawyer, said: "They're not employees. That's always been Elite's position. We believe then and now they're independent contractors."
Drivers at two other large limousine companies -- Prime Time and Telecar -- have voted on whether to unionize, but the votes have been impounded pending a labor board determination on whether the drivers are employees or contractors.
At another black-car company, Last Radio Group, the drivers voted decisively in favor of unionizing, but the company has resisted the effort, insisting that the workers are contractors.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Clinton's plan for Social Security has its backers. But does America want the Government to be a big shareholder?

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
President Clinton's proposal to shore up the financially shaky Social Security system leans heavily on a leading Republican plan. He would grab trillions of dollars of general tax revenue and invest some of it in the stock market. The plan is attractive, since neither Mr. Clinton nor the Republicans would need to propose higher payroll taxes or reductions in retirement benefits. On this feature, Democrats and Republicans easily agree.
But under Mr. Clinton's plan, the Government would own stocks. The leading Republican plan, proposed by Prof. Martin Feldstein of Harvard and backed by Senator Phil Gramm and others on Capitol Hill, would turn the general revenue over to individuals for deposit into their own investment accounts. Therein lie profound political and financial differences. 
 The retirement of the baby boomers early next century combined with their increased longevity will throw Social Security into deficit. The Administration proposes to balance the books by tapping Federal surpluses that it expects will total about $4.4 trillion over the next 15 years. Mr. Clinton aims to pump about $2.7 trillion of that amount into the trust fund. About $700 billion of the $2.7 trillion would be invested in stocks. Under current law, the entire trust fund is invested in low-yielding Government bonds.
The combination of new revenue and return on stock investments would be expected to generate enough money to eliminate deficits in the program for the next 50 years or so.
The proposal has the political virtue of closing the deficit in Social Security without cutting retirement benefits. And by preserving the central feature of the current system -- paying benefits entirely out of public funds -- it avoids certain pitfalls of private accounts. The plan would pay retirees a benefit based on their lifelong earnings, not on the vagaries of stock and bond market returns. It would preserve the ability to transfer money from high- to low-paid workers. And the costs of administering a single public fund are very low compared with those of setting up 150 million individual accounts.
But the plan solves those financial problems by creating a severe political problem. The Administration estimates that the Government would come to own 4 to 5 percent of the value of shares on Wall Street. The danger is that Congress will meddle, for example steering Federal dollars into environmentally friendly companies rather than, say, tobacco companies, which were a target of Mr. Clinton's speech on Tuesday night.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, added his weight to the critics yesterday.
"I do not believe that it is politically feasible to insulate such huge funds from Government direction," Mr. Greenspan said in Congressional testimony. "I am fearful that we would use those assets in a way that would create a lower rate of return for Social Security recipients."
Michael J. Boskin, chief economist to President George Bush, rejects the Clinton plan as "politically naive."
"Congress," Mr. Boskin said, "will simply not stand by and let huge surpluses accumulate without spending them. Congress is much less likely to tamper with private accounts."
Economists point out that investing Social Security revenue in stocks would not in and of itself affect the nation's savings rate or raise future living standards. It would merely shuffle stock out of accounts of private investors and into a public account. But, as a recent report from a panel of the National Academy of Social Insurance pointed out, the shuffle would have an important impact nonetheless.
Wealthy families, the report observes, need not care if the public trust fund invests their payroll contributions in stocks, because they can invest their private savings in stocks, reaping the high rate of return that stocks have historically provided. But most families save and invest very little. The only way their retirement income can reflect the value of investing in stocks is if the Government does the investing for them. Mr. Clinton's proposal to invest some of the trust fund in stocks brings the benefit of stock investing to a larger swath of American families.
Whatever the financial merits, though, the Administration is left with Chairman Greenspan's political demerit. Here the Administration has a plausible response provided by two economists at the Brookings Institution. Those economists, Henry Aaron and Robert Reischauer, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, outline safeguards that they say would insulate stock purchases from political interference.
The basic idea is to create a board that would turn the Social Security money over to private managers of widely diversified mutual funds. No Government official would have any say over actual purchase decisions. Mr. Boskin remains unconvinced. Congress can build whatever fire walls Mr. Aaron and Mr. Reischauer want, he says, "but in the end Congress can tear them down."
Mr. Clinton's Social Security plan was proposed in the context of a larger budget plan that places other claims on future surpluses. About $500 billion of the $4.4 trillion would be used to help create individual retirement accounts that would be separate from Social Security. The White House envisions contributing, say, $100 into accounts for low- and middle-income families. Families that add more would have their contributions partly matched by the Government.
The obvious purpose behind the idea is to encourage families to save more for retirement, the best way to raise future living standards. But the Administration also wants to use these individual accounts to blunt the Republicans' fervor for setting up private accounts as part of Social Security. The virtue of keeping the accounts separate from Social Security, the Administration hopes, is that they will not provide a ready excuse for cutting benefits under the Social Security program, or lead to a cascading momentum that drives Social Security increasingly away from a public plan to a private plan.

HEADLINE: Study Urged On Cancer And Races

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The National Institutes of Health needs to develop a broader strategy for finding out why poor people and some ethnic minorities are more prone to certain cancers and less likely to survive them than is the rest of the population, an expert panel said today.
The institutes, the Federal agency that sponsors most of the nation's medical research, needs to expand the study of why ethnic and racial groups are disproportionately affected by cancer and make certain that minority groups are adequately represented in research trials, the panel said in a report. 
 The 15-member committee of medical, health and research experts, convened by the Institute of Medicine, said the effort to understand the impact of cancer on subgroups in the population would be helped by discarding traditional racial categories and studying people on the basis of their ethnic and economic backgrounds.
Use of the term "race" is scientifically inaccurate because it implies fundamental biological differences among groups that do not exist and masks the influence of ethnic background and life style differences that could be big factors in cancer, panel members said at a news briefing.
Dr. M. Alfred Haynes, former president of the Drew Postgraduate Medical School in Los Angeles and chairman of the committee, said studies within and between ethnic groups could not only help in determining what affected their cancer risks, but also provide insights for the general population. Finding out why some ethnic minorities are less affected by certain cancers could lead to ways to reduce risks for the majority, Dr. Haynes said.
"This information will benefit all Americans and help the medical community craft prevention strategies that work," he said.
The panel said African-American men, for example, had unusually high rates of prostate cancer, while people of Asian descent were more likely to develop stomach and liver cancer than whites. Cervical cancer is higher among Hispanic and Vietnamese-American women, while African-American women are less likely than others to develop breast cancer but also less likely to survive it. And while Alaska natives have high rates of colon and rectal cancer, low-income whites in rural areas like Appalachia have some of the highest rates of lung and other cancers in the nation.
Having people in cancer studies in traditional racial categories -- white, black, Asian or Pacific Islander, or Native American -- makes it hard to pinpoint factors affecting incidence of the disease and its treatment within subgroups, the panel said. Asians, the report noted, include Vietnamese and other Southeast Asians, Koreans, Japanese, Chinese, Indians and others who are ethnically and culturally very different.
Congress asked the independent Institute of Medicine, part of the National Academy of Sciences, to examine the Government's efforts to understand and deal with cancer as it affects poor Americans, with little insurance and limited access to care, and ethnic minorities. The committee said the health institutes, and its National Cancer Institute, were trying to address these issues, but needed to devote more money and develop a Government-wide plan to deal with them.
The panel said the cancer institute spent about $24 million a year, or about 1 percent of its budget, on programs specifically addressing cancer among ethnic minorities and the poor. These groups also are included in more general research studies, it said, but more resources need to be devoted to programs targeted to minorities and the medically underserved.

HEADLINE: Fed Report and Housing Data Are Strong

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's latest reading on the nation's economy suggests the current expansion, already at a peacetime record, will persevere in 1999 while inflation remains at bay.
"Most regions are showing solid economic growth over all," the Fed said. "Most districts report generally stable or declining prices." 
 The Fed's regional outlook, known as the beige book, is based on reports from the Fed's 12 district banks. It is published eight times each year. The latest edition was compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. Information for the report was collected before Jan. 11.
The report will help form the basis for discussion on interest rate targets at the Feb. 2-3 meeting of the Fed's policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee.
In today's report, the Fed also said many retailers resorted to more drastic discounting than usual during the holidays and that labor shortages persisted in most parts of the country, with some regions reporting heightened wage pressures.
"Looking forward, business contacts in most districts remain optimistic about 1999, especially the first half," the Fed said. "However, respondents in most districts expect somewhat slower growth in 1999 than in 1998."
The job of collating and writing the Fed's report is randomly rotated among the 12 regional banks. The identity of that bank is kept confidential until the report's release. The research director of the district bank in charge of compiling the latest edition writes a summary based on the other banks' data.
In another report today, the Commerce Department said housing starts rose in December as builders enjoyed the busiest year for new- home construction in more than a decade.
Starts rose 3.5 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.720 million houses, led by a rebound in multifamily construction. For all of 1998, 1.616 million homes were started, the most since 1.121 million in 1987.
By region in December, housing starts rose 24.7 percent in the Midwest, to an annual rate of 414,000 units in December; rose 3.9 percent in the Northeast, to 158,000 units; increased 3.1 percent in the West, to 428,000, and fell 5.6 percent in the South, to 720,000.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: THE PUBLIC;
Plan for Social Security Wins Support in Buffalo

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
When President Clinton gave his folksy version of his State of the Union Message today to the blue-collar and middle-class residents of Buffalo and its environs, he got an ardent response from people like Beverly Brigantia, for whom Social Security, the centerpiece of the President's message, is no academic matter.
"I'm going to be one of those women on Social Security that he's talking about," Ms. Brigantia said, listening to Mr. Clinton's speech on a small television propped up on a satellite truck outside the Marine Midland Arena here. "I'm single and currently unemployed and, there's $6,000 in my pension in the teachers retirement system. I'm probably going to have to work until I drop." 
 Ms. Brigantia, a 55-year-old former community college writing instructor, said Mr. Clinton's plan to reserve 62 percent of the budget surpluses over the next 15 years -- an estimated $2.7 trillion -- for Social Security "sounded reasonable to me," and at least put the issue squarely on the national agenda.
Of course, to generate excitement after his State of the Union address, the President could scarcely have picked a more receptive audience than the one in this heavily Democratic city of about 300,000 people. Buffalo's mood today was as bright as the sunshine that ended a week and a half of snow, with a total accumulation of about 60 inches.
This Lake Erie city, where Grover Cleveland was Mayor in 1881 and President William McKinley was assassinated in 1901, has made a slow and somewhat mixed economic recovery since the 1970's, when Bethlehem Steel closed its plant in neighboring Lackawanna and chemical and automobile companies downsized. Unemployment is at 7 percent or 8 percent, said Vincent J. Lovallo, chief of staff to Mayor Anthony M. Masiello. That is almost twice the national average, but far less than the double-digit rates that Mr. Lovallo said prevailed before Mr. Clinton's election in 1992.
The President was delighted with the long ovation he received after a fiery introduction by Vice President Al Gore. "You got so excited you melted the snow for miles outside the arena," Mr. Clinton told the crowd of about 15,000 people.
The warmth was by no means unanimous. Fifty demonstrators stood across from the domed arena, the home of the Buffalo Sabres hockey team, with signs saying "Jail to the Chief!" and "Can You Trust a Liar?"
One protester, Andrea Tice, a 30-year-old mother of two from the suburb of Marilla, said she had not watched Mr. Clinton's speech on Tuesday night -- "I prefer to go to sleep at night without rage in my heart," she said -- but she disliked his Social Security plan anyway.
"Social Security is fine, but he should give the hard-working people a tax cut," Ms. Tice said, echoing a proposal made by Republicans in Congress on Tuesday that called for a 10 percent across-the-board cut in income tax rates.
But mostly the crowds outside and inside the arena seemed impressed with a President spunkily going on with his job despite a Senate impeachment trial that could remove him from office. Even the baby boomers who doubt that the Government will have surpluses for the next 15 years were glad Mr. Clinton enunciated something to shoot for that may protect them when they retire. And many were simply tickled at glimpsing the President and his wife, Hillary, and by his colloquial delivery today, with lines about Social Security like this one: "Seniors today have no sweat unless they live to be 120 years old."
Nellie B. King, who had trouble getting into the arena even though she is superintendent of the Lackawanna City School District, described the Social Security plan as "excellent." Ms. King said she did not want to end up in the kind of poverty she was born into as a sharecropper's daughter in Mississippi.
"I am 56 and I hope to retire in the 21st century, and I hope the Social Security system will be there for me," she said. "It was through education that I was able to rise above the poverty level, and when I retire I don't want to go back into poverty."
