HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fed Chief Supports Aid for Social Security
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the House Ways and Means Committee he supports the President's notion of putting almost two-thirds of the Federal budget surpluses over the next 15 years into Social Security reserves.
But Mr. Greenspan and some Republicans in Congress disagreed with the President's idea of having the Government invest part of the money in the stock market. Political pressures, Mr. Greenspan said, could lead to inefficient investments that would result in a lower rate of return for retirees and a lower standard of living for Americans. Page A1. 

President Clinton's proposal to shore up the Social Security system by investing some money in the stock market disagrees with a Republican plan to turn revenue over to individuals for their own investment accounts. Michael Weinstein: Economic Scene. A21.
 
United Interested in America West
United Airlines, the nation's largest airline, said that it was interested in buying America West Airlines, a move that would escalate its battle with American Airlines on the West Coast. America West said several airlines had approached it about a range of deals. C8.
 
Profit Up at Texas Instruments
A slimmed-down Texas Instruments reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings. Analysts said the company's moves out of memory chips, computers and defense combined with its concentration on more specialized products like digital signal processors and analog chips had begun to pay off with higher profit margins and more consistent earnings growth. Shares of Texas Instruments rose $6.625, to $99.625. C2.
 
American Airlines and U S Airways posted disappointing quarterly earnings on weaker-than-expected revenues, while America West Airlines exceeded Wall Street estimates. C8.
 
General Electric said its fourth-quarter profit rose 14 percent as the company sold more industrial service contracts. C16.
 
Bristol-Myers Squibb said its fourth-quarter profit rose 13 percent. C4.
 
G.M.'s Profits Increase 7.7%
General Motors announced an unexpectedly large increase in profits during the fourth quarter as the very strong American auto market and the company's continued recovery from a strike last summer more than offset losses in Latin America and East Asia. G.M.'s profits rose 7.7 percent, to $1.77 billion, but fell 53.2 percent, to $2.96 billion, for the year. C2.
 
Stocks Start Out Strong but Fade
Stock prices marched higher during the morning but then faded in the final hour or so and ended mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.31 points, to 9,335.91. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.62 points, to 1,256.62. The Nasdaq composite index edged up 7.32 points, to 2,415.49, its second consecutive record. In the bond market, Treasury prices fell as the yield of the 30-year issue rose to 5.17 percent from 5.14 percent. C14.
 
E-Mail Presented at Microsoft Trial
The Government presented documents and E-mail in Microsoft's antitrust trial as evidence for its contention that the software giant had imposed contract restrictions on computer makers to thwart competition. C16.
 
A Record Sum for Super Bowl Ads
Anheuser-Busch is spending a record sum for 9 spots during 5 minutes and 15 seconds of commercial time during the Super Bowl on Jan. 31, the most by far for any advertiser. The spots will probably mark the beginning of the end for the popular Budweiser beer campaign about talking frogs and lizards, executives said. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C10.

HEADLINE: New York Moves on Plan To Ship Trash Out of City

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
New York City took the first steps yesterday toward its goal of shipping up to 2,000 tons of garbage a day from Manhattan and Queens to transfer stations, landfills and incinerators outside the city, with industry officials saying sites in New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester County were all likely candidates.
"This is the first time we're asking transfer stations outside the city to take our waste," said Peter Montalbano, director of the Sanitation Department's Bureau of Waste Disposal. 
 Officials began taking bids yesterday from private companies to transport and dispose of the two boroughs' trash as part of an interim solution to the long and increasingly complicated process of closing the giant Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island by the end of 2001.
Ultimately, the city plans to build a new infrastructure to ship its garbage beyond its borders at an estimated cost of $6 billion over 30 years. Last month, as part of that effort, the city announced that it was asking private companies to build huge transfer stations in New Jersey and Brooklyn to export waste by rail and barge to other states. A barrage of protest followed, with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman lambasting the plan for its potential impact on New Jersey's environment.
More recently, the possibility that New York might ship more of its garbage to landfills in Virginia started a protracted war of words between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. James S. Gilmore 3d of Virginia.
The interim effort, intended to provide new places for the garbage while the long-term plan is being created and put into place, has been criticized by environmentalists.
Both the permanent and short-term initiatives depend on transfer stations, where garbage is relayed from one mode of transport -- usually trucks or barges -- to another before being shipped to incinerators or landfills. The stations are also typically where the trash is compressed and sealed in larger containers. Environmental concerns are often raised about these transfer points because of the increased truck traffic they generate and the possibility that mishandling or a barge accident could pollute the water.
In the short term, a likely destination for the garbage from Queens and Manhattan is a large transfer station run by the Bergen County Municipal Utilities Authority. The station has the capacity to handle 5,000 tons of garbage a day, but currently processes only 1,400 to 1,500 tons a day, said Jerome Sheehan, acting executive director of the authority.
Mr. Sheehan explained that waste companies that use the county's transfer station would be responsible for entering into contracts with New York. "No one's approached us," he said.
Other possibilities mentioned by industry executives, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, include incinerators in Essex and Union Counties, N.J., and another in Hempstead, N.Y. An incinerator in Peekskill, N.Y., was also mentioned.
Wendy Patella, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Whitman, said New Jersey counties were responsible for making decisions about their own transfer stations and incinerators. "That's the first line of defense, so to speak," she said.
Susan Tolchin, communications director for the Westchester County Executive, Andrew J. Spano, said that Waste Management Inc., a large waste company, operates an incinerator in Peekskill. She said that its capacity is 657,000 tons a year, and that it processes about 550,000 tons annually. She noted that that did not leave much room for the city's garbage.
"The reality is very, very negligible," she said. "You're talking about a couple of trucks."
Marlene Kastleman, a spokeswoman for the Town of Hempstead, said a company there called American Ref Fuel was running its incinerator at capacity. "Were a deal to be struck, it would replace existing waste," she said. "We would not agree to expand the capacity."
Each site must be able to accept a minimum of 10 garbage trucks an hour and at least 150 tons of waste a day, about the amount generated by each of the city's 59 community board districts. The companies winning contracts are responsible for securing all local permits and approvals.
The companies must also submit to regular city inspections of the stations. The city contracts will run for three years with the possibility of two one-year renewals. Bids will be opened in March, and environmental reviews may take as long as six months.
Since 1997, all Bronx garbage has been exported as part of this interim effort. Late last year, the city began shipping 2,400 tons a day of Brooklyn's garbage to out-of-state landfills from transfer stations in the borough. But the Brooklyn plan is being challenged in court on environmental grounds.
According to city policy, garbage from one borough cannot be processed in another borough. There are no transfer stations in Manhattan and very few in Queens.
James Tripp, general counsel of the Environmental Defense Fund, who also served as a member of the task force that planned the closing of Fresh Kills, said that an original draft of the planning document specified that each borough would handle only its own garbage. The policy was not included in the final document because of fears it would act as a straitjacket on policy makers, but it has nonetheless been repeatedly stated as city policy by Mr. Giuliani and other city officials.
"The policy made no sense from any point of view," Mr. Tripp said. "I mean, after all, we live in one city."
In particular, Mr. Tripp said he was concerned that the policy would cause a great increase in truck traffic through the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels as garbage from Manhattan and Queens headed to transfer stations or incinerators in New Jersey.
"In order for the city and state to prove their commitment to closing Fresh Kills by 2001, do we have to do something that makes little environmental and economic sense?" he asked.
Thomas Outerbridge, an environmental consultant who serves as co-chairman of the Citywide Recycling Advisory Group, an unpaid consulting panel, agreed with Mr. Tripp's assessment. "For the discussion to start intelligently, somebody is going to have to stand up and say that borough self-sufficiency doesn't make sense," he said.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: THE FUTURE;
Greenspan Sees Possible Threat In Clinton Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that President Clinton's proposal to have the Government invest a portion of Social Security reserves in the stock market would endanger the economy.
But while some influential Republicans said the plan proposed by Mr. Clinton in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night was so off base that it left no room for compromise, many others saw the proposal as an opening bid that could lead to fruitful negotiations. 
 In testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee today, Mr. Greenspan, whose views on economic matters carry considerable weight in Congress and on Wall Street, said he supported the President's notion of putting almost two-thirds of the Federal budget surpluses over the next 15 years into Social Security reserves.
But Mr. Greenspan added that the idea of having the Government invest part of the money in the stock market could threaten the economy.
The most pessimistic of the top lawmakers interviewed today was Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a Republican who is one of the foremost authorities in Congress on Social Security. "I was profoundly disappointed in what the President proposed," Mr. Gramm said.
He said he feared that "the whole thing is dead for this Congress" and that "we may have to wait for a new President to take office" before the long-term financial problems with Social Security could be resolved.
Asked about that view, Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, replied, "I'm not that pessimistic."
"I think the President's opening shot ducks out on facing up to the real issues," said Mr. Archer, whose committee will have first crack in Congress at writing a new law, "but I'm not sure this is his final shot."
 Under Mr. Clinton's plan to address the potential insolvency of the retirement system when the baby boom generation begins to retire, 62 percent of the projected surpluses in the Federal budget over the next 15 years -- about $2.7 trillion out of total surpluses of about $4.4 trillion -- would be allocated to the Social Security trust fund. Since the fund is expected to be solvent for decades, it would lend most of the money back to the Treasury, in a bookkeeping measure, to pay off the national debt.
Economists believe that lowering the debt, now about $5.5 trillion, would reduce interest rates, generate private investment and stimulate economic growth. The stronger the economy, the more income there would be to pay Social Security taxes. The Treasury would also have to eventually pay back the money the Social Security fund lent it.
The Clinton Administration calculates that all this would help extend solvency to 2055 from 2032, protecting almost everyone who is now working.
But the President would invest $700 billion of the $2.7 trillion in the stock market, which over the long term has historically produced substantially higher returns than Government bonds, where the Social Security reserves are now placed.
The White House says these higher returns would extend Social Security solvency for an extra five years, to 2055 instead of 2050.
Administration officials insist that care would taken to make sure the investments were insulated from politics.
But Mr. Greenspan and Republicans in Congress are skeptical of Government participation in the private financial markets, and this is where they take strongest issue with Mr. Clinton's proposal.
Mr. Greenspan, for example, said he supported the idea of using most of the surplus to shore up Social Security reserves. But as for the Federal Government's investment in the stock market, he said, "I do not believe that it is politically feasible to insulate such huge funds from government direction."
Political pressures, Mr. Greenspan said, could lead to inefficient investments that, in turn, would result in a lower rate of return for retired people and a lower standard of living for all Americans.
Many Republicans took a similar stand. "It amounts to nationalization of American industry," said Representative Jim Kolbe of Arizona. "It's scary. They haven't thought it through."
Republicans, almost without exception, favor investing retirement money in financial markets, but they would have workers invest the money themselves in their own private accounts rather than having the investments placed by the Government.
The President, with the support of most Democrats in Congress, believes that such individual investments could result in unsophisticated workers' risking their retirement savings.
Outside of Social Security, Mr. Clinton proposed spending about $500 billion over the next 15 years to subsidize workers who established investment accounts that would work like the 401(k) plans that many workers have. Republicans objected to this on the ground that it would create a new government entitlement program.
Republicans are not united behind any particular plan. Some, like Mr. Kolbe, would allow workers voluntarily to invest part of their payroll taxes. Their guaranteed Social Security benefits would be reduced accordingly.
Other Republicans would maintain the current Social Security tax and benefit structure but would give workers an income tax cut if they invested the money for their retirement.
This would ultimately cause the Federal deficit to rise again if taxes were not raised or the Government's spending reduced.
Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr. of Florida, the new chairman of the Social Security Subcommittee in the Ways and Means Committee, said he was optimistic that a compromise could be reached.
"The President has opened the door toward investing in the private sector," Mr. Shaw said. "Republicans don't support the idea of the Government doing the investing, but it's a good thing the President has opened the dialogue."
Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, calculated the odds of finding a consensus at 20 to 1. But before Mr. Clinton's speech, the Senator said, he would have set the odds at 200 to 1.
Mr. Archer, the Ways and Means Committee chairman, is retiring at the end of this Congress, and he said that like the President, he would like to leave a solvent Social Security system as a legacy of his years in politics.
"I really do want to work something out and get this solved during the last two years for Clinton and me," Mr. Archer said. Then, referring to the impeachment trial, he added, "Assuming he goes on for another two years."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, appeared before the House Ways and Means Committee yesterday. (Justin Lane for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "AT A GLANCE: The President's Social Security Plan"
Key points of President Clinton's proposal to revamp Social Security:
 
-- Out of projected Federal budget surpluses of $4.4 trillion over the next 15 years, 62 percent, or $2.7 trillion, would be used to bolster Social Security's cash reserves. This would keep the Social Security system solvent until 2055. Mr. Clinton would like to see additional unspecified steps to keep it solvent until 2075.
 
-- The Government would invest $700 billion of transferred money in the stock market. Steps would be taken to make sure that the investments were made independently and without political interference.
 
-- Additional money from the surplus would be used to help workers establish private retirement savings accounts, much like 401(k) programs. The Government would provide seed money to get the accounts started and match a portion of workers' contributions.
 
-- Workers would be allowed to earn full Social Security benefits at retirement age even if they did not retire. Under current law, workers 65 to 69 lose $1 in benefits for each $3 of earnings over $15,500 a year. The President did not specify where the money to pay for this would come from.
 
-- About $700 billion from the surplus would also be used to help shore up Medicare, the Government's health insurance program for retirees and disabled people.
 
(Source: White House)(pg. A21)
 
Chart: "IN THEORY: Ripple in a Sea of Money"
The annual impact of the proposed investment of Social Security money in the stock market would be relatively small compared with other sources of investment. Graph shows amount of budget surplus that would be invested in the stock market each year, from 1998 through 2008. Graph shows new investment in all stock mutual funds, from 1996 through Nov. 1998.
 
Over 15 years, the $700 billion that would be invested in the market is small compared with the current holdings of other groups of stock investors.

HEADLINE: Scaffold in Times Square Collapse Was Built Improperly, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A 700-foot construction scaffold that buckled and broke in Times Square last summer, killing a woman in a nearby hotel and disrupting traffic for several days, was built improperly and was missing critical support braces on 10 floors, according to citations issued yesterday by Federal safety officials.
The citations issued by the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration against the builder of the scaffold, Universal Builders Supply, do not state that the defects were the cause of the collapse, the city's most serious construction accident in a decade. But investigators involved in a city inquiry say that the violations are among the problems that contributed to the accident on July 21 at the construction site of the Conde Nast building, on Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets. 
 In issuing the citations accusing the company of four safety violations, the Federal agency recommended fines totaling $26,000. Universal Builders, which is based in Mount Vernon, N.Y., has until Feb. 10 to contest the citations.
"After the accident," said Robert Kulick, the director of the Federal safety agency in New York, "we found that the scaffold had not been built in accordance with an engineer's plans, that support braces were missing and that the company had failed to insure that the mast bolts were maintained for tightness. We consider these serious safety violations."
The city's official investigation into the causes of the accident is still months away from completion. One person involved in that investigation said that early on, "it was clear that there was some crossbracing that was missing." The braces were designed to insure that the scaffold remained straight, level and square against the building.
"My suspicion is that we'll undoubtedly agree with OSHA," said the investigator, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
City investigators and engineers said that they were unsure whether they could identify a single reason for the accident, but that they could probably identify a series of problems that built on one another, creating a "cascade effect," until the scaffold collapsed.
Kevin O'Callaghan, president of Universal Builders, declined to comment on the accusations of violations because the city was still investigating the collapse. He did issue a statement saying that "the actual cause of the collapse has not yet been determined."
Universal Builders, which erected scaffolding for the renovation of the Statue of Liberty, Grand Central Terminal and the Washington Monument, is already contesting citations for other safety violations in the death of a carpenter, Charles Robbins, in an earlier accident at the Conde Nast site, which is known as 4 Times Square.
The city's report may not be completed until May 1, said Gaston Silva, the city's Buildings Commissioner.
"We have not completed our investigation," Mr. Silva said yesterday. "But we will look at OSHA's findings and incorporate them into our findings."
The collapse of the scaffolding last summer cast a pall over what was supposed to have been a triumph for the developer, Douglas Durst, and a symbol of the rebirth of Times Square. Mr. Durst was building the first new office tower in Manhattan since the recession in the early 1990's.
But on the morning of July 21, the scaffold and an elevator tower that had been erected next to the 48-story tower buckled at the 21st floor as the sound of tearing metal echoed across midtown. The scaffolding above the 20th floor dropped about eight feet, wrenching the elevator tower, which snapped off and fell. A 50-foot section of that tower pierced the roof of the Woodstock Hotel across 43d Street, knocking a concrete slab onto Thereza Feliconio, 85, and killing her as she sat in her top-floor apartment.
Traffic in midtown was disrupted for the better part of a week as city officials, fearful that the scaffold would plummet to the street, blocked off large portions of the Times Square area to traffic.
Workers spent the next two months dismantling the twisted aluminum beams piece by piece and transporting the pieces to a pier in Brooklyn, where the scaffold was reassembled for examination by forensic engineers looking into the causes of the accident.
Yesterday, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration contended that the scaffold, one of the tallest used for skyscraper construction, had not been built in accordance with the plans of a professional engineer and that the structure was not capable of bearing the maximum weight required by safety regulations.
There were also support braces missing from floors 15 through 24, as well as disconnected braces on the 25th floor and a cut brace on the 26th floor, according to the citations.
"Everyone in the industry is keenly awaiting the reports by top technical professionals in the business to determine if any design, installation or inspection procedures should be modified or added to hoist and scaffolding construction," said Richard M. Kielar, senior vice president of Tishman Realty and Construction Company. A unit of the company, Tishman Construction Corporation, is the construction manager at 4 Times Square.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Hints Rate Cut Is Unlikely

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today there is little evidence that the economy is slowing. But he warned for the first time since the stock market's most recent run-up that equity prices might be getting excessive.
His comments, analysts said, suggested that the central bank would leave interest rates unchanged for some time to come. 
 "While there are risks going forward," Mr. Greenspan told the House Ways and Means Committee, "to date domestic demand and hence employment and output in the United States certainly has remained vigorous. Though the pace of economic expansion is widely expected to moderate as 1999 unfolds, signs of an appreciable slowdown as yet remain scant."
Among the risks, he suggested, is that stock prices may again have become unrealistically high. One of the reasons that Wall Street has rebounded so smartly from its brief but sharp dip last summer is Mr. Greenspan himself, who engineered a series of three interest-rate cuts in the fall.
"The level of equity prices would appear to envision substantially greater growth of profits than has been experienced of late," he said, restating a theme he has sounded on and off for more than two years.
The markets, which have come to expect some low-key jawboning from Mr. Greenspan, largely shrugged off his comments. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had advanced well over 100 points during the day, retreated to end with a 19.31-point loss, at 9,335.91. Broader market indicators closed modestly higher, including the Nasdaq composite index, which set another record. Bond prices fell. Page C14.
Mr. Greenspan has not directly addressed stock market valuations in public since the market tumbled and then recovered. But he has warned in general terms about what happens when investors fail to make appropriate judgments about risk, whether on Wall Street or in emerging markets. And the minutes of the Fed's policy-making meeting on Nov. 17, when Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues cut rates by a quarter of a percentage point, show that some members of the committee were worried that pushing rates down would send the stock market to unjustifiably high levels.
Economists have assumed for several months that the Fed is likely to hold rates steady at least the next few months unless the global financial turmoil that has unsettled markets and economies flares anew.
Mr. Greenspan reinforced that view today, though he acknowledged that Brazil's recent problems create uncertainty. He suggested that the Fed was again concerned that stronger-than-expected growth could rekindle inflation if the economy did not slow on its own. Growth in the fourth quarter of 1998 may have been as high as 5 percent, according to some estimates, ending a year in which the economy expanded by nearly 4 percent.
Fed officials and many economists expect growth to slow to a range of 2 to 3 percent this year.
Mr. Greenspan also discussed subjects including Social Security, tax cuts and trade policy, saying that "some moderation" in growth might be required to sustain the nation's long expansion.
"Through the end of 1998, the economy continued to grow more rapidly than can be currently accommodated on an ongoing basis, even with higher, technology-driven productivity growth," he said.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony marked something of a return to his customary views after the tumult of last fall, when the Fed cut interest rates by a total of three-quarters of a percentage point to calm anxious investors and insure that the financial upheaval that began in Asia did not spread to the American economy.
As it has for most of the last three years, the economy is cruising along, defying predictions of a slowdown. The stock market is regularly setting new highs. But even though unemployment is low and demand is strong, there are almost no signs of inflation, leaving policy makers, including Mr. Greenspan, pleased but wary.
A survey released today by the Federal Reserve System provided much the same view of the economy's performance as Mr. Greenspan's testimony. The survey found that "most regions are showing solid economic growth over all," with "generally stable or declining prices."
No element of the economy's performance draws more attention these days than the boom in the financial markets, and Mr. Greenspan used much of his prepared testimony today to explore the link between Wall Street and the buoyancy of consumer demand.
He said there have been valid reasons for the jump in stock prices over the last few years.
"Lower inflation, greater competitiveness and the flexibility and adaptability of our businesses have enabled them to take advantage of a rapid pace of technological change to make our capital stock more productive and profitable," Mr. Greenspan said.
He declared that the Fed had not sought to use monetary policy to move stock prices up and down to reflect its view of appropriate market valuations, adding, "We need to react to changes in financial markets, as we did this fall, but our objective is the maximum sustainable growth of the U.S. economy, not particular levels of asset prices."
At another point, referring to last fall's rate cuts, he said, "We were not attempting to prop up equity prices, nor did we plan to continue to ease rates until equity prices recovered, as some have erroneously inferred."
But the markets have a direct if complex effect on the economy that must be factored into monetary policy, Mr. Greenspan said. The rise in stock prices, he said, had clearly affected the personal savings rate, which declined from almost 6 percent in 1992 to zero last year. Instead of saving through traditional channels, individuals are accumulating wealth through the stock market. There is evidence, he said, that all or most of the decline in personal savings is concentrated among the wealthy, who benefit the most from capital gains.
The wealth effect -- the theory that consumer spending rises along with increases in the value of investment portfolios -- "has been real and significant," Mr. Greenspan said. But the wealth effect could also work in reverse, he said, since "a decline in equity values, especially a severe one, could lead to a considerable weakening of consumer demand."
The markets have stabilized substantially since the fall, Mr. Greenspan said, but the forced devaluation last week of Brazil's currency illustrates the tenuous nature of that calm. And he noted that global economic crises continue to have an effect in the United States, not least in leading to a growing trade deficit as foreign markets for agricultural and industrial products dry up and other nations look to this country to import their goods.
Moreover, Mr. Greenspan said, central banks had to be careful that interest-rate changes did not unduly unsettle the financial markets, given their fragility. Policy makers, he said, "are going to have to be particularly wary of actions that unnecessarily sow uncertainties, undermine confidence and interfere with the efficient allocation of capital."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Federal Reserve Chairman's Testimony

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from testimony by Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, before the House Ways and Means Committee today as recorded by the Federal News Service: 
 The American economy through year-end continued to perform in an outstanding manner. Economic growth remained solid, and financial markets, after freezing up temporarily following the Russian default, are again channeling an ample flow of capital to businesses and households. Labor markets have remained quite tight, but, to date, this has failed to ignite the inflationary pressures that many had feared.
To be sure, there is decided softness in a number of manufacturing industries as weakness in many foreign economies has reduced demand for U.S. exports and intensified competition from imports. Moreover, the underutilized production capacity and pressure on the domestic profit margins, especially among manufacturers, are likely to rein in the rapid growth of new capital investment. With corporations already relying increasingly on borrowing to finance capital investment, any evidence of a marked slowing in corporate cash flow is likely to induce a relatively prompt review of capital budgets.
The situation in Brazil and its potential for spilling over to reduce demand in other emerging market economies also constitute a possible source of downside risk for demand in the United States. So far, markets seem to have reacted reasonably well to the decisions by the Brazilian authorities to float their currency and redouble efforts at fiscal discipline. But follow through in reducing budget imbalances and in containing the effects on inflation of the drop in value of the currency will be needed to bolster confidence and to limit the potential for contagion to the financial markets and economies of Brazil's important trading partners, including the United States.
While there are risks going forward, to date, domestic demand and hence employment and output in the United States certainly has remained vigorous. Though the pace of economic expansion is widely expected to moderate as 1999 unfolds, signs of an appreciable slowdown as yet remain scant.
But to assess the economic outlook properly, we need to reach beyond the mere description of America's sparkling economic performance of eight years of record peacetime expansion to seek a deeper understanding of the forces that have produced it. I want to take a few moments this morning to discuss one key element behind our current prosperity -- the rise in the value markets place on the capital assets of U.S. businesses. Lower inflation, greater competitiveness, and the flexibility and adaptability of our businesses have enabled them to take advantage of a rapid pace of technological change to make our capital stock more productive and profitable. I will argue that the process of recognizing this greater value has produced capital gains in equity markets that have lowered the cost of investment in new plant and equipment and spurred consumption. But, while asset values are very important to the economy and so must be carefully monitored and assessed by the Federal Reserve, they are not themselves a target of monetary policy. We need to react to changes in financial markets, as we did this fall, but our objective is the maximum sustainable growth of the U.S. economy, not particular levels of asset prices.
. . .At root, the remarkable generation of capital gains of recent years has resulted from the dramatic fall in inflation expectations and associated risk premiums, and broad advances in a wide variety of technologies that produced critical synergies in the 1990's.
Capital investment, especially in high-tech equipment, has accelerated dramatically since 1993, presumably reflecting a perception on the part of businesses that the application of these emerging technological synergies would engender a significant increase in rates of return on new investment. . . .
While discussions of consumer spending often continue to emphasize current income from labor and capital as the prime source of funds, during the 1990's, capital gains, which reflect the valuation of expected future incomes, have taken on a more prominent role in driving our economy.
The steep uptrend in asset values of recent years has had important effects on virtually all areas of our economy, but perhaps most significantly on household behavior. It can be seen most clearly in the measured personal saving rate, which has declined from almost 6 percent in 1992 to effectively zero today. . . .
We have some evidence from recent years that all or most of the decline in the saving rate is accounted for by the upper income quintile where the capital gains have disproportionately accrued, which suggests that the wealth effect has been real and significant. Thus, all else equal, a flattening of stock prices would likely slow the growth of spending, and a decline in equity values, especially a severe one, could lead to a considerable weakening of consumer demand. . . .
Despite brisk demand and improved productivity growth, corporate profits have sagged over recent quarters. This is attributable in part to some acceleration in labor compensation, but other factors have been pressing, especially intensified competition and lower prices facing our exporters and those industries competing with imports. In these circumstances, businesses will feel under considerable pressure to preserve profit margins should labor costs accelerate further, or should the falling prices of commodity inputs, like oil, turn around. But, to date, businesses' evident pricing power has been scant. Either that would change and inflation could begin to mount or, if costs could not be recouped, capital outlays might well be cut back.
The recent behavior of profits also underlines the unusual nature of the rebound in equity prices and the possibility that the recent performance of the equity markets will have difficulty in being sustained. The level of equity prices would appear to envision substantially greater growth of profits than has been experienced of late. . . .
Our task going forward -- at the Federal Reserve as well as in the Congress and Administration -- is to sustain and strengthen these policies, which in turn have sustained and strengthened our now record peacetime economic expansion.

HEADLINE: American and US Airways Report Weak Fourth Quarters

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
American Airlines and U S Airways posted disappointing quarterly earnings yesterday on weaker-than-expected revenues, while America West Airlines exceeded Wall Street estimates by a wide margin.
Analysts said that American and U S Airways, like other major domestic airlines, were hurt during the final months of 1998 as revenue declined from the premium fares most often paid by business travelers flying at the last minute. 
 "Airlines make most of their money off business travelers and you saw business travel stall in the fourth quarter," said Glenn Engel, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York.
Inexpensive fuel prices helped ease the carriers' pain by lowering expenses. But the savings were not enough to offset the slide in revenues.
The AMR Corporation, the holding company for American, the country's second-largest airline, said earnings declined 13 percent, to $182 million, or $1.09 a diluted share, compared with $208 million, or $1.16 a share, during the corresponding period a year earlier.
Adjusting for a stock split and one-time gains, AMR earned $1 a share, compared with $1.09 in 1997. The consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation was $1.16 a share.
While total revenue at AMR rose 1.3 percent, to $4.6 billion in the quarter, passenger revenue at American Airlines fell 3 percent, to $3.5 billion, compared with the period last year. The company attributed the decline primarily to softening demand on its international routes.
"What we are seeing are weaker economies in Europe and Latin America and Asia at a time of capacity increases by the industry," Gerard J. Arpey, AMR's chief financial officer, said.
U S Airways, the sixth-largest domestic airline, earned $104 million, or $1.18 a share, in the quarter, compared with $479 million, or $4.66 a share, in the period a year earlier. Excluding a one-time $125 million charge and a $467 million tax credit, earnings declined 25 percent. The consensus earnings estimate by First Call had been $1.20 a share.
The airline's costs, not including fuel, fell 1 percent compared with a year earlier, largely because of the introduction of Metrojet, the low-cost airline it started last year to combat growing competition by Southwest Airlines. But Metrojet also charges lower fares, which along with the softening of business travel pushed U S Airways' total per-passenger revenues down nearly 5 percent.
The company was also hurt during the quarter by the transition to a new computer reservations system that confused many reservation agents.
Mr. Engel said that Rakesh Gangwal, U S Airways' chief executive, told analysts yesterday that downward pressures on revenues would continue this year as the airline expands Metrojet and faces more competition. Mr. Gangwal warned that the consensus 1999 earnings estimate of $6.40 a share might be too high.
America West, which struggled to improve its operations last year, bucked the industry trend by attracting more business travelers on long-haul flights to cities like New York and Boston from its hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas, Nev.
Net income for America West, based in Phoenix and the ninth-largest airline in the country, remained flat at about $20 million in the quarter, but soared 11 percent, to $22.4 million, after excluding a one-time charge. Stock purchases helped per-share earnings soar to 56 cents, from 43 cents in 1997, easily surpassing the First Call consensus estimate of 39 cents a share.
W. Douglas Parker, America West's chief financial officer, said America West plans to continue to woo business travelers this year and will expand capacity by 10 percent.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, America West shares rose $1.375 to $19.50; U S Airways fell $6.3125 a share, to $51.125, and AMR fell $4.4375, to $59.8125.

HEADLINE: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?;
Stocks Are Too Risky

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Unbowed, Clinton Presses Social Security Plan" (front page, Jan. 20): The new approach presented by President Clinton has serious dangers. There is the possibility that Wall Street will not enjoy continuing good times, nor is any explanation given for the economics of replacing assets of the Social Security trust fund, which have yielded a small but dependable return, with stocks, which are much riskier investments. Support for his line of thinking comes from financial institutions that will benefit because of the influx of new money. 
 A sounder proposal would be to raise the income cap for the FICA tax, making the program more finacially stable. Or we could drastically raise the corporate part of the FICA tax and remove the income cap.
 
FRANK RIESSMAN
New York, Jan. 20, 1999
 
The writer is founding editor of Social Policy.

HEADLINE: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?;
Elderly Have Paid

 BODY:

To the Editor:
For years the Treasury has benefited from the fact that the Social Security trust fund was required to buy United States bonds with its surpluses, thus lowering the Treasury's interest burden. The general taxpayer benefited at the expense of the elderly, whose retirement funds could have been more fruitfully invested. Therefore it is only fitting that the Treasury help solve the Social Security shortfall by transferring part of its surplus to the trust fund, as proposed by the President in his State of the Union Message (front page, Jan. 20).
 
DAVID MERMELSTEIN
Brooklyn, Jan. 20, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Polytechnic University.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Jobless Rate Shows Drop in New Jersey

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New Jersey's economy, like the nation's, seems to keep humming along.
The state's unemployment rate for December was 4.4 percent, down from the November rate of 4.5 percent. If the December rate holds up after officials adjust the numbers next month, it would be the lowest since February 1990. 
 The unemployment rate for all of 1998 would then be the lowest in nearly a decade. The State Labor Department says the preliminary rate for 1998 was 4.8 percent, the lowest since 1989, when the annual rate was 4.1 percent.
"New Jersey is enjoying a vibrant and growing economy which continues to reach new employment records," said State Labor Commissioner Mel Gelade, who noted that every new job created in New Jersey adds to a record number of jobs provided by state employers.
Even so, New Jersey's unemployment picture still does not outshine the nation's. The December unemployment rate was still slightly higher than the national average of 4.3 percent posted for December.
And the national rate for 1998 was 4.5 percent, lower than New Jersey's expected rate of 4.8 percent.
New Jersey employers added 65,900 jobs in 1998, a healthy increase but not up to the best-of-the-decade growth of 87,000 jobs in 1997. Following an established pattern, the year saw New Jersey add jobs in the service sector and lose jobs in manufacturing. More than 60 percent of the new jobs -- 41,200 -- were service sector jobs. The state lost 9,600 manufacturing jobs in 1998.

HEADLINE: Planet Africa: Black History on Disk;
Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Microsoft Produce A Long-Awaited, Much-Debated Encyclopedia

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
IN 1995, Henry Louis Gates Jr., a Harvard professor and perhaps the most widely recognized African-American scholar today, cast himself in the role of fast-talking encyclopedia salesman. Dr. Gates, who had begun dreaming of creating a comprehensive encyclopedia of the black world two decades earlier, found himself in New York presenting his proposal to executives from the giant publishing company Random House. But before he could finish his pitch, the company's chief executive, Alberto Vitale, asked him if the encyclopedia could be done as a multimedia CD-ROM, rather than in the conventional print-only manner.
"Of course," was Dr. Gates's response. The only hitch: he had no idea what a CD-ROM was. 
 But Dr. Gates is a famously quick study. And the result is the Encarta Africana, a new electronic encyclopedia that attempts to distill the black experience into two honey-hued CD-ROM disks.
The disks -- crammed with 2.5 million words and more than 2,500 pictures, maps, graphs, sounds and video clips on practically all things of African descent -- reverberate with their subject. A mouse click can send users, even those with modestly powered personal computers, on a cinematic voyage along the Swahili coast, or permit them to retrace centuries of slave routes between the "dark continent" and the New World, or simply watch, in stunningly stark video clips, haunting scenes of civil rights marchers being attacked with fire hoses and police dogs. A keystroke can call up a 1929 performance of "Saint Louis Blues" belted out by Bessie Smith, or samples of Duke Ellington's elegant redesign of jazz, or the Temptations crooning in their Motown glory years in the 1960's or sounds from hip-hop's humble birth in the Bronx.
"We have finally a technology that can explore and explain the expressive features -- music and dance, art and cinema, literature and story-telling -- that are the heart of cultural achievements of people of African descent," Dr. Gates says in a three-minute video clip in the encyclopedia.
There are other CD-ROM collections of some of the sounds, words and deeds of blacks, like last year's Encyclopedia Britannica Profiles Black History. But most of them have been very limited in scope and imagination. By contrast, Encarta Africana, officially released Monday by Microsoft to mark the celebration of Martin Luther King Jr.'s birth, had from its inception the audacious task of chronicling black history and culture stretching back to the first Africans and, for that matter, the first humans, some four million years ago.
Almost for its ambition alone, the project has attracted an enormous amount of attention and some controversy. For Dr. Gates and his co-editor, Kwame Anthony Appiah, a Harvard colleague, the struggle to create the encyclopedia had taken many paths. Some led to dead ends and crushing disappointments. Others met with debate over whether the project was taking an Afrocentric or Eurocentric perspective, and over who actually had the rights to the idea of a black encyclopedia, long a recurring dream among some African-American intellectuals.
In the process of creating the Encarta Africana, Dr. Gates and Dr. Appiah called on more than 400 scholars to research and write more than 3,000 articles that could appeal to everyone from grade-school students to graduate-school students. Dr. Gates also persuaded noted figures like Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian-born recipient of the Nobel Prize in literature, and Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations, to participate in the project. Dr. Gates even called upon his friend Michael Jordon, recently of the N.B.A., to preview the encyclopedia. Mr. Jordan's endorsement -- "a reference work which every family should own" -- appears on the encyclopedia's packaging.
Borrowing some of the most popular features from Microsoft's Encarta series, Africana was designed, its makers say, to show as much as tell. Some officials at Microsoft have been describing the encyclopedia, which costs $49.95 after a $20 mail-in rebate that expires at the end of this year, as a groundbreaking marriage of content and technology. One feature, for example, offers users six virtual tours that include the slave castles of Goree, off the coast of Senegal, West Africa, and the Egyptian ruins at Medinet Habu, using 360-degree photographs that rotate with the nudge of a computer mouse.
"The majority of people in the United States are not going to have a chance to make it over to Africa, so we really try to bring you the sights and sounds in a stimulating format," said Evette Gee, a Microsoft project manager for Encarta Africana.
The earliest dream of a comprehensive black encyclopedia belonged neither to Professor Gates nor to Bill Gates, but to a man whose life ended long before the advent of personal computers, the Internet and CD-ROM's. In 1909, W.E.B. Du Bois, who was the first black person to earn a Ph.D. from Harvard University and who went on to become an influential American intellectual, writer, social scientist and Pan-Africanist, called for the creation of a black encyclopedia. He said he wanted this work, which he called the Encyclopedia Africana, to tell the complete saga of Africa and its diaspora in Europe, Asia, the Caribbean and the Americas.
"Du Bois thought in 1909 that the principle cause of racism was ignorance," said Dr. Gates, who is director of the W.E.B. Du Bois Institute for Afro-American Research at Harvard, in an interview. "And if he could marshal scientific evidence -- that was his phrase -- that we could defeat racism. And the best way to marshal scientific evidence was through an encyclopedia."
While his belief would change over the years, as he came to the conclusion that racism was rooted in economics, Du Bois nonetheless pursued his dream of producing an encyclopedia of the black world until his death in 1963 in Ghana, at age 94. For the last two years of his life, Du Bois lived in Ghana at the invitation of its president, Kwame Nkrumah, and was at work leading the creation of the Encyclopedia Africana. Since then, his work has slowly continued in Ghana, with three volumes published so far.
While a student at Cambridge University in 1973, Dr. Gates said, he dreamed of completing the vision of Du Bois, whose brilliance and self-confidence, he acknowledged, still stagger him. At Cambridge, he met a young philosophy major, Kwame Anthony Appiah, whose uncle is an Asante chief in Ghana. They became friends and collaborators in trying to make real what Dr. Appiah calls Du Bois's "noble idea."
In 1979, Dr. Gates, then an assistant professor at Yale University, approached Encyclopedia Britannica with the idea. But the company was not convinced that the project would be make money. If Dr. Gates could raise the millions required to create the encyclopedia, the company told him, Britannica would produce it
It wasn't until 1995, after having taught at Harvard for four years, Dr. Gates said, that he felt secure enough there to try once again to resurrect the idea. He had received pledges of development money from Quincy Jones, the composer and media entrepreneur, and Martin Payson, a high-ranking executive at Time Warner, for the project. It was then that he met with Random House officials and was asked to consider making a CD-ROM.
Six months later, after working with Dynamic Diagrams, a Rhode Island-based design group, Dr. Gates had a CD-ROM prototype of his encyclopedia. But when he returned to Random House with it, he was told that the bottom had fallen out of the CD-ROM market. The company was no longer interested.
"They said that they were only doing games," Dr. Gates recalled recently. "I could have cried. I was devastated."
Even today, the "edutainment" CD-ROM market is rapidly shrinking as more users turn to the vast, ever-changing resources of the Internet, rather than the static data on disks, said L. Butt Jr., director of entertainment and technology strategy at Forrester Research. There are some exceptions, however, for CD-ROM encyclopedias like Encarta, Mr. Butt said.
After his rejection by Random House, Dr. Gates shopped the project around New York, making presentations to numerous companies, including the Voyager Company and Simon & Schuster. Still no deal.
But in the spring of 1997, while approaching Prodigy, the Internet service provider, to set up an on-line version of the encyclopedia, Dr. Gates was also talking separately with Perseus Books and Microsoft. The day after Dr. Gates finalized a deal with Perseus to produce a single-volume text version of the encyclopedia -- scheduled for publication in November -- Microsoft agreed to produce the CD-ROM encyclopedia. Microsoft and Perseus quickly reached an agreeement to split the costs. No one will say how much the compendium cost, but a source close to the project said the research budget was about $2 million.
Although Dr. Gates had finally found publishers for the encyclopedia, he learned that the original name he had in mind, Encyclopedia Africana, would have to be dropped. The group still working in Ghana to complete Du Bois's project, it turned out, owned the rights to that name.
Some say the scholars involved in the project, who have so far produced three volumes of an anticipated 20-volume Encyclopedia Africana: Dictionary of African Biography are the inheritors not only of the project's name but also of its true spirit.
"What we have here is a commercial product for the white buyers," said Molefi Kete Asante, a widely published author and former chairman of the African studies department at Temple University in Philadelphia. "It is a project that is flawed, because the people who created it, even though they have strong credentials in the white academies, do not understand the African world."
Dr. Asante, a founding father of Afrocentricity, which holds that black history must be seen from what he calls an "African center." Encarta Africana, he said, takes a more Eurocentric approach to examining the black world.
Specifically, Dr. Asante points to the encyclopedia's passages on Egypt, passages that he said work to confirm some historians' views that despite its place on the African continent, Egypt's civilization is somehow more akin to that of the Middle East, rather than having evolved from core African cultural and historical roots.
Dr. Asante and Raymond A. Winbush, a professor and director of the Race Relations Institute at Fisk University in Nashville, also say that Dr. Gates and Dr. Appiah asked few, if any, Afrocentric scholars to join the more than 400 scholars who contributed articles to Encarta Encyclopedia.
"I'm just disappointed that some of our great scholars, like on slavery in America, were not invited," said Dr. Winbush, who is an advisor to the Ghana-based project. He said the electronic encyclopedia was not the "definitive view of Africa." He acknowledged, however, that it was "a good first step, a baby step."
The encyclopedia has drawn strong praise from Robert. L. Douglas, a noted African studies scholar. "The sheer magnitude of its size, scope and chronology -- from four million B.C. to the present -- is magnificent in itself," said Dr. Douglas, professor of art history and Pan-African studies at the University of Louisville in Kentucky. "Only with the coming years of its use in the multitude of educational forums and the research potential that it promises for teachers and scholars will its successes and failures be realized."
Dr. Gates concedes that Encarta Africana is "mainstream, very mainstream." But that does not devalue its scholarship, others agree. Any potentially controversial passage in the encyclopedia is, he said, clearly identified so. And often, he says, his group of scholars, which he described as "ideologically diverse," tried hard to include opposing arguments on interpretations of black history and culture.
"We don't have a God complex," Dr. Gates said. "We are not saying that this is the Bible." He noted that this week he started an Internet site (www.africana .com) inviting anyone to send in "ideas and opinions" regarding the encyclopedia's content. "The more the merrier," Dr. Gates said, suggesting that the encyclopedia may be revised over time. Still, the CD-ROM is not yet for everyone. It does not come in a Macintosh version (or a single-disk DVD version). And there are no immediate plans for a Mac Encarta, said Evette Gee at Microsoft. That could present a problem, some educators say, for poor, urban school districts that may be more likely to have older, Macintosh computers.
Microsoft announced that it plans to donate 2,000 copies of Encarta Africana to urban schools, part of an overall donation of 8,000 copies of the encyclopedia to schools, including historically black colleges and universities and selected public libraries in the South.
Dr. Gates said he is immensely proud of the encyclopedia and is pleased with the thought that Du Bois might be pleased as well. Last month, when Encarta Encyclopedia was being shipped, he received a letter from David G. Du Bois, the 71-year-old son of W.E.B. Du Bois.
In part, it read, "Anthony Appiah and Henry Louis Gates Jr., inspired by Father's original idea, have made a magnificent, state-of-the-art contribution to African and African American studies and humanities with Encarta Africana. Dr. Du Bois would have been proud."

1909 -- W.E.B. Du Bois has idea for an encyclopedia of the black world.1934 Du
1934 -- Du Bois becomes head of a project to publish an "Encyclopedia of the Negro."
1961 -- Du Bois accepts invitation from Ghana's first president, Kwame Nkrumah, to go to Africa and create the Encyclopedia Africana.
1963 -- Du Bois dies in Ghana at age 94. Project continues under African scholars.
1979 -- Encyclopedia Britannica turns down idea of a black encyclopedia, calling it unprofitable.
1993 -- The composer Quincy Jones joins effort to raise development money for encyclopedia.
1995 -- Random House executive suggests releasing encyclopedia on CD-ROM.
1997 -- Henry Louis Gates Jr. signs deal with Microsoft to produce Encarta Africana.
1999 -- Encarta Africana is officially released.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 24; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.
 
Now Playing
 
 * "AFFLICTION," starring Nick Nolte, James Coburn, Willem Dafoe, Sissy Spacek and Mary Beth Hurt. Directed by Paul Schrader (R, 114 minutes). Mr. Nolte is devastating in the performance of his career, as Wade Whitehouse, a New Hampshire loner fighting a losing battle with demons from his past. Foremost among them: Mr. Coburn, terrifyingly authentic as the drunken, abusive father who long ago cowed his sons into submission. As directed by Mr. Schrader, this pure, unfettered adaptation of Russell Banks's novel starts on a deceptively ordinary note, then escalates into inexorable fury. Every little detail matters. Ms. Spacek and Ms. Hurt expertly play the women who trigger Wade's crisis (Janet Maslin). 

 "AT FIRST SIGHT," starring Val Kilmer and Mira Sorvino. Directed by Irwin Winkler (PG-13, 128 minutes). In this overlong and often desperately banal version of a case study reported by Dr. Oliver Sacks, Mr. Kilmer plays a man whose nearly lifelong blindness was suddenly alleviated by surgery. Ms. Sorvino plays the bright-eyed New York career woman who falls in love with him, then urges him to change his once-peaceful life. But the film brings little more than case-study data to communicating how this man's restored sight affected him, or what made it a mixed blessing. Sample dialogue: "Have you ever listened to the rain? I mean, really listened?" (Maslin).
 
 * "CENTRAL STATION," starring Fernanda Montenegro, Vinicius de Oliveira and Marilia Pera. Directed by Walter Salles (R, 115 minutes). In this quiet, luminous Brazilian gem, a joyless older woman crosses paths with an orphaned young boy. There's plenty of room for sentimentality here, but the wonder of Mr. Salles's film is all in the telling. As these characters develop a fractious bond, then embark on a road trip that takes them vividly to Brazil's hinterlands in search of the boy's father, Mr. Salles brings great tenderness and surprise to the events that punctuate their journey. Ms. Montenegro's tough bravura performance was one of last year's very best (Maslin).
 
 * "A CIVIL ACTION," starring John Travolta and Robert Duvall. Directed by Steven Zaillian (PG-13, 120 minutes). This story of a David-Goliath lawsuit against industrial polluters, with Mr. Travolta first-rate as an ambulance chaser who develops a conscience, could have been business as usual in the legal thriller genre. But Mr. Zaillian's keenly observed, beautifully acted film, based on Jonathan Harr's nonfiction best seller about a case in Woburn, Mass., doesn't follow familiar formulas. It follows all the surprises and frustrations of a story that was never black and white, and is all the better for its shades of gray. Mr. Duvall is outstanding as a corporate lawyer full of wily tricks (Maslin).
 
 "DR. AKAGI," starring Akira Emoto. Directed by Shohei Imamura (not rated, 128 minutes). This bawdy gallows comedy centering on the treatment of hepatitis is an eclectic footnote to the career of a Japanese filmmaker known for quirky daring (as in, most recently, "The Eel"). Based on a novel called "Dr. Liver" and set near the end of World War II, it unfolds with comic sprightliness in a seaside village near Hiroshima, where the health of the doctor's friends and neighbors is generally no laughing matter. The film's blend of frank earthiness, harsh flippancy, bizarre kinks and flashes of unlikely formal beauty may not do much to make liver disease riveting. But they do make the septuagenarian Mr. Imamura arguably the youngest-hearted filmmaker in Japan (Maslin).
 
 * "THE GENERAL," starring Brendan Gleeson and Jon Voight. Directed by John Boorman (not rated, 125 minutes). Mr. Boorman's best and most stylish film in years is the deftly told story of Martin Cahill. Nicknamed "the General" for his crime-plotting strategies, this Irish gang leader and master thief is played with splendid brio by Mr. Gleeson. Photographed gorgeously in black and white, the film tells of his elaborate art and jewel heists, his unusual domestic arrangement with his wife's sister and his singular difficulties with the I.R.A. and the law. Mr. Voight is outstandingly good as the police detective who knows all of Cahill's tricks (Maslin).
 
 "IN DREAMS," starring Annette Bening, Aidan Quinn and Robert Downey Jr. Directed by Neil Jordan (R, 112 minutes). At heart this is just a campfire story, and a pretty loony one at that. But Mr. Jordan directs it furiously a la "Interview With the Vampire" with a lush, insinuating visual style that gets right under the skin. Working with the inventive cinematographer Darius Khondji, he stirs up a nightmare brooding and intuitive enough to recall at times the richly textured mysteries of Nicolas Roeg's "Don't Look Now." Ms. Bening plays a psychic plagued by the thoughts of a serial killer, whom Mr. Downey makes as bizarre and disturbing as he can, in a performance that makes this story's craziest dreams come true (Maslin).
 
 * "MISSISSIPPI MERMAID," starring Catherine Deneuve and Jean-Paul Belmondo. Directed by Francois Truffaut (not rated, 123 minutes). The Film Forum (209 West Houston Street in the South Village) continues its two-week run of this bewitching, circuitous love story in the guise of a globe-trotting caper film, with Ms. Deneuve and Mr. Belmondo at their most dazzling. She plays a demure mail-order bride who swindles Mr. Belmondo's wealthy tobacco grower, and by the time she is revealed to be a con woman, the intrigue is over -- but that's where the romance really starts. Rarely shown theatrically, it now includes 13 especially tender, character-revealing moments that had been cut for the film's 1970 American release (Maslin).
 
 "PATCH ADAMS," starring Robin Williams and Monica Potter. Directed by Tom Shadyac (PG-13, 110 minutes). As a maverick doctor intent on making terminal patients laugh, Mr. Williams delivers a little clowning and a lot of maudlin feel-good sentiment, along with vulgarity left over from the filmmaker's "Ace Ventura" days. He also spends a lot of time being congratulated for his good works, as the film's minor players are kept busy marveling at his antics. The real-life story of this doctor may sound like a fine excuse for Mr. Williams to cut loose, but the film version proves narrow and predictable. Ms. Potter, with a nostrilly resemblance to Julia Roberts, figures in a romantic subplot with a bizarre twist (Maslin).
 
 * "THE PRINCE OF EGYPT," starring the voices of Val Kilmer, Ralph Fiennes and Michelle Pfeiffer. Directed by Brenda Chapman, Steve Hickner and Simon Wells (PG, 93 minutes). First came the great expectations for this animated magnum opus from Dreamworks. Then came reality, in a film struggling mightily to balance animated whimsy and biblical stature. The upshot is an admirably worthy rendering of the Exodus story, even if Moses must initially be seen as a playful young scamp. Biblical plagues and miracles serve as special inspiration for the animators' reality-bending ingenuity (Maslin).
 
 "PRIVATE CONFESSIONS," starring Pernilla August and Max Von Sydow. Written by Ingmar Bergman. Directed by Liv Ullmann (not rated, 127 minutes). The pedigree is irresistible, the screenplay often wrenchingly astute, as Mr. Bergman delves with wisdom into a spiritual and marital crisis experienced by his mother. In a film directed by Ms. Ullmann with Bergmanesque watchfulness, and with enough assurance to recall his devastating "Scenes From a Marriage," an adulterous liaison becomes a defining event in the life of a lonely, restless woman. Set mostly in 1925, the film also visits her past and her future, and features a formidable performance from Mr. Von Sydow and from Ms. August, passionately extending upon her "Best Intentions" role (Maslin).
 
 * "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE," starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow, Geoffrey Rush, Ben Affleck and Judi Dench. Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile this tirelessly inventive comedy envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today, and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
 * "A SIMPLE PLAN," starring Bill Paxton, Billy Bob Thornton and Bridget Fonda. Directed by Sam Raimi (R, 120 minutes). This onetime cult horror director makes a flawless transition to mainstream storytelling with a quietly devastating thriller. And its fine cast plays out the consequences of a harmless-sounding error in judgment that winds up leveling everything in its path. The catalyst is $4.4 million that literally falls out of the sky, and Scott Smith's story proves how deadly the morality of expediency can become. When you get the shivers watching this wintry tale, which features an especially memorable performance from Mr. Thornton, it won't be from the cold (Maslin).
 
 "STEPMOM," starring Susan Sarandon, Julia Roberts and Ed Harris. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG-13, 120 minutes). A man's ex-wife and new girlfriend lock horns over who can be nicer to his two children, in a sudsy story made livelier by its two female stars, both in appealingly high gear. Ms. Roberts plays the nicest person ever to wear black to a downtown photo shoot, while the especially fiery Ms. Sarandon plays the suburban mother as mama lion. Even when the prospect of mortality looms, the story manages to maintain its big, lavish look and peculiar (under the circumstances) sense of fun. As in "Home Alone," Mr. Columbus directs with sunny indifference to reality, medical, economic or otherwise (Maslin).
 
 "THE THIN RED LINE," starring Jim Caviezel, Ben Chaplin, Nick Nolte, Sean Penn and Woody Harrelson. Directed by Terrence Malick (R, 166 minutes). From the first frame of this huge, drifting war epic loosely derived from James Jones's Guadalcanal novel, it's viscerally clear that Mr. Malick is back. The exquisite, oddly detached visual style that made "Badlands" and "Days of Heaven" the most beautiful films of the 1970's is instantly apparent here, even if the narrative vagueness and brooding voice-overs are also familiar. The film sprawls, gets lost and occasionally delivers visual poetry, the kind that could have been greatly helped by tighter editing. Bottom line: no one who admired Mr. Malick's early work should miss this. But those expecting anything simple will not find it here (Maslin).
 
 * "YOU'VE GOT MAIL," starring Meg Ryan, Tom Hanks, Greg Kinnear and Parker Posey. Directed by Nora Ephron (PG, 110 minutes). This cozy, inviting comedy romanticizes the rivalry between two bookstore owners, while also finding time to fall in love with books themselves, the instant intimacy of E-mail and a picture-perfect rendering of Manhattan's Upper West Side. With a feel-good ambience much less forced than that of "Sleepless in Seattle," Ms. Ephron borrows adroitly from "The Shop Around the Corner" while making this knowing, urbanely funny film very much her own. Ms. Ryan is fresh and adorable without trying, while a ruefully lovelorn Mr. Hanks proves that he can do anything. Again (Maslin).
 
 Film Series
 
 "ANIME: THE HISTORY OF JAPANESE ANIMATED FILMS." A series at the Japan Society devoted to anime, the increasingly popular Japanese animated films that evolved from the comics, reaches a high point this weekend with a two-day symposium devoted to the genre. Tomorrow and Sunday, creators, critics, scholars and industry representatives will discuss anime and its influence on Japanese society and visual culture elsewhere in the world, and audiences will be shown a world premiere and other films. Directed by Hiroyuki Okiura, the world premiere film, "Jinroh," at 4:30 P.M. tomorrow, will be introduced by its writer, Mamoru Oshii. Based on "Little Red Riding Hood," the film portrays a cruel but sentimental relationship between a police officer and a 17-year-old girl who has lost her motivation for life. On Sunday, Mr. Oshii will discuss "Ghost in the Shell" a film about a cyborg pursuing a computer criminal that is to be shown at 8:30 tonight. The series continues through Feb. 26 at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, Manhattan. Two-day symposium tickets, purchased in advance: $55; $25 for students. Symposium single tickets: $30; $15 for students. Screening tickets: $8; $5 for students. Information: (212) 752-3015 (Lawrence Van Gelder).Philip V. Caruso/MGM

HEADLINE: Microsoft and the Question of Monopoly

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The judge in the Microsoft antitrust trial asked the company's expert witness on economics a series of skeptical questions today, suggesting that the Microsoft Corporation may have a difficult time with one of its defenses -- that it does not have a monopoly in the market for personal computer operating systems.
Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson interrupted when a Microsoft lawyer was questioning Richard L. Schmalensee, an economist and dean of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management, about the price Microsoft charges for its industry-standard Windows operating system. Mr. Schmalensee was explaining his view that the modest price Microsoft charges for Windows, typically less than 5 percent of the cost of a personal computer, indicated a company concerned about current and potential competition instead of the predatory monopolist the Government has tried to paint for the court. 
 But Judge Jackson cut in to ask if there could be sound business reasons that even a monopolist might charge less today "in search of larger glory at some later date."
To illustrate his point, the judge spoke of the hypothetical case of a cigarette company that might keep its prices low to hook generations of future smokers and customers.
"There isn't any indication," Mr. Schmalensee replied, "that Windows is that kind of addiction."
Judge Jackson seemed unconvinced. "Do you have kids?" he asked Mr. Schmalensee.
Yes, the M.I.T. dean replied, "but not all kids use Windows, Your Honor. Some use Macs," a reference to Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh machines, which run the Mac operating system.
The judge's occasional questions are scrutinized by both sides as a possible clue to his thinking. This is not a jury trial, so at least at the Federal district court level, Judge Jackson will determine the outcome of the case. Legal experts say that queries from the bench do not foreshadow a verdict but do suggest the issues a judge is focusing on when weighing testimony.
Whether Microsoft has a monopoly in the market for personal computer operating systems is not directly at issue in this case. The Justice Department and 19 states are not suing Microsoft for having a monopoly but for illegally using its market muscle to defend and extend the reach of its monopoly.
Still, if Microsoft can convince the court that it is not a monopoly, the Government's case collapses.
Under questioning from Richard Urowsky, a Microsoft lawyer, Mr. Schmalensee explained that his key assumption in explaining the company's business practices -- its pricing, investment spending and deals -- is that it lives in an industry characterized by "dynamic competition."
Unlike old smokestack industries, Mr. Schmalensee said, the software business requires even the incumbent leaders to move quickly, to keep prices low and to innovate continually. "Microsoft is constantly concerned with being displaced as a leader," he said.
The Government argues that Microsoft's behavior is that of a modern monopolist. It is in a fast-moving high-technology business, the Government concedes, but its monopoly position is nonetheless resilient partly because of the reluctance of consumers to switch operating systems once they have taken the time and trouble to figure out Windows, which runs on more than 90 percent of personal computers sold. This kind of self-reinforcing dependency -- "high switching costs," in economic terms -- was what Judge Jackson was alluding to with his cigarette-monopoly example.
The Government contends that Microsoft used exclusionary contracts with personal computer makers and others to unfairly shield its monopoly from the threat posed by the Internet generally, but especially by the Netscape Communications Corporation, the pioneer in software for browsing the World Wide Web, and Sun Microsystems Inc., the creator of Java, an Internet programming language.
But Mr. Schmalensee testified that even if one assumed that Microsoft was indeed a monopoly, there was no convincing evidence Microsoft did anything to restrict the distribution of Netscape's browsing software.
The Justice Department has introduced documents showing that some PC makers complained when Microsoft imposed new contract restrictions in 1996 that limited their freedom to do as they please with the first desktop screen that appears when users turn on their machines. The PC makers would prefer a free hand in selling that valuable commercial real estate to software makers, including Microsoft's rivals, to load their icons.
But Mr. Schmalensee testified that those restrictions were mostly modest, such as limiting the size of icons that can be displayed. Microsoft, he added, typically uses for its own software seven of the available 49 spaces for desktop icons.
"There is lots of room for PC makers to put on other icons, so Microsoft does not limit software distribution through the desktop," Mr. Schmalensee said.
The Government replies that by bundling its browser with Windows and giving it away free, Microsoft used its monopoly to give its browser an unfair edge and drive up the distribution costs of Netscape.
