HEADLINE: Income-Based Medicare Proposal Is Offered

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Higher-income Medicare beneficiaries would have to pay higher premiums under proposals outlined today by Senator John B. Breaux, the chairman of a bipartisan commission seeking ways to avert a financial crisis in the health insurance program for the elderly.
In his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, President Clinton proposed using some of the Federal budget surplus for Medicare. Mr. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, said that would help shore up Medicare but would not solve its long-term financial problems and did not reduce the need for radical changes in the program. 
 The 17-member commission plans to meet on Tuesday and is to submit final recommendations to the President and Congress by March 1. Mr. Breaux's proposals are the text from which the panel will work, and he said he thought he could win the necessary 11 votes on the panel.
Mr. Breaux said his proposal would transform Medicare into an arena for competition between the fee-for-service Federal program and dozens of private health plans. Instead of paying separately for each medical service, the Government would offer a fixed amount of money to each beneficiary to buy insurance, and the original Medicare program would be one option among many.
Senator Breaux said private health plans would have to offer benefits at least equivalent to those offered in the Government-run program. A new Federal agency, the Medicare Board, would be established to supervise and negotiate with the private health plans.
Federal payments to health plans would be set through a process of competitive bidding, Mr. Breaux said. Health plans would submit bids to the Medicare Board, and the Government would pay a fixed percentage of the average premium charged by all health plans participating in Medicare. There would be a limit on the Government's contribution, and beneficiaries would pay any costs above that limit.
In addition, Mr. Breaux said, "higher-income Medicare beneficiaries should be required to pay a larger share of their Medicare premiums than moderate- and low-income beneficiaries." The extra revenue would subsidize the premiums of low-income beneficiaries.
The eligibility age for Medicare would be increased to 67 from 65, over 24 years, from 2003 to 2027.
John C. Rother, director of legislation and public policy at the American Association of Retired Persons, deferred judgment on Mr. Breaux's proposal. "It could be positive for beneficiaries, or it could be negative, depending on how it's structured," he said. "We don't have enough details, enough numbers, to know."
To judge the impact on consumers, Mr. Rother said, it is necessary to know how much of the average premium they will pay, and how much will be paid by the Government.
Senator Breaux bristled at suggestions that he was proposing to give each Medicare beneficiary a "voucher" to buy health insurance.
"A voucher just says to somebody, 'Here's X amount of money, go find yourself a health plan,' " Mr. Breaux said. "My proposal uses the strength of the Federal Government to negotiate on behalf of people so they can get the best deal. We're not leaving people at the mercy of the marketplace. There would be quality standards and a minimum package of benefits."
Mr. Breaux said Medicare's financial problems were more urgent than those of Social Security. "This is much more important than Social Security, as far as the timing is concerned, because the due date is much earlier," Mr. Breaux said. "We have a much more immediate problem with Medicare."

HEADLINE: Ex-Latin King Says U.S. Reneged;
Killer Turned Informer, Seeking Leniency, Fears for His Life

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER 

 BODY:
One day a few years ago, Federal prosecutors investigating the Latin Kings, one of the most brutal and highly organized gangs in New York, got the break they were looking for. A high-ranking member of the gang offered to act as an informer.
The volunteer, Jose Melendez, then in Federal custody, said he was seeking a cooperation agreement with the Government in hopes of receiving a lesser sentence for his crimes. 
 Mr. Melendez gave detailed information to prosecutors about the gang's previous and current activities, but now, in secret court hearings in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Melendez has accused the authorities of reneging on a promise to give him a deal, thus placing his life in jeopardy.
"I believe no cooperating witness in the whole Latin Kings case gave them more information in our case than I did," he said in an interview in the Metropolitan Correctional Center.
Mr. Melendez met with Federal prosecutors in Manhattan more than 20 times, records show, giving details of killings and other crimes. He even called with a tip that allowed prosecutors to break up a jail house plot to kill Luis Felipe, the imprisoned leader of the Latin Kings.
Prosecutors made good use of the information, the records show, but eventually rejected Mr. Melendez's bid to become a Government witness, which would have given him a signed agreement from prosecutors and a letter to the judge describing his assistance, the first step toward substantial leniency in sentencing.
Prosecutors contended that even though Mr. Melendez pleaded guilty in a secret proceeding to racketeering and admitted conspiring in at least eight murders, he lied repeatedly about his involvement in various crimes. As a result, prosecutors said, they refused to give him a deal.
Mr. Melendez's case sheds light on a recurring problem for prosecutors: how to treat witnesses who are participants in heinous crimes.
The Government often makes deals with criminals to further some larger objective, such as bringing down a criminal enterprise or convicting its leaders. But there is a debate over where to draw the line.
"We like to think of justice as absolute and indivisible," said Michael J. Sandel, a professor of government at Harvard University. "But in fact it is subject to a kind of moral economy, which involves trade-offs, concessions and prosecutorial discretion."
"It makes us uneasy," he added, "for the Government to be in the business of bargaining with criminals, but it is unavoidable if prosecutors are to seek the greater measure of justice on behalf of the society as a whole."
In one prominent case, prosecutors argued for leniency for Salvatore Gravano, known as Sammy the Bull, whose testimony helped convict John Gotti and nearly 40 others. Mr. Gravano received only five years in prison despite his admitted involvement in 19 killings.
But most such deals occur out of public view, as in the case of Mr. Melendez, whose dispute with the Government has been fought out behind closed doors at the order of Judge Lawrence M. McKenna, apparently to protect Mr. Melendez's role as an informer.
But details were gleaned from several recent court documents that were filed publicly, as well as documents Mr. Melendez provided to The New York Times. Those included a 50-page letter detailing his cooperation that he sent to Judge McKenna, due to sentence him next month.
Saying he was duped by prosecutors and now fears for his life, Mr. Melendez has asked the judge to rule that the Government unlawfully denied him a deal, and to sentence him as if he had received one. That would mean he could be given time served and be released immediately.
"The Latin Kings want me dead for my cooperation," he told Judge McKenna, a transcript shows.
The Government wants him to serve 20 years, the maximum for the racketeering charge, saying he would have served far longer had he been convicted in the murders. Mr. Melendez described the trade-off as inadequate considering the "substantial assistance" he gave prosecutors.
Even within the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, where the rule is "you either cooperate or you don't, there's no middle of the road," as one prosecutor said in court, the decision to allow Mr. Melendez to plead to a charge carrying 20 years spurred debate. The prosecutor, Steven M. Cohen, acknowledged to the judge, "It was not a popular decision in our office."
The dispute over whether Mr. Melendez deserves a deal centers on whether he was completely truthful in what he said to prosecutors.
Mr. Melendez denied that he ever lied to prosecutors or minimized his own role in crimes. In his defense, he has cited the Government's own accounts crediting him with substantial assistance.
Lloyd Epstein, a lawyer for Mr. Melendez who entered the case after he had pleaded guilty and met with prosecutors, would speak only generally about his client's case. "There has to be some compensation given to somebody who has taken a risk by cooperating," Mr. Epstein said. "I don't think the public at large would want criminals not to cooperate."
Prosecutors told Judge McKenna that Mr. Melendez did provide them with "a voluminous amount of information," but they also said he violated the Government's policy requiring a potential witness to be truthful from the start.
A spokesman for the United States Attorney's office declined to comment on the case.
The 1994 racketeering indictment against the Latin Kings charged Mr. Melendez and 19 others with a pattern of murders, robberies and drug dealing. Officials described Mr. Melendez as third in command of the gang, which included beheadings and burnings in its methods used against rivals and wayward members.
The indictment outlined the gang's rigid hierarchy and cultlike rules, and said violations could result in a "B.O.S.," beating on sight, or a "T.O.S.," termination on sight.
Mr. Melendez, known as King Epic, was one of the gang's most violent men, the indictment charged, giving and carrying out termination orders. In one killing, prosecutors said, he dragged a rival gang member from a car and shot him in the head.
Today, Mr. Melendez, 29, says he accepts responsibility for his crimes, and contends that helping the Government was a means to reform his ways.
"I know I did some bad things," he said in the interview, "and nothing can ever change that for the victims' families, and the suffering they have gone through.
"I feel a lot of remorse, regret," he added. "But at the same time, I feel that I have, through these years, gone through a very great transformation in life."
Federal prosecutors said Mr. Melendez got in touch with them in 1994, saying "that he was willing to truthfully disclose his own criminal activities and his knowledge of the activities of the Latin Kings."
It was understood that the process could lead to a formal deal, but he would have to be truthful.
Prosecutors say Mr. Melendez ultimately "provided a relatively accurate version of events," except for denying or minimizing his role in killings and other crimes.
Only later, prosecutors told Judge McKenna, after they gathered more evidence and confronted Mr. Melendez with accounts of his role in the crimes, did he admit that the Government's version was accurate. But he "would typically deny that he ever had misled or lied," the prosecutors said.
Mr. Cohen said prosecutors concluded that Mr. Melendez would not be a reliable witness. "We really didn't want to deal with Mr. Melendez any more," Mr. Cohen told the judge.
Still, Mr. Melendez persisted in offering information.
One day in March 1995, Mr. Cohen told Judge McKenna, Mr. Melendez called another Federal prosecutor, Richard Zabel, and said "he had crucial information" about a plot to kill the gang's leader, Mr. Felipe. Mr. Melendez said a homemade knife would be left in the recreation area on the jail's roof, where it would be used to kill Mr. Felipe the next day, Mr. Cohen said.
He said the authorities moved quickly and found a knife and some documents indicating that a plot was under way. There was "no question Mr. Melendez was the cause of Mr. Felipe's life being saved," Mr. Cohen said in court.
But prosecutors told the judge that they also received information suggesting that Mr. Melendez had been involved in the plot from the start. Mr. Cohen said prosecutors wondered whether the entire scheme was an "elaborate manipulation" by Mr. Melendez so that he could call the Government with a dramatic piece of news and win credit toward a deal.
Mr. Melendez denied any role in the murder plot. Mr. Cohen acknowledged in court papers that prosecutors did not have enough evidence to charge him.
Mr. Cohen told Judge McKenna that he and Mr. Zabel "struggled with the fact that we had received a lot of information from Melendez."
"It was decided that fairness dictated that Melendez receive some kind of benefit for the assistance he rendered," Mr. Cohen said in a court document.
The prosecutors allowed Mr. Melendez to plead guilty to one racketeering charge, which carried a maximum term of 20 years. The plea bargain made no mention of a cooperation agreement, although Mr. Melendez said he was led to believe that one was forthcoming.
Prosecutors told Judge McKenna that 20 years was a reasonable reward for Mr. Melendez, considering the number of killings he was involved in and that he had no formal deal. Had he been convicted, he would have faced life in prison.
But in his letter to Judge McKenna, Mr. Melendez asked for a hearing to "seek out the true facts of this case."
In court, he said: "I dealt in good faith with the Government. I never lied to them."

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
Journalists all over the country are scrambling for ideas to fill out their coverage of Pope John Paul II's visit to St. Louis next week. Pity them. It is really not so easy to come up with a fresh approach after the news media blitz that surrounded the Pope's trip to the United States less than four years ago and the many overviews of his papacy, which marked its 20th anniversary last fall.
Well, here's a suggestion. On Dec. 17, Dr. Joaquin Navarro-Valls, the Pope's spokesman, who will be accompanying him on his American visit, made a brief statement about the bomb and missile strikes against Iraqi targets that had begun a day earlier. The statement included this sentence: "The Holy See hopes that this aggression ends as soon as possible and that international order is re-established." 
 "This aggression"? A very strong term, to put it mildly. Given the Roman Catholic Church's teaching on just and unjust war, it appears to mean that American and British forces were acting immorally in hitting Iraqi targets while Iraq's military was simply exercising justifiable self-defense.
The condemnation was echoed, although in words less stark than Dr. Navarro-Valls's, by a flurry of other statements: from Vatican Radio; from Patriarch Raphael I. Bidawi, who heads the Chaldean-rite Catholic community in Iraq and was then visiting Rome; from Achille Cardinal Silvestrini, head of the Vatican office for Eastern churches; from Angelo Cardinal Sodano, the Vatican Secretary of State, and from the Pope himself.
Much of this flew beneath the radar -- pardon the metaphor -- of the American news media, the Catholic press included. The Catholic News Service did begin an article on the attacks with a sentence saying that "the Vatican called the move an act of aggression," and a few Catholic papers picked up that blunt language in their headlines. But even that did not seem to stir up much reaction, pro or con, among the American Catholic population.
Church leaders' concern was manifest, however, in a letter that Archbishop Edwin F. O'Brien, who is responsible for the pastoral care of Catholics in the United States armed forces, sent to Catholic military chaplains.
Archbishop O'Brien was visiting troops in the Middle East when the action against Iraq occurred, and his letter almost certainly reflects a desire not to appear to be blessing the bombs and missiles that the Pope was at that very moment decrying. The result is a carefully composed statement.
First, Archbishop O'Brien praises "the courage and professionalism" of American troops risking themselves "in the role of peacekeeper" in Bosnia, the Middle East and elsewhere.
Second, he affirms that "once civilian leadership decides a policy requiring military action, it is the sworn obligation of all in our armed forces to execute their mission in complete obedience unless in a specific instance the required action is judged clearly illegal or immoral."
Third, he reviews all the misgivings about military action against Iraq voiced by the Vatican, and last fall by the American Catholic bishops, and whether that action meets "just-war requirements" that civilians not be made targets, that expected good results outweigh the expected harm and that there be likely prospects of success.
And finally he leaves military personnel with a two-sided admonition. "In executing orders that might violate just-war requirements," he reminds them, they "are not exempt from making conscientious decisions." But when they lack sufficient evidence to reach a clear conclusion of their own, they may follow "the presumably better-informed decision" of their military superiors.
This letter resurrects a perennial debate, of course, about the relevance of just-war teachings not so much to policy makers as to those in the military. Moralists of differing views may ponder why a Catholic bomber pilot should prefer the "presumably better-informed decision" of a military superior in a moral judgment call to that of the Pope -- and also ponder the prospect of chaos within the chain of command if the pilot did not.
This entire episode can spark other reflections quite pertinent to the approaching papal visit.
It shows how far the Catholic reality is from the model of Pope commands and Catholics follow (unless they are "dissenters") that still dominates the imagination of a surprising number of people. Rome seldom speaks with an utterly single voice. The subtle but significant differences between Dr. Navarro-Valls's characterization of American-British "aggression" and, say, the Pope's vaguer lament for "peaceful solutions" and Iraqi civilians are typical indicators of the range of opinion that almost always creates a space for Catholics to continue the discussion.
Archbishop Theodore McCarrick of Newark, chairman of the American Catholic hierarchy's International Policy Committee, recognized this reality in a Dec. 17 statement that Archbishop O'Brien quoted. "In my view," Archbishop McCarrick said, "these military strikes unduly risk violating just-war criteria." But he also granted that "these questions are not easy, and people of good will may come to different conclusions."
The Iraq episode also illustrated the Pope's profound ambivalence about the use of military force. John Paul II swings between just-war teaching and something approaching pacifism, between declaring that "the aggressor must be disarmed" in regard to Bosnia and that war "will never be an appropriate way to solve problems" in regard to the Middle East.
Finally, the episode adds to the impression that the extent of contemporary Catholics' adherence to papal positions will never be separated from the strength of the arguments backing them. The Vatican is understood when it denounces economic sanctions on Iraq for the toll they take on innocent civilians. It is understood when it abhors military destruction. But it does not offer any comprehensive moral analysis of what should be done about a regime like Saddam Hussein's and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Is this not really a problem? Or, if it is, should it be left in God's hands?
Perhaps it is because the Vatican's positions appear ad hoc and incomplete that Catholics here so easily deflect even the language of American "aggression."

HEADLINE: Caldor, in Bankruptcy, to Shut Its Stores

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

DATELINE: NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 22

 BODY:
The Caldor Corporation, the discount retail chain that filed for bankruptcy more than three years ago and has since struggled to stay afloat, announced today that it would liquidate its holdings and close all of its 145 stores in nine East Coast states.
The decision, company officials said in a statement, stems from its inability to negotiate a reorganization plan with a group of creditors. 
 Caldor's chairman, Warren D. Feldberg, said that the company had explored a number of options, including court-ordered mediation with its creditors, since filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in September 1995.
"The company was left with no alternative but an orderly wind-down and liquidation," Mr. Feldberg said.
The statement added that Caldor would begin going-out-of-business sales in the next several weeks and that the closing of the stores should be complete by mid-May. Besides selling its inventory, company officials said they intended to sell off Caldor's real estate holdings. The size of those holdings was not immediately known; the company leases all but three of its stores.
Mr. Feldberg also said that many of the company's 20,000 employees would be retained during the liquidation process, but it did not say how many, or what sort of severance program would be offered.
"The company is working on a package for severance and extended medical care but it is too early to discuss any specifics," said Wendi Kopsick, a Caldor spokeswoman.
Ms. Kopsick said that the staff at the corporate headquarters here was being reduced immediately to a core group, although she would not say how many employees worked there or how many would continue to do so for the next few months.
"There were layoffs," she said.
The terminal condition of the company, which was founded in Port Chester, N.Y., in 1951 and has $2.5 billion in sales, clearly unnerved employees today. At the corporate headquarters, workers carrying cardboard boxes filed out of the building after learning of the liquidation at noon.
Not far away, at a Caldor store in Norwalk, employees looked shellshocked. Some of them learned of the liquidation today through an article in The Hour, a local afternoon newspaper. The paper's top headline, stretched across page 1, read, "Caldor Near Death."
"Most of the employees here are worried, but not scared, because soon they will not have jobs," said Luis Mejia, the store manager.
He said he was not too worried about being unemployed because the local economy was strong and there was continued demand for retail managers. "I'll get a job," he said.
Joseph C. Carbone, 62, of Southampton, N.Y., was almost as sanguine. He and other employees were notified of the closing at a meeting in the Bridgehampton, N.Y., store today.
"It's a little sad, but we're hoping someone else takes it over," said Mr. Carbone, who has worked for nine years in the auto and hardware sections. He added, "There's a certain amount of sadness but no tears."
Many shoppers were distressed at the news. "I'm going to miss it," said Ursula E. Thomas, a flight attendant from East Hampton, N.Y. "It's a pretty good store, very reasonable prices, fairly good quality, and you can get very good buys at the sales."
"Working people shop here," she said. "Where will they go now?"
Richard La Bella, 65, a beauty parlor owner from Greenwich, Conn., said he shops at the Caldor in Norwalk. "It's a shame," he said of the closing. "It's been here how long? I like it. I've been coming here a long time. It will be a great loss."
Watching his 2-year-old grandson, Cole, riding a coin-operated merry-go-round, Mr. La Bella said, "He's going to miss the rides."
Though some employees and shoppers expressed shock over the closures, it was not a complete surprise. The company, which was delisted last year by the New York Stock Exchange, announced two weeks ago that it was no longer placing orders or accepting deliveries from suppliers.
There have also been recent reports that Caldor was trying to sell 64 of its stores to other retailers, including Kohl's, a chain of department stores mainly located in the Middle West; Dayton Hudson Corporation, which owns the Target discount chain, or Kmart. Indeed, some Caldor employees said they expect another company to take over the stores.
Calls to Kohl's and Dayton Hudson late yesterday were not returned; no one answered the telephone at Kmart headquarters in Troy, Mich.
"There has been a lot of interest in the sites, but it is too early to discuss specifics of the sale of any store locations," Ms. Kopsick said.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Christopher S. Wren

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
RUSSIA: REJECTS EASING MISSILE TREATY Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov ruled out any amendments to the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty with the United States. In a letter this week, President Clinton asked President Boris N. Yeltsin to discuss changes to the treaty because Washington is considering a new defense umbrella against threats from rogue states like North Korea.
 (Reuters)
 
RUSSIA: KEEPING MIR ALOFT, IF OTHERS PAY Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov ordered the aging Mir space station to remain in orbit for three more years if private investors pay all its expenses, estimated at $250 million a year. Russia had agreed earlier to abandon the Mir, which is nearly 13 years old, in June and concentrate its meager resources on an international space station. (AP)
 
NORTHERN IRELAND: CHANCELLOR MITCHELL George Mitchell, left, the former United States Senator and broker of Northern Ireland's peace accord, will become Chancellor of Queen's University in Belfast in May, a spokeswoman for the university said. Mr. Mitchell, who is advising President Clinton on his impeachment trial, will probably not move to Belfast, but will preside over ceremonies like graduations. (Reuters)
 
 
BRITAIN: LIMIT ON VIAGRA PRESCRIPTIONS The Government has ruled that the National Health Service will limit treatment with the impotence drug Viagra to patients whose conditions stem from surgery or serious injury. It is the first instance in its 50-year history that the service has excluded care for cost reasons. Frank Dobson, the Health Secretary, said unlimited prescriptions would increase tenfold the $20 million now spent on impotence treatments.
 Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
ARGENTINA: A PESO-DOLLAR SWITCH Stock and bond prices rallied after the Government suggested replacing its currency with the United States dollar, calming fears of a run on the peso. The Central Bank's president, Pedro Pou, said on Thursday that the bank was considering opening talks on such a treaty with Washington. The switch would help shield Argentina from currency crises like the one caused by Brazil's devaluation. (Bloomberg News)
 
CANADA: CHARGES AGAINST CLERIC DROPPED Stalking and harassment charges against a Vatican envoy to Canada have been dropped because of insufficient evidence. The police had charged the cleric, Msgr. Vito Rallo, the second-highest official at the Vatican's Embassy in Ottawa, with criminal harassment on Nov. 10 after a 10-week investigation prompted by a complaint from woman who had worked there. (AP)
 
CUBA: PROTESTING JOURNALIST'S SENTENCE The French free-press group Reporters Without Borders has protested the conviction of a Cuban journalist for antisocialist conduct. The newsman, Jesus Joel Diaz Hernandez, was sentenced to four years in prison by a court in Ciego de Avila province for "social dangerousness." In a letter to Fidel Castro, Reporters Without Borders demanded his release. (AP)

Hussein told Hassan through aides that he would appoint him as his deputy, a new post that appears to entail limited authority. (AP)
 
ISRAEL: A DRIFT AWAY FROM LIKUD Yitzhak Mordechai, the popular Defense Minister, seems poised to abandon the Likud Party to join a new center party, or perhaps even lead it. He declined to meet a deadline Friday to place his name on a Likud list of parliamentary candidates for the May 17 elections. But a statement from his office warned reporters not to jump to conclusions, and said he was still a member of Likud.

Under the lunar calendar, which is shorter than the solar one, the 100th anniversary falls this year.

HEADLINE: Medicare Safety Nets Fail To Catch Many of the Poor

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Many of the poorest among the nation's 39 million Medicare beneficiaries, people with incomes below $10,000 a year, are going without aid from government safety net programs that are intended to help them pay their health care expenses.
The biggest, most generous of the programs covers doctor and hospital care that Medicare does not cover, typically 20 percent to 30 percent of the elderly's health care expenses. It also exempts its enrollees from paying Medicare's $45.50 monthly premium for doctors' office visits, deducted from Social Security checks. Two other programs exempt Medicare recipients with slightly higher incomes from paying the premium. 
 But studies by Families USA, a consumer advocacy group, as well as the Urban Institute and research philanthropies like the Kaiser Family Foundation and the Commonwealth Fund, estimate that three million or four million people, about 40 percent of those who are eligible, have never enrolled in the biggest safety-net program. Somewhat higher proportions have not joined the other programs, the groups report.
The studies, the gist of which the Clinton Administration does not dispute, attribute the low enrollments to conflicts between Federal and state agencies as well as a dearth of program leadership and coordination, labyrinthine red tape and demeaning application procedures.
"A lot of people think we have a generous safety net for health care," said Marilyn Moon, a health policy economist at the Urban Institute and a public trustee of the Medicare trust fund. In reality, Ms. Moon said, the shortfall in enrollment "is kind of a secret that people don't want to talk about very much."
Most of the aid has been available for a decade, but until a study last year by Families USA, little was known of the shortfall.
"We were all surprised by the low levels," of enrollment, said Nancy-Ann Min DeParle, head of the Health Care Financing Administration, which manages Medicare, the program for the elderly and disabled, and Medicaid, the insurance program for the poor.
President Clinton is concerned, Ms. DeParle said, "and we have a campaign this year to raise awareness of it."
Congress, she noted, has given the Social Security Administration a $6 million grant to test ways of expanding the programs' coverage.
For the poor, the issue is urgent, said William Waldman, executive director of the American Public Human Services Association, formerly the American Public Welfare Association, with Medicare looking for ways to cut costs. A bipartisan national commission is grappling with overhauling Medicare to prevent insolvency soon after the year 2000.
Prominent proposals before the commission ask beneficiaries to bear more of their medical costs, which would further strain the poor.
In all, Congress has enacted four health-insurance safety nets for Medicare recipients, with all of them based on the Federal poverty guideline. The programs limit enrollees' assets, excluding a home, a car, some life insurance and a burial plot, to less than $4,000 for individuals and $6,000 for couples. Applicants must apply for the coverage to state agencies that supervise welfare services.
The biggest of the programs, enacted 11 years ago, is the Qualified Medicare Beneficiary program. It is open to individual recipients with incomes of less than $8,292 a year and couples with less than $11,100 in income.
People who qualify are exempted from paying Medicare's monthly premium, the 20 percent share of the charges for doctors' office visits and the initial $768 in charges for hospitalization that Medicare requires of other recipients.
Individuals earning up to $9,900 annually and couples with incomes up to $13,260, figures that are 20 percent above the poverty guideline, can enroll in the Specified Low-Income Medicare Beneficiaries program. This program picks up Medicare $45.50 monthly premium.
Both programs require that the states pay 23 percent to 50 percent of their costs, which are calculated on formulas based on the strength of the states' economies. The same formulas are used to prescribe the states' share of Medicaid, with the rest paid for by the Federal Government.
Two newer programs, created by the Balanced Budget Agreement of 1997, both of which terminate in 2002, are paid entirely by the Federal Government. But unlike the other programs, Congress limited the financing, so that if demand for them was high, late applicants would be turned away. The maximum spending is $1.5 billion over five years.
One, called Qualifying Individuals-1, raises the threshold for exemption from the Medicare premium to 135 percent of the poverty line, or $11,112 for an individual and $14,892 for couples and could aid about 500,000 Medicare recipients. Although enrollment began a year ago, Ms. Moon said only 16,000 people had signed up.
The second program, Qualifying Individuals-2, has proved of little benefit and enrollment is almost nil.
The first two programs are stirring the most controversy because states must share the cost while they have little flexibility in managing the benefit.
"The states have no control," said Bruce Bullen, the Massachusetts commissioner for medical services and chairman of the National Association of State Medicaid Directors. "They must follow these Medicare, cookie-cutter approaches to providing services to seniors."
Struck by the reports of the shortfall in the programs' enrollments, many states say they are redoubling their efforts to find low-income people eligible for them.
"It would be unfair to allege that Ohio has done anything to hide from these folks," said Barbara Coulter Edwards, Ohio's Medicaid director. But she said, "We are asking, 'Are there some things we could do to encourage a higher rate of participation?' "
There is no federally organized method for seeking out Medicare recipients who would be eligible for the two main programs.
Ronald F. Pollack, executive director of Families USA, explained part of the shortfall this way: "Social Security says, 'We don't run these programs. They're run by" the Health Care Financing Administration. "H.C.F.A. says, 'We have oversight, but they're administered by the states."'
To streamline the process and get around the welfare stigma, Denise Cross, Missouri's director of family services, said her state, like some others, was encouraging application by mail and phone.
And Congress has granted the Social Security Administration $6 million to test new approaches, like assigning state welfare aides to Social Security offices to take and screen program applications.
But given the magnitude of the shortfall, critics call that tokenism.
"I think it would take a substantial effort to get more people signed up," Ms. Moon of the Urban Institute said. "I doubt that $6 million is going to do it."

HEADLINE: Internet Stocks Falter, Causing Wider Worries

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT and DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
George E. Nichols, a 22-year-old management major at the Georgia Institute of Technology, put more than $1,500 of his student loan money in a mutual fund investing exclusively in high-flying Internet stocks.
Shalin Madan, 23, left his job as an accountant at State Street Bank in San Francisco to become a full-time "day trader," moving his money frantically in and out of stocks like America Online, Amazon.com and Yahoo, often every few minutes. 
 As this delirium has spread, Internet stocks have soared. Shares of newly public companies like Marketwatch.com and Theglobe.com have risen three- or fourfold in a day; more established companies like Yahoo or Amazon.com more than doubled over the last three months. Marketwatch now sports a market value of nearly $950 million -- bigger than a host of established companies such as Reebok, Polaroid and Tupperware.
But this week, a bit of the air leaked out of what many Wall Street pros call the Internet bubble, with some highfliers falling sharply from recent highs. And while most of the stocks are still ahead for the year, many analysts are warning of a steep decline that could rattle the wider market.
That's because Internet fever has spread in recent months to other kinds of technology companies and even to companies with only the most tangential connections to the Internet. And it leaves investors in 401(k) plans and mutual funds who have not bought into companies with "dot com" after their names increasingly vulnerable.
The latest warning about an Internet selloff comes from Barton Biggs, a Morgan Stanley strategist who has been bearish on the market for some time. "I promise you, like all bubbles, this bubble will come to a very bad end," he said on Thursday.
If it does, it's not just Amazon and Broadcast that will suffer. Pension and fund managers who are worried about the high prices of Internet stocks or who are having trouble buying large stakes in these small companies have driven up the stock prices of companies like Cisco Systems, which builds equipment that connects computers to the Internet, and Oracle, whose data-base software is used by on-line retailers.
Even more cautious fund managers have turned to companies like Walt Disney, CBS and Sotheby's. When Disney unveiled its Internet joint venture, Go Network, earlier this month, investors bid up Disney's market value by $5.6 billion.
While valuations of Internet stocks remain in the stratosphere, those of technology stocks have doubled in three months. And those of broad market indexes like the Standard & Poor's 500 have leaped by 50 percent.
The prices of Internet stocks have risen so high so fast that even analysts enthusiastic about the Internet's long-term effect on the economy have warned that prices in the entire sector are likely to fall more than 50 percent.
A sharp, widespread decline would cause headaches for regulators and could cause problems for many on-line investors, who dominate the trading in many Internet stocks. A group of senior officials from several big Nasdaq trading firms has met to discuss recent volatility among the Internet stocks, virtually all of which trade on the Nasdaq.
Several brokerage firms have acted to squelch speculative trading by restricting on-line transactions. Among other things, they have made it more difficult to borrow to buy Internet stocks and put certain limitations on initial public offerings.
But this has done little to dampen the enthusiasm of investors like Mr. Madan. "It's a gold mine," he said. "The Internet stocks are the epitome of the 90's. They're a reflection of what is going on in the stock market. It's just more extreme."
Last week's initial public offering of Marketwatch, which provides financial data to Internet sites, was one of the hottest ever. The shares were initially offered to select investors at $17; but public trading opened on Jan. 15 at $90. The stock finished the first day at $97.50 but has since fallen to $80.50. That means most investors who bought after trading began have suffered a loss, as have recent arrivals to most Internet stocks.
Like Marketwatch, nearly every Internet company boasts an outsized valuation. America Online is worth more than half the companies in the Dow Jones industrial average. Yahoo is valued higher than Eastman Kodak. And the market value of Amazon.com exceeds the combined value of Barnes & Noble, Nordstrom and Federated Department Stores.
Richard Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation, recalls that a similar frenzy for computer stocks emerged in the summer of 1983, about the time the personal computer was introduced. But few of the favorites then -- like Prime Computer and Coleco -- are around today.
"The enthusiasm over the growth of technology as an industry was well founded," Mr. Hoey said. "But we learned that today's hot stock is not necessarily a long-term winner."
Judging by market values, though, few Internet stock prices reflect the possibility of failure. Consider Broadcast.com, which offers audio and video from 345 radio stations and 17 television stations, as well as its own coverage, over the Internet. The company has a market value of $2.33 billion. That amounts to $9.3 million for each of its 250 employees -- a benchmark for valuing Internet companies since they rarely have earnings and sometimes no revenues. By that measure, Broadcast. com's value is more than 15 times the $600,000 per employee at Infinity Broadcasting, which operates 160 radio stations in the United States and sells billboard space.
Yahoo is worth $35 million per employee, and Ebay, an Internet auction site, $61 million. That compares with $14 million at Microsoft and $5 million at Coca-Cola.
While Coca-Cola, Microsoft and Infinity earn millions of dollars each quarter, most Internet companies are years away from profits. Broadcast.com, for example, lost $10.5 million on revenues of just $11.4 million in the first nine months of last year.
Even people who expect the Internet to bring fundamental changes in the economy say there is no sense to the huge valuations.
"The Internet is making huge changes in how we live our daily lives," said Lise Buyer, an analyst who follows Internet companies at Credit Suisse First Boston. "But there is no way to correlate what is happening with these stocks to the underlying businesses. What we have is a mania."
The recent Internet frenzy has come in two phases. The first began on Oct. 8, after stock prices had fallen sharply on worries about the turmoil in emerging markets.
When the Federal Reserve cut interest rates three times in a matter of weeks, investors began to believe the American economy could withstand any pressure. At about the same time, the technology bellwethers Intel and Microsoft reported robust earnings and said they expected profits to continue to grow.
"All that got technology stocks going, and they kept going," said Charles A. Morris, manager of the T. Rowe Price Science and Technology fund.
Mr. Morris said he had little doubt that the madness swept up stocks like Cisco and Oracle. "Everyone got caught up in the Internet excitement, and that has dragged along all of the technology stocks associated with it," he said.
Internet stocks shifted into overdrive on Dec. 16, when a little-known Wall Street analyst, Henry Blodget, stirred speculative juices with a seemingly outrageous prediction.
Mr. Blodget, a 32-year-old analyst at CIBC Oppenheimer, forecast that Amazon.com, its shares then trading for $242, would reach $400 in 12 months. They surpassed that level in early January, and the stock split.
Even though Amazon shares have since fallen, they are up 52 percent since Mr. Blodget's report when adjusted for the split. But Mr. Blodget now says Internet stocks have gotten ahead of themselves, and predicts they will fall 30 to 60 percent from their highs.
"I don't think there's a sector in history that's been valued at these heights," he said. "It's frightening."
Mr. Blodget said part of the reason for the rapid climb is that there are only about four dozen "pure play" Internet stocks, and fewer than 10 of those have moved much beyond the planning stage.
Among them is Yahoo, which operates an entry site, or "portal," to the Internet. Investors hope that the services offered by portal companies, like free E-mail and connections to shopping sites, inspire loyalty among users, which the companies can capitalize on by selling advertising.
Other big favorites are on-line shopping sites like Amazon.com, which, although unprofitable so far, hopes to capture customer loyalty as it expands.
Because many young companies have relatively few shares outstanding, big investors like pension and mutual funds have found it hard to buy large stakes without significantly moving share prices. Broadcast.com, for example, has 17 million shares outstanding, but until this month only 2.5 million of those were available to be traded.
With an average of 900,000 of its shares trading each day, the price rose from less than $40 three months ago to $289.50 this month, before falling back to $136.25 yesterday.
So limited is the supply of pure Internet investments, in fact, that many institutional investors have tried to ferret out Internet opportunities elsewhere.
That is what caused people to bid up shares of CBS, which owned 50 percent of Marketwatch -- a stake reduced to 38 percent in the recent public offering. In addition, CBS owns 10 percent of Sportsline USA, which operates sports-related Internet sites.
Shares of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette rose last week after the brokerage firm said it might offer to the public shares of its on-line brokerage unit. And since December, when Sotheby's made clear its intention to use the Internet for some auctions, its shares have risen 50 percent.
The heavy trading in pure Internet stocks like Broadcast.com appears to be driven by individual investors: the average size of Internet trades is in the hundreds of shares, far smaller than the thousands typical for companies like Microsoft or Intel, according to Birinyi Associates, a research firm.
And those individual investors are starting to feel a bit of pain as some of the frenzy has subsided.
"I'm worried, but I was kind of expecting this," said Mr. Nichols, who recently graduated from Georgia Tech and took an accounting job. "But I'm in for the long term."

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 2; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: A Challenge to Scientific Economics;
An Older School Looks at a Broad, More Intuitive Picture While Modernists See Just the Numbers and Facts

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Ask economists in the baby boom generation why they became economists, and any number will give some credit to Robert L. Heilbroner. His 1953 book, "The Worldly Philosophers," which has sold nearly four million copies, is a "Profiles in Courage" of the great thinkers who shaped modern economics. So it is somewhat surprising to find Mr. Heilbroner increasingly critical of the economists he helped inspire. They have missed the point, he says.
Mr. Heilbroner, 79, is at one end of a growing debate over whether economics, as practiced today, is effective. Sure, economists do a lot of good research, Mr. Heilbroner acknowledges. Some of it yields important insights. But their models are too simplistic. They overlook factors that shape the economic and social system and in doing so forfeit the deep understanding achieved by an Adam Smith or a John Maynard Keynes, two of his worldly philosophers. 
 "The worldly philosophers thought their task was to model all the complexities of an economic system -- the political, the sociological, the psychological, the moral, the historical," Mr. Heilbroner said. "And modern economists, au contraire, do not want so complex a vision. They favor two-dimensional models that in trying to be scientific leave out too much and leave modern economists without a true understanding of how the system works."
The worldly philosophers would have agreed.
"Noneconomic motives are an essential element of economic theory," Joseph A. Schumpeter wrote in 1942, two years after Mr. Heilbroner graduated from Harvard, where he had heard Schumpeter lecture. A few years earlier, Keynes had said that "no part of man's nature or his institutions must lie entirely outside an economist's regard." And Alfred Marshall, the 19th-century British economist, warned that "economics cannot be compared with the exact physical sciences, for it deals with the ever changing and subtle forces of human nature."
The shift from this way of thinking came after World War II, when economics gradually ceased to be a social science and took on the techniques of a natural science. Mathematics became the language of economics, and computer models of the economy became the chief research tool. These models require assumptions about the way markets and people behave, assumptions that are often unrealistic, although in recent years economists have fed more and more actual data into their equations in an attempt to approximate the real world.
"If math is correctly used, then it can incorporate all kinds of things that really make the analysis very much broader," said George Akerlof, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley. "The best of this new work pays attention to psychology and sociology."
That still falls short of what Mr. Heilbroner has in mind. The modern economists separated out the subjective, often intuitive judgments that earlier economists had considered so important. These were considered not susceptible to scientific inquiry, not measurable.
In the process, economists also squeezed out the word capitalism, the once traditional name for the market system, with its subjective connotation of class struggle between owners or managers and workers and with its suggestion of the privileges that go with various levels of wealth. The word capitalism rarely appears in popular textbooks for Economics 101.
Explaining why, N. Gregory Mankiw, 40, a Harvard economist and author of a popular new textbook, "Principles of Economics," said: "We make a distinction now between positive or descriptive statements that are scientifically verifiable and normative statements that reflect values and judgments. The question is, can you do positive economics without normative economics. I think so."
The science of economics, for example, has found that the causes of extreme income inequality, a relatively new phenomenon, can be objectively measured.
Those who are well educated are well paid in the American high-tech service economy, and those who have not gone beyond high school are not well paid. For Mr. Mankiw, that is a "positive" statement in that it is verifiable.
But left out of this finding are factors like job insecurity, which tends to make wages more unequal -- whatever the education level -- and labor union bargaining power, which helped to equalize wages until union power declined. These are subjective observations that Mr. Mankiw or Paul Romer, a 43-year-old Stanford University economist, would classify as political or public policy issues but not part of a scientific explanation of the workings of the economic system.
"There was a kind of a hubris among earlier generations of economists who thought they themselves could make the scientific statements and then the value judgments," Mr. Romer said.
He likens an economist's role to that of a doctor who explains what will happen if a cancer patient is taken off an aggressive program of chemotherapy and radiation. "You can let the pastor, the legislator, the family and the philosopher struggle with the moral question of whether to actually stop the treatment," Mr. Romer said, "but what you want from a doctor is correct scientific statements about what will happen if."
Keynes made no such distinctions. Drawing on intuition, observation and his own broad experience, he concluded that the United States and other nations found themselves stuck in the 1930's Depression in large part because business refused to invest, although the nation offered plenty of savings to finance investment. Keynes's sweeping insight forever changed the way economists think about the way a capitalist system functions. And Keynes, having found the problem, saw no reason to be shy about solutions, calling for enormous Government spending to offset the decline in business investment.
"Keynes certainly had a view of what was a good society," said Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "And he tried to save society from itself."
 
Leaving Politics To the Politicians
Modern economists reject such a role. Mr. Romer's father, Roy Romer, the former Governor of Colorado, had to decide while in office whether to cut taxes or spend more on education, a value judgment properly left to politicians, in the son's view. "I saw my father as someone very skilled at what he does," the son said. "I have sought to be as skilled on the scientific side."
The father chose more education, partly on the advice of his son, who told him of the scientific finding of economists that income inequality is a result of unequal education.
But in this sort of a case, science does not take you far enough, says Mr. Heilbroner, an economics historian at the New School for Social Research. "You have to ask, what is the correlation between high levels of education and high levels of wealth," he said. "Is education in our system a privilege of wealth and a function of the class structure?"
These are questions that science cannot address but economics must, says Mark Blaug, an economics historian. Otherwise, the findings are skewed. "There are so many things going on in the economics world at the same time," he said. "Not just standard economic forces, but all the other elements that shape an economy -- politics, morals, psychology, sociology -- and therefore economics will always be vague and imprecise, more like history than math."
Going beyond science sits easier with older economists like Mr. Heilbroner or Mr. Blaug, who is 71, or Mr. Solow, who is 74 and, like Mr. Heilbroner and Mr. Blaug, came of age as an economist in the 1950's, while Keynesianism was still in its heyday and the cold war had not yet helped squeeze value judgments out of economics.
Mr. Solow, however, is a pillar of mainstream economics. His economic growth theory, in which he explained the interactions of capital, labor and technology in generating economic expansion, is a model of economics practiced as a science. He would never, he said, "advise a student to go to work on the nature of the class structure."
"You are condemning him to failure," he continued. "We do not know if there are applicable rules."
And yet in an autobiographical sketch, he argued against thinking of economics as science with a capital S. "That is perfectly consistent," he wrote, "with a strong belief that economics should try very hard to be scientific with a small s. By that I mean only that we should think logically and respect fact." Fact, he said, should be enlarged "to include, say, the opinions and casual generalizations of experts and market participants, attitudinal surveys, institutional regularities, even our judgments of plausibility. My preferred image is the vacuum cleaner, not the microscope."
And gradually economics is moving this way. The younger generation, while holding tight to its scientific approach, is nevertheless opening up its equations, feeding into them all sorts of new data from other disciplines, then trying, more than in the past, to make the hypotheses fit the data. Surveys are increasingly being used, and old assumptions -- that supply and demand, for example, balance at a healthy level -- are being amended or put aside.
The new approach was on display at the recent annual meeting of the American Economics Association, where economists at one session reviewed their research into today's unusual spectacle of an unemployment rate and an inflation rate falling together instead of moving in opposite directions, as economic theory dictates and as they once did. Drawing on psychology, the researchers have even tried to quantify how people actually behave or feel about work. "Our modeling now is much more flexible," said Lawrence Katz, a Harvard labor economist. "I really think we are seeing a blossoming of a broader social science field, where the core research techniques are maintained but are supplemented with findings from other fields that were once quite separate."
 
Judging Numbers, Not Just Calculating
And Mr. Heilbroner applauds. But it is not, in his view, enough. The questions that absorb the younger economists are too narrow, he says. From Adam Smith's day, economics has always been an inquiry into the nature of capitalism in its various forms, an inquiry that requires as much history, sociology and ethics as it does science, Mr. Heilbroner says.
Economists, for example, cannot just chronicle the rise of output as an economy grows. There must also be a judgment about the quality of that output: Does it show up as more school construction or warmer clothing in winter or as more channels of bad television programs and higher pay for chief executives. That is how the worldly philosophers would have thought, Mr. Heilbroner suggests in a new chapter added to the seventh edition of "The Worldly Philosophers," to be published in the spring by Simon & Schuster.
"Economics will not, and should not, become a political torch that lights our way into the future," he writes, "but it can and should become the source of an awareness of ways by which a capitalist structure can broaden its motivations, increase its flexibility and develop its social morale."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Led by I.B.M., Dow Closes 1.6% Lower

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market finished lower yesterday as I.B.M. fell sharply after mainframe sales in the fourth quarter disappointed some investors. The economic crisis in Brazil was also bothersome, helping send bank and financial stocks lower.
Despite the selling, investors did not seem to extrapolate the problems at I.B.M. to the expectation of poor results elsewhere. And that is why although the Dow Jones industrial average, which includes I.B.M., dropped 1.6 percent, the rest of the major stock indexes were down far less. 
 "A couple of tech companies have already reported good earnings," said Douglas R. Cliggott, a United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities. "So the market said tech was strong and a couple of disappointing revenue or earnings numbers have not led to widespread selling."
It was a volatile day of trading, however. The market opened down across the board, with the Dow 175 points, or 1.9 percent, lower by 10:30 A.M. while the Nasdaq index dropped 40 points, or 1.7 percent.
Along with the fall in I.B.M., market-opening declines in Amazon.com, Yahoo, Excite and other Internet stocks set a gloomy tone early. The selling came on top of sharp losses Thursday and a general Internet selloff for the last week and a half.
At their intraday lows yesterday, Yahoo was 43 percent below its intraday high of 445 on Jan. 11 and Amazon.com was 50 percent below its high of 199 1/8 on Jan. 8. But the concerted selling recently seemed to get prices back down to levels that attracted investors again and these and other Internet stocks turned around to end the day higher.
Yahoo, which fell 12 at the opening, rallied to close up 21 at 286, and Amazon.com rose 17, to 123, after beginning the day down 7 5/8. This Internet turnaround helped the Nasdaq rebound. It was up 20 points at one point but finished the day down just 5.84 points, or one-quarter of a percentage point, at 2,338.88.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 9.97 points, to 1,225.19.
The Dow finished down 143.41 points at 9,120.67. It had rallied in the early afternoon but then fell the rest of the day.
I.B.M., which is the heaviest- weighted stock in the Dow, accounted for almost half of the day's decline as it plunged 17 1/4, or 8.76 percent, to 179 3/4. Although I.B.M.'s fourth-quarter earnings, which were released after the market closed Thursday, beat expectations, analysts said that they were disappointed that both mainframe and server sales were down because I.B.M. cut prices to compete with Hitachi and Fujitsu.
Other stocks leading the Dow lower were American Express and J. P. Morgan, which weaken when the crisis in Brazil looks worse, and the Dow's two drug stocks, Merck and Johnson & Johnson.
In the bond market, concerns about Brazil helped push prices higher as some investors sought the safety of Treasury securities. Brazil's Bovespa index dropped 1.8 percent and the country's currency, the real, continued to decline in value. It is now down 29.4 percent since it was allowed to trade freely last week.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 28/32 , to 102 22/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.07 percent, from 5.13 percent.

HEADLINE: Tax Rebates in New Jersey

 BODY:
Like two-thirds of the nation's governors, Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is now wrestling with the "problem" of fat budget surpluses brought on by a booming economy. This month, to no one's great surprise, Mrs. Whitman proposed in her State of the State Message to send money back to taxpayers in the form of a rebate for their local property taxes. The proposal is certain to be popular, but there is a worrisome catch. The cost of the rebate would grow from $200 million the first year to $1 billion annually in five years, raising questions about whether the money will be there to pay for it if the economy turns down.
Mrs. Whitman's zest for tax-cutting is a signature of her career and crucial to her claim for consideration as a nominee for Vice President in the next national election. She first ran in 1993 on a pledge to cut the income tax, and then kept her word by using budget gimmicks to make up for the lost revenues. Her past tax cuts now amount to about $1.2 billion in annual lost revenue. Currently she proposes to cut taxes in the next five years by nearly as much as in the last five. But since Mrs. Whitman cannot run for a third term, it will probably be up to her successor to deal with any adverse long-term consequences of her actions. That should give pause to the State Legislature. 
 In her re-election campaign in 1997, Mrs. Whitman discovered that voters were less grateful about the enacted state income-tax cuts than angry over rising property taxes and insurance rates. Her victory over a little-known Democratic opponent was close and hard-fought. Mrs. Whitman's response, an average $600 rebate for homeowners, is politically understandable. But it fails to address the basic structural problems that drive up property tax rates, which include the duplications and inefficiencies in New Jersey's 566 municipalities and 611 school districts.
The Governor's State of the State address featured several commendable but modest spending initiatives, including more money to maintain parks and open space, as well as an expansion of health services for children and the elderly. Some of the money for the health programs may come from $7.5 billion that New Jersey is to receive over the next 25 years in the tobacco suit settlement. Over all, Mrs. Whitman's preference for being known as a tax-cutter rather than a spender is likely to be noticed by the national Republican Party.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
In Utah, More Investigations and More Anxiety

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 22

 BODY:
When the 2002 Winter Olympics were finally awarded to this city after years of struggle, many residents said Utah's capital, long regarded as clean and quiet and little else, had finally arrived on the world stage, equal to the best.
But now, many people here say that the other shoe has dropped. With revelations in recent weeks that money and gifts had been given to International Olympic Committee officials to influence the bidding process, and with state, Federal and independent investigations churning behind closed doors, Salt Lake City, its residents say, has also revealed itself to be no better, either. 
 Bryan De Vries, for one, is glad.
"Most people think of it as the capital for the Mormons, the headquarters of the church, and we shouldn't have any problems," said De Vries, a computer programmer who works and lives in the city. "But we do. We've got gang-related problems. We've got corruption in politics. We've got this, that and the other, just like any other city."
De Vries said he hoped the collective soul-searching that has become part of the debate here on the Olympics will have a positive effect on how the city regards itself in the future. "Maybe it will help us focus on our other problems," he said.
Victoria Ostradicky, a land surveyor who was on her way downtown to work this morning, said reaching for the Olympic rings had simply proved the city had feet of clay. "I guess we are just normal humans like everybody else, and business is business," she said.
The Salt Lake Organizing Committee has admitted to giving hundreds of thousands of dollars in gifts, medical treatment, tuition reimbursements and other perks to I.O.C. members or their families. But the gifts, the officials have said, were humanitarian aid, or tokens of good will, and not bribes. No criminal charges have been filed against any current or former official involved in the Olympic bid.
But the multiple investigations under way have accentuated the sense of held breath. In one downtown building, for example, a team of United States Justice Department lawyers from Washington has been questioning witnesses this week in the local F.B.I. offices. Six floors below, a separate independent ethics investigation by the organizing committee was conducting its work. A few blocks away, at the State Capitol, the Attorney General had begun her investigation into possible violation of state laws.
With so many questions still unanswered, perception has heightened this city's Olympic anxiety.
Some residents and local leaders say, for example, that they think some members of the national and world news media have falsely elevated the city's supposed ethical and moral purity as a device to make the bribery allegations appear more newsworthy and more shocking than they are -- that it could happen (gasp) even here.
Others say they think that Salt Lake City should genuinely be held to a higher ethical standard, because of its religious heritage, and that the costs to the city's psyche of what appears to have been involved in bidding for the Olympics are yet to be calculated.
The reality is somewhere in the middle. Economists and securities law experts say, for example, that Salt Lake City's past ethical pedigree is not as pristine as local idealists or outsiders have suggested.
For many years, for example, it was one of the centers in the nation, along with Denver, in penny stock trading, which was notorious for its swindles and scams, in which low-priced shares in often nonexistent companies -- especially in things like gold mines and oil wells -- were sold to gullible investors.
A spokesman for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Michael Otterson, also said it would be the "height of arrogance" for him to say that Salt Lake City was more moral or ethical than other places. What the church does, he said, is teach principles, and then allows people to govern themselves.
In the Olympic bidding process, Otterson said, the church took no formal position and donated no money. Individual corporations owned by the church, however, including The Deseret News and the company that owns the local CBS television affiliate, did make contributions to the bid committee totaling about $211,000. And Otterson said many church members were involved in the bidding process, including the former president of the organizing committee, Tom Welch.
"The church believes in following the highest moral and ethical principles," Otterson said. "There seems to be at least prima facie evidence that that wasn't done here."
Just as big a question as right and wrong, however, is who is talking and who is not. The lawyer for Welch, who ran the Olympic bid committee until his resignation in 1997 after being accused of spousal abuse, said his client had not been subpoenaed. The lawyer, Thomas A. Schaffer, said Welch had not been questioned by any state or Federal authorities or asked to appear. He said the facts, in any case, would show Welch had done nothing illegal.
Welch's secretary, Stephanie Pate, however, was interviewed by Justice Department lawyers and F.B.I. agents on Wednesday, with questioning to resume next week. Her lawyer, David B. Watkiss, declined to discuss anything about the questions or answers but said his client had done nothing illegal and had not witnessed anything illegal.
Residents here today said that rumor and perception were making them confused about what to think of themselves. "In some ways, when the world is looking at you like this, you could look at it as a compliment, too -- that Salt Lake lives at a higher standard than the rest, so they shouldn't have been involved," said Duane Carter, who works in computer security for a local utility company. "But right now, it's kind of an embarrassment."
Donna Caporale, an insurance agent, said she believed there might be a badge of honor, of sorts, yet to be found. The fact that questions about the Olympics happened to blow up here is partly a result, she said, that people began admitting what they had done.
"We're not too smart," she said. "Or we're too honest."
